HEADLINE: Distributor of Flu Vaccine Comes Under Fire

BYLINE: By MELODY PETERSEN

 BODY:
With flu vaccine in short supply nationwide, customers of one big distributor say their longstanding orders are going unfilled while other customers that ordered only recently, but at higher prices, are getting the medication.
The distributor, Henry Schein Inc., and its subsidiaries are the exclusive suppliers in the United States of vaccine made by Medeva, a British company that is the only flu vaccine producer that has not had manufacturing problems this year. 
 Some Schein customers that ordered early, at low prices, said in interviews over the last week that they had received only partial shipments or no vaccine at all. At the same time, Schein is taking new orders at higher prices, and at least some of those orders have been quickly delivered.
Schein, which is based in Melville, N.Y., said yesterday that its policy was to first fill orders placed early by doctors, and then to fill other early orders, like those of state governments.
Susan Vasallo, a spokeswoman for Schein, said she could not explain why the company was shipping vaccine to some customers that placed orders only in the last few weeks.
"We are trying to fulfill orders as best we can," Ms. Vasallo said. "There probably are some exceptions. How many of those took place I could not say. But those are the exceptions, not the rule."
Flu vaccinations have been delayed around the nation this year because of the difficulties that other companies had in making the vaccine. With health care providers desperate for vaccine, prices have shot up.
Delays in shipments of vaccine ordered by the state of California have led Representative Gary A. Condit, a Democrat, to ask the General Accounting Office to investigate.
"Any price manipulations that may put profit ahead of the health and well-being of the American people is simply wrong," Mr. Condit said this week. "We think the distribution of the vaccine should be fair. It should not be awarded to the highest bidder."
By last week, the California Department of Health Services had received only about 35 percent of the 700,000 doses of vaccine that it ordered in February, at $1.80 each, from a Schein subsidiary, General Injectables and Vaccines. Flu clinics across the state have been postponed.
"This has put our clinics in a very difficult situation," said Dr. Natalie J. Smith, chief of the department's immunization branch.
By contrast, General Injectables delivered all the vaccine that the state of Maine had ordered -- 123,500 doses at either $3.10 or $3.99 each, about twice as much as California's price, according to Paul Kuehnert, director of the Maine division of disease control. Maine placed its order in June, about four months later than California, and received it in early September.
In addition, an order placed a few weeks ago by Dr. Stephen Dickey at the Doctors Walk-in Clinics in Tampa, Fla., for about 3,000 doses at about $7.50 each, was delivered last week, Dr. Dickey said. That order was filled by another Schein unit, Caligor.
Ms. Vasallo said she could not comment on individual customers' cases, but she insisted that Schein was not delivering vaccine based on the price paid. "That is not the policy," she said.
"The price has gone up as the season has progressed," Ms. Vasallo acknowledged. But she said that Medeva had also increased its price. "Our costs have gone up," she said.
Powderject Pharmaceuticals, a company in Oxford, England, that bought Medeva in October, said that Schein had discretion to set the sales price of vaccine in the United States. "From what we understand, they are making every effort to fulfill their customers' orders," a spokeswoman for Powderject said yesterday.
Medeva is expected to sell about 15 million of the 75 million doses of flu vaccine that will eventually be available in the United States this flu season. Unlike Aventis and American Home Products, the other vaccine makers, Medeva had no problems producing flu vaccine this year and has been shipping it to Schein on schedule, Rob Budge, a spokesman for Powderject, said this month.
Ms. Vasallo said that Schein had also placed orders with the other vaccine makers, and therefore did not yet have all the vaccine it was counting on.
Dr. Smith, the California health official, said that when she heard this summer that some vaccine shipments would be delayed because of manufacturing problems she was relieved that California had ordered the vaccine made by Medeva.
General Injectables had told state officials that it would try to deliver the vaccine in August, and no later than Sept. 15, she said. The company later told California that its order would be complete by October, so that vaccination clinics could be held as scheduled.
With the arrival of thousands of additional doses on Wednesday, the state has now received about 65 percent of its order, Dr. Smith said, and is anxiously awaiting more.
Also waiting are hundreds of customers of Insource, another Schein subsidiary, that have not received any vaccine. Many of them are regional medical distributors that sell to doctors' offices and clinics.
Michael Jekoski, vice president for sales at Delaware Valley Surgical Supply in Boothwyn, Pa., said his company had ordered 5,000 vials of drug vaccine from Insource early this spring at a price "in the low $20's" for each vial, containing 10 doses. The company then took orders to sell the vaccine to doctors' offices at prices "in the mid to upper $20's" per vial, Mr. Jekoski said.
"We have been left with nothing to give physicians," he said.

HEADLINE: World Trade Talks Revived By Pacific Rim Conference

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS

DATELINE: BANDAR SERI BEGAWAN, Brunei, Nov. 16

 BODY:
Efforts to restart global trade talks, which failed in Seattle last year amid riots, received a push today when 21 nations of the Asia and Pacific region agreed to set a date of 2001 to form an agenda and begin negotiations for eliminating trade barriers.
The agreement reached by leaders of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation, or APEC, was a victory for the Clinton administration, which has made free trade a top priority and has often used this Pacific Rim forum to press its free-trade agenda. 
 The accord ensures that no matter who wins the White House, or who succeeds other departing leaders of APEC, a mandate and deadline have been set for reviving trade talks.
"We believe that a balanced and sufficiently broad-based agenda that responds to the interests and concerns of all World Trade Organization members should be formulated and finalized as soon as possible in 2001, and that a round be launched in 2001," the leaders said in a statement.
But the agreement amounted to little more than a consensus that the talks must restart. It did not address the subject that blew up the Seattle meeting, the fears among developing nations that the United States would impose labor and environmental standards that would undercut the competitiveness of poorer nations.
Saying they were tired of being railroaded into agreements that were not in their best interest, the developing nations, led by Malaysia, initially insisted on seeing an agenda before agreeing to a fixed starting date for negotiations.
After two days of heated debate, mainly by United States and Brunei leaders, a compromise was reached that both the agenda and initiation of talks would be achieved by next year.
It was the first time that the group had met in this oil-rich sultanate of 300,000 people who have one of the highest standards of living in Southeast Asia but are governed by an absolute monarchy, the Sultan Hassanal Bolkiah. Known for his gilded palaces, fleets of luxury cars and other excesses, the sultan, in a speech to delegates, warned that "disparities between the rich and poor continue to grow, and many people are at risk of being marginalized."
Still, the sultan treated the regional heads of state to ornate pins of gold and precious stones and in keeping with an APEC tradition, matching wacky shirts -- the color was deep blue this year.
For President Clinton, who is widely recognized as having been the driving force behind the group, the forum marked what was likely his last meeting with many world leaders. Today, Mr. Clinton met separately with the Japanese prime minister, Yoshiro Mori, and President Jiang Zemin of China.
Aides to Mr. Clinton said that in his meeting with Mr. Mori, the two leaders mainly discussed the situation in North Korea, but that the president also expressed opposition to Japan's stepped-up whaling activities.
White House aides said that Mr. Clinton discussed nonproliferation issues with the Chinese leader, and aides indicated a significant development was in the works.
Mr. Clinton and Singapore's prime minister, Goh Chok Tong, agreed to negotiate a free-trade agreement between their nations that would be modeled after a recent accord between the United States and Jordan that removed all trade barriers between the two countries.
If that deal is approved by Congress, Jordan would become only the fourth country with which the United States has a free-trade agreement. The others are Canada, Mexico and Israel. United States officials said they hope to complete the Singapore agreement by the end of the year.
Separate pacts like the one the United States has proposed with Singapore are seen as helping to pave the way for the larger APEC free trade agreement. It is an ambitious goal that would create the world's largest free-trade zone, embracing four continents and encompassing more than half the world's population, economy and commerce.
But the Malaysian prime minister, Mahathir Mohamad, had a different view. He said that it was important for developing countries in Asia to form their own individual trade blocs to combat what he called the dominance of regional powers. The prime minister, who is an outspoken critic of the impact of globalization on the developing world, said that small countries like Malaysia often have difficulty putting forth their case at regional trade forums. He said that groupings of these smaller countries would be in a better position to exert pressure on more developed countries and have their problems heard.
In their final communique, APEC leaders also expressed concern over rising oil prices, urged countries recovering from the Asian financial crisis to continue their economic reforms and called for new efforts by the public and private sectors to help bridge the so-called digital divide.
Noticeably absent from the meeting were antiglobalization protesters that have disrupted other world trade meetings in recent years. Organizers said that the demonstrators might have been put off by Brunei's remoteness and authoritarian rule.

HEADLINE: Key House Leader Withdraws Support for Colombia Aid Plan

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER MARQUIS with JUAN FORERO

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16

 BODY:
Representative Benjamin A. Gilman, chairman of the House International Relations Committee, has abruptly withdrawn his support from the decision to funnel $1.3 billion in mostly military aid to Colombia, arguing that the United States is on the brink of a "major mistake."
Mr. Gilman, Republican of New York, sent a letter this week to the White House drug policy coordinator, Gen. Barry R. McCaffrey, contending that the American plan to increase the role of the Colombian military in the drug fight will end disastrously, because the military has undermined its political support after a history of corruption and human rights abuses. That position echoes other critics of the plan. 
 Mr. Gilman called on the Clinton administration to redirect its assistance, including at least 40 Black Hawk helicopters, from the military to the national police in Colombia. Mr. Gilman has long admired the police, which he views as more effective and less tainted by human rights violations.
"If we fail early on with Plan Colombia, as I fear, we could lose the support of the American people for our efforts to fight illicit narcotics abroad," Mr. Gilman said. "If we lose public support, we will regret we did not make the mid-course corrections for Colombia that I have outlined here."
Last summer, Mr. Gilman voted to support Plan Colombia, a $7.5 billion strategy drafted jointly by American and Colombian officials and passed by Congress. In addition to the military spending, the program allocates money to promote alternative crops, economic renewal and human rights. The plan seeks to halve drug production over five years in Colombia, reportedly the source of most of the cocaine and heroin that enters the United States.
Congressional sources said Mr. Gilman was troubled by recent military failures in rural areas where rebel forces operate.
It is unclear what effects, if any, Mr. Gilman's shift will have. A Senate Republican aide who follows Colombia closely said it was "far too early" to criticize the plan. Mr. Gilman is expected to relinquish his chairmanship next year because of term limits.
Critics of the plan have argued that the military aid would merely intensify the conflict in which two rebel groups have joined forces with narcotics traffickers against the government, a conflict that could eventually draw the United States directly into fighting the rebels.
Leaders of Colombia's neighbors also have expressed fears that the fighting will spill into their countries.
Washington counters that Colombia's increasingly jumbled battle lines make it necessary to equip and deploy the military in the fight against drugs. The American plan calls for training three counternarcotics battalions, with a total of up to 3,000 troops.
The administration also has promised to watch over the military's record on human rights. A spokesman for General McCaffrey, Robert Weiner, said today that denying aid to the military on the basis of its past performance would ensure defeat.
"Granted they're not a superpower," Mr. Weiner said. "One of the major purposes of the Plan Colombia is to provide the military with the resources they need. This actually scares the cartels to death."
In southern Putumayo Province, where half of the coca in Colombia is grown, rebels have sealed off roads, arguing that the military has to rein in right-wing gunmen who are associated with the armed forces.
A botched operation in a northern town, Dabeiba, resulted last month in the downing of one of the army's seven American-made Black Hawks and the deaths of 22 troops.
The helicopter had been carrying reinforcements to assist soldiers locked in a firefight with rebels of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia. But sloppy communications led the pilot to land in a rebel-controlled area, an American official said.
The rebels "were waiting for them," the official said. "What kind of intelligence is that? They were dug in like the Ho Chi Minh Trail."
A high-ranking official in President Andres Pastrana's government defended the military involvement on the grounds that the drug war has fundamentally changed in the last five years.
"It used to be an urban drug war, which the police were very capable of handling," the official said. "It has now become a drug war fought in the jungles, and you can't do that without military support."
Another official said, "The fact that there are voices that are against these tactics doesn't mean that the strategy is going to change."

HEADLINE: Fed Cited Two Points in Holding Rates Steady in October

BYLINE: Bloomberg News

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16

 BODY:
At their October meeting, Federal Reserve policy makers unanimously approved leaving the overnight bank lending rate unchanged because of slowing economic demand and an easing of inflation pressures.
"Growth of aggregate demand now appeared to be closer to, and perhaps slightly below, the rate of expansion in the nation's output potential," central bankers said, according to minutes of the Federal Open Market Committee meeting on Oct. 3, which were released today. 
 "Moreover, cost pressures and price inflation had remained subdued for an extended period despite low rates of unemployment that in the past had been associated with increasing inflation," the minutes said.
At the October meeting, the committee voted to keep the target rate for overnight loans between banks at 6.5 percent given "indications of appreciable slowing in the pace of the expansion from outsized increases experienced in the latter part of 1999 and the first half of this year," the minutes said. The Fed raised interest rates six times between June 30, 1999, and May 16.
With demand rising less rapidly, inflation posed less of a risk, the minutes said. Yet, with unemployment at 3.9 percent in September -- matching a 30-year low set in April -- and energy costs above year-earlier levels, policy makers agreed to issue a statement after the October meeting that focused on the risk that inflation posed to the record-long economic expansion.
The minutes indicated that policy makers might be preparing to eliminate the inflationary warning.
"Some expressed the opinion that those risks were now less decidedly tilted to the upside and that a reconsideration of the sentence might be warranted over the next several months," the minutes said. Even with this view, those members "believed that a change at this point would be premature."
The minutes of the previous meeting helped shape analysts' understanding of how likely the Fed is to raise or reduce rates. The rate changes tend to affect the terms for rates on loans to consumers and businesses.

INTERNATIONAL A3-15
 
Clinton Lands in Vietnam; Visit to Focus on Future
President Clinton arrived in Hanoi, becoming the first president to visit Vietnam since Richard Nixon visited American troops in 1969. Mr. Clinton said earlier that he wanted to focus on Vietnam's economic and political potential and that he did not believe that America owed an apology to Vietnam for its wartime role. He is to be greeted today by President Tran Duc Luong and will give a speech at Hanoi National University that Vietnamese officials said would be broadcast nationwide. Senator-elect Hillary Rodham Clinton arrived in Hanoi separately, earlier in the day. A1 

Pacific Trade Talks Scheduled
The Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation agreed to form an agenda and begin negotiations next year on eliminating global trade barriers. A12
 
Outlooks for Mideast Peace
Prime Minister Ehud Barak of Israel and Yasir Arafat differed on whether a peace agreement could be reached before President Clinton left the White House in January. Mr. Arafat expressed optimism, Mr. Barak was pessimistic. A10
 
Push to Expand U.N. Seats
Yukio Satoh, Japan's ambassador to the United Nations, recommended that the Security Council be expanded to 24 members from 15. Japan is seeking a permanent seat. A15

NATIONAL A16-32
 
Florida Supreme Court Lets Recounts Proceed
The Florida Supreme Court ruled that at least two heavily Democratic counties -- Broward and Palm Beach -- could continue recounting ballots by hand. But pending legal challenges left it unclear whether any such votes would officially count in determining the outcome of the presidential race. That issue was left for a Leon County circuit judge to rule on today. Florida's secretary of state, Katherine Harris, a Republican, has said she will not consider any such late results. Lawyers for Gov. George W. Bush filed papers with a federal appeals court in Atlanta asserting that further recounts were unconstitutional because they would treat some votes differently from others. The Bush campaign also said it would not contest the count in another close state, Iowa. A1
 
Vice President Al Gore emerged as the winner in Oregon. A30

HEADLINE: Teenager and Boyfriend Strangled Disapproving Parents, Police Say

BYLINE: By C. J. CHIVERS

 BODY:
A high school senior and her boyfriend were charged yesterday with strangling the girl's mother and father in the parents' apartment in Spanish Harlem two weeks ago and then dumping their bodies, with belts still tight around their necks, in the East River last week, the authorities said.
The police said the student, Connie Leung, 17, and her boyfriend, Eric Louissaint, 20, had been dating for about a year and had recently been quarreling with Ms. Leung's parents. 
 Lt. Louis Caniglia, commander of the 23rd Detective Squad, said that on the day before the killings, Ms. Leung and her father, Stephen Leung, had argued in front of a counselor at the Manhattan Center for Science and Math on East 116th Street, where she was enrolled. Mr. Leung had been concerned that his daughter, once an A and B student, had stopped attending class to spend time with Mr. Louissaint, who is unemployed, Lieutenant Caniglia said.
Other police officials said race was also a factor in the deteriorating relationship between Ms. Leung and her parents. The police said Mr. Leung, 55, and his wife, Chilin, 41, were immigrants from Hong Kong, and were upset that their daughter was dating Mr. Louissaint, who is black.
Whatever the young couple's motive, the police said, their anger escalated so wildly that on Nov. 2 they overpowered her parents in the family's fourth-floor apartment at 2120 First Avenue.
Sgt. William Cannon, also of the 23rd Detective Squad, said Mr. Leung was the first to die. A waiter at Le Parker Meridien on West 57th Street, Mr. Leung had come home from work about 6 or 7 p.m. and dropped into a chair in his bedroom to watch television. Mr. Louissaint came from behind, slipped a belt taken from Mr. Leung's raincoat over the man's head and strangled him, the sergeant said.
For more than three hours, the young couple waited for the girl's mother, an employee of the New Good Taste II Chinese Restaurant at 1974 Second Avenue, and strangled her with a leather belt as she came through the door about 10:20 p.m., the police said.
Assistant Chief William Taylor, commander of detectives in Manhattan, said Connie Leung helped her boyfriend in both killings, but he would not say how. "We're not going to go any further with that, other than that she participated and assisted in strangling both the mother and father," he said.
Asked if Connie Leung had shown remorse in the interviews yesterday with detectives, the chief said, "No."
After the killings, the couple placed the two bodies near each other on the bedroom floor and locked the door, the police said.
Over the next several days, Ms. Leung and Mr. Louissaint sold her parents' rings and gold chains, worth about $5,000, at a Lower Manhattan pawn shop, the police said. Detectives recovered most of the jewelry.
Last week, the police said, the killers began to dispose of the bodies. First, on Tuesday night, the police said, the two stuffed the mother's body in a shopping cart, wheeled it outside and pushed the cart into the East River.
Early last Friday, the police said, the couple repeated the journey with the father's body, first stuffing it into a laundry bag, then moving it from the building in a luggage cart before tossing it into the river about 2 a.m.
Mr. Leung's body quickly floated to the surface. A passer-by saw it in the river near East 61st Street at 11 a.m. on Friday, and authorities retrieved it. Mrs. Leung's body has not been found. The police said they expected to send divers to the river's bottom to look for it.
Mr. Leung's body was not immediately identified, however, and the daughter and her boyfriend were not at first suspected of a crime.
On Monday, Mrs. Leung's sister Shirley Sung grew concerned that Connie Leung, her niece, had not been seen in nearly two weeks, and filled out a missing-person report. On Wednesday, Connie Leung's sister Teresa Leung, of Brooklyn, reported that her parents had disappeared.
Lieutenant Caniglia said detectives investigating the missing- person reports found Ms. Leung and Mr. Louissaint living at the Y.M.C.A. on West 63rd Street.
Neither Ms. Leung, who lived with her parents, nor Mr. Louissaint, formerly of Edson Avenue in the Bronx, had a criminal record, the police said. The crime confounded those who know them.
One friend who spoke on the condition of anonymity said he was a former classmate of Ms. Leung's and had known the couple for more than a year. He said Ms. Leung and Mr. Louissaint had "a classic interracial relationship" but had endured cultural tensions and her parent's initial disapproval.
He also said that Mrs. Leung had warmed to Mr. Louissaint over time, and that the relationship between the couple and the parents had gradually become congenial.
He expressed disbelief at the accusation. "How can people change that quickly?" the young man asked yesterday. "They were doing O.K. with her parents, and actually got along."

HEADLINE: COUNTING THE VOTE: DUVAL COUNTY;
Democrats Rue Ballot Foul-Up In a 2nd County

BYLINE: By RAYMOND BONNER with JOSH BARBANEL 

DATELINE: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Nov. 16

 BODY:
Democrats in Duval County prepared meticulously for Election Day. They registered thousands of voters and ferried enough people to the polls in predominantly African-American precincts to give a solid boost to Vice President Al Gore in a county expected to swing reliably into Gov. George W. Bush's column.
But the results of Duval County's vote left Democrats here shaking their heads. More than 26,000 ballots were invalidated, the vast majority because they contained votes for more than one presidential candidate. Nearly 9,000 of the votes were thrown out in the predominantly African-American communities around Jacksonville, where Mr. Gore scored 10-to-1 ratios of victory, according to an analysis of the vote by The New York Times. 
 The percentage of invalidated votes here was far higher than that recorded in Palm Beach County, which has become the focus of national attention and where Democrats have argued that so many people were disenfranchised it may be necessary to let them vote again. Neither Democrats nor Republicans have demanded a hand recount or new election in Duval County.
Local election officials attributed the outcome to a ballot that had the name of presidential candidates on two pages, which they said many voters found confusing. Many voters, they said, voted once on each page. The election officials said they would not use such a ballot in the future.
Rodney G. Gregory, a lawyer for the Democrats in Duval County, said the party shared the blame for the confusion. Mr. Gregory said Democratic Party workers instructed voters, many persuaded to go to the polls for the first time, to cast ballots in every race and "be sure to punch a hole on every page."
"The get-out-the vote folks messed it up," Mr. Gregory said ruefully.
If Mr. Gregory's assessment is correct, and thousands of Gore supporters were inadvertently misled into invalidating their ballots, this county alone would have been enough to give Mr. Gore the electoral votes of Florida, and thus the White House.
The voters turned out by Democrats, Mr. Gregory said, took the instructions to vote in every race to mean: "I've got to vote for Gore. I've got to be sure Bush doesn't get elected. I've got to vote on every page."
Democratic officials, Mr. Gregory said, should have told voters they were bringing to the polls. Vote for Gore, then skip the next page.
"In hindsight," he said, "we didn't fully understand the problem. "
The Duval County ballot listed Mr. Gore on the first page, along with Mr. Bush, Ralph Nader and two other candidates. Then on the second page were the names of five other presidential candidates. After voting for Mr. Gore, many Democratic voters turned the page and voted for one of the remaining names, Mr. Gregory said.
The double-marked ballots substantially affected Mr. Gore's showing, a Times analysis of voting data suggests. More than 20 percent of the votes cast in predominantly African-American precincts were tossed out, nearly triple the majority white precincts. In two largely African-American precincts, nearly one-third of the ballots were invalidated.
Altogether, 21,942 ballots were rejected because the voter punched the hole beside the name of more than one candidate, and another 4,927 were invalidated because the voter punched no hole next to a presidential candidate, said the Duval County supervisor of elections.
The Times analysis shows that about 16,500 of the votes thrown out were cast in precincts with Democratic majorities that, when taken together, were comfortably carried by Mr. Gore. The remaining 10,000 invalid votes were cast mostly in precincts in which Republicans outnumber Democrats and that were, as a group, solidly behind Mr. Bush.
When the results for Duval County were first tallied, those mathematics made it look like Duval County was a place in which Republicans could pick up some votes in a recount.
But Republican officials with ties to the Bush campaign said they concluded that it was doubtful a manual recount in Duval would, on balance, help their candidate.
The Bush campaign chairman in northeastern Florida, Michael Hightower, did not agree and said he doubted a substantial portion of the invalid ballots were cast by Gore supporters. They might be from districts where the registration was heavily Democratic, but many Democrats voted for Mr. Bush, he said.
The invalid ballots were cast "by people who did not, could not, or would not follow directions," said Mr. Hightower, an executive with Blue Cross/Blue Shield and a Bush Pioneer, which means he raised more than $100,000 for the candidate. "I am not going to make a judgment why." But he said, he believed that more than half of those who did not follow directions were Republicans.
Although there is plenty of grousing about the ballot, the Democrats have not mounted a challenge to the vote here as they have in other parts of the state. For one thing, confusing though the ballot might have been, "there is nothing illegal about that ballot," said James Holland, a lawyer who worked as a poll watcher for the Democrats on voting day.
Amandlyn Brooks, 38, was one of many voters here who said she was taken aback by the two-page presidential ballot. "It was confusing to me," she said. "It was my first time voting." She does not know which precinct or district she voted in; she had gone to the polling station the Democrats had shown her. After first making a mistake and voting for Mr. Bush, she managed, after considerable assistance, to get a new ballot, she said.
But she still was not certain what to do. "I kept looking around, pleading for help," she said. "But they just kept saying, 'read it, read it.' " Ms. Brooks said.
"I wanted to run out of there, but I was determined," she said. "So I just punched whatever. When I got home, I told my husband, I don't know who I voted for."
Stephanie Brown, an 18-year-old studying journalism at Florida Community College, also found the ballot confusing, but said she was saved from voting incorrectly by a warning from her mother, who voted just ahead of her.
But she said her 67-year-old grandmother had voted on each page, thus invalidating her ballot.
A spokesman for the Duval County elections office, Susan Tucker Johnson, said the 26,000 invalidated votes were four times the total recorded in 1996. Ms. Johnson said the county had fit the presidential candidates on one page in 1996, but had gone to two pages this year because there were so many parties. In addition to the Democratic, Republican and Green Parties, there were the Libertarian, and Socialist Workers Parties on page 1; and on page 2, the Natural Law, Reform, Socialist, Constitution and Workers World Parties, as well as a place for a write-in candidate.
In the final tally for Duval County, Mr. Bush received 152,114 votes, or 58 percent, and Mr. Gore 108,048, or 41 percent.
Democratic officials were pleased because Mr. Gore had exceeded Mr. Clinton's 35 percent showing in 1996, said Michael Langton, of the executive committee of the Duval County Democratic Party. He added, however, that he was disturbed by the number of invalid ballots from predominantly Democratic precincts.

HEADLINE: For the Two Gladiators, One State, One Prize;
We Won't Fall Apart

 BODY:

To the Editor:
The fear is unfounded that economic markets and international affairs will explode while we go about our messy work of assuring that Florida voters' rights are preserved (news article, Nov. 15). 
 Is our memory so short that we forget that domestic and international institutions did not fail during the lengthy, vitriolic and highly partisan impeachment process that threatened the loss of a president? And here he is still today, enjoying considerable popularity and maintaining a steady hand on the national rudder.
This time, we will gain a president. Both candidates are highly motivated to take office and to do a good job at leading the country for the next four years. We should keep moving forward until the voters in Florida, through their right to seek adjudication of their grievances, tell us it's time to stop.
 
MUREM SHARPE
Bloomfield Hills, Mich., Nov. 15, 2000

HEADLINE: Metro Business Briefing;
UPSTATE JOB GROWTH LAGS

BYLINE: By Leslie Eaton

 BODY:
The number of new jobs in New York State has surged in the last 12 months, but the growth has been concentrated in New York City and its suburbs, according to figures released yesterday by the State Department of Labor. Across the state, the job count rose by more than 169,000, or 2 percent, which is faster than the national average of 1.8 percent. But almost 131,000 of those new jobs were downstate, where the job count soared by 2.4 percent. Upstate, the number of jobs grew by just 1.2 percent. Across the state, however, the unemployment rate continued to drop, and is far lower upstate -- 3.8 percent -- than in New York City, where it is 5.4 percent, adjusted for seasonal factors. The national average is 3.9 percent. Leslie Eaton (NYT)

HEADLINE: CLINTON IN HANOI, INTENT ON FORGING NEW RELATIONSHIP

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: HANOI, Vietnam, Friday, Nov. 17

 BODY:
More than a quarter-century after a war that cost 58,000 American lives and shaped the politics of his generation, President Clinton arrived here late Thursday promising a new relationship with Vietnam, a country that is at once fascinated by its former enemy and deeply ambivalent about opening its society and economy to a world that America dominates.
As he stepped into the cool night air, Mr. Clinton became the first president to set foot in Vietnam since Richard M. Nixon made an unscheduled six-hour visit to American troops outside Saigon in 1969, and the only one to visit Hanoi. The headquarters of the North Vietnamese command here was the target of countless American bombing sorties. 
 Mr. Clinton opposed the war as a young man, and did not serve in the military. But on this trip he plans to focus resolutely on the future. He has made Vietnam a test case of his proposition that deepening commercial ties create a powerful gravitational pull that can draw former enemies, even hard-line Communist governments, into gradual alignment with the West.
But it is still far from clear if that experiment will work here.
On Thursday night, Air Force One lazily descended through the same skies where B-52's once flew, coming in low over rice paddies that were dotted then with bomb craters and now bear billboards advertising Korean-made cars and electronics.
A motorcade sped the president over the Red River into one of Asia's most gracious capitals, where people began to line the streets in groups of a dozen or so, almost none of them old enough to remember the war.
The crowd had grown to thousands when, just before midnight, Mr. Clinton's limousine with its District of Columbia license plates drove by on the way to his hotel, a mile or so from the simple house where Ho Chi Minh and his generals prosecuted the war.
But that carefully preserved site, one of the city's most visited attractions, and the mausoleum nearby where Ho's body is on display, have been omitted from the president's three-day itinerary.
So have most other reminders of the past. Save for a trip Saturday morning to a site where investigators believe they have just found the remains of an American pilot whose plane crashed outside the city 35 years ago -- one of 1,499 Americans still unaccounted for in Vietnam -- Mr. Clinton will not be looking back at the war, the White House has said.
This morning, Mr. Clinton's route wound through the main streets of Hanoi, where thousands of young people, including many small children, stood on the sidewalks to wave in greeting.
His car crossed the central square and through the gate of the presidential palace, an imposing, mustard-colored French colonial building that once was home to the French governor general.
As he stood on a reviewing stand, the sounds of "The Star-Spangled Banner" wafted into the square.
Mr. Clinton then stepped into a large ceremonial room on the first floor of the palace for his meeting with President Tran Duc Luong, where he thanked him for the greeting that the Clintons had received.
"I've been struck by the friendliness of the people on the street, last night and this morning," Mr. Clinton said. "It is a very good omen for our relationship."
When they were joined briefly by Hillary Rodham Clinton, who had arrived here earlier Thursday, President Tran congratulated her on her election to the Senate. "We are all very happy," Mr. Tran said.
The two men then disappeared into an anteroom for an hour of talks before Mr. Clinton's planned visit to the ancient Temple of Literature. In addition to Hanoi, Mr. Clinton was to visit Ho Chi Minh City, the former Saigon, before leaving the country on Sunday.
What little Mr. Clinton has said on this trip suggests that his time as president -- and the decisions he has had to make about military interventions -- has led him to think differently about the hard choices, from bombing the north to expanding the American military presence here, that Lyndon B. Johnson made.
"I see now how hard it was for him," Mr. Clinton said on his trip across the Pacific to Brunei, Malaysia, his first stop. "I believe he did what he thought was right under the circumstances," Mr. Clinton said in speaking of Johnson. "One of the things that I have learned, too, is when you decide to employ force, there will always be unintended consequences."
Asked if America owed Vietnam an apology, though, he quickly said, "No, I don't," and left it at that.
Instead, he wants to focus on Vietnam's economic and political potential. During an economic summit meeting in Brunei, Mr. Clinton noted that this year, for the first time, Vietnam is presiding over the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, or Asean, "which means it is heading an organization that was invented to contain it."
The president was preceded here by his wife, Senator-elect Clinton, who went shopping on one of Hanoi's main streets and drew a crowd of hundreds of curious people. Today Mrs. Clinton is scheduled to visit a village outside Hanoi.
Mr. Clinton will spend a considerable part of the visit celebrating the results of his seven-year-long effort to draw Vietnam out of its self-imposed economic isolation, and his bet that both Vietnam and China will discover that prosperity in the information age necessitates a measure of political openness and the free flow of information.
In fact, Mr. Clinton and the American ambassador here, Pete Peterson, a former prisoner of war in the what came to be known sarcastically as the Hanoi Hilton (now mostly demolished), argue that personal freedoms have improved since the administration made its overtures to the country in 1994.
That year Mr. Clinton lifted the trade embargo that had been in place since the fall of Saigon 25 years ago. With the support of former P.O.W.'s in Congress, including Senator John McCain, the Arizona Republican, he offered diplomatic recognition to Vietnam in 1995.
He dispatched his Secretary of State at the time, Warren Christopher, to lay the groundwork for a new relationship, and Mr. Christopher warned that economic reform was akin to "a passage over a ravine."
"You cannot do it by taking several little steps," Mr. Christopher said. "Only one giant leap will get you across."
The Vietnamese ignored him. It took five years to negotiate a comprehensive trade agreement that promises -- but hardly guarantees -- far more vigorous economic ties with the United States.
But in the interim many foreign companies that poured in here in the early 1990's have pulled up stakes in frustration. Mr. Peterson argues that American executives overstate the difficulties of dealing with Vietnamese bureaucracy and corruption, but he acknowledged the other day that Mr. Clinton would "see a country that is 8 years old, not 4,000."
Now Mr. Clinton arrives in the midst of a fierce division within the Vietnamese government over whether the prospect of reversing a huge decline in foreign investment by opening up the country is worth the threat to the Communists' rule.
In an echo of the debate under way in China, Vietnam's top Communist leader, Le Kha Phieu, warned in February that the battle with the West continued, on battlefields that bear little resemblance to lush fields of Hue or the rocky harbor at Haiphong.
"They continue to seek ways to completely wipe out the remaining socialist countries and attack the movements for independence, democracy and social progress," he said. "We should never relax our vigilance for a minute."
So it is Mr. Clinton's challenge over the next three days to accomplish what Kennedy, Johnson and Nixon could not achieve: to win the hearts and minds of the Vietnamese people.

HEADLINE: ART GUIDE

 BODY:

A selective listing by critics of The New York Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free.
*denotes a highly recommended show.
 
Museums 

"AMAZONS OF THE AVANT-GARDE," Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, 1071 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street, (212)423-3500 (through Jan. 7). A concise exercise, monographically arranged, this show focuses on six Russian women who painted around the time of the revolution. Several continued to work much later and do more than paint, but this is a tendentious affair, plausibly so. If just a couple of the women, Natalia Goncharova and Liubov Popova, were truly great painters, the exhibition still isn't a case of special pleading. The Russian avant-garde wouldn't have been what it was without them collectively. The story as it unfolds here seems, if anything, more remarkable, not less, for having as little to do with sex as it does and almost everything to do with painting. Many of the works have a surprising fortitude. Revolution. A brave new art world. The dream persists even though the form it takes keeps changing. Hours: Sundays through Wednesdays, 9 a.m. to 6 p.m; Fridays and Saturdays, 9 a.m. to 8 p.m. Admission: $12; $8 for students and the elderly (Michael Kimmelman).
 
"EGYPTIAN ART AT ETON COLLEGE: SELECTIONS FROM THE MYERS MUSEUM," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth avenue at 82nd Street, (212)535-7710 (through Jan. 21). Many of the stunning objects here are no bigger than a man's hand, and some are as small as a fingernail. They are almost all from the collection of Maj. William Joseph Myers (1858-99), an alumnus of Eton College who was an avid acquirer of things Egyptian and bequeathed the objects to his almna mater. Including some 150 objects from the pre-dynastic to the Roman period - wooden figures, amulets, jewelry, vessels, mummy ornaments and cosmetic contrainers - the show is particularly rich in those made of blue-green faience, a much-used ceramic material whose base was ground quartz. One of the tiniest and most beguiling exhibits is a faience hedgehog that served as an amulet, presumably for the animal's supposed resistance to poison. Hours; Sundays and Tuesdays through Thursdays, 9:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays until 9 p.m. Admission: $10; $5 for students 12 and older and the elderly (Grace Glueck).
 
* "THE EMBODIED IMAGE: CHINESE CALLIGRAPHY FROM THE JOHN B. ELLIOTT COLLECTION," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth avenue at 82nd Street, (212)535-7710 (through Jan. 7). In China the written word has traditionally been the highest art form and a source of political and emotional power. To see that power in action, check out this grandly scaled exhibition, which brings together two superb calligraphy collections - from Princeton University and the Met - in the most comprehensive survey yet seen in these parts. The dozens of scrolls covered with handwritten words collectively radiate a kind of conversational buz and suggest a richly varied cast of personalities: fastidious court functionaries, impulsive social agitators, unworldly monks, visionary poets. Together they offer an ice-breaking introduction to an art that to anyone who doesn't know Chinese can seem unapproachable. Hours and admission: See above (Holland Cotter).
 
LEE KRASNER, Broklyn Museum of Art, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, (718)638-5000 (through Jan. 7). Despite its restless energy and moments of formal power and elegance, Lee Krasner's career int his economical retrospective looks more like one of tantalizing frustration than real fulfillment. In the 1950's and early 60's, Krasner painted splattery, ambitious Abstract Expressionist works, but they look indebted to other artists, Pollock and de Kooning mainly. Where she looks most herself is in collage; a set of large collages on canvas from the early 50's have raw density or explosive buoyancy. Collages made in the 1970's using 40-year-old charcoal drawings have a beautiful Cubistic elegance; they are the best works of her career. Hours: Wednesdays through Fridays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m (until 11 p.m. on the first Saturday of each month); Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Admission: $4; $2 for students and the elderly (Ken Johnson).
 
*"POWER AND DESIRE: SOUTH ASIAN PAINTINGS FROM THE SAN DIEGO MUSEUM OF ART, EDWIN BINNEY 3RD COLLECTION," Asia Society at Midtown, 502 Park Avenue, at 59th Street, (212)517-2742 (through Jan. 7). The album-size paintings known as Indian miniatures, produced for an elite clientele who demanded the finest workmanship, are rightly renowned for their suave forms and brilliant colors. They also embody the moral values, political ambitions and personal aspirations of the culture that produced them. All of these ingredients come into play in this show of 67 top-of-the-line examples from the 16th to the 19th centuries. They add up to a kind of grand but intimate theater, equal parts farce, melodrama and mystery play, where men strut like gods, gods have the failings of men, and nature is a gorgeous curtain behind which infinity lies. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Sundays, noon to 5 p.m Admission: $4; $2 for students and the elderly (Cotter).
 
"RAVE REVIEWS: AMERICAN ART AND ITS CRITICS, 1826-1925," National Academy of Design Museum, 1083 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street, (212)369-4880 (through Dec. 31). A year after the Academy opened as a school for art instruction it organized its first annual show, 170 contemporary portraits, landscapes and historical sagas. This entertaining hodge-podge of a show, described as "the first comprehensive historical examination of American art criticism," brings together more than 70 paintings and sculptures that first appeared in these shows, with the reviews they got at the time. One immediate and large success was Winslow Homer's "Prisoners From the Front" (1866), which portrayed a lineup of scraggly Confederate soldiers with their leader confronting a smartly uniformed young Union officer. The contrast made by Homer between the two sides was seen, by the painting's most perceptive reviewers, as a comment on why the South lost the Civil War. Hours: Wednesdays, Thursdays, Saturdays and Sundays, noon to 5 p.m.; Fridays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m Admission: $5 (Glueck).
 
* BRIDGET RILEY, "Reconnaissance," Dia Center for the arts, 548 West 22nd Street, Chelsea, (212)989-5566 (through June 17). Once overly identified with Op Art, this British abstract painter never got her due in anti-Op New York, but a beautifully installed show of 40 paintings from 1961 to 1984 should change things. Concentrating on the early black-and-white paintings that made Ms. Riley famous, it presents stringently pure yet accessible works that have, at their best, extended the optical potential implicit in the work of Mondrian, Josef Albers and Ad Reinhardt. At their weakest, their meticulously calibrated patterns can be so aggressive that they virtually kidnap the eye, take it on a joy ride and leave it in a crumpled heap. Either way, the overall effect is of an artist of unusual dedication who has remained loyal to the original premises of her art and yet stead-fastly refused to repeat herself. Hours: Wednesdays through Sundays, noon to 6 p.m. Admission: $6; $3, students and the elderly (Roberta Smith).
 
"ROBOTS AND SPACE TOYS," the Robert Lesser Collection, Brooklyn Museum of Art, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, (718)638-5000 (through Jan. 28). Connoisseurs of kitsch and youngsters of all ages should get a kick out of this exhibition of more that 200 toy robots, as well as rocket ships, flying saucers, astronauts and space stations, most produced by Japanese manufacturers after World War II. It includes the first toy robot, a little yellow machine-man made in the later 1930's; dozens of boxy figures from the 1950's with names like Mr. Atomic or Radicom, and many versions of Robbie the Robot from the movie "The Forbidden Planet." These mechanical homunculi are amusing but scary: could they be symbols of modernity's Faustian exchange of soul for power? Hours and admission: See above (Johnson).
 
* SANTIAGO-HOGE: "THE DEAD HAVE ARRIVED," El Museo del Barrio, Fifth Avenue at 104th Street, (212)831-7272 (through Dec. 3). This wonderful, room-filling installation by the artist team that calls itself Santiago-Hoge was commissioned by the museum in observance of the Mexican religious holiday known as the Day of the Dead. Five separate altars are banked by marigolds and incorporate a staggering wealth of materials - candies, toys, photographs, dolls, holy pictures, liquor bottles, fruit, even a video of a skeleton dancing to a Tito Puente beat - for the entertainment of day-tripping spirits and museum visitors alike. Hours: Wednesdays through Sundays, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. Admission: $4; $2, students and the elderly (Cotter).
 
* SCYTHIAN GOLD. "The Golden Deer of Eurasia: Scythian and Sarmatian Treasures From the Russian Steppes," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212)535-7710 (through Feb. 4). "God of the Nomads: Scythian Treasures From Ancient Ukraine," Brooklyn Museum of Art, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, (718)638-5000 (through Jan. 21). Certain kinds of art are box-office gold. Art made of gold is one of them, and there's a Fort Knox-size supply of the precious stuff in these two opulent exhibitions. The Brooklyn show is a survey-style glimpse at some exquisitely wrought 14-carat objects drawn from museums in Ukraine, where the Scythians put down roots in the first millennium B.C. The Met has drop-dead museological rarities from the State Hermitage Museum, but the focus here, which gives the proceedings a kind of treasure-hunt thrill, is on a cache of objects excavated fairly recently from tombs belonging to non-Scythian people whose identity is something of a mystery. Ideally, the two shows should be seen together: they offer a really substantial archaeological update on the last big Scythian showcase in these parts, the Mt's smash-hot "In the Land of the Scythians" of 25 years ago. Hours and admission: See above (Cotter).
 
*EDWARD STEICHEN, Whitney Museum of American Art, 945 Madison Avenue, at 75th Street, (212)570-3676 (through Feb. 4). A big, thorough exhibition, maybe a little too big and glossy, of one of the great photographers in American history, a restless, benign, flawed genius. Steichen also painted, made films, designed textiles, organied aerial reconnaissance photography in two world wars and put together the most popular photography exhibition ever, "The Family of Man." We'll see how people respond to someone whose eclectic work can look, if anything, almost too elegant and self-regarding. Steichen ultimately seemed to reduce everything and everyone to props to demonstrate his own refined and stage-savvy sensibility. But what refinement. His best work has a finesse that borders on the erotic. Hours: Tuesdays through Thursdays and Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays, 1 to 9 p.m. Admission: $10; $8 for students and the elderly (Kimmelman).
 
* "UNTITLED PASSAGES BY HENRI MICHAUX," Drawing Center, 35 Wooster Street, SoHo, (212)219-2166 (through Dec. 20). The books of the Belgian-born French poet and writer Henri Michaux are not exactly unknown on these shores, but his considerable achievement as a visual artist - a self-taught one - has yet to gain a solid foothold. This exhibition of more than 100 works on paper should change things. Spanning the late 1920's to the late 1970's, it includes examples of his finely textured "mescaline" drawings, his raucous inkscapes and his animated, often preening calligraphies. It reveals an artist profoundly influenced by Asian art who assiduously mined the fault line between language and sign, text and drawing, image and abstraction, manifesting the flow of human thought and energy in different, often hypnotic ways. Hours; Tuesdays through Saturdays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Free. A related show, "Henri Michaux: Works on Paper," is at Michael Werner, 4 East 77th Street, (212)988-1623, through Nov. 25 (Smith).
 
'THE YEAR ONE: ART OF THE ANCIENT WORLD EAST AND WEST," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212)879-5500 (through Jan. 14). The Met puts the millennial-marking art exhibition in a new perspective with a show that only an institution of its stature and girth could pull off. Drawn from seven departments, it revisits the beginning of the "modern era" around the time of the birth of Jesus with 150 sometimes tiny artworks that sample the nearly two dozen cultures flourishing at the beginning of the first millennium. The array stretches from imperial Rome to Han dynasty China, with many stops in between. High points include bronzes from Thailand and Indonesia, A Chinese mortuary pillar and a stunning re-creation of the frescoed bedroom of a Roman villa. The display is supposed to reflect the beginning of a new world consciousness brought on by expanding empires and trade, a thesis more complex than the actual objects can sustain. But no matter, most of them are considered masterpieces, all are beautifully installed and the opportunities for cross-cultural visual comparisons are rich. Hours and admission: See above (Smith).
 
Galleries: Uptown
 
BALTHUS, "Drawings From the Collection of Stanislas Klossowski de Rola," Dickinson Roundell, 19 East 66th Street, (212)772-8083 (through Nov. 22). Among 42 works on paper belonging to the artist's son are some fine portraits, like the image of a sultry-looking girl in a green-and-red pullover said to be Balthus's only surviving pastel. Most, however, including landscapes and nude studies, are disappointingly sketchy and, even if related to famous paintings, are missing Balthus's distinctive air of erotic suspense. Also on display is a copy of the book "Mitsou," which the precocious artist illustrated at age 11, and a charming small painting of a fully clothed girl from 1932 (Johnson).
 
CARL CHENG, "Nature Observed/Art Tool 2000," Sculpture Center, 167 East 69th Street, (212)879-3500 (through Dec. 16). The long-overdue New York debut of this California artist has as its centerpiece an extraterrestrial landscape made entirely of sand and spread out across the gallery floor. Its topographic features - hills, canals and cryptic pictograph patterns - were shaped by a computer-driven metal cylinder that resembles a player-piano roll but is as sensitive to the touch as a drafting pencil. Mr. Cheng has been inventing such art tools" for more than 30 years, and he is definitely on to something worth knowing a lot more about (Cotter).
 
ABELARDO MORELL, "The Universe Next Door," Bonni Benrubi, 52 East 76th Street, (212)517-3766 (through Dec. 2). For his best-known works, many of which are included here, this photographic magician turns whole rooms into cameras obscuras and then photographs the results, creating cityscapes layered over the walls and furnishings of apartment or hotel interiors. He can also transform a stack of old dictionaries or a single pencil casting a wide shadow into something of mysyteriously monumental import (Johnson).
 
'THE PUPILS OF ANNE MARIE EVANS," Ursus Books and Prints, 981 Madison Avenue, (212)772-8787 (through Nov. 30). Nature scrutinized is the theme of this attractive little exhibition of watercolor botanical studies from England that demonstrate how individual style can warm exacting scientific objectivity. A peppermint-stripe rose conjures visions of beach cabanas in a wind. Venturing into Impressionist terrain, little nosegay of spring flowers seems to tremble around the edges with delight (Cotter).
 
Galleries: 57th Street
 
LESLEY DILL, George Adams Gallery, 41 West 57th Street, (212)644-5665 (through Nov. 25). Words and their relationship with the body - physical, emotional and spiritual - are the subjects of Lesley Dill's explorations in sculpture and works on paper. The best things here are two small, wraithlike personages of white cast paper, one titled "We Live in Smoke," after a poem by Hank Hine. The figure sits crumpled on a stool, the words of poem ("We live in smoke/the words no sooner out/than we are lost to them") tumbling across its head, shoulders and chest. Ms. Dill's own pet word, "radiance," appears often in these works. Her work can be haunting, but sometimes its preciousness palls (Glueck).
 
* DONALD JUDD, "Lake Work," Pace Wildenstein, 32 East 57th Street, (212)421-3292 (through Nov. 25); "Stacks," Luhring Augustine, 531 West 24th Street, (212)206-9100 (through Dec. 2). At Luhring Augustine, four of the great Minimalist's stacks of sumptuous boxes, one per wall, create a still, chapelesque ambience. In Pace Wildenstein's busier show of late works, we see Judd working within strict limitations yet constantly discovering new, urgently felt nuances of scale, rectilinear composition and material - from breadbox-scale stacks of warmly rusted Corten steel and colorful plexiglass to an industrial-strength quintet of open five-foot aluminum cubes (Johnson).
 
* BILL VIOLA, James Cohan, 41 West 57th Street, (212)755-7171 (through Nov. 25). "Ascension," Mr. Viola's breathtaking new video projection, is unabashedly soulful and powerfully sensational, a 10-minute essay on death, beauty and resurrection. A man plunges explosively into water, hovers like a crucified Christ and sinks slowly out of view. In the front gallery is a riveting set of super-slowmotion video portraits, in which professional actors emote at glacial speeds (Johnson).
 
Galleries: Chelsea
 
SEONG CHUN AND DARO MONTAG, Caren Golden, 526 West Street, (212)727-8304 (through Nov. 25). Ms. Chun crochets thin strips of paper imprinted with writings by Mondrian into gridded compositions that look like deconstructed and slyly domesticated Mondrian paintings. Mr. Montag, a British photographer who does not use a camera, leaves pieces of organize matter - kiwi slices in the works here - on color negatives for time. In the large prints made from these chemically altered negatives, haloed, radiating images in toxic colors glowe out of deep black backgrounds. (Johnson).
 
R. CRUMB, "Restaurant Placemat Drawings," Paul Morris Gallery, 465 West 23rd Street, Chelsea, (212)277-2752 (through Dec. 9). All the drawings are from the last 10 years and were done, doodle-style, while Mr. Crumb waited for his meal. If the veteran Comix-meister makes no big advances here, that's O.K. His draftsmanly style and thematic obsessions are classics by now (Cotter).
 
SAM EASTERSON, Rare, 435 West 14th Street, (212)645-5591 (through Nov. 25). Mr. Easterson went to the desert and attached small video cameras to live animals and plants - an armadillo, a tarantula, a cactus - to capture nonhuman points of view. The uneventful tapes are shown on monitors suspended over camera -equipped, stuffed animals surrounded by colored electrical cords arranged in topographical map patterns. Mr. Easterson is apparently serious, but his project looks like something made up by Monty Python (Johnson).
 
ARTURO HERRERA, Brent Sikkema, 530 West 22nd Street, (212)929-2262 (through Nov. 25). This delightfully versatile and imaginative artist presents as expansive, tangled forest-scape cut from a single 20-foot length of black felt; a large, cut, layered and painted paper collage that has the decorative elegance of Matisse and the funky buoyancy of Elizabeth Murray; small dense paintings made of solid plastic shaped like cartoon fragments; and, on the floor, asky-colored geometric object made of corrugated cardboard called "Hurry Home, Blue" (Johnson).
 
DAMIEN HIRST, Gagosian Gallery, 555 West 24th Street, (212)741-1111 (through Dec. 16). Welcome to the Damien Hirst Universe. It's a big shiny place with mathematical grid paper printed on the walls, pale pristine dot paintings and mahy large vitrine sculptures, including two outfitted as gynecological examining rooms and filled with water and fish. It shows the artist moving beyond the dead animals and putrefying flesh that catapulted him to fame while clarifying and enriching the grandiose themes of his art: life and death and their complex, sometimes oppressive relationship to science and commerce. It contains some undeniable duds, but if it doesn't win over those who have resisted the work of this notorious young British artist, it won't be for lack of trying (Smith).
 
ALLAN McCOLLUM, "The Event: Petrified Lightning From Centra Florida," Friedrich Petzel, 535 West 22nd Street, (212)680-9467 (through Nov. 24). The fulgurite, a piece of heat-fused sand caused by lightning hitting the ground, is the subject of Mr. McCollum's perplexing installation. In one room are 10,000 replicas of a fulgurite, while stacks of booklets about fulgurites and related subjects occupy another. Fulgurites are not very sexy, so while the installation arouses curiosity, it does not crystallie modern experience as pointedly as this artist's best work has done (Johnson).
 
BJARNE MELGAARD, "The Mutilation of the Apes," Alleged Galleries, 809 Washington Street, Chelsea, (646)486-1110 (through Dec. 2). Mr. Melgaard, 33, is one of the Europe's current crop of bad-boy artists and his multi-media American debut show is raw, raunchy and adamantly content-intensive, with references to child pornography, race wars and a pantheon of heroes calculated to push a whole keyboard of hot buttons. It ain't a pretty picture, but its Goth-anarchist messiness looks right at home in one of Chelsea's liveliest galleries (Cotter).
 
Galleries: SoHo
 
LYDIA DONA, Von Lintel & Nusser, 555 West 25th Street, Chelsea, (212)242-0599 (through Nove. 25). Ms. Dona brings together the sensuous and the mechanical to dissonant effect in acridly hued, Neo-Cubist paintings in which schematic images of engines and straight-edge spatial divisions are layered with gaseouscolor fields and accented by passages of thick, gloppy paint or pointillist texture (Johnson).
 
"FROM INSIDE THE BODY: CHINESE NEW PHOTOGRAPHY AND VIDEO," he Cultural Foundation, 555 Broadway, near Prince Street, SoHo. (212)925-1649 (through Jan. 6). Most of the 11 participants in this show are appearing for the first time in the United States, and together they give some idea of ways in which many young Chinese artists, with access to international art magazines, museum catalogs ad the Internet, are tailoring global styles to culturally specific ends. Some cook up contemporary riffs on traditional genres; others dive straight into a hallucinatory present, with themes that sometimes dovetail with those in recent work by artists in New York (Cotter).
 
ORIT RAFF, PETRUS SCHAESBERG, Baumgartner, 418 West 15th Street, Chelsea, (212)633-2276, (through Nov. 29). Two artists who create large, glossy color photographs, one Romantic, the other ironic. Mr. Schaesberg produces landscapes or still lifes, some arranged in grids, some with sophomoric, aphoristic texts added, that exude dry, philosophical moods. Ms. Raff's pictures of refrigerator freezer compartments desperately in need of defrosting combine impression of arctic desolation and domestic banaltiy to wry effect (Johnson).
 
ANTHONY JOSEPH SALVATORE, Cavin-Morris, 560 Broadway, at Prince Street, SoHo, (212)226-3768 (through Nov. 25). The self-taught Salvatore (1938-1994) used oil sticks to make boldly patterned, juicily colored, brusquely textured pictures that hover between abstraction and visionary, biblical narration. They are well complemented by a set of Chinese scholar stones: natural, unusually formed rocks mounted on beautifully carved wooden bases. Vibrant evangelism meets Zen contemplation (Johnson).
 
JANE SCHNEIDER, June Kelly, 591 Broadway, near Houston Street, (212)226-1660, SoHo, (through Nov. 29). Working with fallen trees or logs found in upstate New York woods, Ms. Schneider assembles, carves textures and subtly paints gnarly, partily surrealistic, party expressionistic abstractions. They look raw at first, but on closer examination you see they have been worked with skilled and imaginative sensitivity (Johnson).
 
Other Galleries
 
ERIK PARKER, Leo Koenig, 359 Broadway, near Franklin Street, TriBeCa, (212)334-9255 (through Dec. 2). Mr. Parker is a kind of self-appointed archivist of postwar New York art and culture, and the paintings and drawings in this sparky first gallery show are made up mostly of words: elaborate litanies of names of people, places and movements, familiar and half-forgotten, that together evoke an era or specific scene. Each name is enclosed in a thought balloon, and these link up into pulsating cells of verbal energy framed by sinewy ornamental patterns that often spill off the canvas and across the wall (Cotter).
 
Last Chance
 
JEAN ARP, "Line and Form," Mitchell-Innes & Nash, 1018 Madison Avenue, at 78thStreet, (212)744-7400 (through tomorrow). Arp's art still looks fresh, sweet and humorously subversive, adn it is well served by this 32-piece retrospective of drawings, paintings, reliefs and sculptures. Arp's two-dimensional works, like "Profile," an amoebic yellow head or puddle, are marvels of enigmatically suggestive economy. The smooth marble "Dream Flower With Lips," which looks like a female torso or an inverted cartoon leg, marries Grecian classicism and a wacky, polymorphous eroticism (Johnson).
 
JASON RHOADES, David Zwirner, 43 Greene Street, (212)966-9074, SoHo (through tomorrow). In one room of Mr. Rhoades's latest essay in sculptural extravagance stands a sort of giant Tinkertoy sawmill - Sutter's Mill, birthplace of the California gold rush - made of polished aluminum pipes and clamps. In another room is an identical but incomplete version. During the exhibition, an assistant will always be building or dismantling one or the other mill, acting out a Sisyphean loop of construction and deconstruction (Johnson).
 
W. EUGENE SMITH, Alan Klotz, 22 East 72nd Street, (212)327-2211 (through tomorrow). This is a fine small survey of images by the great photojournalist, who worked for Life and many other magazines and died in 1978. Smith's prints have a velvety richness and an unabashedly romantic humanity. The show includes war pictures shot in Japan, like the amazing "Soldier Finding a Baby;" near-visionary views of steelmaking in Pittsburgh; images from his famous series "The Country Doctor"; and portraits of the jazz great Thelonious Monk (Johnson).
 
* SARAH SZE, Marianne Boesky Gallery, 535 West 22nd Street, Chelsea, (212)680-9889 (through tomorrow). Ms. Sze, 31, came on the scene in the late 1990's and quickly gained international attention for her sculptural installations made of many tiny objects - screws, matches, toothpicks - grouped in patterns that suggested computer boards and Job Lot store displays. The seven pieces in her belated New York gallery solo debut are more organic and dramatic: they look like midair explosions with fragments of furniture zooming off into space, boring into walls, breaking into splinters, with everything held together by a network of clips, cables and bentwood strips. Coming from a virtuoso of improvised accumulation, the results may seem a little too "done," but they're still pretty astonishing (Cotter).
 
"TRES COMPLEMENTAIRES," Mary Ryan Gallery, 24 West 57th Street, (212)397-0669 (through Wednesday). Time has dimmed the success story of two American artists, Maud Hunt Squire (1873-1954) and Ethel Mars (1876-1959), who expatriated themselves to France in 1906 and spent the rest of their lives there (except during World War I). This show, mounted in cooperation with the Susan Sheehan Gallery, is an attempt to re-establish their work, best represented by their early prints: Squire's color etchings and Mars's color woodblocks. After the war the two moved to the south of France, where they concentrated on drawing and painting, producing slight but charming scenes of beach and village life. But the early prints stand out (Glueck).

SECTION: Section C; Page 3; Column 3; Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 327 words

HEADLINE: Housing Starts Continued To Edge Up In October

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17

 BODY:
Housing construction moderated last month as builders broke ground on more apartments than single-family homes, the latest evidence that the nation's economy is slowing.
Housing starts inched up to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.53 million in October, a 0.1 percent increase from September, the Commerce Department said today. 
 Even with the small advance, housing construction, which declined each month from May through August, remained at a solid level, analysts said.
"It's not the fantastic market we saw one year or one and a half years ago," said Stanley Duobinis, director for forecasting at the National Association of Home Builders.
"Traffic is a little reduced, sales are not coming as quickly and as easily, and builders are telling us the marketplace is cooling," he said. "But nobody is telling us the market is really dropping like a rock."
The latest housing report was weaker than many analysts expected. They had estimated that September's strong 0.7 percent increase would be matched in October.
Still, said Joel L. Naroff, an economist at Naroff Economic Advisors in Holland, Pa., "not too many builders will be crying too loudly; they are still digging those holes."
Fixed-rate 30-year mortgages averaged 7.8 percent last month, down slightly from the average 7.9 percent in September and October 1999.
With mortgage rates holding steady below the 8 percent mark, builders say they feel good about sales.
Economists expect housing starts and home sales, which have been an engine of the robust economy, to soften this year, reflecting the toll of higher interest rates.
In October, starts of apartments, condominiums and other multifamily housing projects rose by 1.3 percent, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 305,000, after a 3.8 percent gain in September.
Starts of single-family homes, however, fell a modest 0.2 percent in October, to a rate of 1.2 million, after holding steady the month before.

HEADLINE: CLINTON IN VIETNAM: THE PEOPLE;
Excited Welcome for Clinton, Part Celebrity, Part Hero

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS

DATELINE: HANOI, Vietnam, Nov. 17

 BODY:
It happened twice: the president of the United States, his face glowing, walked right up to Dang Dinh Hiep, grasped his hand and gave him a brilliant smile. Then he returned and did it again.
"He shook my hand and then he came and shook it again!" exclaimed Mr. Hiep, 52, a post office worker -- one of tens of thousands of people who thronged the streets today to catch a glimpse of President Clinton as he toured Hanoi. "I'm a happy man." 
Twenty-five years ago as a Communist soldier, Mr. Hiep said, he had helped capture the southern capital, Saigon, sharing in Vietnam's moment of victory over the United States. Today he had met the president and he was thrilled again.
"He's a wonderful man," cried Mr. Hiep, as if Mr. Clinton could still hear him. "Very happy and smiling. He was against the war in the past and now he is contributing to better relations between our countries."
And then, like a baseball fan brandishing a home-run ball in the stands, he held up two fistfuls of yellow police tape, something to show to his grandchildren to prove that he had been here.
Almost everywhere Mr. Clinton went today on his first full day in Vietnam -- at his hotel, at the government guest house, at the Temple of Literature, at Vietnam National University -- he was met by huge, excited crowds, waving and calling out to him.
Neither the visiting American delegation nor the Vietnamese authorities, it seems, had anticipated their numbers or their enthusiasm.
Police officers in forest-green uniforms used nightsticks and electric prods to hold back the crowds, sometimes chasing and taking a whack at someone who tried to stray too close.
"He's coming! Here he comes!" people shouted as the president's motorcade approached the Temple of Literature, a historic landmark in the center of town. "I can see him! There's his wife! How handsome he is! He seems so young and healthy, he's so pink, just the way he looks on TV, but even handsomer! I want to shake his hand! I want to give him a hug!"
Le Thi Loan, 33, who works in a tea shop, had been waiting for five hours with her 8-year-old son to see Mr. Clinton. "We really look up to him," she said. "He's a talented man, a great man."
Nguyen Tra My, 30, who works for an Austrian food-processing company, was wearing her finest clothes and most brilliant lip gloss.
"Looking at Clinton is our dream come true," she said as she waited, speaking in excellent English. "We hope that we can contact him and say some sentences to him. He is a very, very nice man and he really supports Vietnam very much. Actually, all of us, we really like him and respect him very much."
Two old veterans shared tiny cups of tea as they waited nearby.
"During the war we had a very hard time here, and after the war it was very difficult too; not even rice to eat," said one of them, Le Xuong, 79. "Life is much better now. And we are trying to erase our hatreds of the past and turn a new page in our history."
That is right, said Nguyen Trong, 70, a retired colonel who said he had served in four wars, involving France, Cambodia and China as well as the United States. "That's the way it is," he said, "close down the past. We have a saying in Vietnam: 1,000 friends are not enough, but one enemy is too many."
After about half an hour Mr. Clinton emerged from the Temple of Literature, his pale blue necktie shimmering in the bright fall sunshine.
"Hello! Hello!" people called to him in English.
And Mr. Clinton responded: he plunged into the crowd, moving from right to left and then to the right again along the sidewalk.
Nguyen Ngoc Ba, 40, an electronics repairman, was directly in the president's path.
"He just came right up and grabbed my hand," he said. "His hand was warm, maybe from shaking so many hands. It was very quick, just long enough for me to feel the warmth of his hand."
The warmth seemed to flow both ways. Mr. Clinton paused before climbing at last into his black limousine. "Look at the children," he murmured to a security agent.
The biggest crowds of the day were in the streets outside the university, where students and residents packed the sidewalks, some sitting on walls and some perching in the branches of trees for a better view.
"Vietnam-America: Close the past, open up a new horizon," read a hand-lettered sign in English held up by several young women, students at the university. "We want relations to be better and better," said one student, Do My Hien, 20.
But soon, a group of security men came up and seized the sign, folding it into a small square before marching away with it. "I don't know why they took it," said one of the young women. "Maybe they don't understand what it says."
In the Giao Duc bookstore nearby, staff members gathered with several friends by a small television set to listen as Mr. Clinton addressed the nation in a live broadcast from the university's auditorium.
Some of them said they had stayed up until almost 1 a.m. today to watch his motorcade when he drove down their street from the airport after his arrival in Vietnam.
"We didn't know the schedule so we waited for him all day," said Le Thi Tam, one of the workers at the bookstore. "Some people began waiting for him at 3 p.m."
Surrounded by shelves of textbooks -- philosophy, economics, psychology, computer science, foreign languages -- they watched now as Mr. Clinton strode to the lectern, a bust of Ho Chi Minh to one side.
"A big guy," commented Tran Quang Binh, who teaches mathematics at the university.
"He looks like Kennedy," said Chu Anh Quan, a bookstore worker, adding in English: "Very handsome."
"No, not like Kennedy," said another worker, Tran Thu Lan. "Kennedy was more stylish, more like a playboy."
They leaned forward in their chairs as Mr. Clinton began to speak, one woman embracing another from behind, their heads almost touching.
"He's explaining the war," said Mr. Binh, the mathematics teacher, at one point. "Back in the war time he was one of the antiwar protesters."
And then there was a murmur of agreement when Mr. Clinton said, "We cannot change the past. What we can change is the future."
"That's right," Mr. Binh said. "He's talking sense."
Ha Tuan Anh, the bookstore manager, offered a sobering aside: "He'll be out of a job in eight weeks," he said. "They have a law limiting them to two terms."
Which led Mr. Binh to observe: "In our system you can stay on for years and years."
There was a small silence in the room as the speech ended and the bookstore audience sat back in their chairs considering their verdict.
"Pretty good speech," Mr. Anh said.
"Very good," Mr. Binh agreed. "It's probably written by his speechwriters."
