PUB-DATE: November 19, 2000

SECTION: Section 6; Page 82; Column 2; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 4409 words

HEADLINE: A Hatred Smoldering In the Hills

BYLINE: By Michael Finkel; Michael Finkel's last article for the magazine was about sailing illegally to America with a group of Haitian refugees.

 BODY:
Of all the odd and misguided tenets by which Eddie Vaughn lived his life, perhaps the most troubling was his view of the law. "There's the law way, and there's my way," is a maxim Vaughn frequently repeated. He expressed this doctrine by beating his wife and dealing in narcotics and pulling a gun or a knife on whoever he felt required it. Anyone who believed in the righteousness or sanctity of the legal system was, by definition, Vaughn's enemy. He had a temper both violent and unpredictable, and even those who admired him realized that if Vaughn were to encounter the wrong person, in the wrong situation, he was liable to impose a punishment of his own furious creation.
Fred Capps was a lawyer. He was a state prosecutor, a zealous -- some have said excessively zealous -- defender of the law, a man with morals so rigidly defined that he was usually loath to pursue anything less than the maximum possible punishment. "With Fred it was either right or it was wrong," says one of his closest friends. "There was no soft middle." During trials, Capps was so intense that he could neither sleep nor eat nor discuss anything other than the case at hand. His reverence for the law was as strong as Vaughn's disdain, and his abilities in a courtroom were at once remarkable and daunting. To Fred Capps, the notion of removing from society people like Eddie Vaughn was his life's motivating force. To Eddie Vaughn, the idea of being punished by a man like Fred Capps was his vision of hell -- in fact, as it turned out, he deemed it a fate worse than death.
It is clear that people like Eddie Vaughn and Fred Capps should never come near each other, and in a big city or even a large town they probably would not. But Vaughn and Capps were reared in the same tiny place, a community called Burkesville, nestled deep within the Cumberland Mountains of far southern Kentucky. 
 Eddie Vaughn grew up in the highlands that surround Burkesville, the brilliant green foothills of the Cumberlands, where he could throw his knives and grow his pot and fire his shotgun and no one would care to trouble him. The Cumberland hills are quarters to bootlegging businesses -- prohibition remains in effect in most of southern Kentucky -- as well as marijuana plantations and cockfighting rings, none of which would benefit from the notice of policemen or sheriff's deputies. And so the people who live in these hills are schooled in a sort of home-brewed Hammurabi's Code known as "country justice" and indoctrinated with a distinct sense of apartness. Here, the seasons are often referred to by the cycles of the tobacco crops (planting, blooming, cutting and curing), the chickens run free and many of the mobile homes appear to have surrendered to gravity and slumped into the hillsides.
Fred Capps was from the valley, the flat, fertile flood plain of the Cumberland River, upon which all of Burkesville's commercial buildings are clustered. In town, every third building seems to be a church, and the largest structure is the Cumberland County Courthouse, a boxy, solemn edifice, made of stone and brick, that appears to announce that this is a law-and-order kind of place. Life in the Burkesville valley literally revolves around it. Main Street encloses the courthouse within a traffic circle, and along the outer perimeter of this circle are the town's chief businesses -- the Cumberland County News; the Corner Pool and Lunch; Smith Pharmacy; Keith's Barber Shop; and Capps's law office, out of which Fred Capps served as commonwealth's attorney. Whittling is still a practiced time-killer in Burkesville, and little mounds of cedar shavings can be seen beneath the benches outside the courthouse. The town is home to exactly one stoplight, which means there are more stoplights than there are movie theaters, or bookstores, or restaurants serving anything more daring than cheeseburgers. The homes in the valley tend to be fancier-looking than those in the hills, and there are no chickens, free range or otherwise, anywhere in town.
Burkesville, in fact, is one of the more isolated places in the United States. It's an hour's drive to the closest Interstate, past the villages of Marrowbone and Willow Shade and Nobob. Every morning, provoked by the warm, pale-green waters of the Cumberland River, a thick layer of fog hovers above town, stuffing the gaps between the hills like chinking and giving an observer the impression that nothing exists in the lands beyond except an endless lather of clouds. To many locals, any place outside Cumberland County is known, quite simply, as "off."
Very few families move to Burkesville -- there's not one housing development under construction in the entire county -- and those already there tend to measure their nativeness in terms of generations rather than years. The first mention of both a Vaughn and a Capps in the book "History of Cumberland County" happens to occur in the very same sentence, one that describes a group of vigilantes in 1861. Neither family, it seemed, ever got a dollar ahead. This is hardly surprising; even today, almost everyone in Cumberland County is poor: the median annual household income is less than $18,000. Nearly one-third of the residents live below the poverty line, and 60 percent of the adults have not graduated from high school. The county's population is currently 6,800, which is less than it was in 1980.
Vaughn's parents were tenant farmers who worked modest corn and tobacco plots in the Burkesville hills. Eddie, born in 1950, was the oldest of nine children and often had to attend school barefoot -- a state of undress he apparently adapted to, for he continued to embrace it even after developing various clothing and grooming fetishes later in life. Capps, born in 1953, was the older of two brothers; his mother labored in a garment mill, his dad in a machine shop. The principal difference between the two men was less economic than geographic: Vaughn lived in the hills; Capps was from the valley.
Eddie Vaughn and Fred Capps were not strangers to each other. They were not strangers to anyone in Burkesville. Rather, they were two of the best known people in Cumberland County. If Burkesville is divided into two loose circles -- those who live in the hills and those who live in town -- then Vaughn and Capps represented the extreme outliers of each of their worlds. They are worlds that seem to foster extraordinary allegiance: Fred Capps never wanted to live anywhere else, and Eddie Vaughn, though he spent several years away from Burkesville, always returned to the Cumberland hills.
Some small towns -- those, say, amid the farmlands of the Great Plains, which are often celebrated as icons of American spaciousness -- feel like distant outposts in a giant realm. Not Burkesville. Instead, Burkesville feels as though it is the epicenter of its own little kingdom, with the Cumberland Mountains serving as ramparts. Conversations at the Pool and Lunch, even political ones, seem always to be focused on local characters. The two dozen pages of the weekly Cumberland County News frequently contain not a single story from off. There is something about such insularity -- something about the press of the mountains and the changelessness of the citizenry and the somnolence of the days -- that causes differences to be amplified rather than dissipated. Citizens still talk about the woman who came (briefly) from off who did not shave her underarms. Walk one lap around the courthouse with a cell phone pressed to your ear and you'll be branded a city slicker for life. A local barbecue restaurant owned by an outsider whom the town has decided is a hippie has been informally boycotted and is now for sale. Amid this mind-set, within this ring of mountains, it isn't surprising that two men as forceful as Eddie Vaughn and Fred Capps could not remain separated forever.
They attended the same elementary school, albeit briefly. Vaughn dropped out after the fourth grade, having mastered neither reading nor writing. As a youth, he was a known troublemaker. "He was the type of person," says David Williams, who grew up in Burkesville -- in town -- and is now president of the Kentucky State Senate, "you'd cross the street to avoid encountering." Over the years, Vaughn compiled a police record that included arrests for disorderly conduct, public intoxication and marijuana possession. He continually struggled with his temper and his addictions, both to alcohol and drugs. "One minute he'd be fine," says his mother, Versie Young, "and the next he'd be berserk. It was like a switch was thrown in his head."
Capps was a diminutive, pedantic child; serious, intense, moral almost to a fault. "He always had a poetry book under his arm," recalls Williams, "and he was never particularly social." In a yearbook photo of the 1971 Cumberland County High School senior officers, Fred (the class secretary) is peering from behind Coke-bottle glasses and is the only one wearing a tie. He looks about five years younger than anyone else in the picture. Even in adulthood his face -- blue-eyed and wrinkleless -- never came within a decade of his age. Capps put himself through Western Kentucky University by working as a welder; his Basic Ferrous Welding certificate is hanging on his office wall next to his college diploma.
Both men married women with local ties, and married them young -- Patricia Ferguson was 15 when she wed Eddie Vaughn, who was 10 years her senior; Catherine Brown was 16 when she wed Fred Capps, who was 4 years older. For Vaughn, marriage initiated a reign of abuse. "My dad beat my mom just about every day of my life," says Tommie Vaughn, the couple's only child, who is now 24. "He'd get ideas in his head like my mom was cheating on him, and he'd go crazy." Vaughn never held a steady job; he never received a driver's license. In the early 80's, the Vaughns moved to Louisville, though most summers they returned to the Cumberland hills. Several years ago, Vaughn had a cancerous left kidney removed, and federal disability payments of $760 a month constituted the bulk of the family income.
Fred Capps attended law school at Northern Kentucky University, then promptly headed home to Burkesville. In 1982 he joined a law practice with his wife, Cathi, and 12 years later he was elected commonwealth's attorney, serving as state prosecutor in Cumberland and three adjacent counties. "He was a workaholic and a perfectionist," says Cathi. "He couldn't turn it off; he could never stop working." He usually operated on less than five hours of sleep, and during pressing trials he'd often drive to his office at 3 or 4 in the morning. As prosecutor, his sense of morality, always strong, became even more solidified. "Most of us, we have to plea-bargain cases; there's just too many to attend to," says Phil Patton, the commonwealth's attorney in the district just west of Capps's. "But Fred was willing to put in all the work. He rarely amended charges. If you violated the law and Fred was prosecuting, you could expect that you were going to prison."
Vaughn was the epitome of a country-justice adherent, one who took the hill dweller's ideal of unquestioned privacy to fanatical degrees. "There was no such thing as friends with my parents," says Tommie. "No one was allowed to visit the house. If someone knocked on our door, my dad would beat him bad enough so that he'd know never to come back." Eddie Vaughn's two passions, according to his son, were fighting and working out. He would exercise for five, six, seven hours a day, curling cinder blocks or punching a bag until he'd split all 10 of his knuckles. Stories of his physical prowess circulate around Burkesville like modern-day Paul Bunyan tales. He could throw a knife so accurately that if a person pressed a dime into a tree 20 yards away, he could sink the tip directly into Roosevelt's ear. He could run a pool table, even with the stipulation that every ball bounce off three rails before hitting the pocket. He could climb up a tree until it began to bend, whereupon he'd hop into another tree without touching the ground, and continue as far as he wanted -- like a squirrel," says his son. He once walked across ice so thin that a dog fell through. He could stand on the floor, leap up, perform a forward flip and land atop a table.
Capps's obsessive work habits spilled into his personal life. He treated the Little League field as though it were his garden, importing Alabama red clay for the infield and continually tending to the grass. He hated crowds, he hated traffic -- He'd drive 30 minutes to avoid sitting in traffic 10," says his brother, Rick Capps -- and he especially hated Bill Clinton (a sentiment widely shared in town). He left southern Kentucky only 10 days a year, when the family vacationed in South Carolina. His favorite meal was a hamburger; he never once in his life flew in an airplane.
He and Cathi had two children, John, now 16, and Lydia, 11, and the demands he placed on his family were sometimes as insurmountable as the workload he placed on himself. "He wasn't the type of person who was free with compliments," says Cathi. To see him smile was a rare event -- so rare that Cathi kept a photo of a grinning Fred on the corner of her desk, to remind her that he could occasionally relax.
Vaughn's most tender affections, it seemed, were for poisonous animals. In his home he kept cages filled with snakes and scorpions and spiders, and he handled them with impunity. He owned one snake for two years, a copperhead named Young Billy, and when it died Vaughn gave him a full burial, including a coffin. Vaughn graffitoed his body with tattoos -- a spider, a cross bearing the inscription "Eddie," a flag wrapped about a skull, a nude woman, a dagger piercing three hearts and "L-O-V-E" spelled across the knuckles of his left hand. On his chest he displayed a blue-and-green tattoo that read "Try Me Baby." He had pale blue eyes and a long nose and hewn cheekbones. His nickname was Fast Eddie, and he posed a longstanding wager to the world: if anybody could land the first punch in a fight with him, he'd never fight again. Apparently, no one ever did. "His goal in life," says Tommie Vaughn, "was to be the toughest guy around. He wanted to be a legend in Cumberland County."
Throughout their lives, Vaughn and Capps were frequent topics of town gossip, with no shortage of admiration or animosity delivered toward either man, depending, generally, upon whether the speaker was from town or from some of the more extremist encampments up in the hills. What is surprising is not that Vaughn and Capps clashed, but that it took nearly four decades before they did. Though when the moment came, even the most cynical souls in Burkesville admitted that the encounter was more virulent and explosive than anyone had anticipated.
It was a 9-year-old girl who brought the two men together. In July 1998, Eddie and Patricia Vaughn moved back to the hills of Burkesville. They'd been there less than three months when the daughter of a neighbor accused Eddie of fondling her genitals through her clothing and then forcing her to touch his genitals. The charges were serious, and they were in the hands of the commonwealth's attorney, Fred Capps. For the first time in his checkered life, Eddie Vaughn was facing significant jail time, perhaps as much as 10 years.
In January 1999, Vaughn was indicted by a grand jury on two counts of child molestation. He spent 49 days in custody before he was freed on bail. After his release, Eddie's behavior was even more erratic than usual. He became convinced that the charges, which he vehemently denied, were part of a personal vendetta orchestrated by the Burkesville elite -- in his mind, those who lived in town -- to force him to leave again. And Fred Capps, he believed, was the totem of that elite. "The people who have power in Burkesville," says Tommie, "wanted my father gone, and they found a way." The young girl, Eddie Vaughn claimed, was upset over her parents' divorce proceedings and wanted to escape from her house and live with the Vaughns. When Vaughn refused her, according to his story, the girl was so upset that she invented the sexual-abuse charges.
While it's true that Vaughn had never before been accused of such a crime and that there were no eyewitnesses to the alleged abuse, the chief investigator on the complaint, Sgt. Lisa Rudzinski of the Kentucky State Police, was convinced that she had a solid case. "Based on the evidence gathered," says Sergeant Rudzinski, "there was obvious probable cause. I caught him in several lies while interviewing him. All of the elements of the crime I believe I had evidence to support."
Even Vaughn's lawyer, Scott Johns of Louisville, agreed that the outlook seemed unfavorable. He suggested to Vaughn that perhaps a guilty plea might result in a lighter sentence, of three years. With good behavior, Johns predicted, Vaughn could be released on parole in less than six months. Upon hearing this, Vaughn blew up. "He was out of his head with anger," says Tommie. "He told me he'd never plead guilty to a crime he didn't commit -- never, ever." In the Cumberland hills, the code of country justice has its own odd yet systematic ideals. It's a dogma that honors fist-fighting and knife-throwing talent, and by these measures, Vaughn was a near legend. But touching a little girl is unacceptable, and a guilty charge on such a crime will forever doom an outlaw to an ignoble existence. In a secluded county where everyone knows everyone, it is difficult to imagine Eddie Vaughn, guilty or not, receiving an impartial trial. And so Vaughn, feeling trapped, arrived at an extreme solution -- extreme, yet possibly the only one in which his reputation would not merely be salvaged but infinitely bolstered.
The trial was set to begin last summer on Monday, June 5. Early that morning, just as dawn was breaking, Eddie forced Patricia to drive him to the home of one of his brothers, James. James lives in a rusty white trailer a few miles back in the Burkesville hills, on a lot populated with cherry trees and peach trees and giant, flamboyant rhododendrons. Eddie and James hadn't spoken in years, since the two argued, violently, over a marijuana deal. The June encounter was also violent. Apparently, Eddie did not know where Fred Capps lived and needed his brother to show him the way. He entered James's home, threatened him with a knife, smashed his telephone and said, "Today is a great day to die."
Eddie decided that James's car, a 1983 Olds Cutlass, would be more dependable than Patricia's scarcely operable Buick, and he shoved James into the driver's seat. Patricia sat next to him. Eddie climbed in back, clutching a Chinese-made SKS semiautomatic rifle, with a banana clip in place holding 30 rounds of ammunition. Also with him was a 16-gauge, single-barrel sawed-off shotgun; a hunting knife with a nine-and-a-half-inch blade; a second hunting knife with a five-and-a-half-inch blade; a lock-blade knife; two boot knives in leather sheaths; a hatchet; a second clip for the SKS; 22 shells for the shotgun; and a pit bull named Redson who was trained to kill at an instant's notice. Eddie was wearing black jeans and a white crew-neck T-shirt, both of which appeared as though they had just come from the dry cleaners. Eddie had a fixation with wearing unblemished attire and would sometimes beat his wife if she hung his jeans improperly. He'd also shower three or four times a day, brush his teeth every hour or so and continually comb his long brown hair, which was now tied back with a pink ribbon. He wore no shoes.
The Cappses' home, a two-story brick colonial house, was emblematic of a valley spread, with a stately circular driveway, a manicured lawn and six slender columns framing a classic Southern front porch adorned with rocking chairs, wicker furniture and hanging plants. Fred and Cathi were asleep in the master bedroom on the first floor. The children were in bed upstairs. It was a little before 6 a.m. Most days, Capps would have been in his office by then, but he'd had a full Sunday -- his kids' piano recital at the Baptist church, several hours of preparation for the Vaughn trial, then coaching duty at a late-evening Little League practice. The car pulled into the driveway, circled partway around and stopped directly in front of the door. Eddie Vaughn opened the rear door and stepped out.
There was no hesitation, not a nod toward stealth. As he strode to the Cappses' front door, Vaughn sprayed the porch with eight quick shots from his semiautomatic rifle, five of which passed through the front window and into the foyer. When he reached the door, he shot 10 more times around the handle and lock, then kicked the door in. The Cappses' neighbors, Mack and Mae Walker, were awake, watching television. They heard the shots. Mack ran to his door, saw Vaughn enter the Cappses' house and shouted for his wife to call the police. She did. It was 5:55 a.m.
Once inside the house, Eddie Vaughn continued firing. By this time, Fred Capps had leapt out of bed. He was wearing boxer shorts and a T-shirt. He poked his head out of his bedroom door. Vaughn turned to his left and leveled his gun at Capps, who dove back into the room. Vaughn approached the room, still shooting. As Fred Capps was reaching between his mattress and box spring, where he kept a loaded .357 Magnum, a bullet penetrated the bedroom wall and struck Capps in the lower back. Wood fragments pried loose by other shots nicked Cathi. Even though the bullet lacerated his liver, punctured his left lung and traveled through his aorta, Capps managed to grab the weapon. He told his wife to get on the intercom and tell the children not to move. Then he spun around and again peeked out of his doorway. At this point, Vaughn had almost reached the room. The two men were less than 10 feet from each other.
The standoff lasted only an instant. Vaughn fired his gun four more times, striking Capps in his abdomen, his neck, his right forearm and again in his lower back. Capps managed to discharge his weapon twice, hitting Vaughn in the upper chest. Both men fell backward, face up, Capps collapsing into his bedroom, onto the beige carpet, his gun flung over his left shoulder, Vaughn toppling to the hardwood floor of the foyer, the stock of his rifle beneath him. The two men's feet, both bare, were scarcely a body's length apart. By the time the police entered the house, three minutes after the neighbors had called, both men were dead.
Some locals believe that life in Burkesville is now irrevocably altered. The town, they say, feels deflated: less innocent, less cheery, less welcoming. A sense of distrust has crept in that can never be extinguished. Families, especially those in the valley, are installing home-alarm systems. More people are applying to carry concealed weapons. The courthouse, once a symbol of security, now seems a mocking reminder of the ultimate triumph of lawlessness.
Other citizens insist that the tragedy has drawn people closer to one another and even, in some ways, has made them proud to be a part of Burkesville, home of the man who was finally able to stand up to Eddie Vaughn. Fred Capps is buried in the Burkesville Cemetery, in the valley, where a small mountain of flowers is piled over his grave. He is only the third prosecutor in the nation to have been slain by a defendant in the last 20 years. Three thousand people attended his funeral, during which he was repeatedly praised as a hero whose actions may have saved the lives of as many as a dozen others, including the rest of his family. Eddie Vaughn, according to his brother James, had claimed early that final morning that he was determined to kill not only Capps, but also the girl who had accused him of molestation and as many police officers as possible.
A third opinion, perhaps the majority one, is that nothing in Burkesville has essentially changed -- there's still the valley and there's still the hills, there are still assumptions and prejudices and despite the two killings, there are still the same families. Cathi Capps refused to be cast out of her home. Within hours of the shootings, her neighbors had replaced the front door, the porch window and the bedroom carpet, and Cathi and her children slept in the house that same night. She was offered the job of commonwealth's attorney, though she turned it down because of the concerns of her children. The Vaughns also remain in Burkesville, though not all of their own volition. On Aug. 3, a grand jury charged Patricia with complicity to murder and James with the lesser offense of facilitation to murder. During the killings, Patricia never left the car; James wandered into a hayfield behind the Cappses' house. Patricia, who has been unable to post bond and remains in jail, could be sentenced to 20 years to life in prison. James, free on bond, faces a sentence of one to five years. Their trial is scheduled to begin in February in the Cumberland County Courthouse.
And then there's Tommie Vaughn. His father is buried in a small cemetery up in the hills, the site marked with a metallic, helium-filled balloon, from Patricia, that says "I Love You." The only place where Eddie Vaughn's name appears is on an index card, wrapped in plastic and attached to a stake. One hundred and twelve people signed the visitation book at Ballou Funeral Home, several of whom apparently believe that Vaughn's actions were also heroic.
Tommie, who has seemingly inherited much of his father's anger, is now in the process of cultivating Eddie's infamy. "I don't blame my dad for a thing he did," says Vaughn's son. "He worked hard getting his reputation. My dad was a violent person, but he wasn't a child molester. He didn't want to lose his reputation over some false charges. I'm proud of him. He died defending his honor." Tommie says he is soon going to place a larger marker at his father's grave site. He plans to construct it himself, on poster board, and seal it in a waterproof frame. "I'm going to decorate it with an eagle and a flag," he explains, "and then I'm going to write on it, 'Fast Eddie: American Legend."' It's his hope, he says, that the site will become a type of shrine, a meeting place for anyone else in the Cumberland hills who wants to live his life like Eddie Vaughn.

PUB-DATE: November 19, 2000

SECTION: Section 5; Page 11; Column 1; Travel Desk

LENGTH: 3317 words

HEADLINE: The Glow of the Past Is Restored

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE; BARBARA CROSSETTE is chief of the United Nations bureau of The Times.

 BODY:
SOMETIMES when the day's work is done, the master maker of cellos and violins settles down on a seat outside his cottage on the main street of Nagyvazsony, a small town in western Hungary, and begins to play. There are few competing sounds to intrude on his music, except for the barking of dogs. Just beyond the treetops, colorful flags rise and fall on the breeze over the watchtower of a castle commanded by a heroic Hungarian patriot who held off the Turkish invaders centuries ago. Has nothing changed here in several hundred years?
In some ways, everything has. 
 A decade after the collapse of Communism, this small Hungarian town and others encountered in neighboring Slovakia are being reborn, both in celebration of new freedoms of choice under democratic governments and in the hope that the best of old central European cultures can be revived. Warm, welcoming, family-run inns offer the comfort and cuisine that were once eclipsed by the austere ugliness and utilitarianism of Socialist hotels -- when any hotel could be found. Gothic and Baroque churches, castles and public squares are being restored to perfection. Family vineyards and all manner of other small enterprises are being expanded and improved. Conversation is no longer constrained by politics.
The moment may not last forever. But for now, in the countryside of central Europe -- unlike in cities such as Budapest and Prague -- the traveler is still a guest, not a victim of rapacious cabdrivers, shopkeepers and hoteliers who sometimes seem to be shamelessly, even belligerently, exploiting the infinite possibilities of uncontrolled capitalism. Village streets are inviting. A mix of languages and lifestyles, with German, Slavic and Hungarian roots, enriches daily life. Old ethnic tensions may one day resurface, too, but for now, there is peace and a joyful sense of renewal.
Our trip in July was a kind of movable family reunion -- 11 Americans from one to three generations away from our roots in these villages, reconnecting with relatives from the extended family left behind by my immigrant mother. We focused on two towns: Nagyvazsony (pronounced Nahzh-VAH-sohn), with a population of 1,700, in the wine-growing region of Hungary about 10 miles north of Lake Balaton; and Kezmarok, in the shadow of the High Tatra mountains of Slovakia, where my mother was born. Some of us had made this pilgrimage, or parts of it, in the past, during some of the darkest years of the 1960's and 1970's. This trip was very different.
Nagyvazsony, two hours west of Budapest's airport by road, is not a developed tourist town. We came because a cousin had a country home there, within striking distance of both the lake and the marvelously restored ancient city of Veszprem with its hilltop palace and churches, a thriving farmers' market and a large pedestrian-only shopping area, with plenty of places to sit and rest or eat.
But even little Nagyvazsony had two recently opened panzio, the Hungarian equivalent of a European pension. Ours, the Malomko -- created by Erika and Tamas Holenyi on the site of what was once a blacksmith's shop -- had a small pool, a restaurant, an outdoor cafe and a patisserie that also sold very good ice cream. In a virtually traffic-free town in midsummer, we could walk along village streets to the 500-year-old fortress of Pal Kinizsi, the legendary warrior with superhuman strength who championed King Matthias and was rewarded with the castle. Much of it is now in ruins, but enough is intact to recreate another age.
Every day in summer, the tale of the indomitable Kinizsi is retold in a performance of medieval swordplay, horsemanship and jousting by a troupe of young people re-enacting the humiliation of the invading Turks -- nowadays, Hungarians in turbans who scale the walls and threaten the defenders from the parapets. The narration is in Hungarian, but not much interpretation is needed as the crowd gleefully cheers on the patriots and boos down the Turks.
A quieter national pride has gone into a small ethnographic museum just a few hundred yards away on Var Street, which leads to the castle compound. The museum is housed in a well-preserved traditional home characteristic of this region, the model for many of Nagyvazsony's present-day houses. Rooms have been restored to show village life over the centuries, down to the elaborate tile stoves that provided winter heat, and still do for many families. In the courtyard on some evenings there is chamber music.
Lake Balaton is an acquired taste. Long one of the most popular tourist destinations in central Europe, Balaton's "beaches," often just grassy lawns leading to a rocky shore, are mobbed in summer. Lakeside towns rattle with the honky-tonk of cheap souvenir stores and fast-food cafes, where hamburgers and pizza create serious competition for the local deep-fried bread specialty, the langos, a plate-size crust topped with almost anything you choose, from garlic to sugar.
An exception was Tihany (pronounced TE-hahnee), a town without a beach, or much public transportation, high on hills along a peninsula that juts out from the lake's northern shore, about 10 miles from Nagyvazsony. The crowning glory of Tihany is its Benedictine abbey, with a lavishly ornamented Baroque church and 11th-century crypt that houses not only the tomb of the founder, King Andrew I, but also a copy of the first official document known to have been written in Hungarian. Around the abbey are several galleries devoted to artifacts from the building's past and contemporary art exhibits. The view of Lake Balaton from the abbey grounds is unparalleled.
If Nagyvazsony was a happy surprise, Kezmarok was a miracle. This town, at the gateway to the High Tatras, a branch of the Carpathian Mountains bridging the Slovakian-Polish border, was settled by Germans from Saxony in the 13th century, brought there by Hungarian rulers to augment the local rural Slovak population against numerous and diverse invaders. The Hungarian king, Stephen V, gave the town and others in the region, called Spis, unusual privileges of self-government and autonomy. These boons lasted almost 600 years.
By the late Middle Ages, local historians say, Kezmarok-- known as Kasemark to its German-speaking inhabitants, who included my ancestors -- was a trade and craft center known for its educational institutions and its artistic and cultural life. In this century, two world wars and authoritarians of the left and right devastated the independent spirit of the town, which now has a population of about 20,000. When I first saw Kezmarok, with my mother before her death more than 20 years ago, it seemed a gloomy place, summer and winter, with dull, gray streets and sooty buildings. I mentally dismissed her stories of what a fine place it had been as exaggerated memories of a happy childhood.
Now it is hard to find a home, church or public building that has not been restored, with old facades repainted in white or one of a palette of colors. Tourists, especially Germans, come to see a unique piece of European history. Architecturally, the town survived mostly intact, from many small private homes to a 15th-century castle, now reopened as a museum. Restaurants, cafes and ice cream parlors further brighten the cobbled streets, where cars are few.
THE Slovak Republic is still a poor agrarian country by European standards. Unemployment is high, we were told, and wages are low. In fact, when I asked where the money for restorations was coming from, several people offered the explanation that labor was cheap and that foreign investors, Austrians in particular, saw the potential for an urban travel boom in towns like these and for eco-tourism in the rich green hills and gentle mountains. Local people welcomed more tourism development for the jobs it could bring.
We found the Hotel Club, near the center of Kezmarok, through the Internet. It was another post-Communist private venture, like our panzio in Hungary. The hotel is owned by the Soltys family and managed by a daughter, Janka, and her husband, Juraj Gantner. Like other small hotels we saw -- the hotel has 50 beds in 19 rooms and suites -- the simple but pleasing furniture was handmade of solid wood. The dining room had a hunting-lodge air about it, with a brick floor, a cast-iron wood stove and so many pelts and trophy antlers of all kinds on every wall that my 7-year-old granddaughter, Emily, felt sad and lost her appetite.
We had traveled to Kezmarok from Budapest on a series of trains -- and one inexplicable bus, linking two stations near the Slovak town of Kosice. Our eastern European rail passes brought us through the Tatra rail center at Poprad all the way to Kezmarok's grand old railway station, also recently refurbished. The hotel was a short walk away, and we didn't need a car again during our stay, except for a trip to visit family graves at Spisska Bela, about five miles away. Even in a steady drizzle, or through a summer shower, everything in Kezmarok was within easy walking distance.
Just behind the Hotel Club was one of the Kezmarok's four notable churches, the Gothic-era Roman Catholic Church of the Holy Cross, with a free-standing Renaissance bell tower beside it. With the Reformation and the Counter-Reformation that followed, Kezmarok felt the pull of religious tensions. An old wooden Protestant church built in the 17th century and the 19th century cathedral-size replacement next door had to be constructed outside the now-destroyed old city walls. But religious dividing lines ebbed and flowed here, with Catholics and Protestants sometimes trading churches as one group or another was in the ascendancy. The little Baroque Paulinus church, built into a row of houses on Castle Square, is on land given as a gift to Catholics during a period in the 17th century when Protestants controlled the town.
Kezmarok's castle, in a rambling walled enclosure near the edge of town, was a local fortress built to safeguard this independent city-state, though as the fortress changed hands and fortunes it once found itself under attack by the townspeople it was built to protect. Many rooms and galleries have been renewed and furnished with period antiques, a process that began under the Communist government in the 1960's and was only recently completed. Exhibitions include fascinating old portraits of citizens of yore, their schools and homes and avocations.
The Hotel Club recommended that we visit the Grandhotel Praha, a magnificently restored turn-of-the-century mountain lodge in Tatranska Lomnica, an hour or so away by car. Tatranska Lomnica, like Stary Smokovec and Strbske Pleso, were the Tatra Mountain equivalents of American and European 19th- and early 20th-century mountain resorts or colonial Asian hill stations. High, cool and health-giving, the towns had sanitariums, resort lodges, hiking trails and sometimes thermal pools.
My son, Jonathan, remembered visiting these towns as a small boy and wanted to go back, so he and his wife, Linda, and their children, Nathan, who is 9, and Emily, detoured with me into the mountains by car for a few days before ending our central European trip with a long train journey to Prague, where we rejoined the rest of the traveling family.
Again, so much was different in the Tatras. Not knowing about the Grandhotel Praha, we had already booked rooms in a brand-new mountain lodge, the Hotel Hubert, in the shadow of the Tatras's highest peak, 8,711-foot Gerlachovsky. A big hotel set in a sweeping meadow ringed by dense spruce forests, the Hubert had all kinds of diversions for children, from ponies to skittles to a heated indoor pool. The coffeehouse had great ice cream.
But the Hubert will never be the equal of the Grandhotel Praha, where we spent a day. Nor will it match another restoration in progress, the Grand Hotel in Stary Smokovec, set to reopen by the end of the year. These are magnificent turn-of-the-century buildings full of splendors of a gilded age, from deep leather chairs by the fire to chandeliered dining rooms where even the smallest diners are treated royally.
Tatranska Lomnica serves as headquarters of the Tatra National Park, known as Tanap, which was established more than half a century ago and recently expanded. There is an excellent small museum here that provides an easy-to-follow introduction to the mountains, their plants and animals and their people. Nearby, a nature garden has taken shape to display the granite and limestone that form the Tatras, along with fossils, mosses and other vegetation.
From the Grandhotel Praha, between a morning coffee and a long, late lunch, we climbed nearly 1,000 feet and at least a mile up into the mountains along hiking trails softened by carpets of needles from the towering evergreens that cover the Tatras's lower reaches. Then, at a place called Start, at about 3,800 feet, we caught a ski lift to the glacial lake at Skalnate, above the tree line at about 5,700 feet. It was a breathtaking ride. Had the weather been clearer, we might have been tempted to go to the top of Lomnica, an 8,635-foot peak, and the lift's last stop. Instead, we rode back down to Tatranska Lomnica and hiked back to the warmth of the Grandhotel Praha.
At last, in these mountains, lost in trees, we were back to a recognizable place. Tourism in central Europe is undergoing a revolution in many ways. But nothing in this glorious natural landscape had changed. Slovakia has decided some things can't really be improved, and should certainly not be commercialized. A new guidebook to the Tatra National Park museum at Tatranska Lomnica asks a little plaintively, "How are we doing?" Just great.
 
Exploring small towns in Eastern Europe
United States citizens require only a valid passport to enter Slovakia; for Hungary, the passport must be valid for six months past the entry date.
 
Transportation
A rental car is a popular way to travel in central Europe, and roads are good and well marked. But because we were a large group with a lot to talk about, we made most journeys by rail with a European East Pass, which can be used in Austria, the Czech Republic, Hungary, Poland and Slovakia. A first-class pass good for five days within any 30-day period cost $205 for adults, with extra days $23 each. Passes must be bought outside the countries where they will be used; they are sold in the United States by Rail Europe, (800) 438-7245 or www.raileurope.com.
Passes must be validated at a train station on the day travel begins, and dates must be entered for each subsequent journey before boarding a train. Reservations, for an additional few dollars, are often required on express trains. Railway clerks or conductors seldom spoke any foreign language. In Slovakia, we asked an English-speaking hotel receptionist to write out in Slovak what reservations we wanted, and we took this to the station to book seats several days before the next trip.
Trains were best in Slovakia and the Czech Republic. The most disappointing ride, about five hours long, was in a very dirty Hungarian train with no food services from Budapest to the eastern city of Miskolc, where we were loaded into buses to be deposited at the Slovak border more than an hour later and put on another train to the Slovak city of Kosice. The express train from Kosice to Poprad, the rail center of the Tatra region, and on to Prague was superb, with delightful scenery. There was a dining car, though the food was poor and the selection limited.
Taxis and car rentals are available in larger cities and towns where tourists visit, though Kezmarok and Nagyvazsony did not have car rentals. In the Tatras, several taxi services operate, some using meters but others preferring to negotiate prices in advance. The 35-minute trip from Kezmarok to the Hotel Hubert in Gerlachov, for example, cost about $20 (at 51.48 koruna to the dollar). From the Hubert we used metered taxis to Stary Smokovec (about $10) and Tatranska Lomnica, which cost $12 to $14. Two local train lines connect the mountain towns to each other and to Poprad. The nearest train stop to the Hubert is Tatranska Polianka, about a 15-minute walk uphill.
In Hungary, we had a private van with driver arranged by relatives in Nagyvazsony. The owner-driver charged us $400 for four days (at 313 forints to the dollar). Renting a van with driver in Budapest would have cost more. International car rental companies can provide this service if you make reservations.
 
Lodging and Dining
The Malomko Panzio, on Kinizsi Street in Nagyvazsony, telephone and fax (36-88) 264-165, had about a dozen rooms that could be configured in various ways. Double accommodation with private bath costs $25. A suite sleeping four was $50. Rates included a copious buffet breakfast. Other meals were very cheap, with a main course of paprika chicken or goulash and noodles for $2.
Our meals in the Nagyvazsony area were never equaled anywhere else for quality or value. One evening, about 16 of us dined out in a small private vineyard with picnic tables under the trees, on schnitzels and other local dishes, washed down by carafes of wine and topped by Hungarian crepes called palacsinta -- all for less than $50. These vineyards do not normally advertise (our dinner was organized by relatives who knew the vineyard owner), but local innkeepers can arrange wine tastings with snacks or full meals at a number of places. The region's wines tend to be light, rieslings and chardonnays.
In Kezmarok, the Hotel Club, at 24 Mudr. Alexander, telephone (421-968) 452 4051, fax (421-968) 452 4053, charges $34 for a double room and bath, including buffet breakfast, in high season and $26 in low season. The hotel dining room serves good local food, including cheese-filled pirogies, mixed grills and dumplings, all in the $4 to $6 range, including a glass of local beer.
Kezmarok also has several good restaurants, among them The Three Apostles, on 9 Hlavne Namestie, near the Town Hall; telephone (421-968) 452 3272, fax (421-968) 452 5725. Prices are similar.
In general, food in small-town Slovakia relied more on pork than veal or beef, which is more widely available in Hungary. Slovakian schnitzel was also sometimes made of tenderized chicken.
The Hotel Hubert, near Gerlachov, (421-969) 442 5262, fax (421-969) 442 2734, www.tanap.sk/hubert/, charges $69 for a double with bath and balcony with panoramic views, breakfast included. Meals, with the usual fare, were a little disappointing here, and cost more, though were still far from expensive. A dinner for three adults and two children cost about $43 with drinks.
In Tatranska Lomnica, the restored Grandhotel Praha, (421-969) 446 7941, fax (421-969) 446 7891, has double rooms for $41 in summer and $59 in ski season. A generous lunch for five with drinks cost $36.
 
Language
An ability to speak some German -- for those who do not speak Hungarian or Slovak -- is useful and sometimes a necessity in small central European towns. But young people are learning English in school, and most Slovak hotels in particular seemed to have someone on the staff who could speak it. Rail employees and other government workers were the least multilingual as well as the least helpful.
In villages and towns, however, there is little chance of getting lost. Good maps are available from inns and hotels, streets are well marked, as are mountain trails, and townspeople want to be helpful when they can. Ask a hotel to establish taxi rates and write down directions you may need. In the Tatras, mountain towns usually have a central bus-taxi and sometimes cable-car station grouped together, along with a cafe or at least a kiosk for snacks and a money-changer. Bigger towns, including Kezmarok and Stary Smokovec, have A.T.M.'s. BARBARA CROSSETTE

HEADLINE: ART/ARCHITECTURE;
Reading a Civilization Through Its Ancient Shards

BYLINE: By DEBORAH WEISGALL; Deborah Weisgall writes about the arts from Boston.

DATELINE: WORCESTER, Mass.

 BODY:
ENTERING the Worcester Art Museum, the first thing a visitor sees is a sixth-century late Roman mosaic, more than 20 feet square, set into the floor of the entrance hall. In it hunters pursue lions, tigers, bear, antelope. A youth on horseback snatches a tiger cub from its snarling mother. Fruit trees, flowers and vignettes of landscapes relieve the carnage, and in the center, a hunter, weary and victorious, crosses his legs and leans against his spear, which pierces the throat of a wild boar.
This spectacular and brutal scene paved the floor of a private house in Antioch, founded in 300 B.C. and one of the great cities of the classical world. Today ancient Antioch lies beneath the modern Turkish city of Antakya, near the Syrian border at the northeast elbow of the Mediterranean. The mosaic, along with other equally stunning and tantalizing glimmers of an almost mythical place, arrived in Worcester nearly 60 years ago. Now, an important exhibition, organized by Christine Kondoleon, the curator of Greek and Roman art at the museum, places these works of art in their archaeological and historical context for the first time. 
 "Antioch: The Lost Ancient City," which remains on view until Feb. 4, when it travels to Cleveland and Baltimore, recreates the splendor of what was one of the four great cities of the Roman empire. Four silver-gilt tyches on display -- female deities personifying the good fortune of a particular city -- representing Rome, Constantinople, Alexandria and Antioch attest to Antioch's status. Sculptures, mosaics, jewelry and intriguing inscriptions, most of them from the second to the sixth centuries A.D., bring to life a complex metropolis that thrived in an era whose economic, political and spiritual circumstances were in many ways similar to our own. It was a time when the Roman Empire's dominion over the diverse civilizations bordering the Mediterranean led to unprecedented prosperity and spiritual hunger.
Until the 1930's, Antioch's remains were almost entirely literary; its physical glories had been obliterated by earthquakes, floods and invasions from the east. Ancient philosophers and historians extolled the city's cosmopolitan, tolerant atmosphere of luxury and learning; by Roman times it had supplanted Athens as the center of Greek intellectual life.
It was in Antioch that followers of a new mystery cult were first called Christians. For nearly a decade, St. Paul used the city as a base of operations for missionary work, and many scholars believe that Matthew wrote his gospel there. According to Josephus, the first century Jewish historian, Jews numbered among the city's original settlers.
In 1932, a consortium including the Worcester Art Museum, Princeton University, the Louvre and the Baltimore Museum of Art sponsored a series of archaeological expeditions to unearth Antioch's treasures and monuments. But the expedition's leaders and its sponsors were badly disappointed. They discovered no palaces, no golden cathedrals. Most of what they dug up under tons of silt were houses. Their walls were almost always demolished, but their floors survived, adorned with more than 300 mosaics. In 1939, the sponsoring institutions divided the spoils (more than half remained in Antakya), often splitting up the floors from a single room. Excavation pits were filled, olive groves replanted and the ancient city was lost again.
Since then, however, as the study of history has focused as much on ordinary citizens as on their leaders, attention has shifted from throne rooms to dining rooms. Only 10 percent of Antioch's population was rich, according to the fourth-century pagan philosopher Libanios, and only 10 percent was poor. The remaining 80 percent lived remarkably well, and at its height, Antioch's population numbered more than 400,000 citizens and freedmen, not counting women, children and slaves. The exhibition focuses on their dining rooms, or triclinia, in order to recreate the city's great middle-class era, and for middle-class America at the beginning of the third millennium, those ancient houses reveal a familiar ostentation.
"Antioch: The Lost Ancient City" reunites many of the artifacts and objects excavated by the expedition, including some of the most beautiful mosaics. During the five years of preparations for this show, scholars examined for the first time in decades some of the material from the excavations that had been in storage, and the show's catalog presents much of their new research.
Related objects from ancient Syria, including bronzes and glass and silver vessels, fill in many gaps in the city's archaeological record. Such artifacts are rare, and some new finds don't survive their discovery. For instance, mosaics like those at Antioch, unearthed last summer at Zeugma farther west along the Turkish coast, will soon be flooded by water backing up behind a new dam.
Antioch marked the crossroads of trade routes between Persia and the Far East, Egypt and Rome. Founded by one of Alexander the Great's generals, Seleukos I, who named the city after his son and successor, Antiochus I, it quickly became an oasis of Hellenic culture in the Semitic Near East and remained so even after its conquest by Rome.
Although Greek remained Antioch's lingua franca, Rome imposed its shell of administration and customs: Emperors built public baths (several were found) and boulevards; they introduced gladiatorial combat and staged wild animal hunts (the Worcester Hunt mosaic could have derived from those bloody entertainments). Antioch's middle class took full advantage of the economic and cultural efficiencies of empire; their houses and furnishings resembled those built in Pompeii or Carthage. By and large, rulers countenanced any religion as long as it did not interfere with civic pagan ritual; the elite adapted Roman customs, displayed Roman gods beside their own and celebrated dinner as the social and intellectual high point of the day.
During the centuries of the Roman peace, Antioch flourished; its baths and wide arcaded streets were theaters where strangers -- Romans, Syrians, Jews, Christians, Persians, Greeks -- mingled and learned from one another. Its dining rooms set a more intimate stage upon which to continue the dialogue.
Ms. Kondoleon has structured the exhibition as a kind of dialogue as well. Overlapping themes -- water, entertainment, the Roman house, religions -- illuminate different aspects of Antioch's civic character.
The city's pivotal geography proved the source of both its vitality and its vulnerability. Persian emperors of the Sasanian dynasty coveted Antioch, sacked it twice -- in A.D. 256 and 540 -- and incorporated the phrase "better than Antioch" into the names of the cities they built closer to home. Sasanian stylized art, using birds and animals in patterned design -- a mosaic border of ram's heads, for instance -- found its way into Antioch's houses.
Most of the mosaics, however, employ realistic imagery. In a gallery constructed to evoke a dining room in the Atrium House excavated at Antioch, the arrangement of mosaic panels, reassembled from Paris, Baltimore, Princeton and Wellesley, defines the placement of furniture. Three couches, or clinia (hence triclinium, the Roman name for dining room) would have been arranged on a U-shaped geometric mosaic border surrounding pictorial panels arranged in a T. Guests entering the room would have walked on a panel illustrating a drinking contest between Dionysius and Hercules, flanked on either side by a dancing maenad and satyr. Reclining on their couches, diners could contemplate a Judgment of Paris, then Aphrodite and Adonis enthroned. Through a portico, they could glimpse a fountain with marble statues displayed in its niches.
If some of the domestic sculpture tends to be modest, the mosaics in Worcester flicker with life. Paris, surrounded by his flock of cows and goats, looks to Hermes for advice, while the three goddesses, glowering with almost comical impatience and competitive fury, await his decision. And if a silver ewer and plate excavated in a neighboring suburb are not the most elaborate Roman serving pieces ever found, they are nevertheless quite elegant. An intricate golden arm band set with emeralds and sapphires is hardly understated. Life in Antioch was good.
One delight of the show is that it offers, as Ms. Kondoleon says, "the big picture of life in the city as well providing intimate glimpses into the very personal." A rolled curse tablet contains an inscription begging a demon to "bind" a grocer named Babylas, to "sink him like lead" and destroy his house and animals. A gold ring is engraved with its wearer's horoscope; another ring bears the names of two men who were friends and correspondents of the philosopher Libanios.
Did these men reflect aloud on the hubris of trying to best a god as they chugged wine from rhytons like the one Hercules is draining in the mosaic at their feet? Did they discuss with Hellenic detachment John Chrysostom's diatribe against Jews as Christ-killers? Did they admit to having buried a curse tablet in a city well? Although magic was a crime in the Roman Empire, it was also as common as jaywalking is today.
Probably they discussed religion. The Pax Romana, of course, has found its modern parallel in the Pax Americana, in the worldwide exportation of American culture. Ideas, art, politics and religions circulate, blend and clash. The yearning for a spiritual haven was perhaps even more urgent in Roman Antioch than it is today. Independent finds, like the Antioch Chalice, an elaborately decorated fourth-century cup loaned by the Cloisters in New York, attest to the richness of the early church and to its profound allure.
The expeditions of the 1930's dug up no pagan temples or synagogues, but they did uncover in Antioch's port remnants of a church whose ambulatory was paved with a mosaic of animals and birds. Elephants, flamingos, zebras, gazelles, peacocks, a lioness and her cubs: all creation circled the church in a docile parade. In this floor, pagan entertainment translated into a vision from Genesis: the bloody staged hunt has been converted to a peaceable kingdom.

SECTION: Section 2; Page 13; Column 4; Arts and Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 2043 words

HEADLINE: FILM;
How the First World War Changed Movies Forever

BYLINE: By STUART KLAWANS; Stuart Klawans is the author of "Film Follies: The Cinema Out of Order."

 BODY:
I WAS face to face with the awful reality," the French filmmaker Marcel L'Herbier used to say of World War I, despite his never having come near the trenches. Posted to the Army Cinematographic Service, the young L'Herbier spent his war in Paris. Yet each day at work he found his life "turned upside down," just as surely as if he had been in battle.
"Everything that was filmed at the front passed through our hands," he recalled. "We cut, we spliced, we chose what could be shown. I watched scenes of horror; I saw soldiers who had been eviscerated, cut in two, decapitated. That shock revealed to me that I had to become a filmmaker." 
 As these memories reminds us, the Great War was the first to be fought before the motion picture camera. In the field, reconnaisance became airborne and cinematic; at home, propaganda leapt from the page to the screen. The effects were so far-reaching, argues Paul Virilio in his often-cited book "War and Cinema," that the war zone itself may be thought of as a kind of film. On the front, perceptions became accelerated, discontinuous, mechanized, as if the soldiers' eyes had turned into cameras. From this condition, there was to be no release; after 1918, cinema's shock techniques continued wartime perception by other means.
I summarize this theory with caution, since Mr. Virilio develops it through that mixture of hyperbole and non sequitur which is French scholarship at its zaniest. But grant him this much: If a thoroughgoing aesthete like L'Herbier could be so altered by the war, then whose life wasn't turned upside down? World War I, which changed everything, had film as one of its main tools of transformation.
The war also changed the conditions of filmmaking, in France, Germany, Russia and the United States. To a remarkable degree, today's film industry retains the shape it was given by the war -- which means that every picture we see is in some sense a World War I movie.
For French cinema, the war was a debacle. Before 1914, the Pathe and Gaumont companies had enjoyed commanding positions throughout the world. After the war, these two giants all but ceased production, and French cinema became (by and large) the work of small, quasi-artisanal companies, perpetually struggling to reach markets outside their borders.
Yet French film could still attempt great things, as a World War I epic soon proved. Abel Gance solidified his reputation and revived the industry's hopes with "J'Accuse" (1919), the story of a frail poet who goes off to the front and comes home, shellshocked, to a village of widows and grieving mothers. For the last of the several accusations he hurls, the poet calls up the specters of the dead, who troop back from their graves by the thousands.
Gance first released this picture in a version that was as long as three normal features; in 1922, he brought out a shortened version, which ran only three hours and was altered in meaning. The original was generally understood as an outcry against the war. In the 1922 version, nationalist fervor resurfaced: Gance trimmed his battle sequences and added a victory parade.
If he was now leveling his accusation exclusively against German militarism, perhaps one reason was the rise of the German film industry. In cinema, at least, the war's losers had come out far ahead of the winners.
The preparation for this triumph was made in 1917, when the German supreme command initiated the consolidation of the film industry, so that cinema might be "put to work with the highest priority." The result was UFA, a company that did little for the war effort (despite such productions as "Anna Makes Artillery Shells") but that after the war grew to be the biggest and most technically advanced studio in the world.
Comedies, romances, fantasies, historical spectacles and chamber dramas poured out of UFA in the 1920's. But for the most part, World War I went unaddressed until 1927, when the studio fell into the hands of Alfred Hugenberg, an industrialist, publisher and early supporter of Hitler. Suddenly, UFA was bringing out Leo Lasko's two-part "The World War," a film that was deemed suitable for showing to a paramilitary organization.
It's not surprising, then, that the great German film about World War I, G. W. Pabst's "Westfront 1918," was made not for UFA but for the smaller, independent Nero-Film. The story of the lives and deaths of four representative German soldiers, "Westfront 1918" came out in 1930, the same year that Universal released Lewis Milestone's "All Quiet on the Western Front," and was favorably compared to its American competitor. Pabst had made a far tougher film -- so tough, in fact, that the most gruesome sequences are now missing from all prints.
On the Eastern Front, the war's effect on cinema was decisive, since there could have been no Soviet film without a Soviet Union, and no Soviet Union without the war. This interrelationship is plain to see in "The End of St. Petersburg" (1927), a film commissioned for the 10th anniversary of the Bolshevik revolution, in which Vsevolod Pudovkin makes his Great War scenes flash across the screen like blasts from a flamethrower.
The experience of disorientation that's key to Mr. Virilio's theory -- the soldier's sense of being hurtled through abrupt changes in landscape, as seen from strange and shifting viewpoints -- finds stunning formal expression here and in the works of the other great innovators of Soviet film. This visual violence is meant to stimulate the mind as much as the eye. To suggest the causes of the war -- a subject that filmmakers in other nations generally avoided -- Pudovkin contrasts his soldiers' doomed charge across no man's land with the frenzied rush of stock traders on the home front, as they shove their way toward war profits.
The great victor of World War I in cinema, as in all else, was, of course, the United States. Alone among the combatants, America emerged with its society and economy intact. One immediate consequence was Hollywood's domination of screens around the world. It took over the markets from which France had withdrawn; it hired away (or provided refuge to) the best talent that UFA developed. When you hear studio executives today claim that Hollywood succeeds simply by giving people what they want, maybe you'll want to think of these names: Ypres, Verdun, Passchendaele.
American filmmakers ventured into this territory even before the fighting was done. In 1917, D. W. Griffith went to the front, having received the encouragement of Lloyd George to make a picture for the war effort. (It says a lot about the state of the British film industry that this request should have gone to an American.) But the director of indelible Civil War battle scenes found that trench warfare wasn't what he'd expected. He retired to encampments in the English countryside, to make "Hearts of the World." It was not his best work. Charles Chaplin did better with his classic "Shoulder Arms" (1918), a picture about the victories that the Little Tramp dreams up for himself while slogging about in the trenches.
The full potential of World War I as a Hollywood subject did not become apparent until 1925, with the making of "The Big Parade," produced by Irving Thalberg and directed by King Vidor. The story of a bland young fool who is caught up in patriotic fervor, only to return home maimed and disillusioned but also deepened in spirit, the picture established John Gilbert as a star and gave the newly formed MGM studio its first big hit. With the coming of sound, however, the picture's fame was eclipsed by that of "All Quiet on the Western Front," which isn't a bad movie if you accept the conventions of a previous era's acting style and stick your fingers in your ears during Maxwell Anderson's speeches. But "The Big Parade" needs no apologies. Both exhilarating and sobering in the best Hollywood manner, it conveys meaning through the sheer scale that's possible in moviemaking. Panoramic spectacles evoke the awesome power of the war; the attractive but loosely drawn protagonist comes to represent the entire World War I generation.
Among the notable movies that followed was the winner of the first Academy Award for best motion picture: the 1927 Air Service drama "Wings," directed by William Wellman, a much-decorated flier in the war. Special mention should also be made of "The Dawn Patrol" (1930), the first of several World War I pictures by another flying director, Howard Hawks. Although he was later nominated for an Oscar for "Sergeant York" (1941), Hawks took particular pride in this earlier aviation feature because of its terse dialogue and restrained acting -- qualities that hadn't been much in evidence in the early talkies, and were surely appropriate to this subject.
But it was a French veteran of the air war who made what is surely the greatest World War I movie -- and he did it without filming a single battle scene. In "Grand Illusion" (1937), Jean Renoir brought out the meanings of World War I as no one else had, by dramatizing the journey of French soldiers through prisoner-of-war camps and out into the German countryside. In traversing a series of credible yet symbolic places (industrial barracks, a feudal castle, an idyllic farmhouse), the wonderfully individualized yet highly representative soldiers leave behind the class-bound Europe that the war had destroyed. They end their journey, by implication, on the verge of the next stage in destruction: World War II.
"Grand Illusion" proved to be a career high point for all of its actors, including Jean Gabin (who wore Renoir's own uniform as his costume). But for Erich von Stroheim, the film was an apotheosis. He had made his name in D. W. Griffith's Hollywood by impersonating the cold, brutal Hun, both on screen and off. Reprising that character in "Grand Illusion," he received from Renoir what he had never been able to give himself: nobility.
From here, the World War I movie underwent a steep falling off. World War II supplanted the First World War as a subject, and the few filmmakers who went back to the earlier period seemed to have lost touch with its meaning. (Witness the Technicolor flapdoodle that John Ford made out of "What Price Glory?" in 1952.) I think there's been only one first-rate film made about the First World War since "Grand Illusion": Stanley Kubrick's "Paths of Glory" in 1957.
Here you do see battle, as no soldier ever experienced it: smoothly, continuously, from above. This clarity of vision may be the film's most terrifying irony -- irony, of course, being the mode most appropriate to artworks about World War I, as Paul Fussell wrote in his study "The Great War and Modern Memory." For Kubrick, the war provided an opportunity to explore the gap between the way people plan (including the justifications they give for their decisions) and the way they behave, as planning meets circumstance. Only one area of life could be held immune from the tricks of happenstance: his own work. In "Paths of Glory," he gave us human disaster, impeccably realized.
Since then, a mere handful of films have returned to the war as their primary setting. Some have been grand (David Lean's "Lawrence of Arabia," 1962), some good (Bertrand Tavernier's "Life and Nothing But," 1989) and others neither (Peter Weir's 1981 "Gallipoli"). Maybe this drop-off in numbers and quality is to be expected. Sentimentalities about "the greatest generation" now seem to mark the horizon of our historical imagination.
But then, out of nowhere, comes "Time Regained" (1999), Raul Ruiz's meditation on Proust's "Remembrance of Things Past," and we once more feel the shock that L'Herbier experienced. Early in the film, at a moment set in the Belle Epoque, young Marcel watches a magic lantern show about chivalric adventures. Then, without transition, he encounters a soldier of World War I -- Robert de Saint-Loup -- who is gazing through an eyepiece. We see what Saint-Loup sees: black-and-white footage of a wounded horse, struggling in a trench.
These images are not suitable for you, says Saint-Loup. Too late. From chivalry and magic lantern shows to trench warfare and cinema: we've made the transition, and we live with it.

HEADLINE: YOUR HOME;
Windfalls In Tax and Water Bills

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO

 BODY:
FEW people would idly sit by if their banks failed to credit the interest due on savings accounts. And few people would hesitate to protest if items rung up by supermarket cashiers exceeded the correct sales prices.
As it turns out, however, owners of large residential properties in New York City -- including some co-op buildings -- may be losing thousands of dollars in unused or misapplied tax credits and inadvertent overpayments on water bills. 
 "There seems to be a significant amount of money out there in unused tax credits and water bill overpayments that owners of large buildings are just not aware they are entitled to," said Herb Rose, a Manhattan co-op consultant.
Mr. Rose emphasized that city officials are under no obligation to uncover unused tax credits and overpayments on water bills. Rather, he said, it is typically the property owner's responsibility to ensure that credits are received and that bills are not overpaid.
"In most cases, the reason money hasn't been returned is because the property owner has never made any effort to get it back," Mr. Rose said. He noted that the division of responsibility between a building's board and its managing agent may also explain why some money is not found.
He pointed out that while ferreting out unused credits and water bill overpayments requires the assistance of experts, the amount of money at stake can sometimes be stunning.
"The first board I referred out for this got a return of more than $700,000," he said. "They were flabbergasted."
Irwin Strauss, president of a Brooklyn real estate consulting firm bearing his name, is one of the specialists Mr. Rose was referring to.
"My strength is my ability to determine if anything is wrong with a building's property taxes," Mr. Strauss said. "The majority of my work is trying to find lost tax abatements and tax exemptions and then bringing that money back to the client."
Like other consultants who perform similar services, Mr. Strauss works on a contingency-fee basis; that is, clients pay him only if he is able to get them some money.
"Most of the time we work on a contingency of 25 to 33 percent of what we collect," Mr. Strauss said. "And most of the time, our clients were not even aware they had any money coming to them."
One of the most fertile fields for consultants like Mr. Strauss is the rather arcane area of J-51 tax abatements. Such abatements, he said, are granted by the city when the owner of a multiple dwelling performs certain repairs or capital improvements. For example, Mr. Strauss said, if a property owner -- including a co-op -- installs $100,000 worth of new windows, the property owner may be entitled to recoup 90 percent or more of the money spent in the form of tax abatements spread out over a period of 12 years or so.
There are times, however, when an abatement may legitimately be revoked by the city. For example, he said, if a property owner fails to pay all or a portion of the property taxes that are due on a building and the arrearage is carried on the city's books for more than a year, J-51 abatements can be revoked.
"You don't even have to have the entire tax bill outstanding to have your abatement revoked," he said.
At the same time, however, the abatement can be reinstated, in some cases retroactively, once the late taxes are paid.
"When the taxes are caught up, the city doesn't automatically reinstate the J-51 abatement," Mr. Strauss said. "It's up to the property owner to make sure it gets done."
And in some cases, he said, failure to do so can be a costly mistake.
"In a large building, a J-51 abatement can mean a lot of money," Mr. Strauss said. "I have two co-ops right now that are getting back six-figure tax credits."
Another area in which property owners may lose money without being aware of it involves tax credits due under the Senior Citizens Rent Increase Exemption Program -- commonly referred to as Scrie (pronounced scree). Under that program, Mr. Strauss said, elderly residents who meet certain age and income requirements (generally, those who are 62 or older and have yearly household incomes of less than $20,000) are exempt from rent increases. Any increases that the property owner would be entitled to, he said, are instead paid by the city in the form of property tax credits.
In many cases, however, property owners with tenants eligible for Scrie benefits lose track of the benefits they are entitled to while still foregoing rent increases for tenants who -- for one reason or another -- no longer participate in the Scrie program. Indeed, Mr. Strauss said, it is generally up to the property owner to ensure that eligible tenants reapply for benefits -- as required by law -- with each lease renewal.
"If the tenant doesn't file the renewal, the city doesn't issue the credit, and the landlord may never be aware of it," he said.
Another way property owners -- including co-op and condominium boards -- can lose money in their buildings is by overpaying for water and sewer use.
Gerald Hirsch, the owner of Gerald Hirsch Water Management, a consulting firm in Brooklyn, said property owners sometimes pay more than they should for water and sewage charges because of the different methods the city uses to calculate such charges.
Mr. Hirsch explained that traditionally water charges in the city have been calculated using the "frontage" method, which uses such factors as the size of the property, the number of units and the number of water-using fixtures to arrive at an annual charge for water and sewage use.
In recent years, however, the city has stepped up efforts to get all buildings on a metered billing basis and has allowed buildings that install meters to remain on frontage billing for a period of time.
In some cases, Mr. Hirsch said, buildings that have had meters installed are still being billed on a frontage basis even though it would be less expensive to switch to metered billing. At the same time, he said, there may be some buildings in which it would be more economical to stay on frontage billing for as long as possible.
"From a management perspective, it is useful to evaluate the most economical method of billing," Mr. Hirsch said.
Alan Rothschild, president of Vantage Group, a water cost management company in Monroe Township, N.J., agreed. "I have a building I'm working with now that has had a meter for five years and has paid $50,000 more for frontage charges than they would have paid if they were on metered billing," he said.
Mr. Rothschild said that in addition to scouring old water bills to determine whether a building owner is paying more than necessary for water and sewage charges, his company will also perform a physical survey of the building to identify existing water-related problems.
"The most common and expensive water-related problem is unreported toilet leaks," he said. "It may not seem like much, but in a large building a bunch of leaking toilets can end up costing a property owner tens of thousands of dollars every year."
