HEADLINE: A Walkway Filled With Words and Images of Connecticut's Past

BYLINE: By ALBERTA EISEMAN

 BODY:
THE crew of a whaling ship in New London harbor, circa 1907; a smiling young Algonquian man, portrayed in 1645; munitions workers during World War II; a Yankee peddler in his horse-drawn wagon; the legendary Charter Oak -- these are some of the images, well known or unfamiliar, chosen to tell the story of Connecticut in an exhibition mounted along the walkway between the Capitol and the Legislative Office Building in Hartford.
The 25 historical images, collectively entitled "Imagining Connecticut," set the scene for a group of interconnected programs designed to introduce the state's history to the thousands of residents and tourists who visit the two adjoining structures: the grand, gold-domed Victorian Capitol and the sleek office building dedicated in 1988. 
 "The whole story of Connecticut is not found anywhere else in the state, and this is one of our great public spaces," said Bruce Fraser, executive director of the Connecticut Humanities Council, which produced and financed the project with the support and assistance of the Joint Committee on Legislative Management.
"People come here to visit, to attend meetings, to lobby their representatives: little kids, seniors, casual visitors with little understanding of Connecticut and people who spend a great deal of time here and are intimately connected to the process. We wanted to reach them all, so we needed to set up a series of programs that would satisfy the varied audiences," he said.
Nothing was left to chance. To create "Imagining Connecticut," Mr. Fraser gathered together a panel of historians who hammered out the themes for the display.
"What essential 15 or 20 things do we want people to appreciate about our distinct past?" Mr. Fraser asked at their first meeting. "What images best capture these points and tell us who we are?"
And so the viewer is presented with an early painting of the three churches on New Haven's town green, a choice intended to emphasize the importance of the state's strict religious origins; a daguerreotype of workers at the Eli Terry Clock Factory, which pays homage to Connecticut's inventors and their key role in the industrial revolution. Mark Twain and his neighbor, Harriet Beecher Stowe, represent the state's cultural heritage; a portrait of James Mars -- a little known, but noteworthy former slave who led a movement to extend voting rights to African-Americans -- reminds visitors that the struggle for equal representation was long and hard, and that slavery was not abolished in the state until 1848.
The most ambitious component of the project, on view in the atrium of the Legislative Office Building, is an eight-panel, 500 square foot, permanent exhibition on the history of self-government in Connecticut, whose title, "An Orderly and Decent Government," is a quotation from the Fundamental Orders, drawn up in 1639 by early colonists.
"To mayntayne the peace and union for such a people there should be an orderly and decent Government established," wrote the doughty Puritans. They also proclaimed the radical ideas that the authority of government came from the "free consent" of those governed and that "representation," or letting the people choose their own leaders, was the way to make government work.
"Their handiwork," the exhibition states, "was the world's first document putting in practice the principles of self-government" -- in other words, the basis for Connecticut's claim to the title "Constitution State," an assertion some scholars find debatable.
Dense with pictures and text, the exhibition presents the history of the state in detail and shows the influence of the general assembly on it. Each panel is divided into three concurrent tracks. The upper third presents major trends and developments at the national and state level -- wars, migrations, economic and political upheavals -- and how they shaped the period under consideration. The middle track, "Searching for the Common Good," explores the major issues created by these forces, and how the legislature addressed them. At the bottom, "Making Self-government Work," traces the story of the legislature itself as it evolved over time, from a single legislative chamber to the complex institution of today, from a gathering of white, male property owners to the diverse House of Representatives and Senate of our time.
Unhurried visitors will be rewarded with dozens of intriguing episodes: the religious controversies of the 1740's, for example, as Anglicans, Quakers, Baptists and other groups entered the colony and pressured the General Assembly to recognize their religious practices; or, after statehood, the westward migration of thousands of the state's people in search of fertile land -- 750,000 men and women left Connecticut between the years 1760 and 1840; the exploits of the "privateers," privately owned vessels authorized by the state to attack British ships during the War of 1812, or the rise of the "Know-Nothing" party, which took control of the General Assembly in 1855 and quickly passed a tough anti-Irish, anti-Catholic program.
No effort is made to gloss over the less appealing aspects of Connecticut's heritage.
"What we worked hard on in this exhibition is trying to tell the truth," Mr. Fraser said.
History buffs and other visitors who want to learn more about a particular topic can turn to "History on Demand," an interactive video station located between the two exhibitions. The station offers 15 brief vignettes on such issues as the Fundamental Orders, the legend of the Charter Oak, the clash between Yankees and immigrants or the struggle of women to win the vote.
A handsome, short brochure on the history of the General Assembly and of the state is available as part of this multi-faceted program. Moreover, a collection of resource materials and teacher guides is being readied for fall distribution, so that tomorrow's voters can better understand the heritage of Connecticut.
The Capitol and the Legislative Office Building are open to the public Monday through Friday from 8 a.m. to 5:30 p.m. Tours of the two buildings are offered by the League of Women Voters at quarter after the hour from 9:15 a.m. to 2:15 p.m., free of charge. Tour information is available by calling (860) 240-0222.

LENGTH: 1942 words

HEADLINE: Safety and Zoning vs. Freedom of Religion

BYLINE: By ALICE SPARBERG ALEXIOU

DATELINE: NORTH AMITYVILLE

 BODY:
THEY have names like The Revelation Church of God in Christ, Ephesus Church and Living Waters Evangelistic. They are scattered about North Amityville like seeds sown by the wind. They range from structures originally built as houses of worship to storefronts to converted houses in residential areas.
Their numbers are increasing, with Town of Babylon officials estimating the total at about 40 in North Amityville, an unincorporated hamlet of about 16,000. They also exist in nearby Wyandanch. Wherever they are, the neighbors who wake up one morning to find that they are living next to a church often find it anything but a blessing. 
 Peter Casserly, Babylon's commissioner of planning and development, said that neighbors often called the town to complain of increased traffic and noise, often in the form of amplified music during religious services. Some churches stand for years in an uncompleted state. Living Waters Evangelistic, for example, at 335 North Albany Avenue, began construction in 1994. Today it consists of a steel skeleton surrounded by piles of plastic-covered cinderblock.
Having a church next door, said Milton Bond, president of the North Amityville Taxpayers Association, has a negative effect on property values, which residents and local officials are striving to boost as the community recovers from a crime wave that created havoc in the 1980's.
For the past four years, some residents have been working closely with the Town of Babylon to stem the tide through enforcement of zoning and fire codes. One church has been shut down and dozens of code citations have been issued.
But the churches have members, and some of them oppose the crackdown. And beyond the sensitivity of the attempt to regulate the exercise of religious beliefs, a racial overtone has crept into the debate, pitting some black congregations against white town officials.
"I don't think the town should have taken the position that they did," said the Rev. Carrie Wilson, whose New Life Christian Ministries is the only church to have been shut down for code violations. "There are at least 25 or 30 other churches in houses, and they didn't close them down! So why did they get an injunction for New Life Church?
"I asked Gil Hanse, the town's fire marshal, 'Can't you be compassionate enough to allow us to continue to worship here as we continue to work through the things we need in order to comply?' But he said he didn't think I could bring it up to code."
Mr. Hanse acknowledged that "it's a hard thing for us," and added: "It's such an emotional issue with people. They say to us, 'You can't go after churches.' "
But Mr. Bond insisted that "churches were not targeted. Code violations were."
As places of public assembly, churches fall under specific building and fire safety codes, which govern such subjects as emergency exits and electrical wiring. Mr. Casserly said that these little churches uniformly ignored the codes, posing a safety hazard.
"A house may hold 30 or 40 people," he said. "They tear out the interior walls and install pews. These are wood-frame houses with no sprinklers and only two means of egress. The carpet is not flame-resistant."
"Code enforcement, or lack thereof, is the greatest concern among homeowners in this community," Mr. Bond said. "Where there is space available, and zoning code allows it, churches should be built. And where there is not, they should not."
The debate over the churches comes in the context of a larger drive to clean up North Amityville, which has had a black community since before the Civil War but fell on hard times only in the last quarter of the 20th century.
In the early postwar years, North Amityville was a model community for America's emerging black middle class. Many black veterans of World War II settled here as an alternative to Levittown, which was segregated white.
"North Amityville was a social experiment," said Mr. Bond, the son of a World War II veteran and a North Amityville native. "And I was part of that social experiment."
Chuck Howlett, a social studies teacher at Amityville High School since 1977 and a scholar of North Amityville history, said that it was only in the late 1970's and early 80's that crime became a serious problem. The intersection of Great Neck Road and Albany Avenue, known as the Corner, became an open-air market for drug dealers and a mecca of the crack cocaine epidemic of the late 1980's.
The drug market enraged the community, Mr. Howlett said. "I remember students saying to me, 'This isn't us,' " he said. "It was a sore point. So the community fought back."
Residents formed grass-roots groups that worked closely with the Suffolk County Police Department to rid the hamlet of abandoned vehicles, crime and drugs. Their efforts, which were helped by federal financing, have paid off. Police spokesmen say crime has decreased significantly. The Corner now boasts a Rite-Aid drug store and a European-American Bank.
Frank Dell Accio, owner of Century 21 AA Realty in Lindenhurst, said home prices had increased recently in North Amityville and more homes were owner-occupied. And Robert Toussie, a Brooklyn developer, is scheduled to break ground next year for a 76-home subdivision near the intersection of Albany Avenue and Schleigel Boulevard. Houses in the new development will be priced at $300,000 to $400,000, double the average sale price of a North Amityville home, according to Mr. Dell Accio. Mr. Casserly said that five years ago such an investment in North Amityville was "unheard of."
As part of the cleanup campaign, the town also began stricter enforcement of building codes and included the little churches were included in the scrutiny.
Standing next to a lateral file in the planning office of Babylon's Town Hall, Mr. Casserly pulled open a drawer stuffed tight with files, all of which contained the paperwork on code violations for individual churches. Some of the recorded code violations go back as far as 1984.
At least 15 churches are now in violation in the North Amityville area, having ignored town summonses, Mr. Casserly said, with many more churches in various stages of getting their facilities up to code.
Shutting down a church is an arduous legal process that can take months, he said. "You actually need to witness the violations. You need affidavits," Mr. Casserly said. Often the town must pay overtime for a church to be inspected on a Sunday, because during the week nobody is there.
Ms. Wilson of New Life Christian Ministries, at 124 Albany Avenue, said she did not understand why the town acted.
"We are charged to serve," Ms. Wilson said. "It all started when God told me to build a house for him." The church, she said, is just trying to give homeless people a better quality of life.
"People didn't come in here with hats and dresses," she said, but they were coming in off the street, "and it was making a difference."
Ms. Wilson also operates six homeless shelters in North Amityville and Wyandanch. All are part of New Life Ministries, which she founded in 1988 with five other people.
She bought 124 Albany Avenue, which was a deli with a small house behind it, in October 1999. She soon converted it into a church, complete with facade and pews. She made the house in the back into another shelter.
Maxine Postal, the Suffolk County legislator whose district includes North Amityville, said that when the church opened, her office promptly received calls from neighbors.
"Carrie Wilson is very well known in the community," Ms. Postal said. For years, she said, residents have been upset about her shelters. Ms. Postal said that only two of Ms. Wilson's six shelters were in compliance with town building codes.
Since 1994, Suffolk County's Department of Social Services has contracted with New Life to provide shelter for the homeless. Dennis Nowak, a spokesman for the department, said that the county was not aware that Ms. Wilson's shelters had ever had code violations. County contracts stipulate that shelters must comply with town codes.
But Ms. Postal said the social services department turned a blind eye. "They obviously continue to pay people who are not in compliance," she said. "We've talked with social services. I think they just want to get the problem out of their hair."
Ms. Postal said that residents of Ms. Wilson's shelters had frequently called her office to complain about bad treatment, reporting that they were forced to surrender their food stamps, were not allowed to use the phone and were not given enough food.
Mr. Nowak said that these were old issues that were either unsubstantiated or have been resolved.
When Ms. Wilson opened her church on North Albany Avenue, Ms. Postal said, "this was the icing on the cake." According to Patricia Howlett, an attorney for the town, the church had "hundreds of violations." The town obtained an injunction against New Life in September, which enabled them to close the church down. The case is still in litigation.
Ms. Postal called Ms. Wilson a "poverty pimp."
"Carrie -- and this strikes everyone -- is covered in diamonds and gold," she said. "She drives a new Mercedes. She has had extensive work done on her house on Parkway Avenue in Amityville. I think all these things make people think she is ripping them off."
Ms. Postal, who is white and has represented the district since 1987, said that because Ms. Wilson was a pastor no one challenged her.
"We're working so hard to fix up North Amityville," Ms. Postal said. "And I'm fed up."
Ms. Wilson said her ministry had been part of the solution in North Amityville. "Before, there was a dog blight in the community, just drugs, prostitution and people hanging out," she said. "God wants us to clean up our own backyard."
Other pastors in North Amityville say they have a good relationship with the town. The Rev. Jimmy Jack of Freedom Chapel, at 641 Broadway, which was forced to tear down a wooden house that was used for offices and children's Sunday church services, said nevertheless that the town had been "patient and very cooperative."
Frank Alberti, one of six Babylon town lawyers, said that state courts expected local zoning boards to give greater deference to religious institutions than to commercial or residential owners. Therefore, Mr. Alberti said, the town tries to help churches get up to code as best they can.
Mr. Casserly said that the churches' problem often was inadequate financing. But in the last year, he said, perhaps because of the improved economy, about a dozen churches have come up with the money to bring themselves up to code.
St. Paul's Christian Tabernacle of America, at 589 Broadway in Amityville, is one of those churches that the town has, in Mr. Casserly's words, "nurtured along." The church broke ground in 1984, then ran out of money. For 10 years, the congregation, which numbers about 100, has been holding services in the foundation with tar paper on top.
"It's been a difficult history," said the Rev. Raymond Thompkins, St. Paul's pastor. "Banks don't like to lend churches money. And there are so many charlatans out there. One guy got our money and disappeared. He did the same to seven or eight other churches in Amityville, $37,000 from each church."
But St. Paul's now has its finances together. With loans from Fleet Bank and the United Mortgage Company, Mr. Thompkins hopes that St. Paul's will be finished by the end of the year.
"Over the years the town has been very good to us," he said. "As the Bible says, we are subject to the laws of the land. These churches must be constructed in the right way."

HEADLINE: In the Region /Connecticut;
$320 Million Gives State Universities a New Look

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON

 BODY:
ALMOST $320 million of construction is completed, under way or ready to begin at the four campuses of the Connecticut State University system as part of a five-year capital improvement program that is changing the look of the schools.
At Western Connecticut State University in Danbury, Thomas E. Carlone, the director of planning and engineering, said that the university had completed a $19 million library expansion and a $22 million, 425-bed residence hall. Planning is soon to begin, he said, for a $9 million student center. 
 "When I came to Connecticut 11 years ago, there was a tremendous amount of money being spent on prisons," Mr. Carlone said. "Then people started to say maybe we should spend money on the good kids rather than the bad kids. Today, our kids are benefiting from that redirection of funds."
At Eastern Connecticut State University in Willimantic, a new four-story library and a 3,500-square-foot admissions building are in use this semester, as is a new residential village that accommodates 440 students in apartments with common computer laboratories, study areas and exercise rooms.
At Central Connecticut State University in New Britain, a $5 million, 2,400-seat football stadium was dedicated last Saturday. Construction is nearing completion on its new 83,000-square-foot Vance Academic Center, the first new academic building there since 1973.
At Southern Connecticut State University in New Haven, a 600-car parking garage went up in just eight months. "We need about three more of them, but this is a start," said Robert G. Sheeley, Southern's associate dean for facilities planning and operations. "We have no place to go but up -- if we did only surface parking, we've have an all-asphalt campus."
University officials say the state plan should go further. Richard L. Judd, president of Central, said that he is still short about 800 beds in his residence halls, that he can no longer get most of the parts for the four circa-1922 boilers that heat the school, and that the smokestack has been deemed unsafe for anyone to climb inside for an inspection.
"If two of those boilers go down, the campus would have to close," Dr. Judd said. In addition, he said, he is short on staff space, with as many as three faculty members sharing 90-square-foot offices. Most schools try to provide at least 150 square feet per professor, he said. He also said he has no auditorium large enough for graduation ceremonies and other functions.
William J. Cibes Jr., the chancellor of the university system, which last year had 18,400 full-time and 7,800 part-time students, has asked the Connecticut Board of Higher Education to seek an additional $600 million, $120 million a year for five years. Such an appropriation from the state, he said, would allow the campuses to build new academic buildings, heating plants, libraries and athletic centers.
"Now that we are nearing the end of the first five years, we want to know what's going to happen next," Dr. Cibes said. Before the capital improvement project that got under way in the 1997-98 fiscal year, he said, it had been 20 years since there was any major construction on the four campuses. "This would basically bring the universities back to where they should have been," he said.
In 1995, the state appropriated almost $1 billion for construction and renovation at its major research and graduate university, the 17,800-student University of Connecticut at Storrs, which is separate from the state university system. Two years later, legislators turned their attention to the other components of the state's higher education system, allocating $320 million for the state universities, and $320 million more for the 12 two-year state community colleges.
Mayor Lucian J. Pawlak of New Britain said that the state universities bring a lot of attention to their cities. Central's Institute for Industrial Engineering and Technology, he said, complements the city's efforts to replace the large manufacturers that have left and attract smaller high-technology firms.
"It is a major asset -- on any given day there might be 300 or 400 people here training, and two or three companies looking to become members," Mr. Pawlak said. "It really does enrich our community."
Over the last few years, more new construction and renovation has taken place on the state university campuses than in the tenure of all but the most senior staff. "This work was long overdue," said Dr. Felton O. Best, a professor of philosophy, history and religious studies at Central who is head of the faculty senate. "When I came here in 1991 I though the university had some real potential, but it needed some work. Now morale on campus is improving because of all the construction."
Dennis A. Hannon, vice president for finance and administration at Eastern, said the construction had also offered an opportunity for innovation at the Willimantic campus. The nine-story residence hall on that campus will have its electric heating system removed and a new geothermal heating and cooling system installed.
WITH the construction of the new library at Eastern, the old library building has been renovated and turned into a student support services center. A 40,000-square-foot addition is to be built at the old library next year to bring together, for the first time, all the administrative offices.
At Western, Mr. Carlone said that some of the smaller projects have been the most noticed. About $4 million was spent on new lighting, a brick sidewalk, underground electric wires and other improvements on a new quadrangle at the Danbury campus.
"Even though that was not the largest project in terms of dollar value, it's probably had the biggest impact on student morale," Mr. Carlone said. "We've been able to clean up the campus a lot. The mayor and a lot of local folks have told me that the transition has just been miraculous."
Much of the work in the five-year plan for the four campuses remains to be completed. At Central, construction is to start next summer on a 1,000-car parking garage. An $11 million expansion and renovation of the student center is to begin soon after, as is a $20 million renovation of the current science building, where some of the equipment no longer meets safety standards.
Dr. Cibes, the chancellor, said he expected that his new proposal would face serious scrutiny and debate. He said that the state's yearly capital investment at the four state universities is about $2,740 per student, less than half what it spends at the University of Connecticut in Storrs. Even $600 million in new financing would bring spending at the state universities to only about 71 percent of what it is at UConn, he said. "We're very pleased that UConn got all that money, and we don't want to take anything away from UConn, we just want to get a fair share for our students," Dr. Cibes said.
The state universities have much larger combined enrollment than does UConn, he said. And the state universities are already seeing significant increases in students interested in enrolling, he added -- at Eastern, applications were up more than 40 percent this year.
The growing interest is due at least in part to the construction on the campuses, he said, though he acknowledged that in a good economy more people can afford higher education and that more jobs are demanding a four-year degree.
But whatever the reason, he said, the estimate is that enrollment at the state universities is going to increase about 23 percent over the next 12 years, and the schools must be ready for it.
Mr. Cibes's proposal would finance three projects in the fiscal year that begins next July 1: $12 million for new underground utilities at the Central campus in New Britain, $18 million for a new boiler plant at Southern in New Haven and $43 million for a new science center at Western in Danbury. His proposal includes a $46 million science building at Eastern in Willimantic and $54 million in renovations to the library at Southern in the fiscal year that begins July 1, 2002.
The following year would bring a $50 million fine arts center at Eastern, and $28 million of renovations to classrooms at Central. In 2004-05, the projects would include a $27 million fine arts center at Western and a $20 million classroom building at Central. The final year of his plan would include a $42 million student services building at Southern, a $47 million field house at Central and a $42 million field house at Eastern.
Dr. Judd of Central said the state should view the projects as an investment in its future. Studies of his alumni, he said, show that 95 percent of graduates stay in Connecticut and that 85 percent live in 30 towns surrounding New Britain.
"What that tells you is that when they go to school here, they go to work in Connecticut businesses, government agencies, and so forth," Dr. Judd said. "That clearly contributes to keeping the income levels high in the state, because we have a well-educated work force. If we're going to bring high-technology companies to Connecticut, we're going to need our kids to do it."

HEADLINE: Changing Fields (and Lawns and Gardens)

BYLINE: By ELISABETH GINSBURG

 BODY:
THE gardening bug is an insidious disease. Once stricken, some victims feel a compulsion to spend all their free time digging in the dirt and all their money buying plants and seeds. Others go even further and transform their working lives by entering the horticultural field.
John Holm, a former professional chef, is in the midst of such a career transformation. Born in Norway to a family that owned a restaurant, he was trained as a cook from an early age. Mr. Holm eventually immigrated to the United States and found work at Manhattan restaurants like La Grenouille and Restaurant 44. He also taught cooking at the French Culinary Institute and helped found a successful prepared-food business. 
 While a chef, Mr. Holm began tending a container garden on the terrace of his Brooklyn Heights apartment. Eventually he moved to a 2.5-acre lot in Bedford, N.Y., and began growing things on a larger scale. He applied to the New York Botanical Garden's School of Professional Horticulture, a two-year program that combines course work with hands-on training in the botanical garden itself. He expects to graduate in 2002 and start his own residential landscape design business.
Training that combines horticulture's intellectual and practical sides makes perfect sense to Mr. Holm, who has a high tolerance for the unglamorous and unpaid work in the botanical garden. "Because of my background in cooking," he said, "I am used to working hard and getting dirty." But "I feel a passion for this that I never did for cooking," he added. "I went into cooking because of my family. This I did for myself."
Five years ago, Mary Squires was a corporate attorney living on Long Island. Then she and her husband moved to Upper Saddle River, N.J. After finding out what it cost to hire landscapers, she decided to design her new property herself -- even though she had little experience with plants. "I started researching before I put anything in the ground," she said. Her interest increased, and after she had become a regular at her local retail nursery, a clerk suggested she take some horticulture courses at Bergen County College.
She began her studies with two courses, including Plant, Soil and Science, one of the toughest classes in the two-year degree program. Eventually she became immersed in horticulture education and went to school full time. She received a certificate in landscaping and ornamental horticulture (with honors), and went on to earn an associate's degree in applied science.
With her degrees in hand, Ms. Squires hung out her shingle as a plant consultant, installing and maintaining gardens, doing soil tests and educating her clients about environment-friendly methods of dealing with garden pests.
Ms. Squires specializes in interior "plantscaping," helping her clients with selection and placement of indoor plants. On each job she uses a light meter to gauge the amount of light in specific indoor locations, so people avoid dark corners full of dying plants. This educated approach is something new for her. "In my past life," she said, "I would just buy a plant and water it."
Ms. Squires still does a limited amount of legal work, "just to keep my hand in." In addition to running her own business, she hopes to gain greenhouse management experience by working part time for a local nursery within the next year.
Ms. Squires has no regrets about trading case management for pest management. "The time that I spend in gardens is infinitely more rewarding than the most demanding legal case," she said.
Kathleen Nelson of Gaylordsville, spends her spring, summer and fall days growing and selling perennials, a home-based business that she began when she made a midlife career change two decades ago. Busy outdoors during the growing season, she spends the winter writing copy for her plant catalog, doing bookkeeping and planning for the coming season.
Ms. Nelson grew up in "the swamps of northern Minnesota," collecting plants in the abundant wetlands. After obtaining a master's degree in zoology, she taught biology at Manhattan Community College. "I loved teaching," she said.
But in the mid-1970's, layoffs within the City University system left Ms. Nelson unemployed. A new job at the University of Bridgeport brought an unexpected bonus -- a husband. Ms. Nelson left teaching and entered professional horticulture at the age of 41, when she had her first child.
"The first couple of years, I didn't know what I was doing," she said. Her science background helped her learn quickly, and trial and error enabled her to make the decision to focus on retail rather than wholesale customers. Her business grew, bolstered by the surge in public interest in perennial plants around the time she started in the 1980's.
Ms. Nelson specializes in shade plants, noninvasive grasses and deer-resistant species, which also feature in her landscape designs for a small number of clients.
As her business has flourished, Ms. Nelson's environmental concerns have grown. A stint on a local wetlands commission changed her focus to promoting native plants. Though natives are enjoying something of a renaissance, she thinks they need more exposure.
Ms. Nelson's child is now a college junior, and the second career continues to evolve. Though she gives occasional lectures, she said that a return to the classroom would be "emotionally draining." Running her small nursery, said Ms. Nelson, is the perfect combination of physical and intellectual activity.
That combination also appeals to Laura Leach, who made the switch to horticulture after 15 years as a sales, marketing and development executive. Like Mr. Holm, Ms. Leach, who lives in Hastings, N.Y., is now a student in the New York Botanical Garden's horticulture school.
Ms. Leach, who was born in England, has a love of gardening that she inherited from her mother and grandmother. In high school she considered a horticultural career, but chose other options.
After leaving school, Ms. Leach re-encountered horticulture when she took a marketing job with Britain's National Trust, which oversees many historic structures and gardens. Later she worked as the director of development for the Welsh National Opera.
As with Ms. Nelson, marriage helped propel Ms. Leach into a new life. Several years ago, she and her husband immigrated to California, where she began part-time horticultural studies. The following year the couple moved to the East Coast. She had discovered the botanical garden's program on the Internet, and chose it because it provided "the opportunity to work alongside the best horticulturists." She praises the program's diversity. "Today I am preparing seeds for a seed exchange; yesterday I was climbing an oak tree to prune it," she said.
When she graduates in the spring of 2002, Ms. Leach may work as an administrator for a horticultural institution. She also plans to continue her education in landscape design. But she is also keeping her options open. "I am looking at where my skills are," she added.
Ms. Leach had advice for those considering a similar career change. "It's important to have some practical experience in the field first," she said, noting that the botanical garden program requires such hands-on work as a prerequisite for admission.
And, while a horticultural career may ultimately provide those who choose it with time to stop and smell the roses, she advised anyone approaching the field to be "realistic, not romantic."

HEADLINE: High-Tech but Low Grades

BYLINE: By GEORGE JAMES

 BODY:
WHAT does the rest of the country think of New Jersey as a high-tech state? Not much.
Prosperity New Jersey, a public-private nonprofit partnership created by the state to attract high-tech companies, commissioned the Opinion Research Corporation of Princeton to find out what industry people around the country considered a "hotbed" of high-tech and how New Jersey compared. 
 Stephen R. Sasala II, president and chief executive of Prosperity New Jersey, said that last year and early this year, researchers met with 80 executives from companies in Alexandria, Va., Chicago, Raleigh, N.C., and Austin, Tex.
Asked to list prerequisites for strong high-tech areas, the executives said: access to skilled employees; high quality of life for employees; good transportation, communications and office space; access to equity and capital; a business-friendly environment; education and research institutions; and a critical mass of complementary companies.
What were some hotbeds of techology?
The answers included Silicon Valley in California; Route 128 in the Boston area; Research Triangle Park in North Carolina; the Austin, Dallas and Plano area; and the District of Columbia and its suburbs in Virginia and Maryland. New Jersey received only one mention -- for its pharmaceutical industry.
When the executives were asked to name emerging areas, they mentioned Denver, Boulder, Colo., Chicago, Minneapolis-St. Paul, Salt Lake City. Oak Ridge, Tenn., and Detroit as well as the New York and Philadelphia "areas." But again, no New Jersey.
Just what "images, words and phrases" came to mind when they thought of New Jersey? Don't ask.
"Not high-tech," was one response, although AT&T, Bell Labs and Lucent were frequently mentioned.
Of course, they immediately thought of the New Jersey Turnpike, the Garden State Parkway and traffic circles. They saw New Jersey as a "drive-through state," a suburb of New York and Philadelphia. Newark International Airport did not impress them.
High unemployment, high crime and congestion were mentioned along with high cost of living, high taxes, dying towns, old businesses, refineries, swamps. They even used the word "smelly." The final indictment: "Can't pump your own gas."
When the researchers finally read them a fact sheet listing New Jersey's high-tech credentials and assets, everyone was flabbergasted, Mr. Sasala said.
"My initial thought, that New Jersey is boring, is wrong," said one person.
"What was remarkable," said Mr. Sasala, "was the feedback we got from these people after we shared the facts -- which by the way, nobody refuted."
Mr. Sasala added with a laugh, "We enhanced our credibility, because they said, 'You guys do an incredible job of keeping your light under a bushel.' "

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY & CO.;
From a Cellar, the State's Second-Largest Brewer

BYLINE: By ROBERT STRAUSS

DATELINE: CHERRY HILL

 BODY:
GENE MULLER smiled with a self-effacing grin.
"Yes, we're New Jersey's second-largest brewery," he said. "Second only to Anheuser-Busch. Those are the Bud people, you know." 
 Mr. Muller is the president and, as he calls himself, chief custodian of Flying Fish Brewing Company.
While Anheuser-Busch has its Clydesdale carriages and Super Bowl sponsorships, Flying Fish settles for some T-shirts and tours on Saturday afternoons.
If you want a Bud, you can probably find it anywhere from the World Trade Center to an alley in Calcutta. Looking for a Flying Fish? You had better be within a half-day's drive of Mr. Muller's eight clean steel vats, which back out onto a loading platform in a low-rise building at the edge of an industrial park here.
There are about two dozen breweries in New Jersey, mostly in the northern part of the state. All but Busch make fewer than 7,500 barrels of beer a year, which is what Flying Fish makes and which is, frankly, not much. It's why they call them microbreweries, or what Mr. Muller prefers to call a "craft brewery."
"That means you are trying to do a quality product without additives or preservatives and it really doesn't matter how big you are," he said. "Sam Adams, a craft brewery, does 1.2 million barrels a year, which is almost as much as, say, Beck's. I just want to do a good beer, make some money and have fun. Beer is, after all, a fun product."
Mr. Muller used to have fun making beer in his basement. For 15 years, he said, he was a home brewer while he worked as an advertising copywriter in Philadelphia. Then in 1995, he decided to go to a brewing school, the Siebel Institute in Chicago, where among his fellow students was a young member of a Colorado beer-making family, Brad Coors.
He came back to New Jersey -- Mr. Muller grew up in Pine Hill and now lives in Haddon Township -- and started figuring out what he would do with this newfound knowledge. He thought about opening a brewpub in Philadelphia, but there were already several there. So he sought financing and a home for his own brewery.
In the meantime, the Internet started burgeoning, so Mr. Muller started a Web site for Flying Fish.
"I called it the world's first virtual microbrewery," he said. "We were selling pint glasses and T-shirts and we didn't even have a building, much less a beer."
Slowly, his money, about $1 million for the start-up, came through and he found the right amount of space in the Cherry Hill Industrial Park, just behind the Garden State Discovery Museum. The beer started flowing in late 1996 and the kudos began pouring in not long afterward. Flying Fish has won medals at the World Beer Championships and is the only New Jersey brewery featured in the 1999 edition of the book "Best American Beers."
A tour of Flying Fish does not have the cachet of those Clydesdales and adjacent amusement parks at a Busch Gardens. You find one big open floor in the back of the industrial park where the whole operation takes place, with Mr. Muller, his four brewmasters and a handful of other employees.
Mr. Muller buys malted barley from the Midwest, Canada and Belgium. His hops come from several places: some from the Pacific Northwest, some from the Czech Republic and some from his own backyard. The water is not from some mountain spring, but from right here in Cherry Hill.
"Rolling Rock and Coors would make you believe the secret ingredient in beer is water," Mr. Muller said. "What you need is good water, not exotic water, and Cherry Hill water is just fine. But the big thing is the yeast."
Mr. Muller's yeast is recycled several times through the Flying Fish vats, in essence making each new beer a cousin of its predecessors.
Mr. Muller likes the idea of recycling his products. He give the barley left over from the initial fermentations to Don Emmons, one of the last dairy farmers in Burlington County, for his cows.
"So you get beer and chocolate milk from the same stuff around here," he said.
Flying Fish makes four styles of beer on a regular basis and a variety of seasonal beers. There is the Extra Pale Ale, a gold-colored beer that is the closest thing Flying Fish has to a pilsner. Then there is the dark Porter and the slightly lighter Belgian-style Abbey Dubbel, which is triple-fermented. Finally, there is the ESB, which stands for Extra Special Bitter, which Mr. Muller said goes well with strong foods like meats, cheeses and chocolate.
"That's what people learn when they come here, that beer and chocolate can go together," Mr. Muller said. "But seriously, some beers go better with some foods. You probably wouldn't want to drink a strong beer with a delicate fish. Although then there is pizza. And any beer goes well with that, don't you think?"
Flying Fish is experimenting with new special brews, one with Belgian sour cherries and another using Jack Daniels whiskey. If you find them, though, they will probably be in kegs behind your favorite bar, not in bottles.
"We sell everything we can make," said Mr. Muller, who distributes Flying Fish to New Jersey, eastern Pennsylvania, Maryland, Delaware and, surprisingly, Walt Disney World, where the owner of the Flying Fish restaurant uses the eponymous brew as its house beer.
"If you try to make more, then you may sacrifice quality or get too overextended," he said. "We want to grow, sure, but at a good pace.
"After all, we don't want to scare off Busch, as good as they are for the New Jersey economy."

HEADLINE: Lasers and Laptops Join Hard Hats At Construction Sites

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL

 BODY:
CONSTRUCTION company officials are among the first to admit that their industry had been slow to embrace technology. "It's been a dinosaur," according to Joseph Maguire, a vice president of Bovis Lend Lease in New York. But as if making up for lost time, the industry, which the Commerce Department estimates at more than $400 billion, has bestirred itself in recent years to embrace technology with an alacrity that, if it does not yet approach warp speed, at least takes construction out of the Mesozoic Era.
At construction sites ranging from the Millennium Partners hotel and apartment building at the Battery to AvalonBay's residential tower in New Rochelle, project managers and architects find laptop computers and digital cameras as necessary as hard hats. Crane operators rely on computer screens and on software that programs their every move, and contractors make use of e-mail and digital images to seek advice on solving problems. 
 Even the familiar level, used by generations of plumbers, carpenters and do-it-yourselfers, has undergone a high-tech makeover, its liquid bubbles replaced by pulsating bands of red light that snake around walls and floors to determine whether the construction work is the way it should be.
The main reasons for the rapid embrace of technology have been the power, speed and ubiquity of the computer and the advent of the Internet as well as affordable and improved construction software.
The upshot is that it is a rare major construction company whose job sites or home offices are not aswarm with laptops, digital cameras and scanners, as well as hand-held devices that connect to the Internet and others that can double as phones and two-way radios and are able to send and receive e-mail.
Using the Internet, construction companies submit bids, order material, schedule deliveries and hire workers. Tishman Construction Corporation, a pioneer in applying technology, solicits resumes on its Web site. "The people you're hiring these days expect you to have the technological tools," said Edward J. Cettina, a Tishman first vice president.
Those tools benefit more than builders. Many construction companies photograph their job sites at regular intervals to judge for themselves the state of a project and also to let owners or subcontractors follow the progress.
On the site of the joint-use 40-story Ritz-Carlton Hotel and apartment building going up at the southern end of Battery Park City, Bill Shaughnessy, the Bovis project manager, calls up photos on his laptop, taken from a camera atop a building across the street, of not only the building but also the job site trailer in which he and a visitor are talking.
And the same Bovis Web site can also call up photos of the other projects it is doing for Millennium -- two each in Boston and Washington and one each in San Francisco and Miami. The images "come into our main office lobby over telephone lines, and six monitors show the progress of the various construction sites," said Matthew Hall, a Millennium spokesman. "The photos are very valuable to owners and construction managers, who can keep up to date on their progress. But they're also linked to our Web site and sent to our sales office uptown to show to prospective buyers."
Electronic gear now shows up throughout the construction industry. "Only a few years ago companies used pens and calculators for estimating a project," said Colin Parkes, director of technical services for Bovis Lend Lease. "Today we have computer-aided estimating systems, scheduling systems, financial accounting systems and project control systems. They're not only quicker and more accurate, they let you look at different scenarios. Today our systems bridge the world."
The main thrust of the high-tech gadgetry is to enable project teams on job sites and at corporate headquarters to have immediate access to one another, as well as to architects, designers and engineers who may be hundreds, even thousands, of miles away.
With the help of computer-aided design, architects and engineers increasingly produce plans, drawings and other construction documents on computers. Those documents can be uploaded to the construction company's Web site and from there downloaded into individual computers -- including the computers of clients and subcontractors.
Changes that in the past would have required days of face-to-face meetings to sort out can now be approved in hours. And the e-mails authorizing changes provide an automatic paper trail, buttressed in many cases by the digital photos that document projects in various stages of construction.
DOCUMENTS can also be created by architects and engineers to analyze what Mark P. Job, the director of the Tishman Technologies Corporation, terms what-if scenarios "that study the effects of alternative design, materials and manpower with greater speed and precision than before the use of digital media."
Many contractors say that speed and precision are more vital to their industry than ever.
"We used to denominate everything in dollars," said Thomas C. Leppert, the chief executive of Turner Construction, speaking of the industry generally. "Now we denominate it in time." And access to people and information are the keys.
When the F. J. Sciame Construction Company of Manhattan was building a foundation in Rockland County last year for Columbia University's Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory, the project ran into the problem of how to bridge a rock formation.
"I e-mailed a digital photo of the problem to our engineers in New York and asked how to solve it, and we had an answer within an hour and a half," said Robert D. Trostle, the project manager. "In the past we would have had to send the photo back to the office, the engineers would have had to see it and generate a solution, then fax it back to us. This way, we saved two days."
In construction these days, a lot can be done in just two days. Turner Construction, for example, is building 409 apartments in New Rochelle for AvalonBay Communities, a real estate investment trust based in Alexandria, Va., at what not long ago would have been breakneck speed.
"Our cycle for building the floors is to place concrete on the slab in the morning and at the end of the same day set the columns on top of the concrete for the next floor," said Peter J. Davoren, the Turner senior vice president in charge of construction in the New York area as well as in Philadelphia and Pittsburgh. "At the end of the second day, we're getting the slab ready for the next major pour, and the following day we place concrete in the slab and repeat the entire cycle."
Since a digital camera mounted on a nearby building takes photos of the site every 15 minutes and then downloads them onto the Internet, Mr. Davoren can check the progress in New Rochelle or on most of his other projects.
When A. J. McNulty & Company of Maspeth, Queens, was awarded the job last year of cladding the 14-story Embassy Suites hotel in Battery Park City with brick-faced precast panels, it rolled up to the site with a massive crane capable of lifting as much as 440 tons. At its outer limits, the machine's tower, or boom, stands 207 feet tall and holds a protecting arm, or jib, that is 299 feet long. Taking up a four-month residence at one side of the building, the crane proceeded to lift panels as wide as 30 feet and as heavy as 15 tons clear over the 140-foot high hotel.
"Before, we would have had to place the crane on each side of the building in order to clad it completely," said Larry Weiss, president of McNulty and of its affiliated company, Cranes Inc., a rental company. "This time we were able to clad three sides of it from the same location; then we brought in a smaller crane to do the fourth side."
The huge crane used at the Embassy Suites, like almost all cranes built in the past few years, has an instrument panel that somewhat resembles that of a jet plane. Its built-in computer system monitors the load to be picked up, the radius in which the load will be taken and the pressure that will be exerted by the crane and its load. If the load approaches 80 percent of the crane's capacity, the crane emits both a visual and audible warning signal, then shuts down as soon as it reaches the 80 percent mark.
"Not long ago licensed professional engineers had to calculate the loads themselves before they could secure the permit for using the crane," Mr. Weiss said. "Now they can prepare a drawing and submit the computer's calculations to the city's buildings department for the permit."
Other recently upgraded tools used in construction include the surveyors' instrument, which sends out an infrared beam to an object; the beam is reflected back and the distance is calculated and displayed electronically. The data can be downloaded directly into a computer, which can create a finished drawing to be printed out or e-mailed.
"The surveyor's instrument, which includes a theodolite and an electronic distance measuring device, eliminates the need to measure angles and distances separately," said Robert R. Prescott, the president of the New York State Association of Professional Land Surveyors. "The profession has gone from being extremely labor intensive to being able to focus more precisely on the analysis of the measurements being taken."
Thomas Piciocco, a partner in the Manhattan surveying firm of Earl B. Lovell-S. P. Belcher, said that while the surveyor's instrument can measure distances up to 300 feet, "buildings are too close for me to use it in Manhattan."
Even the familiar level, used by generations of plumbers, carpenters and do-it-yourselfers, has undergone a high-tech makeover. Looking like a cross between a warning light at a rural railroad crossing and strobe lights at a late night disco, the electronic level can be set at any height to emit a band of red light around a room at the push of a button.
"It can be placed on a tripod or any flat surface, and it doesn't take anyone to operate it when it's set up," said Ron Rudolph, a former carpenter and now the project executive for Turner Construction's project to expand the San Diego Convention Center. "It's also much more accurate than the earlier levels, and it can be used by most of the trades."
THE same device can also be used outdoors when preparing sites for construction. Small electronic receivers placed on earth-leveling grading machines zero in on the laser beam, Mr. Rudolph said, and automatically adjust the machine's blade so that it prepares the surface at the predetermined grade.
Construction company executives stress that for all the technological advances, the most important cog in the construction process remains the plumbers, carpenters, steamfitters, electricians and many other tradesmen who do the actual work.
Still, no construction company is likely to forsake the technology that enables the electronic transmission of architectural plans and drawings, that enables work orders to be changed easily and quickly, that processes payrolls and estimates the number of workers and days needed on a project and that does away with layers of paperwork and administration.
"Before all this technology, it required more people to administer projects," said Scott A. Silverman, director of management information systems for Slattery Skanska. "Then, the administrators also put together invoices out in the field. Now they send the amount of work done that day to accountants who create invoices automatically."
Tishman has not done away with its 229-page construction manual, with information on everything from budgeting and estimating to scheduling, purchasing and site safety, but the manual is now available on a CD-ROM as well as online. And Tishman's project schedules for its many contractors are also online.
Two years ago, Clive Chan, Tishman's director of scheduling, sent e-mails with attached drawings and updated schedules to everyone in the company. But by last year he was posting them on the Internet -- in this case, an "extranet," a private network. This enables project-related drawings and documents to be stored online for access to the level of information determined by a user's password.
The Internet is also coming to the rescue of the "punch list" -- constructionspeak for the requisite final check. "It's a tedious job to do a punch list accurately," said Mitchell Solomon, chief executive of the HRH Construction Corporation. "It can easily take a few months to go through a building systematically, because there are thousands of items to check. That makes it easy to overlook something like a missing wall plate or a gouge in a Sheetrock wall."
For that reason HRH put together its own system of listing everything to be checked for each job. "Once the information is loaded," Mr. Solomon said, "you can view all the physical characteristics of a building by floor, by apartment, even by contractor." And because the computerized punch list records the dates that problems were discovered and remedied, he added, "You have a record without having to scramble through a paper blizzard."
Economic pressures have played a part in inducing both contractors and the subcontractors who do much of the specialized work on construction sites to embrace new technology.
"If we had stayed with the usual methods, we wouldn't have survived," said Donald G. Romano, the chief executive of Heritage Air Systems of Deer Park, N.Y., a contractor and manufacturer of heating and air conditioning systems. Heritage worked on the Rose Center for Earth and Space at the American Museum of Natural History and has been at work about 14 months now on the 45-story Bear Stearns headquarters under construction in midtown Manhattan.
Those "usual methods" had some 15 to 18 employees cutting sheet metal with hand tools into patterns according to consulting engineers' specifications. These days, the specifications are put into a computer, then downloaded into Heritage's manufacturing plant, where the information is transferred by fiber optics into four cutting machines, operated by one person each, that automatically cut the material to size.
"It has increased our efficiency dramatically," Mr. Romano said. And in an industry where in the past as much as 30 percent of the workday was estimated to have been spent waiting around for everything from approved design changes to delivery of construction materials, increased efficiency can make a huge difference.
TO stay in touch on the job, Heritage project managers carry palmtop computers and two-way radios, and its other employees also carry the two-way radios. The company also keeps track of its 26 construction and service trucks using the Global Positioning System -- a technology also used to establish the position of boats, airplanes and even adventurers who have lost their way. By punching up a map in the office, Mr. Romano said, the system can be used to show the exact location of every vehicle, so a truck stuck in traffic jams can possibly be diverted to other routes or another vehicle can be dispatched in its place.
But hardly anyone considers high tech the end-all, be-all for construction. "The online project people would have you think you can do it all on the computers," Mr. Solomon of HRH Construction said, "but it's more complicated than that."
Even those huge cranes that seem right out of the space age have their limitations. When the same crane used on the Embassy Suites project worked earlier this year at the New York Public Library on Fifth Avenue, where a four-story building is being added within a courtyard, it easily lifted the 40-ton steel beams over the courtyard walls.
But because the crane operator could not see the other side and even though he had telephone communication with others on the project team who could have directed him, the possibility of a disruption in voice contact resulted in the use of one of the oldest forms of communication known to mankind -- hand signals.

HEADLINE: PRIVATE SECTOR;
Even His Souffles Can't Relax

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH

 BODY:
In the summer of 1999, George David and his 50-foot sailboat, Idler, led a United States team in competition for the Admiral's Cup. He expected to win. He came in third in his class.
Was he mad? Distraught? Disheartened, at least? "I was disappointed," was as far as Mr. David would go. 
 Emotional outbursts are just not part of George David's behavioral repertoire. Take his reaction to General Electric's John F. Welch Jr. Just as United Technologies, the company Mr. David has headed since 1994, was about to announce a merger with Honeywell International, Mr. Welch, the chairman of G. E., topped Mr. David's $40 billion offer by $5 billion. Months of planning, of due diligence, of negotiations, went down the drain.
So, when Mr. David ran into Mr. Welch in Florida a few days later, did the sparks fly? "He acted totally professional," Mr. Welch recalled. "I like the guy, and I think he likes me."
Here is Mr. David's take on it: "I'm not sore. Jack and I are voracious competitors but we have an easy relationship." But, with a twinkle in his eye, he added, "It was nice of Mr. Welch to validate our business judgment and to overpay."
It was vintage George David: calm, controlled, competitive, but willing to accept defeat -- all while probably negotiating another deal. "We have 50 people working on mergers full time, and we probably have $3 billion to $4 billion in deals in various stages," he said.
United Technologies is doing fine on its own for now. It has reported increased earnings for 28 consecutive quarters, it is a market leader in most of its businesses, and its stock has steadily risen during Mr. David's six-year tenure.
Still, losing Honeywell was a blow. It would have doubled United Technologies' size, and given it the huge market capitalization that investors favor. And, it would have created an aerospace business that could have given G. E. some truly heavy competition. "We would have trumped G. E.'s ace," Mr. David said.
So, it was a setback, and a bad one. But at 58, Mr. David has managed to turn more than one apparent loss into a victory.
He was an executive with Otis Elevator when United Technologies took over that company in 1976, and he had expected to lose his job. "I was overtitled, overpaid and underexperienced," he said. Nonetheless, Mr. David rose to become United Technologies' president in 1992, and chief executive two years later.
It was no sinecure. Back then, United Technologies was a laggard by almost every measure. So Mr. David soon began the first of several restructurings, divesting ancillary businesses and slashing thousands of jobs. He pushed United Technologies into more global markets, dismantled its cumbersome headquarters staff and decentralized many management functions.
"He understood every facet of the business, from international currencies to complex technologies to the need to hire local managers abroad," said Alexander M. Haig Jr., who was president of United Technologies before becoming President Reagan's secretary of state in 1981.
Mr. David showed little emotion throughout the bloodletting, a fact that garnered him a reputation for coldness. But those who know him well say the coldness is a facade. "He dislikes all the trappings of false warmth," said Hubert Faure, a former Otis Elevator president who was Mr. David's first boss. "He shows his compassion in deeds, not words."
During that first round of downsizings, Mr. David instituted a program for paying dismissed employees to return to school. It has since expanded into a company-wide benefit. United Technologies pays tuition for employees, and gives them company stock if they graduate.
"His strong social conscience is almost unique among C.E.O.'s," said C. Fred Bergsten, director of the Institute for International Economics, a Washington research concern. Mr. David's simple explanation: "I'm an education nut."
Mr. David's colleagues say he is constantly asking questions and sopping up answers. There are no hierarchical rules about who gets listened to. One example: Many of United Technologies' quality control systems are the brainchild of a Japanese manager Mr. David persuaded to move to Connecticut to fix the company's processes.
"He welcomes disagreement, he welcomes debate and he makes sure no one is afraid to speak up," said Martin Lipton, a partner with the law firm of Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz and Mr. David's legal adviser on acquisitions.
He is the same way about personal hobbies. "He's a sponge for the science involved in sailing," said Thomas A. Whidden, president of North Marine Group and an occasional sailing partner of Mr. David's. "There's no question he's in charge on that boat, but he listens to all the people around him."
The love for learning is rooted in Mr. David's childhood. His father, a history professor, was 58 years old when he was born. "You don't chuck baseballs with a dad that age," Mr. David said. "Ours was an intellectual household."
TILL, Mr. David was anything but a pure intellectual in his younger days. As a physics and chemistry major at Harvard University, he was more interested in his motorcycle than his studies, and his grades showed it. After his second year he took a year's leave -- at Harvard's request -- and worked as a technical writer in New York City. He came back, and aced the last two years. He went on to get an M.B.A. from the University of Virginia's Darden School.
Mr. David, by then married to his high school sweetheart Barbara Osborn -- they were divorced in 1997 and have three children -- joined the Boston Consulting Group. One of his first clients was Otis Elevator; Mr. Faure hired him.
Somehow, Mr. David, who lives in West Hartford, Conn., and has a condominium in Vermont, finds time to sail, ski and cook -- a favorite way of entertaining friends. But plain, ordinary relaxing is not Mr. David's forte. Earlier this year he cracked five ribs when he went over a hidden rock on a particularly difficult ski slope. Cruising rather than competing in his sailboat? "Boring," is his response.
He even finds a way to inject frissons into cooking. "I like to make souffles," he said. But doesn't he know that fallen souffles plague even the finest cooks? He gives the expected answer: "I like the challenge."

SECTION: Section 14NJ; Page 6; Column 2; New Jersey Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1304 words

HEADLINE: COMMUNITIES;
Been Up So Long It Looks Like Down

BYLINE: By GEORGE JAMES

DATELINE: MILLBURN

 BODY:
Two empty stores loom like bookends at either end of town. Sandwiched between the two properties -- where a Saks and a Marsh jewelers once sold costly clothing and trinkets -- are eight vacant storefronts along a one-block stretch of downtown.
"Millburn-Short Hills is one of the most affluent communities in the country," said Steve Suskauer, a longtime merchant in this Essex County community where Wall Street executives and other professionals think little of putting down $3 million for a home. 
 The gaps along the main commercial street -- like spaces in the mouth of a Halloween pumpkin -- have led many residents to question why one of the wealthiest towns in a state with the second-highest per capita income in the country after Connecticut gives an after-the gold rush appearance rather than one of a tony town putting on its best face during a period of enormous economic prosperity.
On most weekend afternoons in downtown Summit, just to the west, shoppers can barely find a seat at Starbucks; drivers have to thread their way through the upscale shopping district a few times before finding a parking space.
In South Jersey, there are towns like Haddonfield, a borough with a mix of Victorians and many older homes, landscaped lawns and historic buildings, which advertises its downtown as place with "shopping the way it used to be."
And Maplewood, Millburn's more down-to-earth neighbor to the east, also has a thriving downtown.
But in Millburn, with a vacancy rate of more than 5 percent, the highest in five years, the overall effect in the compact business district is not good.
"For people driving through the community," said Mr. Suskauer, owner of David Gary Ltd., a fine arts shop, and president of the Downtown Millburn Development Alliance, "seeing some stores empty three years or more on one particular corner creates a poor image."
Where some see vacancies -- and an odd abundance of hair and nail salons and ice cream parlors -- Mayor Elaine Becker sees the "perception" of a troubled downtown. "I think that the town is thriving quite well," Ms. Becker added.
Perhaps her sense of well-being owes mainly to the Mall at Short Hills -- with a vast array of upscale shops and department stores -- which is a sure cure for any town in need of property tax revenue.
To some degree, the vacancies revive memories of the early 1990's, when the newly opened mall drained business and pockmarked the commercial district with empty storefronts. Lord & Taylor a longtime presence on Millburn Avenue, the main business thoroughfare, relocated to another nearby mall in Livingston, and there were almost two dozen vacancies downtown, Mr. Suskauer recalled.
But in 1992, merchants in a six-block area of downtown Millburn created a special improvement district, taxing businesses within the zone to finance improvements and services.
As a result, by 1995 the vacancy rate had dropped off to about 4 percent. Business continued to pick up as the district, known as Downtown Millburn Development Alliance, sought out new business. On the former Lord & Taylor property, for instance, a Fresh Fields Whole Foods Market opened, as well as a pharmacy and a home-furnishings store that subsequently pulled out.
But the vacancy rate downtown, which has 173 retailers, is back to more than 5 percent. About nine stores, including S. Marsh & Sons Jewelers, have gone empty. Marsh, in town since 1971, was taken over in recent years by Fortunoff, which closed the store earlier this year.
On a nine-acre site in the Short Hills section of Millburn Avenue -- outside the improvement district -- the former Saks has been vacant since the store relocated to the mall. The building is actually in neighboring Springfield, though the entrance is in Short Hills. Now it is a highly visible eyesore, and plans for a supermarket there have been in litigation for years because the towns say the added traffic would be a nuisance.
But the most noticeable vacancies -- 8 of 18 stores in a one-block stretch -- can be seen along Millburn Avenue between Main Street and Lackawanna Plaza, 6 of which are owned by Ramon Tublitz, a principal in Scotland Associates, a realty company in South Orange, and two by Jafir Tabib, a local merchant. One of the stores owned by Mr. Tabib and one owned by Mr. Tublitz are currently under lease.
Mr. Suskauer noted that the six properties owned by Mr. Tublitz have been vacant on and off for six years, though Carrie Lemerman, the executive director of the Chamber of Commerce, said she thought the vacancies went back as far 10 years.
Dean Shonts, who owns the Sneaker Factory on Millburn Avenue, echoed others in saying that Mr. Tublitz discouraged tenants from coming and, in other instances, from staying.
Mr. Shonts said that for 16 years he had leased one of the now-vacant stores before moving across the street 5 years ago. "He wanted me to move to one of his other stores and wanted to double my rent, which means I'd be paying twice what I am here," said Mr. Shonts. "He wasn't realistic at all. That's one of the reasons his stores have been empty."
In September 1999, another merchant here, Harold L. Rosen, who operated H. L. Rosen Gift Shop -- moved a property owned by Mr. Tublitz at Millburn Avenue and Lackawanna Place, where he had done business for 12 years. Mr. Rosen, who is 72, said he wanted a two-year lease, as he had negotiated in the past, because he was considering retirement. But he said Mr. Tublitz insisted on a five-year lease with a sizable rent increase. Mr. Rosen shut his doors.
"He's had a number of realtors who have represented him, people that specialize in retail space," Ms. Lemerman of the Chamber of Commerce said. "My understanding is that there's been a lot of interest in the properties over the years but when it comes time to doing the deal, it doesn't get done."
But Michael Mullen, a lawyer from Morristown who represents Scotland Associates, said many prospective tenants had inquired about the stores but few had made serious offers, possibly because they were concerned about competition from the mall and the strong downtown districts in surrounding towns.
"There are very real market forces driving this," Mr. Mullen said. "It's not a question of disinterest or a lack of commitment."
He also took issue with the less-than-generous descriptions of Mr. Tublitz offered by some local merchants. "My impression," he said, "is that the landlord is a lot more flexible and perhaps more compassionate than whatever the public persona or reputation might be in respect to tenants."
Representatives from the township, the business alliance and the chamber have met with Mr. Tublitz's representatives to express their concerns and offer assistance, but the vacancies persist. Mayor Becker, for one, said she met with Mr. Tublitz's lawyer several years ago, and as she put it, the meeting was "helpful."
"Some businesses did come in," Mayor Becker said. "Some were not successful. Unfortunately, they came and went. If there is a real problem there, I am not aware of what it is."
Still, officials remain optimistic about the future of the downtown here. Mr. Suskauer noted that the Marsh property was bought almost immediately after it closed by a Millburn developer, Pinnacle Communities, which was seeking planning board approval to open a retail and office complex.
Beth Peterson, executive director of Downtown New Jersey, a nonprofit organization in Summit that helps commercial business districts, said Millburn should be concerned about its vacancy rate, though it should be able to resolve the problem, "considering the underlying strength of the Millburn demographics."
"My basic thought," said Ms. Peterson, "is that the problem didn't get there overnight and it won't be solved overnight."
