HEADLINE: DEVELOPMENT;
Nets, Mall or Sprawl?

BYLINE: By JOHN SULLIVAN

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
At a time when politicians are lining up to condemn sprawl and taxpayers are voting to spend millions of dollars to buy open land just ahead of developers with their front-end loaders, the last measure expected to pass through State Legislature was a bill easing the way for commercial development.
But that is what environmentalists are calling a measure approved last week by the Senate Economic Growth, Agriculture and Tourism Committee last week. The bill, which would provide public funds for projects like megamalls and amusement parks, is more conducive to sprawl than any measure the Legislature has seen in 10 years, said Jeff Tittle, executive director of the New Jersey Sierra Club. 
 Unlike most existing development laws, the bill -- which would use money from the state general fund to finance roads and utilities in new projects -- is not intended for the inner cities. Instead, it would allow any local government to apply for the funds on behalf of a developer.
As Mr. Tittle sees it, the bill will subsidize the development of huge new shopping centers in suburban and rural areas, and will draw business from the cities.
"This is going to promote sprawl and overdevelopment," he said. "This is pure subsidy. It is nothing more than corporate welfare at taxpayer expense."
But backers of the bill contend the environmental groups are overstating the intention and the power of the proposed legislation. Senator Joseph M. Kyrillos Jr., a Republican of Middletown a co-sponsor of the measure, said it would rarely be used, and then only for large regional projects.
Mr. Kyrillos said he proposed the law after meeting with representatives of the YankeeNets Corporation, which is trying to build an arena for the New Jersey Nets in the northern part of the state.
Although a spokesman for the YankeeNets Corporation said the company was not supporting the bill, Mr. Kyrillos said this type of public financing was needed for the project. And he predicted the Nets arena project would be the main reason legislators would support the measure.
"This is not going to happen very often because the threshold is so high," he said. "This is not for malls, it is for large-scale regional destination projects."
The bill has a long way to go before it becomes law, something the environmental groups insist is unlikely. It must first pass the Senate appropriations committee, then get through the Assembly and the Senate. A spokeswoman for Governor Whitman said she had not yet reviewed the measure.
According to the terms of the bill, developers have to invest at least $100 million to qualify for the state financing. If the local municipality and the state treasurer approve the project, state money can be used to pay for "infrastructure improvements" for the project.
However, the type of improvements seem somewhat uncertain; the bill says the improvements include roads and utilities. But while the bill says those are possible uses, it also says permitted uses of the money shall include, but not be limited to, roads and utilities.
The amount of financing would be based on the sales taxes the project was expected to generate. Environmental groups, including the Sierra Club and the New Jersey Public Interest Research Group, have said the bill would benefit large-scale developments like the Meadowlands Mills development in Carlstadt.
The Meadowlands project, at an estimated cost of nearly $1 billion, would include a shopping mall, light industrial development and a hotel near the Meadowlands sports complex. Environmentalists have opposed the project because of its possible effect on wetlands, and the regional office of the Environmental Protection Agency has recommended rejecting permits for several alternative plans.
But David Donofrio, a spokesman for the Mills Corporation of Arlington, Va., said his company supported the bill, which he noted could help several proposed developments.
Indeed, supporters of the legislation have pointed to other projects they say it would benefit. State Senator Robert W. Singer, a Republican of Jackson, said the Six Flags Great Adventure amusement park, which is in his district, has been debating whether to expand to year-round operations, and that the measure could help spur the company to make the investment.
Mr. Singer proposed similar legislation two years ago, but that bill was defeated.
"These are major projects, and corporations are going to decide whether to come to New Jersey or go somewhere else," he said. "They are not going to invest $100 million without the infrastructure to support it."
While a spokesman for Six Flags Inc., Brent Gooden, said the company had no involvement with the bill, he added, "We do indeed take into account the state and local support as it pertains to capital expansion."
State Senator Robert E. Schluter, a Republican from Flemington, cast the sole Economic Growth committee vote against the bill, saying it was unwise for the state to subsidize projects outside economically distressed areas because it would promote unneeded building and because it would take business from existing companies.
"The state is going to lose money, and there are going to be dislocations in terms of other businesses," Mr. Schluter said.
While the state has an interest in supporting projects that help inner cities or poor rural areas, he said that developments in other places should "be a market situation where the laws of supply and demand apply."
Dr. Joseph J. Seneca, an economics professor at Rutgers who is chairman of the governor's Council of Economic Advisors, said that New Jersey had already made a considerable effort to attract business, including several bills in the last few years specifically aimed at high-tech companies.
He said the incentives are best used to attract companies that would otherwise move out of the area, rather than those that would simply move within the state. He said regional moves were usually the most difficult for politicians because economically it mades little difference whether a business is on one side of a state border or another. Politically, however, the cost can be enormous, particularly when a project affects employment and sales tax figures for the state.
"There is a fairly compelling need to be competitive with other states," he said. "If there are attractive financial inducements in one state and not another, that will effect location decisions."
Curtis Fisher, executive director of the New Jersey Public Interest Research Group, said there was no reason to use state money to attract large retail developments, which are already attracted by New Jersey's large market.
"Growth should occur in areas of the state that can best handle it," he said. "I think New Jersey citizens would say in chorus, the last thing we need is another megamall."

HEADLINE: Untrendy Housing

 BODY:

To the Editor:
One group is invisible in your news article about a Lower East Side tenement (news article, Nov. 13). Along with the last century's immigrants and a wave of "trendsetters," there are lower-income tenants, barely maintaining their homes amid so-called neighborhood revitalization. 
 Some buildings considered "ripe for revitalization" already have residents, and many units are regulated. But the tactics of some new owners result in displacement and the loss of precious housing. Longtime tenants in regulated units are denied heat, gas or repairs, hit with frivolous evictions, threatened for organizing and, when worn down, offered small buyouts.
We should listen to all of the stories, protect regulated units and build affordable housing. Now that would be trendsetting.
 
MICHAEL H. ZISSER
Executive Director, University
Settlement Society of New York
New York, Nov. 14, 2000

HEADLINE: Changing Fields (and Lawns and Gardens)

BYLINE: By ELISABETH GINSBURG

 BODY:
THE gardening bug is an insidious disease. Once stricken, some victims feel a compulsion to spend all their free time digging in the dirt and all their money buying plants and seeds. Others go even further and transform their working lives by entering the horticultural field.
John Holm, a former professional chef, is in the midst of such a career transformation. Born in Norway to a family that owned a restaurant, he was trained as a cook from an early age. Mr. Holm eventually immigrated to the United States and found work at Manhattan restaurants like La Grenouille and Restaurant 44. He also taught cooking at the French Culinary Institute and helped found a successful prepared-food business. 
 While a chef, Mr. Holm began tending a container garden on the terrace of his Brooklyn Heights apartment. Eventually he moved to a 2.5-acre lot in Bedford, N.Y., and began growing things on a larger scale. He applied to the New York Botanical Garden's School of Professional Horticulture, a two-year program that combines course work with hands-on training in the botanical garden itself. He expects to graduate in 2002 and start his own residential landscape design business.
Training that combines horticulture's intellectual and practical sides makes perfect sense to Mr. Holm, who has a high tolerance for the unglamorous and unpaid work in the botanical garden. "Because of my background in cooking," he said, "I am used to working hard and getting dirty." But "I feel a passion for this that I never did for cooking," he added. "I went into cooking because of my family. This I did for myself."
Five years ago, Mary Squires was a corporate attorney living on Long Island. Then she and her husband moved to Upper Saddle River, N.J. After finding out what it cost to hire landscapers, she decided to design her new property herself -- even though she had little experience with plants. "I started researching before I put anything in the ground," she said. Her interest increased, and after she had become a regular at her local retail nursery, a clerk suggested she take some horticulture courses at Bergen County College.
She began her studies with two courses, including Plant, Soil and Science, one of the toughest classes in the two-year degree program. Eventually she became immersed in horticulture education and went to school full time. She received a certificate in landscaping and ornamental horticulture (with honors), and went on to earn an associate's degree in applied science.
With her degrees in hand, Ms. Squires hung out her shingle as a plant consultant, installing and maintaining gardens, doing soil tests and educating her clients about environment-friendly methods of dealing with garden pests.
Ms. Squires specializes in interior "plantscaping," helping her clients with selection and placement of indoor plants. On each job she uses a light meter to gauge the amount of light in specific indoor locations, so people avoid dark corners full of dying plants. This educated approach is something new for her. "In my past life," she said, "I would just buy a plant and water it."
Ms. Squires still does a limited amount of legal work, "just to keep my hand in." In addition to running her own business, she hopes to gain greenhouse management experience by working part time for a local nursery within the next year.
Ms. Squires has no regrets about trading case management for pest management. "The time that I spend in gardens is infinitely more rewarding than the most demanding legal case," she said.
Kathleen Nelson of Gaylordsville, spends her spring, summer and fall days growing and selling perennials, a home-based business that she began when she made a midlife career change two decades ago. Busy outdoors during the growing season, she spends the winter writing copy for her plant catalog, doing bookkeeping and planning for the coming season.
Ms. Nelson grew up in "the swamps of northern Minnesota," collecting plants in the abundant wetlands. After obtaining a master's degree in zoology, she taught biology at Manhattan Community College. "I loved teaching," she said.
But in the mid-1970's, layoffs within the City University system left Ms. Nelson unemployed. A new job at the University of Bridgeport brought an unexpected bonus -- a husband. Ms. Nelson left teaching and entered professional horticulture at the age of 41, when she had her first child.
"The first couple of years, I didn't know what I was doing," she said. Her science background helped her learn quickly, and trial and error enabled her to make the decision to focus on retail rather than wholesale customers. Her business grew, bolstered by the surge in public interest in perennial plants around the time she started in the 1980's.
Ms. Nelson specializes in shade plants, noninvasive grasses and deer-resistant species, which also feature in her landscape designs for a small number of clients.
As her business has flourished, Ms. Nelson's environmental concerns have grown. A stint on a local wetlands commission changed her focus to promoting native plants. Though natives are enjoying something of a renaissance, she thinks they need more exposure.
Ms. Nelson's child is now a college junior, and the second career continues to evolve. Though she gives occasional lectures, she said that a return to the classroom would be "emotionally draining." Running her small nursery, said Ms. Nelson, is the perfect combination of physical and intellectual activity.
That combination also appeals to Laura Leach, who made the switch to horticulture after 15 years as a sales, marketing and development executive. Like Mr. Holm, Ms. Leach, who lives in Hastings, N.Y., is now a student in the New York Botanical Garden's horticulture school.
Ms. Leach, who was born in England, has a love of gardening that she inherited from her mother and grandmother. In high school she considered a horticultural career, but chose other options.
After leaving school, Ms. Leach re-encountered horticulture when she took a marketing job with Britain's National Trust, which oversees many historic structures and gardens. Later she worked as the director of development for the Welsh National Opera.
As with Ms. Nelson, marriage helped propel Ms. Leach into a new life. Several years ago, she and her husband immigrated to California, where she began part-time horticultural studies. The following year the couple moved to the East Coast. She had discovered the botanical garden's program on the Internet, and chose it because it provided "the opportunity to work alongside the best horticulturists." She praises the program's diversity. "Today I am preparing seeds for a seed exchange; yesterday I was climbing an oak tree to prune it," she said.
When she graduates in the spring of 2002, Ms. Leach may work as an administrator for a horticultural institution. She also plans to continue her education in landscape design. But she is also keeping her options open. "I am looking at where my skills are," she added.
Ms. Leach had advice for those considering a similar career change. "It's important to have some practical experience in the field first," she said, noting that the botanical garden program requires such hands-on work as a prerequisite for admission.
And, while a horticultural career may ultimately provide those who choose it with time to stop and smell the roses, she advised anyone approaching the field to be "realistic, not romantic."

HEADLINE: Yesterday's Technology, Ready for the Future

BYLINE: By JIM MOTAVALLI

 BODY:
WHAT is more up to the minute than a hybrid-powered car? Or is it, what is more old-fashioned?
The concept actually originated at the dawn of the automobile. In the early 1900's, Ferdinand Porsche, the influential German designer, built a hybrid that used an internal-combustion engine to spin a generator that sent power to electric motors in the wheel hubs. The car was said to be capable of traveling 38 miles on battery power alone. 
 Another curiosity was the Gas-au-Lec, produced in 1905-06 by the Vaughn Machine Company of Peabody, Mass. The company's ambitious president, Hamilton S. Corwin, thought that the public would flock to buy what his advertisements called "the simplest gasoline car in the world." The 4-cylinder, 45-horsepower car boasted an auxiliary electric motor (connected to the driveshaft) that started the car without a crank and offered extra power for reverse gear and hill climbing. Despite these innovations, the Gas-au-Lec was a failure, with no more than four cars produced.
Another failed hybrid was the Woods Dual Power Coupe, whose electric motor powered the car up to 20 m.p.h., when a 4-cylinder gas engine took over. It was produced in Chicago around 1916-18.
Woods had produced electric cars since 1899, and it built an earlier hybrid in 1905-07. The Dual Power was said to have worked well, but few were sold; at nearly $3,000, it was relatively expensive and its fuel economy counted for little at a time of cheap gasoline. One surviving example sits on shredded tires in the Petersen Automotive Museum in Los Angeles. JIM MOTAVALLI

HEADLINE: BRIEFING: ECONOMY;
OCTOBER UNEMPLOYMENT

BYLINE: By Anne Ruderman

 BODY:
The state's employment rate last month was 3.8 percent, the same as September, according to the State Department of Labor. The state's unemployment rate was 4.5 percent a year ago, and has has matched or been lower than the national level since January 2000. In September the state added 7,500 jobs, mostly in service industries, the department said, reaching a total of 3,943,900. Manufacturing, wholesale trade, and public-sector employment in local government all saw increases, while employment went down in the area of construction, transportation and communications. TICKER: 002235 (SZSE) (57%); 

INDUSTRY: NAICS322121 PAPER (EXCEPT NEWSPRINT) MILLS (57%); SIC2621 PAPER MILLS (57%);

HEADLINE: BRIEFING: ECONOMY;
HOUSING PRICES

BYLINE: By Karen DeMasters

 BODY:
The median price of houses in the Middlesex-Somerset-Hunterdon area increased 17.9 percent in the third quarter of 2000 compared with the third quarter in 1999, the largest increase in New Jersey and one of the largest in the Northeast, according to the National Association of Realtors. The median price of existing houses for the three counties was $234,700. The median price in the Bergen-Passaic area was higher at $245,900, but it was a smaller increase at 10.8 percent. The median price nationally rose 5.1 percent, two points more than inflation, to $142,800. Karen DeMasters

SECTION: Section 12; Page 1; Column 1; Automobiles

LENGTH: 1300 words

HEADLINE: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Toyota Prius;
It's Easier to Be Green

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
TOYOTA executives describe their Prius as a "real car." While that might sound like damning a product with faint praise, it is actually a compliment for an alternative vehicle.
And they are right. The Prius, a so-called hybrid that uses both gasoline and electric power, avoids most of the drawbacks and inconveniences of other vehicles that are designed to be clean and fuel-efficient. Its emissions are among the lowest of any car on the road, and its fuel economy -- 48 miles per gallon in combined city and highway driving -- is second only to that of the Honda Insight, another hybrid. 
 While the $20,450 price is high compared with conventional gasoline cars of similar size, the Prius is still, to my mind, the first truly practical and affordable family car that uses, at least in part, electric power.
As such, the Prius, which went on sale in the United States this summer, is a forerunner of a whole breed of hybrid gas-electric vehicles due to appear from virtually all carmakers in the next few years.
Until now, much of the effort to cut automobile emissions, particularly in California, has centered on fully electric vehicles. While such cars have no tailpipe emissions, they can cost $20,000 more to manufacture than a like-sized gasoline car. And they can travel only 50 to 100 miles or so before the batteries need a lengthy recharging.
Drivers of hybrids like the Prius and Insight do not have to recharge the batteries because that is done automatically as the car is in motion, with power drawn from the gasoline engine and from recapturing the energy of braking, which would otherwise be wasted as friction.
When the car is stopped at a traffic signal, the gas engine shuts down, conserving fuel. And at low speeds, when gas engines are inefficient, the battery does the work. But when the car speeds up, the gas engine takes over. When the car accelerates, the battery kicks in to give the gas engine a boost. (In contrast, the Insight relies mostly on its gas engine, with the electric motor providing a boost when needed.)
Since most of the fuel is saved when the car is idling or moving slowly, the Prius is unusual in that it gets better mileage in the city (52 m.p.g.) than on the highway (45 m.p.g.), according to the Environmental Protection Agency.
The Prius, which is pronounced PREE-us and comes from the Latin meaning "to go before," was the world's first mass-produced hybrid vehicle; it has been sold in Japan since 1997. But Honda beat Toyota to the American market with its Insight, which also sells for around $20,000.
The Insight achieves an eye-popping mileage rating of 61 m.p.g. in town and 68 on the highway, but it has limitations. For now, it comes only with a manual transmission and two seats. And it has a tapered, space-age look that draws stares, for better or worse.
The Prius, which is made in Japan but was re-engineered for American driving conditions, sacrifices some fuel economy for practicality. It has an automatic transmission that is continuously variable, rather than having a discrete number of gears. Four adults and a five-year-old in a child seat fit reasonably comfortably. And from the outside, the Prius looks pretty much like a normal subcompact.
One drawback is that the batteries reduce cargo space. The trunk barely held a child's bicycle with training wheels. Also, acceleration is a bit sluggish. The Prius, which has a 1.5-liter engine, goes from 0 to 60 in a little over 12 seconds, compared with about 10 seconds for a Toyota Echo, which also has a 1.5-liter engine (but no electric backup).
Then there is the price. Toyota has lost money on each Prius it has sold, although executives now say the company is breaking even. Even so, the Prius sells for about $4,000 more than a Corolla and at least $6,000 more than the Echo.
Don't count on making up for that in lower gasoline bills. Fuel costs for the Prius will run only about $200 a year less than for the Corolla and Echo, according to the E.P.A. At that rate, it would take decades to recoup the higher purchase price.
This calculation, of course, does not take into account the savings to society from less air pollution -- and the tax breaks intended to reward buyers of cars like this. Prius owners could be eligible for a federal deduction of up to a $2,000 from their gross income, Toyota says.
Driving the Prius is like driving a regular car: just press the pedal and the car goes. The switch from electric to gasoline power is virtually seamless and imperceptible. The one difference is the gas engine's shutting off at a red light, leading novice drivers to conclude, instinctively, that the engine has stalled. It hasn't, of course, and when the accelerator is depressed the car immediately starts up and begins moving.
Then there is the dashboard. The shift lever protrudes somewhat oddly from the dash to the right of the steering wheel. This takes some getting used to, and I found the lever obscured my view of the radio controls.
More important is a small touch screen that displays how the power is flowing within the car, using arrows and pictures of the gas engine, the wheels, the battery and the motor. The arrows change as the vehicle shifts from electric to gas power, and from draining to recharging the battery.
The display can also show a bar graph of the most recent fuel economy, though I wonder how reliable the figures are. On one trip along a major boulevard here, I recorded 35 m.p.g. for one 5-minute segment and 100 m.p.g. for the next.
In Southern California's bumper-to-bumper freeway traffic, I also registered as much as 100 m.p.g. because the car was operating mainly on the battery. But after about 10 minutes of this, the battery was half-depleted and the gas engine kicked in.
Over all, according to the car's calculation, I averaged 43.5 m.p.g. in about 300 miles of mixed highway and city driving, somewhat below the E.P.A. rating.
Although they welcome hybrids, environmentalists say the ultimate goal should be zero-emission vehicles. Hybrids, after all, drive as well as gasoline cars because they are, in the main, gasoline cars, and they still emit some pollution.
The E.P.A. estimates that a Prius driven 15,000 miles a year will emit 4 tons of greenhouse gases, mainly carbon dioxide. While that is well below the 5.5 tons a year, or more, from small gasoline cars like the Honda Civic and Toyota Corolla, it is still not zero. As for smog-causing emissions like nitrogen oxides, the Prius is a super-ultra-low-emission vehicle, or SULEV, under California rules. That is the best rating short of zero, and it means the Prius's emissions are a tiny fraction of those from most cars. But the SULEV rating has also been achieved by special versions of the gasoline-only Honda Accord EX and Nissan Sentra CA.
Automakers say it is more effective to use hybrids to get a modest reduction in pollutants across a wide range of vehicles than to strive for zero-emission vehicles that no one will buy. The Prius is a case in point. Toyota expects to easily meet its target of 12,000 sales in the first year; orders are already backed up for months. That is several times the total number of fully electric vehicles sold or leased over several years.
The California Air Resources Board, after a summer of intense lobbying, decided to stick with its mandate requiring zero emissions from 10 percent of the cars sold by major manufacturers in the state in 2003. Some hybrids would get partial credit toward that goal, but 4 percent of sales would have to be of true zero-emission cars.
Still, while the Prius may not be the ultimate pollution solution, for those wanting to make a contribution here and now, it is the most practical way to go.
 
INSIDE TRACK: A lean, clean, green machine.

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS: VOWS;
Heidi Smith and Daniel Aronson

BYLINE: By LOIS SMITH BRADY

 BODY:
FRIENDS describe Heidi Medney Smith, 37, as a diehard Brooklynite. She has ridden almost every Brooklyn-bound subway line to the end just to see what was there. She loves ethnic food and cannot stay calm in a traffic jam or in the wilderness. "Heidi was raised in Flatbush by Dodger fans," said Elizabeth Hollander, a friend. "She's very fast and very bossy. She's full of life and speed and intensity and impatience."
After graduating magna cum laude from Wellesley College, Ms. Smith followed some friends to San Francisco, where she became a founder of a revival movie theater called the Red Victorian. She stayed in San Francisco for 11 years, but never stopped missing Brooklyn. "My true nature is to honk at the person in front of me in traffic, and I don't see the virtue of deep breathing my way out of it," she said. 
 When she came back in May 1998, it was because her mother, Claire Medney Smith, who was the president of Harold Ober Associates, the literary agents in New York, had become seriously ill. Her mother died that summer.
"It was very surprising, if terminal cancer can ever surprise you," Ms. Smith said. For more than a year afterward, she said she often stared at the wall of her tiny downtown apartment, unemployed and unsure about what direction to take with her life. "I would go out to the counters at the MAC make-up store and say, 'I have no foundation in my life, but I'll take some foundation on my face.' "
She decided to try graduate school. Last November, as she was filling out applications, she got a call from Daniel Alex Aronson, a sometime date from her San Francisco days. "She was about to go to social work school, and she was saved by the bell," said Erin St. John Kelly, another friend.
Ms. Smith and Mr. Aronson had known each other since the 1980's, dated briefly in 1996 (no chemistry, she recalled) and went their separate ways. "Am I allowed to say I hadn't really thought about him much over the years?" she said.
He, however, had never stopped thinking about her. Having grown up in Great Neck, N.Y., he always saw her as a kindred spirit on the West Coast. "Heidi is eloquent and interesting and challenging," said Mr. Aronson, 38, an Internet engineer and entrepreneur. "One problem about San Francisco is you don't find yourself up at 2 a.m. in a bar or coffee shop having a fascinating conversation with someone. I knew I could find that in Heidi anytime."
He tracked her down, flew East and took her to dinner.
"He was a man with a mission, really," Ms. Smith said. "He knew what he wanted, and all of a sudden it occurred to me that it was me."
After dinner, they went for a walk on the Brooklyn Heights Esplanade. "It was very cold," she said. "So we had to start kissing right away."
As he was starting up Campsix, a San Francisco company that gives technical and financial aid to new Internet ventures, she walked around New York, often in snowstorms, talking to him on her cell phone, gradually coming out of her mourning. By February, they were talking about marriage.
"He's very steady," said Ms. Smith, who is back on the West Coast and working as a counselor for the San Francisco Tenants Union. "You can huff and puff, and you cannot blow Dan down. And I huff and puff whenever I can. I feel everything quite deeply."
Ms. Smith came back to Brooklyn to marry on Nov. 11, in the Hall of the Americas at the Brooklyn Museum of Art. Instead of being overexcited and wearing sneakers, as some of her friends expected, she was serene and wore pumps.
"Last weekend, Dan called me and said, 'What are you doing on your last Saturday as a single person?' " Ms. Smith said.
"I said, 'I'm eating curried goat.' And he said, 'Well, I'm cleaning the house, so I guess we're ready to be married.' "

HEADLINE: It's Hopping in the Lobby As Hotels Party All Night;
Innkeepers are turning lounges, bars and everything between, not excluding the elevators, into a club scene.

BYLINE: By JESSE McKINLEY

 BODY:
IT'S Saturday night, and amid a swirl of Fendi baguettes, lip-gloss reapplication and leather pants, two polite, middle-aged women from rural Kentucky are standing in the lobby of the Hudson hotel, beaming like julep-happy Derby winners.
The two women, Marylyn Todd and Jane Warren, after all, have just emerged from the Library Bar, described by no less a source than Ms. Warren's son (who got them the room) as "a real 'in' place." 
 And indeed, the evidence is everywhere in the bar -- in the drinks (cosmopolitans, of course) as in the decor (the regal-purple pool table) and the clientele, which on this night includes Larry Johnson, the New York Knicks' power forward, who is engaged in, no kidding, a serious game of chess.
Mr. Johnson, entrenched in a knotty middle game, hardly looks up as groups of fetching library science majors and chess hotties titter about the relative star power of Vince Vaughn and Ben Stiller. (Both of whom are in attendance, though neither is man enough to take on Mr. Johnson's vaunted Caro-Kann Defense.)
In the Hudson's lobby meanwhile, other attractive night-trippers shuttle between the high-ceilinged library and the hotel's second lounge, the thumping, low-ceilinged Hudson Bar, leaving a hazy trail of cigarette smoke and martini spill.
None of which, however, seems to faze the two visitors from Sebree, Ky. (population, 1,510). "This is our New York moment," Ms. Warren says. "And all we had to do is come to the lobby."
A recent sweep of Manhattan hotels found a full-blown club scene raging in a number of lobbies, engineered by aggressively hip innkeepers like Ian Schrager, who owns the Hudson. Rarely has the act of checking into the Econ-o-Lodge been so sexy: couples make out beside the concierge desk, disc jockeys spin hip-hop, herds of unshaved men and flocks of high-heeled women greet the nightly drop-ins. It's as if those club-loving siblings Nicky and Paris Hilton were already running their family's business, complete with guest lists and velvet ropes.
In addition to the Hudson's hectic scene, the soaring eight-story atrium of a downtown newcomer, the TriBeCa Grand Hotel, is a gathering place where patrons have engaged in elevator races after $12 cocktails, and the W, on Lexington Avenue and 50th Street, packs a crowd four-deep at the bar from happy hour to after midnight on Fridays and Saturdays.
Other cities have witnessed the hotel-as-nightclub phenomenon in recent years, notably Miami Beach and Los Angeles, even Stockholm. And New York has its precedents like Mr. Schrager's Paramount hotel, where a decade ago the overflow from the cozy Whiskey Bar nightly spilled into the lobby.
But the current scene is bigger and more overtly clublike than ever. It draws hundreds of patrons into designer lairs and runs late into the night. With the 1,000-room Hudson, which opened last month, Mr. Schrager has supersized the concept, unapologetically aiming to turn the hotel's public spaces into as big and celebrity-besotted a club as possible.
He hired a younger generation of clubland aficionados like Zoe Casavetes, who advises about entertainment, and Ben Pundle, late of Lot 61, who manages the Hudson Bar. A nonstop string of post-movie-premiere parties have been booked into the hotel, followed by the predictable mentions in gossip columns. All this has granted Mr. Schrager his wish: a perception that his new hotel is where the action is.
"Everybody likes to be in the know, and everybody wants to go to a bar that is happening," Mr. Schrager, formerly of Studio 54, said the other day in a mile-a-minute Brooklyn brogue. "So why not have those things in the lobby?"
The reaction of overnight guests to the scenes taking place in their midst seems mixed. Besides happily wide-eyed tourists enjoying their New York moments, there are also miffed guests like the latter-day Willy Loman who was waiting to check into the W recently. Sulking in a brown trench coat, Mr. Loman (not his real name) looked over the lobby crowd the way the Grinch looks at Whoville. "I've been to the bar before, but I've never stayed at the hotel," he said. "Now I know why."
The hotel-clubs seem to have more employees assigned to serving drop-ins than to working the registration desk. On one recent Friday, the staff at the TriBeCa Grand included two black-swaddled doormen outside and an all-blond three-woman team at the lounge's maitre d'hotel station. A single registration clerk filed her nails and looked on.
The point of it all is to make the hotel the destination. So, without leaving home, I took a short trip to some of the hotter hotel haunts to determine whether they are places to go, places to stay or places to avoid entirely.
THE first stop was the Church Lounge, which was opened in May at the TriBeCa Grand, a younger sister to the four-year-old SoHo Grand. While the SoHo Grand's second-floor bar, with its giant man-eating lamps and bare bulbs, has mellowed with middle age, the Church Lounge is still at that awkward stage of youth.
Physically, the lounge is lovely, a spacious kidney-shape room with a V-shape bar, lots of tables and a big back room outfitted with a Cadillac-size mirror. The John Portman-style atrium, too, is impressive, with glass elevators zipping up to a blue-tinted dome. On the two nights I visited, however, the large crowd seemed still unsure of itself, like a teenagers waiting for a party to start.
It's a hesitancy that highlights one of the innate dangers of hotel scenes, that creeping sensation that you're not in a real bar, a sense that a friend described as "the feeling that everyone's waiting for a taxi to the airport."
Unnerved, we attacked the problem with one of the hotel's specialty cocktails, which we quickly found cost exclusively in the $12 to $15 range -- another pitfall of the hotel scene, where prices are scaled for those with expense accounts.
Still, there were plenty of seats, and an attractive clientele. The scene was skewed toward singles, with all-male and all-female parties eyeing each other from afar. The age range was roughly 25 to 35, although I should note I counted no fewer than seven guys with shaved heads -- in this context, a camouflage for baldness, not a sign of a skinhead movement below Canal Street. There didn't seem to be any hotel guests; an informal poll of about a dozen people found none at all.
Not that they weren't trying. A visitor named Christopher tipped me off to the final challenge in hot hotels. He had spent all evening talking up a pretty blonde at the bar, finally suggesting that they retire someplace a little less public.
"We tried to get a room," Christopher said. "But the whole place is booked."
How the TriBeCa Grand holds up as a scene has yet to be determined. But for anyone looking for an example of the half-life of a design-driven destination hotel, there is no finer artifact than the Whiskey Blue bar at the W, the first of a chain of W Hotels in New York, which opened in 1998.
The bar has everything you've seen everywhere else: amber lighting and curtains (a la Moomba), black and white photos (a la the late Orient) and little white table candles (a la every other bar in the city). The music, too, is predictable, a steady stream of disco and hip-hop. Wonderbra-wearing waitresses maneuver through shoulder-to-shoulder suits, businessmen who apparently come prepared with the kind of pickup lines distributed wholesale in fraternities across the country.
"Did I tell you I'm a marathoner?" said one man, making eyes at a woman in an apron top.
"You run?" she responded.
"Yes," he answered. "I run marathons."
And so on.
Perhaps the only original flair in the Whiskey Blue is a comfy bed in the middle of the room, on which two middle-aged men -- ties off, it's quittin' time! -- were lounging, along with a young woman who looked as if she had just lost her trust fund.
For all that, there was a sizable line out front, with a stream of taxis and white limousines pulling up. Inside, the bar was packed to capacity. A doorman near the coat check was strict: patrons who left to go to the bathroom, which requires leaving the Whiskey Blue and climbing one flight upstairs, found it difficult to regain entrance.
Those locked out, mind you, could find refuge in the Oasis Bar, a more casual two-level establishment adjacent to the front desk, where visitors sat behind small wooden tables that have backgammon boards and chessboards burned into their tops. (Note to Mr. Johnson: chess doesn't seem to be big at the W.)
It was into this scene that we stumbled on a rainy Thursday evening. Moving through the crowd at a snail's pace, we found ourselves seated at a crowded table occupied by a likable young man named William, who said he was a regular at "the Blue" on Thursdays.
"I go here for the girls," said William, who is 28 and a Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, native. He didn't want to give his last name because his girlfriend might not approve. He added with a shout over the music: "It's easy to talk to people. You know, talk business."
Carlo Dibetetto, William's friend, agreed. "The girls here are from all over the place," he said. "Boston, Jersey, Long Island, all over."
Mr. Dibetetto, 48, said he was an actor and as proof took out of his pocket a snapshot of him and the actor Joe Viterelli, Robert DeNiro's glacierlike sidekick in the movie "Analyze This." Mr. Dibetetto said he came to the craft only recently, after working in "several businesses," and he added that the name of his current film project is, honest, "Wannabes."
"I love acting," he said. "It's like make-believe."
But the movie business, he said, has yet to translate into an active social life. So, Mr. Dibetetto, who said his wife had recently asked him to vacate their house, started coming to the Whiskey Blue to find "nice polite types of girls."
"It's hard to walk in and not walk out with nobody," he said. "That's what the girls come here for." He reflected for a moment and then added, "They come here to meet famous people, I guess."
Call it a hunch, but they may be in the wrong place.
For actual celebrity gawking, we traveled to the Hudson, on 58th Street, between Eighth and Ninth Avenues, where a nice fellow in a black trenchcoat who seemed to have stepped from "The Matrix" shooed us away from the front door.
All the hotels say their guests are given preference in getting in, and at the Hudson only hotel guests are allowed to enter through the main doors -- a tomblike facade bathed in neon the color of green sherbet -- while outsiders are diverted to a small side door.
Around that door we found a messy clump of people, all umbrellas and insistent tones. One woman said she was there to meet three fellow bachelorettes. (She made it in.) Another claimed to be from The New York Observer. (She might still be waiting.)
Past the ropes, a dull stairway leads to the second floor and into the Hudson Bar, where the ceilings loom low, decorated by a swirling mural by Francesco Clemente.
On this evening, when no publicity parties were scheduled, the room was only about half full. A D.J. spun loud dance tunes. The airy feeling of the room was intensified by the design, which includes floating candles in crystal bowls and translucent white tiles underfoot. People seemed to be making space near the center of the room for Jay Z and an entourage, who were slouched on low-slung couches.
Watching Mr. Z from a distance were those other musical innovators, the teeny-bopper group O-Town, which is the subject of the television documentary serial "Making the Band." The five musicians turned out to be the first people I met in any of my travels who were actually staying at the hotel where they were lounging.
The band was in town for a night to record a song. They usually stay at the W, the musicians said, but had chosen the Hudson because, well, they didn't know. But they were unusually qualified to compare the two establishments.
"This seems very foreign to me," said Ashley Parker Angel, the "blond one" in the band.
"Like Germany," said Trevor Penick, the "bad one."
"Or England," said Erik-Michael Estrada, the "cute one."
"Yeah," Mr. Angel said.
Yeah.
All else aside, the band seemed mighty grateful for a place to go. "To tell the truth," Mr. Penick said, "if we are in a hotel where nothing's going on, we don't do anything."
Mr. Estrada agreed.
"Yeah," he said, "we don't really like to take cabs."
"So," chimed in Mr. Penick in perfect harmony, "if it's not happening downstairs, it's not happening."

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW;
The Politics Of Surplus Cut Across Partisanship

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
TO the extent that there is any conventional wisdom left in the nation's capital, it is that the next four years will be defined by gridlock, with neither party having the votes in Congress or the mandate to enact much of an agenda.
That will no doubt prove true in many respects. The prospects for a bipartisan agreement on shoring up Social Security, for example, are dim. 
 Yet it is a mistake to assume that gridlock means that fiscal policy will be frozen and that the mounting federal budget surpluses will go, by default, to reducing the national debt.
The reason is that surplus politics are proving to be guided by wholly different rules from those that defined the long era of budget deficits.
When money was tight in Washington, a standoff meant that neither side got what it wanted. Now we are beginning to learn that when priorities clash in an era of plenty, Washington's solution is to give both sides some, if not all, of what they want.
Put aside for a moment the outcome of the presidential race and look at what the outgoing Congress and President Clinton were up to before Election Day.
Without much debate, the Republican leadership and the White House had generally agreed on a package of tax cuts and spending increases that would have eaten up about $900 billion of the projected budget surplus over the next decade. That is about 40 percent of the anticipated non-Social Security surplus of $2.2 trillion over that period -- the same money the presidential candidates were counting on for their proposals.
That budget deal appears to have fallen apart, for reasons unrelated to the amount of money involved. It may be pieced back together when the lame-duck Congress returns after Thanksgiving, but even if it is not, the principle has been well established: the surplus is a remarkably effective political lubricant.
The same dynamic will no doubt apply over the next four years. While Republicans and Democrats will pick ideological fights with each other to motivate their supporters for the midterm elections in 2002 and the next presidential race in 2004, they will also continue to dole out the goodies made affordable by the surplus.
"Compromise is as easy as 'you scratch my back, I'll scratch yours,' " said Robert J. Barbera, chief economist at Hoenig & Company in Rye Brook, N.Y.
Dividing up the surplus will be made easier by two factors: the near-certainty that the surplus projection will be revised upward again, and the likelihood that the economy has slowed to a point where fiscal stimulus would no longer have to be offset by higher interest rates.
The projection from the Congressional Budget Office is for a surplus over the next decade of nearly $4.6 trillion, of which about $2.4 trillion would come from excess Social Security revenue. The two parties agree that the Social Security surplus should go to reducing the $3.4 trillion national debt or back into the retirement system.
Early word among budget analysts on Capitol Hill is that the budget office's next projection in a few months will add anywhere from several hundred billion dollars to $1 trillion to the 10-year projection. Most of the additional money would fall into the non-Social Security category, and therefore, be available for tax cuts or new spending.
Should the Fed decide to cut interest rates next year to pep up a slowing economy, as some economists predict, it would also remove the argument that fiscal stimulus is the last thing the economy needs. The economic argument against spending the surplus has not been much heeded in Washington anyway, but a faltering economy would provide lawmakers with a justification for some old-style Keynesian pump-priming.
There are reasons why saving the surplus -- using it to accelerate debt reduction -- would be best for the nation. Paying off debt puts downward pressure on interest rates and frees capital for more productive uses.
Moreover, the population is about to get a lot older, driving up the costs of entitlement programs like Social Security and Medicare. The United States would be in much better condition to weather that demographic shift if federal finances are in order.
But there are strong arguments for putting the surplus to work immediately, either through spending programs to address poverty, education, health and the environment, or through tax cuts that might promote higher rates of economic growth.
Washington has probably already committed itself to as much debt reduction as it can credibly promise. Count on politicians to find a way to agree, even across a deep partisan divide, on using all or most of the non-Social Security surplus on proposals that have a more immediate appeal.

HEADLINE: A NIGHT OUT WITH/Andre De Shields;
So Hot, He Needs 2 Stages to Do His Misbehavin'

BYLINE: By LINDA LEE

 BODY:
YOU representin', baby," a friend encountered in the lobby said to Andre De Shields as he left his apartment building, Manhattan Plaza, on West 43rd Street. And indeed he was, dressed in a black tailcoat with a pale blue diamond pattern and a plaid topcoat, on his way to two fund-raising galas Monday night.
What he was representing, however, was the hardest-working actor-slash-song-and-dance-man in Manhattan on his day off. He was not going to be sitting in the orchestra seats with the other swells. He was going to be onstage, upping the energy level as he does every night when he stops the show in "The Full Monty" on Broadway. And he was going to do it twice. 
 "In this industry you spend so much time being anonymous that when you're hot, you're hot," he said. At a well-preserved 54, Mr. De Shields is hot all over again. "There was a time I couldn't get arrested," he said. "And now I've hit pay dirt three times -- wait, four actually." To review, that would be when he played the title role on Broadway in "The Wiz" in 1975, when he starred as Viper in "Ain't Misbehavin' " in 1978 and now as Horse in the stage version of "The Full Monty." (The fourth would be his Tony nomination for playing Jester in "Play On" in 1997.)
But there was a 20-year period in there when perhaps he couldn't get arrested, and he filled his time with a master's degree in African-American studies, began teaching at New York University, did cabaret and turned up every year to perform at La Mama for Ellen Stewart.
Born one of 11 children to a tailor and his wife in Baltimore, Mr. De Shields speaks with the elegant diction of a professor of Shakespeare (which he now teaches at N.Y.U.) and adores $5 words to the point of puzzling those around him. ("Antipodal"?) But he has no problem playing an aging, unemployed manager of a fast-food joint from Buffalo who finds self-esteem through dancing and stripping in "The Full Monty." "I just don't enunciate as clearly," he said.
Mr. De Shields's song "Big Black Man," a sendup of James Brown, brings down the house and has led to talk of another Tony nomination. As Ben Brantley said in reviewing the show in The New York Times, Mr. De Shields, for the duration of his solo, "seems to own the whole island of Manhattan."
No problem there. What he was having a problem with Monday evening was finding the Ford Center for the Performing Arts on 42nd Street, only blocks from his home. There were spotlights splaying outside and a red carpet rolled out in front of the Sony E-Walk theater, and like any actor, he turned and walked right in. Whoops, it was the premiere of an HBO film. The Lena Horne Awards at the Ford Center, his destination, were farther down the block, with no red carpet but a lot more celebrities, hoopla and photographers jostling and flashing.
"It's that 'Full Monty' guy," someone in the crowd said helpfully to those who did not recognize Mr. De Shields.
"No," said Rosie O'Donnell, who was right behind him and was being honored that night, along with Quincy Jones. "It's that guy from 'The Wiz'!"
What she didn't know going in was that Mr. De Shields had sent over his costume from "The Wiz" and that if he could get into it, he was going to put it on and sing for her that night.
While everyone else went into the theater, he took a detour to the left, to the decidedly less glamorous part of the building, a warren of dressing rooms with paper signs taped to the doors saying things like "Stomp Cast" and "Betty Buckley."
"In 1987, I was performing and this zaftig girl with long black hair came up to me and said, 'Mr. Wiz!' 'Mr. Wiz!' " Mr. De Shields recalled. "And I was nice to her -- I'm nice to all my fans -- but little did I know that 10 years later I'd be trying to get her attention. Rosie O'Donnell, with her own talk show."
Through the years of fame and obscurity, Mr. De Shields has always been a New York theater actor, never going Hollywood. "I only go where I'm invited," he said. "And Hollywood hasn't beckoned." Roles for African-Americans are still constrained there, he said. "There's only one leading man, Denzel, and room for one character actor, Morgan Freeman, and one action hero, Wesley Snipes, and one buddy, Danny Glover."
If he ever did make a place for himself in Hollywood, he said, it would be as an African-American man with fine plumage. "I'm elegant, articulate, and I don't know if Hollywood is ready," he said.
But his 42nd Street audience was, and it was time to slither into his 25-year-old skintight Wiz costume. (When the show closed, he kept it, and has used it before on Halloween. But then he had to lie on a bed to get it on.)
Four people were in his dressing room, where only one needed to be, perhaps two, but Mr. De Shields didn't mind. Hey, this is a guy who began his professional career in "Hair" and who bares all every night in "The Full Monty."
"They don't call this 'The Half Monty,' " he said. "I guarantee you we are in our birthday suits." There is also a long scene they play in underwear. "Let me tell you something about men," Mr. De Shields said. "We'd much rather be seen buck naked than in our underpants, especially in a roomful of other men."
But there he was, stripping down to his dance briefs and beginning the strenuous work of getting into costume. First the long stretch legs of the white jumpsuit (shades of Elvis), then up to the waist -- unh! -- and then, but only with a slight backward bend at the waist, first one arm and then the other into the costume.
"Now comes the hard part -- zipping," he said.
Inch by inch the miracle was achieved. But wait. "Can you sew it for me?" he asked his publicist, Merle Frimark. "I brought a needle and thread." Remember, this is a tailor's son, and there, on his right side, was a gaping seam. "I don't want to break out of it up there onstage," he said.
They decided it would be prudent to unzip the top. Sewing done, stomach back in, standing taller, arms back, yes, he was zipped in again. "A few psilocybin mushrooms, and I'll be fine," he said. He put on the white platform boots.
Swirling down the hallway past Elaine Stritch, standing in her underwear in her dressing room (nice legs, Elaine!), then upstairs, and there was the stage. "This is an industry where you can exorcise your demons," Mr. De Shields said. "In any other industry, you're going postal. Here it's expected."
"So you wanted to meet the Wizard?" someone asked the crowd in the house, and Mr. De Shields was on. Really on. Strutting and singing and swirling. He ripped his cape off -- literally ripped -- and stepped out of it and gave the audience a good view of the glittering white star affixed to the rump of his taut jumpsuit. Gasps, a big finish, applause, applause, applause, and he was off.
"It's a calculated risk," he said, "to see if 25 years later, when you are clearly adult -- it's a calculated risk to come back and try it again." The calculation had paid off, but there was no time to preen. It was 8:20, and while the other performers were hanging around to take curtain calls later that night, Mr. De Shields had another appointment, uptown, to be onstage at 8:45.
Off came the costume, on went the tails again and he was out on 43rd Street looking for the car that would get him to Lincoln Center. A short ride and there he was, in his dressing room at Avery Fisher Hall for a gala for Jazz at Lincoln Center, with, what, five minutes to spare?
Now to switch hats from Broadway to Louis Armstrong. But wait. Where was Mr. De Shields's white handkerchief? You can't do Louis Armstrong without a white handkerchief, to mop your face and gesture with. One was found, and he roughed it up, to make it limp, so it would have the right drape over his hand. And on he went to do his patter and to sing "I'm Confessin' (That I Love You)." Right after him came Jessye Norman, singing "Nobody Knows the Trouble I've Seen," while Dr. John stood backstage and watched on a monitor.
Wynton Marsalis tootled his way into Mr. De Shields's dressing room for a hug. ("My man," he said.) It was 10 o'clock. Two shows were over. Mr. De Shields hadn't eaten all day, and he was expected at dinner across the plaza at the New York State Theater with the jazz patrons who'd paid $1,000 and up for gala tickets.
Is this man tired yet? Not a chance. He'd been up since 7 a.m., and had spent the morning at Actors Equity as a representative from "The Full Monty," going over a new union agreement with Broadway producers, then walked from there to the Ford Center for a rehearsal, took the No. 104 bus up to Lincoln Center for the other rehearsal, then the No. 11 bus home to change for the evening.
"And," he said, "all along the way the universe was saying, 'Yes!' "

HEADLINE: How Easy Cash Became Hard Debts

BYLINE: By GRETCHEN MORGENSON

 BODY:
IN a Nov. 2 report, "The Other Side of Leverage," Ravi Suria, a convertible bond analyst at Lehman Brothers, examined the consequences of the recent surge in debt at telecommunications companies at a time when intense competition for customers had reduced revenue growth. It is a sobering piece of research.
Mr. Suria began by pointing out that in the past four years, debt at a group of seven high-grade telecommunications companies, including AT&T, Verizon and SBC, exploded from $93 billion, to $210 billion, an annualized rate of almost 23 percent. At lesser-quality telecom and media services companies, like Global Crossing, Nextel Communications and PSI Net, high-yield corporate debt and convertible bond issuance ballooned to $275 billion, a compounded annual rate of 60 percent, in the period. 
 To put this binge into perspective, the entire value of high-yield debt issued between 1983 and 1990, the heyday of junk-bonds, was $160 billion.
These telecom companies took on such high amounts of debt to capitalize on the explosion in demand for data and voice communications services. Even the watchful Mr. Suria stressed in his report that the business remained highly promising.
So what's the problem? Too much of a good thing: These companies' capital structures now are simply too indebted for their cash flows to cover interest payments.
"The investment thesis for many of these firms was that, as they were nimbler and faster than the incumbents, they would quickly raise capital, build out networks with the latest technologies and then sell the completed networks to the large investment-grade telecom companies which needed the new assets," Mr. Suria wrote. Now, however, even the big companies are strapped for cash and are not in a buying mood.
This puts immense pressure on the speculative companies whose debt levels exceed the value of the plant and equipment they have sunk in their networks. For example, PSI Net has $4.6 billion in debt and preferred stock, more than double its $2 billion in net plant and equipment. Its interest expense and preferred stock dividends for the past 12 months totaled $400 million, compared to revenues of $1.04 billion. The company's net operating cash flow was a negative $241 million in the past 12 months.
PSI Net's stock reflects these difficult economics; it has crashed from $60.94 a share last March to $1.63. The company's bonds are fetching less than 40 cents on the dollar.
On Thursday, PSI Net announced that it had hired Goldman Sachs to help it explore its "financial alternatives."
But other speculative companies' stocks are still trading at fairly fancy premiums, even though their debts exceed the value of their hard assets. This suggests that those companies are bound to feel further pain, according to Mr. Suria.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
The Wall Street Bonanza That Won't Be

BYLINE: By GRETCHEN MORGENSON

 BODY:
EVEN if the nasty partisan battle for the White House of recent weeks goes on to infect all of Congress next year, both parties agree on at least one thing: investing in stocks should be a part of any solution to the problem of funding Social Security in coming years. Naturally, all of Wall Street is agog over what such a shift to stocks might mean to the mood of the overall market. Bear markets, be gone!
Since investing in the stock market has become the national pastime, it is not surprising that Democrats and Republicans alike think expanding the Social Security trust fund to include stock investments would solve the system's ills. 
 And ills aplenty there are. In 1934, for example, there were 16 working Americans for each retired beneficiary. By 2030, this ratio is expected to have dwindled to two to one. And today 45 million people collect Social Security benefits of roughly $400 billion a year. In 30 years, analysts expect that 83 million people will collect over $750 billion a year, in today's dollars.
Since the trust fund's current value of $1 trillion does not come close to covering future obligations -- an estimated $3 trillion -- stocks look like a pretty appealing way out. And last year, Democrats in the House called for the Social Security trust fund to allocate between 40 percent and 50 percent to stocks.
With the broad market averages down significantly for the year, it is fun for Wall Street to fantasize about what $500 million flooding into the stock market would do to prop up prices. After all, that amount is roughly half the money that went into domestic equity mutual funds throughout the entire 1990's.
But Leah Modigliani, a United States equity strategist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, believes putting this money to work in stocks would be no bonanza for shares. And she thinks such a shift would drive interest rates considerably higher, which is nobody's idea of a good thing.
"We have to think carefully through the implementation of such a policy and consider the fact that if we sell bonds it means it's not new cash to the stock market," Ms. Modigliani said. "Also, the effect on the bond market could be quite significant."
Ms. Modigliani said that if the Trust liquidates $500 billion of the Treasury-backed i.o.u.'s that it holds, the Treasury would have to sell that amount of bonds in the open market. Given that the government bond market is currently around $2.5 trillion, $500 billion for sale is a big enough chunk to drive prices down -- and yields up -- significantly. "Bond yields will have to rise to entice investors, who were perfectly happy holding other assets, to buy bonds instead," Ms. Modigliani noted.
As yields rise, Ms. Modigliani argues, some investors will sell stocks to buy bonds. So the net amount going into the stock market will be far below the $500 billion allocated to equities.
Since higher bond yields will make it more expensive for American companies to borrow, their profits will be hurt too. Ms. Modigliani's conclusion?
"Selling government bonds to buy stocks is not nearly as beneficial to the stock market as it first appears," she said. "In fact, on the margin, we think such a transaction could actually be negative for stocks."
New Social Security receipts going into stocks would, of course, mean fresh money for the market. But with the value of the United States stock market at around $13.4 trillion, it is the $500 billion honey pot, not the new receipts, that excites Wall Street.
Wrongly, in Ms. Modigliani's view.
"At least in the near term," she said, "it is unlikely to be the windfall to the stock market that people think."

LENGTH: 2532 words

HEADLINE: Bond Believers See Prelude to a Fall

BYLINE: By GRETCHEN MORGENSON

 BODY:
WHEN the bond market talks, investors don't always like to listen. After all, bond investors tend to spot bad news on the horizon and then telegraph it to the rest of the world in language as complex as Alan Greenspan's when he testifies before Congress.
But with the stock market in a swoon, investors looking for guidance are starting to heed the distress signals that the bond market has been sending up recently. And what some observers fear they see in these signs is a storm for the United States capital markets that may be tougher to recover from than the debacle in the autumn of 1998. 
 That year, a crisis was precipitated by the demise of one giant hedge fund, Long-Term Capital Management. But after the Federal Reserve Board lowered interest rates, recovery came swiftly to the stock market and the economy was relatively unscathed. This time around, market observers say, the turbulence will be set off by many troubled companies buckling under the weight of excessive debt lent to them at the height of New Economy euphoria.
That scares the pinstripes off the pants of some who heed the bond market's signals. If worried investors continue to shun corporate bonds as they turn away from risk, many companies will find it impossible to raise the capital that leads to new job creation and continued economic growth. And since much of the economic growth in this nation over the past few years came from the big money spent by companies that had raised cash in the anything-goes bond market, the economy could slow quite sharply as the money spigots go dry.
Finally, as more and more companies go under, their woes could turn a soft economic landing into a much bumpier one. And the longest American expansion on record could come abruptly to an end.
Byron Wien, chief United States investment strategist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, sees little good in the signals the bond market is sending.
"One," he said, "the hard landing possibility for next year is more realistic than the stock market believes. Two, even if there is a soft landing, corporate fixed expenses have built up during this nine-year period of prosperity and will be hard to roll back, so that a minor shortfall in revenues will cause a major shortfall in profits."
The bond market's condition has implications for interest rate policy as well. "This is a murky picture and even contributes to a more difficult judgmental problem for the Federal Reserve," said Henry Kaufman, the Wall Street economist. Before the Fed can cut rates, he said, it must weigh the decline in credit quality against the need to get the market moving again.
The corporate debt market has grown enormously in recent years, expanding to accommodate the burgeoning capital needs of hundreds of companies. Although most investors focus on the stock market, the corporate bond market dwarfs it in size.
AND the gap is widening. So far this year, companies have raised only $146 billion from new stock issues, compared with $935 billion in the corporate bond market, according to Thomson Financial Securities Data. The peak of corporate issuance came in 1998 when $1.2 trillion worth of bonds came to market, up from $433 billion raised in 1995.
But lately, issuance has slowed considerably as the roster of troubled companies has started to swell. Just last Tuesday, ICG Communications, a telecommunications and internet service provider in Englewood, Colo., filed for bankruptcy. The company, whose stock had traded as high as $39 a share last March, had $2.2 billion in long-term bonds on its balance sheet before the bankruptcy.
And, to cite just one other example among many, on May 17, GST Telecommunications, a Vancouver voice and data services provider, declared bankruptcy. Although Time Warner bought its assets, it paid only 70 percent of the book value of the company's plant, property and equipment. That left just 50 cents on the dollar for bondholders.
As bond investors have digested those corporate difficulties, their appetite for risk has shrunk markedly. Many companies needing cash and willing to pay high interest rates for it have been out of luck. The total amount of money raised in high-yield bonds this year will probably be around half the $99.7 billion raised in 1999, according to Merrill Lynch. In October, only seven high-yield bond issues came to market, raising a total of $1.63 billion. In October 1999, 17 high-yield bond issues raised $3.3 billion from investors.
Meanwhile, the sickliness of the corporate bond market is also seen in the rising interest rates that high-yield issues must pay to attract investors. According to Merrill Lynch, such bonds now yield 13.34 percent, up from the 10.3 percent demanded by investors in September 1998, when Long-Term Capital Management was sinking and the capital markets stood still. And high-yield bonds are trading at yields that are almost 9 percentage points higher than comparable Treasury securities. The difference between those two yields is called the spread.
Today's high yields and high spreads suggest that investors realize that many companies issuing high-yield debt confront much greater risks than they faced two years ago. That is because in the crisis of 1998, even though one big participant was teetering, the overall balance sheets of most issuers remained healthy. Then, the underlying credit fundamentals of high-yield companies were better than they are now, according to Ravi Suria, the convertible bond analyst at Lehman Brothers who became famous for his in-depth and scathing report on Amazon.com last June (from which its stock never recovered). In a recent report on heavy debt among telecommunications companies, he argues that the market's current problems will be more difficult to emerge from. He said that is because the problems are tied to declining credit quality of underlying issuers that have continued to add leverage in the face of falling growth rates.
Diane Vazza, head of global fixed income research at the Standard & Poor's Corporation, agreed: "We are now in the 10th consecutive quarter where we have seen downgrades of corporate debt outpace upgrades. The last time we saw that was in 1990-1991, when we had 11 consecutive quarters of downgrades during a period of record defaults."
Some things are already worse. Last year, Ms. Vazza said, 89 companies with debt that was rated defaulted on $24.2 billion in securities; so far this year, 85 companies have defaulted on almost $24.7 billion of debt. In 1991, when the country was in a recession, 65 companies defaulted on $19.8 billion of debt.
Adding to the unease over the higher default figures of today, companies are defaulting on their bonds more quickly than they have historically. Mariarosa Verde, a director in the loan products group at Fitch, a bond rating company in New York, said: "We looked at defaults by issuance date and found that 84 of the 152 bonds that defaulted this year were issued in 1997 and 1998. That's 55 percent, which is very significant."
For most of the 1990's, high-yield issuers have defaulted in four years on average, not the two to three years that is becoming common. What these companies are running into, Ms. Verde said, is an unaccommodating market just when they need to refinance.
THERE'S another measure by which things appear worse today than in the recessionary period of 1990: how much lenders are recovering after a company emerges from bankruptcy. Robert J. Grossman, group managing director at Fitch, said his company had tracked recoveries made by lenders between 1991 and 1997. He found that lenders holding unsecured debt -- those that stand well back in the creditors' line -- got back on average 40 cents on the dollar invested.
But, in the past three years, unsecured lenders have received 23 percent less on average, or 31 cents on the dollar, because defaulters are so overextended. "The asset values just aren't there," Mr. Grossman said.
Perhaps the greatest surprise to bond investors has been the seemingly overnight collapse of the credit ratings of once high-quality corporations. "Coming out of left field, a number of investment grade companies like Xerox, J. C. Penney and Laidlaw fell off a cliff, going straight from investment grade to distressed," said Martin S. Fridson, chief high-yield strategist at Merrill Lynch.
Some investors fear that the woes of such former blue chips may signal a looming recession, but Mr. Fridson does not. He views the distressed state of the bond market to be the result of too much loose money chasing too many untested companies.
While the stock market partied heartily in recent years with hundreds of initial public offerings that shot straight into the stratosphere, the euphoria was even more evident in the high-yield bond market, where companies of questionable credit strength go for money to fund their operations. It has grown from $213 billion 10 years ago to $508 billion today, Merrill Lynch says -- far beyond the growth of the economy.
Naturally, as the market ballooned, so did the risks. Jack Hersch, a private investor in distressed securities in San Diego who ran research at M. J. Whitman, a New York investment firm, described the change in the junk bond market: "Ten years ago you had good companies with bad balance sheets, that were overleveraged. Very rarely did you have bad business models. Now in some sectors you have truly bad business models, poorly run companies that may have no reason to live."
Such speculation is one thing in the ephemeral world of dot-coms. It is another in an economic backbone sector like telecommunications, where most of the money needed for expansion has been raised in the high-yield bond market. According to Merrill Lynch, telecommunications bonds made up an astonishing 18.6 percent of the market on Sept. 30. The next industry group, cable television, had just 8.63 percent.
"The telecom area is venture capital masquerading as high-yield," Mr. Hersch said. "You had businesses that had good stories to tell and only future earnings to point to." Now, those earnings are in doubt.
Mr. Suria's report compares recent capital spending by telecom companies with spending on other large infrastructure programs in history -- railroads, highways, the telephone system and nuclear power plants. He notes that the enormous spending by telecom companies has never been done before in an unregulated, free-market environment.
This is significant because regulated industries like utilities, and monopolistic enterprises, like the railroads when they were built, can bank on guaranteed income from consumers that can be used to pay interest on the debt amassed to build the projects. But given the intense price competition in telecommunications, Mr. Suria wrote, lucrative cash flows from customers are no sure thing.
That makes many of these bonds precarious indeed.
The precipitous decline of technology stocks in recent months is also contributing to the high-yield bond market's woes. That is because investors who were willing to lend to speculative companies took some comfort in their holdings as long as these companies' stocks -- and overall market value -- were riding high.
"Through 1997, their franchise value or market value was growing and the future outlook for these companies was improving enough that they could add debt without it being too risky," said Allen J. Levinson, managing director of K.M.V., an analytical and advisory firm in San Francisco that specializes in credit risk. "Since then, many of these companies have continued to add debt at a consistent pace, but their market values have stopped growing or are growing at a slower pace. As a result, the market leverage of the companies has grown rapidly and so has their probability of default."
Mr. Suria is also troubled that other indebtedness that is not easily identified is growing at many corporations. These less visible forms of debt include so-called vendor financing, increasingly popular at technology companies, and syndicated lending by banks to new companies.
Vendor financing usually involved a company -- Lucent Technologies is an example -- using its high-grade balance sheet to finance equipment that it sells to customers with weaker credit profiles. The buyer gets the equipment at much lower interest rates than it would otherwise have been able to get from a bank.
But the seller takes on the risk of lending money to a speculative company. And indeed, last month, Lucent warned investors that it was increasing its expenses to cover bad debts from its customer financing. The news sent Lucent's stock reeling, and it dropped 32 percent in a single day.
Syndicated lending by banks is also largely hidden from investors' views, Mr. Suria pointed out. Last summer, federal regulators reviewed large loans made by banks across the nation. They found that classified credits, loans that are defined as substandard, doubtful or lost, increased by almost 70 percent this year over 1999.
On Wall Street, there's another worrisome factor: As the high-yield market has grown in recent years, the number of brokerage firms and banks willing to trade the securities has declined. Some of the decline stems from mergers in the financial services industry, but even the firms that still stand ready to facilitate their customers' purchases and bond sales have sharply reduced the amount of money they are willing to offer for this business.
Mr. Fridson estimated that since 1998, the capital that firms were willing to commit to make secondary markets in high-yield bonds has been slashed by at least 50 percent.
Another important change is that a much wider array of investors now hold these high-yield bonds. In 1990 and 1991, that market stumbled as the country sank into recession and the Resolution Trust Corporation made matters worse by forcing savings and loan institutions to sell their high-yield bonds at fire-sale prices. Most hurt then were financial institutions that were holding these securities; today, the risks in the market are more widely spread among financial institutions, insurance companies, sophisticated investors like those who put money in hedge funds and individual buyers of high-yielding mutual funds.
This shift of ownership has good and bad aspects. On the plus side, some financial institutions may wind up in better shape after the next peak in defaults because they carry less of the total amount of troubled securities than they did the last time around. If these institutions are not at great risk, then the chances of an economic meltdown are reduced.
But some analysts fear that even if Mr. Greenspan cuts interest rates in coming months, it may not help this situation. The cost of debt capital for high-yield telecom companies is 15.6 percent;if the Fed eases by 200 basis points, it wouldn't substantially lower their costs.
Furthermore, since the huge growth in capital spending that has fueled economic growth in the United States was largely funded by high-yield bonds, when the market freezes, it cuts off access to capital. When a big growth engine stalls, the economy could get hit hard.
