HEADLINE: FIVE QUESTIONS for JAMES E. COPELAND JR.;
Can Accounting Firms Live With New Rules?

BYLINE: By JONATHAN D. GLATER

 BODY:
THE Securities and Exchange Commission voted last week to adopt rules for accounting firms that will impose restrictions on the consulting services auditors provide to clients. The rules seek to prevent situations in which auditors have an incentive to skew their reports to make the advice they had provided look more impressive.
The most contentious restriction in the rules, which take effect next year, forbids auditors to operate the advanced technology systems of their clients, although they may consult on information technology projects if the client makes all management decisions. 
 The rules also limit audit firms to 40 percent -- measured as a share of total hours worked -- of a client's internal audit work, to prevent an external auditor from evaluating its own employees' internal audit.
A fierce early critic of the proposed restrictions was James E. Copeland Jr., chief executive of Deloitte & Touche.
Mr. Copeland now says that he generally supports the rules. He discussed his initial concerns and the reasons he is less worried now. Following are excerpts from the conversation. JONATHAN D. GLATER
 
Q. What were your initial fears about the impact of the rules as first outlined by the S.E.C.?

A. Our biggest concern was that the rule would be a de facto requirement that we dismantle our firm and sell off the consultancies and other competencies that really are needed to do a competent audit.
You need a world-class team of people that cross a lot of disciplines, in order to provide adequate audit service, because an auditor to some extent serves as a general practitioner or general contractor. There is no way that you're going to have a person whose background is in education and auditing, for example, also trained in actuarial science.
In consulting, you have talented people with these different backgrounds, and you have to allow them to work on things that are state of the art for them. Auditing is not necessarily state of the art for an actuary or a technologist, so you have to be able to give them a chance to work on the problems that are cutting edge in their professions. Otherwise it is impossible to retain them.

Q. How much of your revenue comes from the consulting business?

A. Deloitte Consulting probably represents around 50 percent of our business in the United States.
But that's not all the consulting that we do, and that's the problem: The rule would've affected every consultative aspect of what we do.
Potentially, our tax consulting might have been at risk, or our information security consulting.

Q. What is the significance of the restriction on the amount of a client's internal audit work that an accountant can perform?

A. I don't think the 40 percent limit makes any sense, that number is just a way of compromising. It doesn't make any difference whether you're getting audit support from your own people or from an accounting firm.
The rule will create some artificial limitations on how much we can do in a given situation. A client will have to decide, O.K., we've used firm X for 500 hours this year on internal audit outsourcing, now we can't use them anymore.

Q. Will the rules hamper accounting firms like yours that want to provide consulting services relative to pure consulting companies?

A. In fact, I see them at a competitive disadvantage. If you want to install a new e-business system, there are some massive tax implications in that. You can deal with those issues independently or you can deal with them in an integrated way, and we believe that a client would prefer to deal with them in an integrated way.

Q. What is the likely long-term effect of the rules on the consulting services offered by accounting firms?

A. There will be heightened sensitivity around this issue and I am sure that will have some impact on clients' purchasing decisions this year. But over time, the market will buy consulting services from the best provider of that particular service. I think that's just economics.

HEADLINE: GRASS ROOTS BUSINESS;
City Survives a Flood, But Faces an Exodus

BYLINE: By JOEL KOTKIN; Joel Kotkin is a senior fellow at the Davenport Institute for Public Policy at Pepperdine University. His column on the Main Street economy appears the third Sunday of each month. E-mail: grassrts@nytimes.com

DATELINE: GRAND FORKS, N.D.

 BODY:
KEN TOWERS had planned to be retired by now, but nearly four years after a flood devastated his two restaurants and much of this city of 47,000, the 62-year-old restaurateur is still struggling to stay ahead.
Mr. Towers said 51 inches of water from several days of rain in April 1997 destroyed the equipment at his two restaurants, driving him out of business for nearly a month. Flooding at his home also forced him to live with relatives. "It was like the feeling you have after the death of a close friend," Mr. Towers said. 
 Yet despite the damage, Mr. Towers's two restaurants, a Wendy's franchise and his own Italian Moon pizza parlor, are back in business, as are most other businesses in Grand Forks, located in the northeast corner of the state on the Red River.
But Mr. Towers now faces what he calls "a financial cancer" -- roughly $500,000 in loans from the Small Business Administration needed to rebuild his business -- and that makes retiring in the foreseeable future almost impossible.
"People here don't tend to give up," said Mr. Towers, who traces this determined spirit to the strong religious faith shared by many local residents. "We are stronger, more resilient. We have the pioneer attitude -- we are not simply going to give up everything we have and move to Phoenix."
But if Grand Forks has come back to life, it remains, like many places in the vast stretches of the Great Plains, an economically troubled place. In addition to the flood, the city's economy has been weakened by a sustained agricultural recession, the recent closing of a local missile base and a persistent "brain drain" of younger, educated people.
The aftermath of the flood remains the most evident problem. Randy L. Newman, president of the First National Bank North Dakota, which is based here, estimates the flood wiped out as much as $1 billion in net worth of residents and businesses.
But other, more fundamental problems also worry Mr. Newman. The city's continued reliance on agriculture, he fears, provides little of the kind of economic growth entrepreneurs like Mr. Towers will need to meet their debt obligations. Taxable sales in Grand Forks, for example, have remained below the level of Fargo, the state's largest city, for over a decade, and overall economic growth has been torpid despite the strong national expansion.
"Until we change our economy, Grand Forks is going to be steady, slow and stagnant," said Mr. Newman, 46, whose bank building was severely damaged in the flood. "We are already stuck in very low growth."
These problems are clearly evident in the downtown area's 12 square blocks.
After the flood, the old central core looked like a war zone. A fire that started in the wake of the flood destroyed 11 buildings, and some residents and officials thought the whole area, across the river from Minnesota, should be abandoned.
INSTEAD, the city, using federal disaster aid as well as local bank loans, rebuilt much of the downtown, restoring many early 20th-century buildings.
Several small parks, graced with public sculptures, flourish today, as do many restaurants, coffee shops and bars. Yet the economic recovery remains spotty, with building vacancies running at least 25 percent.
To entrepreneurs like Mr. Towers, rebuilding the downtown is both a source of pride and contention. Given the massive debt that limits business expansion here, Mr. Towers wonders if the funds spent on restoring that part of the city may have been better used in helping other businesses throughout the region.
"The city did a great job," said Mr. Towers, whose two restaurants are located on the city's outskirts, "but you can see the vacancies. People elsewhere could have gotten more."
The biggest long-term problem facing Grand Forks, Mr. Towers and many other local residents say, is not misplaced priorities but a rapidly aging population and the steady loss of younger, educated people. Two of Mr. Towers's three children have left the state -- one daughter moved to South Carolina, another to Vermont.
"This is a great place to educate a family and raise kids," Mr. Towers said. "But people have to leave if they want to make a decent living."
Since the flood, the city's population has dropped to 47,000 from 52,000. The impact is especially noticeable at the city's schools. The kindergarten class of 2000, for example, is down by 100 from 1997, a decline of more than 12 percent. Most years, the graduating class from the three high schools in Grand Forks gets smaller as families move to Fargo, Minneapolis and places outside the region.
The loss of younger people, Mr. Newman and other community leaders say, is slowing the city's transition to a more high-technology, information-oriented economy.
On the surface, the city has powerful assets, most notably a public education system that sends roughly 80 percent of its high school students to college, as well as the presence of the University of North Dakota.
But Gerald H. Groenewold, president of the Energy and Environmental Research Center at the University of North Dakota, said 70 percent of the graduates from his university and from North Dakota State University in Fargo leave for other states.
"Unfortunately, our biggest high-value export has been people," said Dr. Groenewold, whose research center has been among the leaders in keeping its staff in the area.
The university's faculty and students, he said, helped create companies like Meridian Environmental Technology Inc., which provides computerized weather projections.
Leon Osborne, the company's founder and a professor of atmospheric science, has hired 25 local people, and he finds a large number of students are eager to stay in Grand Forks. Yet most talented students, he said, do not find adequate opportunities for advancement and eventually move on to other places.
"I've seen so many brilliant students come and then leave," Mr. Osborne said. "It's not only that they leave but they can't come back."
PART of the problem, many local residents say, lies in the North Dakota culture. The very stolid spirit that allowed for rebuilding the city from the flood also works against financing start-ups, whether in technology or other fields, said David Badman, who runs a custom jewelry business in the restored downtown.
"There's a very conservative farm attitude," he said. "You'd rather give away money to some guy with a tractor than to a creative person or computer entrepreneur."
Mark Schill, 23, who runs a small Internet business in downtown Grand Forks, agreed. "People here tend to be into cash flow," he said.
That tendency has been reinforced recently because the flood has left many residents too preoccupied with debt to take risks.
"We could survive the flood and start again," Mr. Schill said, "but we won't survive if we don't change how we do things here."

HEADLINE: INVESTING WITH: Katherine Schapiro and Stacey Ho;
Wells Fargo International Equity Fund

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD

 BODY:
DON'T worry about the raised voices behind the closed door at Wells Capital Management in San Francisco. It's just Katherine Schapiro and Stacey Ho, co-managers of the $240 million Wells Fargo International Equity fund, clashing over Japan again.
"We're good friends, but we are very well-known in the company for our discussions, usually loud ones," said Ms. Schapiro, who wants to buy more Japanese stocks for the fund. 
 Ms. Ho, who was raised in Japan, countered, "The mistake that most foreigners like Kate make is not understanding that Japan is a socialist country. You don't get rewarded for making changes." So far, she has convinced Ms. Schapiro to stay on the sidelines until Japan seems like a better bet.
Such outcomes from their heated debates have been good for shareholders. The fund returned 17 percent a year, on average, for the three years through Thursday, compared with 11.4 percent for its foreign stock peers, according to Morningstar Inc.
Ms. Ho, 43, and Ms. Schapiro, 41, scour the world outside the United States, looking for value mostly among the 10,000 or so companies with market capitalizations exceeding $1 billion. They whittle these down by looking for annual per-share earnings growth likely to exceed 10 percent over the next 12 to 24 months, and price-earnings multiples below a Morgan Stanley global index, excluding the United States, that is now about 21 times projected earnings over the next 12 months.
Finally, they boot out companies with what they view as extreme political, currency, economic or liquidity risks, among them those based in Malaysia, Indonesia and Russia.
From the 300 remaining stocks, the managers use five factors to select the 65 to 70 stocks in the fund. Ranking each factor from No. 1, or least favorable, to No. 5, they then calculate a composite score.
The first two factors examine potential earnings growth and various valuation measures, depending on the industry. For banks they review the multiple of price to book value, or net worth. For telecommunications companies, they review the ratio of price to earnings before interest, depreciation, taxes and amortization, or Ebidta. In both cases, the lower the better.
To evaluate management, Ms. Ho said, "We look at whether they are expanding operating margins, and whether they implement what they say they will do, like cost-cutting."
They assess sentiment by looking at whether a stock is being accumulated by investors or sold off, Ms. Schapiro said, and by assessing the market appeal of the company's products or services.
They take a closer look at country risk, like changes in government policies; individual company risk, like major product transitions; and currency risk.
They further reduce risk by diversifying across countries, regions and industries. Its biggest stakes are in Britain, 16 percent; Japan, 14 percent; France, 12 percent; Germany, 8 percent; Switzerland, 6 percent; and the Netherlands, 5 percent.
Most stocks fit into major global, regional and industry trend categories the managers have identified. Right now, they are shifting from pricey growth stocks, especially in technology, into food, drug and other traditional value stocks. They are also buying into the global trend toward outsourcing corporate tasks like payroll administration, product testing and manufacturing.
Ms. Schapiro and Ms. Ho sell stocks when a company's financial performance deteriorates, when they see increased risks or when they lower their opinions of management. The fund's turnover is a modest 35 percent a year.
Corporate outsourcing led the managers to Ase Test, a semiconductor testing firm in Taiwan, whose shares are traded on the Nasdaq. They bought shares in September 1999 for $23, adding more in October when prices fell to $15.43 because of domestic banking problems and concerns about tensions with China. The company tests computer chips from the design stage to the final product.
"Some of the biggest semiconductor manufacturers are based in Taiwan, so they benefit from the proximity," Ms. Ho said, adding that she expects earnings to grow 30 percent a year over the next three years. On Friday, shares closed at $14.88.
THE managers also found value in Total Fina Elf S.A., a global oil and gas company traded on the New York Stock Exchange. The company was formed when Total, in France, bought Petrofina, in Belgium, and Elf Aquitaine, also in France. The company has excellent reserves, Ms. Schapiro said, but it trades at a discount to competitors like Exxon Mobil and Royal Dutch Petroleum. She said it had excellent cost-cutting opportunities.
The fund bought shares in October 1996 for $39 each, adding more in October of this year for $71.63. Shares closed Friday at $70.38.
In February, the fund bought shares in Elan, traded on the Big Board, for $36 each and more shares in October for $51.93. Elan, a specialty drug company in Dublin, now focuses on products used in cardiology, neurology and pain management. It is developing a vaccine for Alzheimer's and treatments for Parkinson's, Crohn's disease and multiple sclerosis. Even so, Ms. Schapiro said, it trades at a discount to major drug companies and other specialty drug firms. She expects earnings to grow about 20 percent a year over the next three years. Its shares closed Friday at $50.56.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 14; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 407 words

HEADLINE: The Ruin of Myanmar

 BODY:
The Southeast Asian nation of Myanmar is a case study in repression and misgovernment. For 12 years a secretive military junta has ground down the liberties and living standards of 50 million people. By banning most contact with the outside world and buying off the leadership of restive ethnic minorities, the junta has deflected serious challenges to its rule, despite the dismal failure of its economic policies and spreading social ills.
The military has ruled Myanmar since 1962, when it was known as Burma. After the violent suppression of a democracy movement in 1988, an even more ruthless set of generals took charge. They permitted elections in 1990, then ignored the results when democratic forces led by Daw Aung Sang Suu Kyi won an overwhelming victory. She has spent 6 of the past 11 years under house arrest. Other leaders of her party have been relentlessly persecuted, university students have been relocated from the cities, and unions and civic associations have been prohibited. The junta has banned computer modems, e-mail and the Internet and made it a crime for people to invite foreigners into their homes. 
 The Times's Blaine Harden recently reported that Myanmar, which a half-century ago had one of Asia's best health care systems and highest literacy rates, is now near the bottom in these and many other measures of development as government spending has been diverted from schools and health care to the military. Most people now live on less than a dollar a day. Drug smuggling and AIDS have grown explosively and threaten to spill over to neighboring countries like China and Thailand.
The United States has led international efforts to isolate Myanmar through economic sanctions, including a ban on new investment. But other Asian countries have been reluctant to apply pressure. China, in particular, has helped sustain the junta through military aid. But an increasing number of countries are losing patience. Last week the 175-member International Labor Organization took the unusual step of condemning the junta's use of forced labor and invited member countries to impose sanctions. A good start would be restricting trade and investment in areas of the economy that profit from forced labor. Washington too should consider additional steps like encouraging disinvestment by American companies. Myanmar's people deserve international support in their struggle against a destructive tyranny.

HEADLINE: INVESTING: FUNDS WATCH;
A Manager Practices What She Preaches

 BODY:
It stands to reason that the prime money manager for the United Nations pension fund would be a booster of global investing. In its $850 million acquisition of Fiduciary Trust International, which runs six mutual funds and manages money for institutions, late last month, Franklin Resources acquired such a booster in Anne M. Tatlock, who will continue as the Fiduciary Trust chief executive.
In global equity accounts, Fiduciary Trust has kept 55 percent abroad, 45 percent in North America, all year. Ms. Tatlock maintains the currency losses on foreign investments have about run their course. "The dollar is not likely to be appreciating 30 percent ad infinitum," she said. "The United States is not the only country that has improved inflation." 
 Besides continuing to run its own funds, Fiduciary Trust will advise the Franklin Templeton mutual funds, owned by Franklin Resources. Fiduciary Trust manages about $16 billion of the United Nations pension fund, one financial industry executive said.

HEADLINE: A New Social Security

 BODY:

To the Editor:
The measures proposed for Social Security ("A Retirement Plan That Wall Street Likes," Economic View, Nov. 12) are bailing water out of a sinking ship. Social Security is a pyramid scam, since retirees get more out than they pay in. The column advocates transferring more income in the form of higher payroll taxes, and cutting benefits, and alleges that this marginal adjustment would cost less than funding the privatization shortfall out of the budget surplus. 
 This adjustment would only keep Social Security afloat for a projected 75 years. Before then, payroll taxes will have to be raised again and again. The only moral and practical solution is to phase out Social Security, and allow individuals to plan for their own retirement.
 
TYM PARSONS
Seattle, Nov. 14

HEADLINE: President's Proclamation

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18

 BODY:
Following is the text of President Clinton's Thanksgiving Day proclamation.
 
Thanksgiving 2000
 
By the President of the United States of America
We have much to be grateful for this Thanksgiving Day. Our Nation is free, prosperous and at peace. The remarkable growth in human knowledge and technological innovation offers real hope for defeating the age-old enemies of humanity: poverty, famine and disease. Our dynamic economy continues to generate millions of new jobs, and, as wages rise and unemployment falls to its lowest level in more than a generation, millions of American families are sharing in the bounty of this great land for the first time. 
 Sharing in God's blessings is at the heart of Thanksgiving and at the core of the American spirit. At Plymouth in 1621, the Pilgrims celebrated their first harvest in the New World thanks to the generosity of their Native American neighbors. In return, the Pilgrims invited these tribal members to share in their harvest festival. At Thanksgiving this year and every year, in worship services and family celebrations across our country, Americans carry on that tradition of giving, sharing not only with family and friends, but also with those in need throughout their communities.
Every generation of Americans has benefited from the generosity, talents, efforts and contributions of their fellow citizens. All of us have been enriched by the diverse cultures, traditions and beliefs of the millions of people who, by birth or choice, have come to call America their home. All of us are beneficiaries of our founders' wisdom and of the service and sacrifice of our men and women in uniform. While Americans are an independent people, we are interdependent as well, and our greatest achievements are those we have accomplished together.
As we celebrate Thanksgiving, let us remember with gratitude that despite our differences in background, age, politics or race, each of us is a member of our larger American family and that, working together, there is nothing we cannot accomplish in this promising new century.
NOW, THEREFORE, I, WILLIAM J. CLINTON, President of the United States of America, by virtue of the authority vested in me by the Constitution and laws of the United States, do hereby proclaim Thursday, November 23, 2000, as a National Day of Thanksgiving. I encourage all the people of the United States to assemble in their homes, places of worship and community centers to share the spirit of fellowship and prayer and to reinforce the ties of family and community; to express heartfelt thanks to God for our many blessings; and to reach out in gratitude and friendship to our brothers and sisters across this land who, together, comprise our great American family.
IN WITNESS WHEREOF, I have hereunto set my hand this seventeenth day of November, in the year of our Lord two thousand, and of the Independence of the United States of America the two hundred and twenty-fifth. WILLIAM J. CLINTON

SECTION: Section 4; Page 1; Column 1; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 1355 words

HEADLINE: Victory Lapse;
One Way to Break a Tie: Start the Next Race

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
WILL Terry McAuliffe, the Democratic fund-raising king, get his wish and become ambassador to the Court of St. James's? Or will Andy Card, the deputy White House chief of staff in Bush I, be promoted to chief of staff in Bush II?
Will Martin Peretz, the publisher of The New Republic and a Gore mentor who last week mocked Gov. George W. Bush as "ordinary" for naming his dog Spot, become the Bebe Rebozo/Vernon Jordan figure of the Gore administration? Or will Robert Bartley, who runs The Wall Street Journal's editorial page, which skewered the vice president for mounting "A Gore Coup d'Etat," serve that role for Mr. Bush? 
 Will Jon Bon Jovi and Ben Affleck and other entertainers who stumped for Mr. Gore in the campaign's waning days get to sleep in the Lincoln bedroom? Or will Heather Locklear and Bo Derek, who pitched in for Mr. Bush, be hanging out in the residence?
Twelve days after the unelection, no one knows how to keep a rendezvous with destiny -- not the politicians, not the lobbyists, not the chatterers in the press, not the hangers-on, not the sycophants, not even the White House interns.
"They've all got whiplash now because they don't know who to play up to," said Mike Murphy, a Republican strategist. "It's a real upside-down world right now."
The effect of all this confusion and anxious calculation is that some strategists are already moving on to the midterm election of 2002 -- and the presidential campaign two years after that -- to plot how to position themselves and their party for best advantage. With the presidential election essentially a tie -- and the House and Senate enduring the closest margins in nearly half a century -- a brutal war, to break the tie in two years or four, is beginning.
The problem, however, is that no one knows how the war should be fought. H. L. Mencken once wrote that "democracy is the theory that common people know what they want." But the split verdicts have left politicians wondering what the people truly want.
Do voters want fierce partisans, championing their core issues? Or do they want the combatants to join forces and get something done?
Senator Charles Schumer, Democrat of New York, believes cooperation is the key. "The only message that comes across," he said, "is one that looks from high up above and says, 'They better work together' and 'We're afraid of one party having too much power.' That's what the American people are saying. It's certainly possible that people will misread that message. But they do so at their peril."
Not so, said Representative Joe Scarborough, a Florida Republican who was elected during the Gingrich revolution of 1994. Tensions over the scrambled outcome are so roiling his constituents, he said, that they are spoiling any hope of bipartisanship. "People are calling our office crying, saying, 'They're stealing the election from us. What can we do?' " Mr. Scarborough said.
Meanwhile, in Florida, The Associated Press reported, Mr. Bush led Mr. Gore by 926 votes with all the absentee ballots counted. Legal challenges and hand recounts continue.
Flying blind, politicians may have to start taking chances. For example, if Mr. Bush wins, should the House Democratic leader, Richard Gephardt, invite him to lunch in a play for bipartisanship? Or should he keep his distance, hoping that if nothing gets done, Democrats will be primed to reclaim the House in 2002? If Mr. Gore wins, the House speaker, Dennis Hastert, must make similar calculations, or rather, guesses.
Senator John Breaux, a Louisiana Democrat, said a great deal hinges on who does not become president and the note of his concession speech. "The losing speaker is the most important speech of the campaign, because that person is going to set the tone for the next four years," Mr. Breaux said. "If he urges cooperation, it will be extremely helpful. If he says, 'The election has been stolen from me, and I'm going to run again the next time,' nothing will get done."
BUT even given the most gracious loser imaginable, politicians in both parties say they foresee fierce battles between Congress and the new president. "You look at the electoral landscape and we're about as divided as they come," Mr. Scarborough said. "You wonder if a candidate exists that can begin to even unite these various demographic factions."
The one certainty in all of this is that politics remains a struggle for power, and if anything, the unstable balance between the two parties will increase the intensity of that contest.
Right now there are two theories about which party will gain from this election. The traditionalist theory says the winning party will gain; the other, stealth, theory, is that this time around, the loser is the winner.
The party that loses the presidential election, said Senator Robert Torricelli, a New Jersey Democrat, will win the elections in 2002.
In fact, even as the candidates cling desperately to every possibility of capturing the White House, there are plot-and-scheme crowds in both parties quietly savoring the possibilities of losing.
One prominent Republican refused to speak publicly about his hope that Mr. Bush would lose, saying, "It's treason."
A well-known Democrat said of Mr. Gore: "I've got a lot of psychic energy invested in him. But there's an argument that if you take the win now, you're almost setting yourself up for a loss in the next two cycles."
For people like these, winning the White House would be a poisoned chalice. They contend that the losing party will be so bitter, and Capitol Hill so deadlocked, that the loser will be in a perfect position to sweep right in four years hence and rescue the presidency from a man who never deserved it in the first place.
This year, "the winner may be the guy who's holding the bag on recession, the bag on gridlock, the bag on a split Congress," said Roger Stone, a Republican strategist. "In four years, people are going to ask whoever is president: Did you solve the Social Security problem? Did you solve the Medicare problem? Did you solve the prescription drug problem? The better part of valor here may be to step aside."
Naturally, others argue just as forcefully that such ideas are nonsense, that the presidency is the indispensable prize. "Why give up?" said Representative Robert Wexler, a Democrat from Palm Beach, Fla. "Once you lose and the other guy is inaugurated, it's over. And four years is a long time in politics."
After all, Americans these days seem to move from crisis to crisis without looking back. Exhibit No. 1 is impeachment; President Clinton emerged intact, and his accusers are the ones who suffered.
"At the end of the day, people will want their president to govern," said Gov. Tom Ridge of Pennsylvania, a Republican. "I don't think they want whoever lost the race to pollute the air with the notion that somehow it's illegitimate."
This year, nobody has any idea how politicians or the public will regard the loser. If Mr. Bush wins, will Mr. Gore be reviled by his own party for losing the White House after eight years of economic boom? Or will he be treated as the king-in-exile, robbed of the White House and deserving to return? David Axelrod, a Democratic strategist in Chicago, believes a losing Mr. Gore would be "the presumptive front runner" in 2004.
MR. BUSH, if he loses, faces similar questions, though he is a more popular figure in his party than Mr. Gore in his.
"If the party perceives that he was done in by post-facto rule-making in Florida," said Steve Forbes, who ran twice for the Republican nomination, "he would have the moral standing to establish himself as the equivalent of a shadow government."
Of course, some people think Mr. Axelrod and Mr. Forbes have it dead wrong. Among the few in Washington who seem sure of themselves these days are two shrewd lobbyists: Haley Barbour, a former Republican national chairman who advises the Bush campaign, and Tommy Boggs, a Democrat. They are partners in the Caucus Room, a new bipartisan restaurant with a pricey wine list. They expect to survive, even thrive, whatever the electoral outcome.

LENGTH: 1798 words

HEADLINE: Global Warming Moves From Impassioned Words to Modest Deeds

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON

 BODY:
Forget the diplomats dithering over protocols and the scientists agonizing over equations. The next wave of the global warming debate is about nuts and bolts. In the New York metropolitan area and in other cities and states, ordinary people in corporations and government -- engineers, teachers and bureaucrats -- are quietly beginning to plan for a future in which climate and geography may be decidedly different.
Many steps are tiny and incremental and uncertain. Many are also self-contained, in some cases the result of a single individual in a city or state agency who has taken up the issue. But environmentalists and politicians say that early steps, in a field where the time horizon stretches into decades, are often the most crucial because they set the patterns and precedents that future generations in the region are likely to have to build upon if the full potential of global warming becomes real. 
 "There's still scientific uncertainty, without a doubt, about what climate change will bring," said William D. Solecki, a professor in the earth and environmental studies department at Montclair State University in New Jersey and a director of a recent federal study on the effects of planetary warming on the New York metropolitan region. "But there's a growing recognition that the future will be different from today."
On Long Island, the Army Corps of Engineers is looking at how to help communities protect themselves from rising sea levels that could bring storm surges miles inland. On Wall Street, El Nino seminars and weather-risk financing have become hallmarks of the newly climate-conscious. In some New York City public schools, complex fluid-dynamic equations of global warming are used to teach math and environmental consciousness.
In New Jersey, which environmentalists say is one of the most active states in coordinating climate-change policies, the state government has begun an aggressive program of buying out property owners whose homes or businesses are in vulnerable flood plains. State economic development officials have been enlisted to promote the idea that global warming defenses can even encourage economic growth, through an energy-efficiency program that helps businesses reduce emissions of greenhouse gases and save money on utility bills.
"It's a balance -- you have to look out in 50- and 100-year increments, but you also have to grapple up front, what your preventative measures can result in now," said New Jersey's commissioner of environmental protection, Robert C. Shinn Jr.
Some experts say the new activity is a product of the region's reservoir of intellectual and financial capital, some of which is finding an outlet in climate-change work and tapping specialties as diverse as energy, oceanography and risk management.
The United Nations, for instance, has become a leading research center on global climate issues. Columbia University's Earth Institute has taken the lead in examining local climate consequences, and the financial district is expected to become a global player in the climate-change economics that are involved in such systems as international trade in greenhouse gas emissions credits. How such a trading system should work is a main agenda item at the international global warming conference now under way in The Hague.
"The metro area is a powerhouse of global warming stuff," said Michael Glantz, a senior scientist at the environmental and societal impact group within the National Center for Atmospheric Research in Boulder, Colo. "There's a lot of innovation, awareness, intellect and knowledge." What's missing, he said, are coordination and communication. "People are still working in their own worlds and not crossing lines," he said.
There is also a sharp disagreement about what the region's approach should be, particularly whether governments should focus on adapting to an inevitable future, or on efforts to mitigate greenhouse gas emissions and thus to try to change that future, if only in a marginal way.
Some groups, like Environmental Defense, a private conservation group, argue that local and state governments in the region should be actively preparing people for a significantly altered terrain in which some coastal areas may have to be surrendered to the rising seas. Scientists at Columbia have projected a worst-case scenario in which the sea rises nearly four feet in the metropolitan area over the next 100 years, an increase that researchers said would pose particular risk to river estuaries.
Most politicians, on the other hand, especially in New Jersey, have adopted what they call a no-surrender policy, vowing to protect at all costs waterfront communities and the millions of dollars in tourism and tax dollars they represent.
Some environmentalists have criticized New York City for declining to join an international federation of cities coordinating efforts to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. Members include Los Angeles and Chicago and, more locally, Bridgeport, Conn., and Newark and Maplewood, N.J.
New York's defenders, including Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, say the city already has the lowest per capita emissions rate of greenhouse gases of any large city in the nation because its reliance on mass transit reduces automobile use, a main source of greenhouse gases.
The city, the mayor has said, is working on the problem in its own way. The Department of Design and Construction, for example, which oversees development and renovation of city government buildings, issued guidelines last year focusing especially on energy-saving technology, from fiber optic lighting to geothermal heating and cooling. The guidelines are being incorporated in 15 pilot projects, from the Queens Botanical Garden to Bronx Criminal Court.
The broader plan, though, is to lead by example and hope that the designs catch on in the booming private construction trades, said Hillary Brown, an assistant commissioner at the department's office of sustainable energy. After electricity and natural gas and heating oil prices began climbing this year, she said, private contractors' and owners' interest in the new techniques has climbed, judging from the jump in requests for copies of the guidelines.
In New Jersey, private corporations with large international operations are working with the state to cut greenhouse gas emissions. Johnson & Johnson, the pharmaceutical giant in New Brunswick, signed up with the state's greenhouse gas plan this summer and is putting it into action at its corporate units within the state. The next step: taking the plan to its worldwide corporate operations. "In New Jersey, we will lead and the rest will follow," said Johnson & Johnson's corporate energy director, Harry Kauffman.
In many ways there is no single future to prepare for but rather a wide array of possible futures, because global warming does not necessarily mean simply a hotter climate. Altering the planet's system of heat and precipitation -- the result, many scientists say, of burning fossil fuels that release gases like carbon dioxide into the atmosphere -- is also expected to increase weather variability and heighten storm damage.
Climate also varies and evolves naturally over time, aside from human influence. Average global temperatures were warmer at the last millennium, the year 1000, than they are today. But the "Medieval warm period" was then followed by nearly 500 years of sharply colder temperatures, "the little ice age." Temperatures began rising again in the mid-1800's, at the same time that the Industrial Revolution, with its reliance on the burning of fossil fuels, was developing.
A group studying the effect of altered weather conditions on New York City's water supply is considering one scenario in which the region is hotter and wetter in 2050 than today, and another scenario in which it is hotter and drier. Some researchers are looking at how rising salt water could contaminate underground aquifers on Long Island, and others are looking at whether alternative distribution systems like new aqueducts or water tunnels might be necessary once the rainfall pattern changes.
Other effects of a new climate are completely unknowable. Doctors at the New York State Department of Health say that a warmer weather pattern in the 21st century could make the region more hospitable to foreign diseases like the West Nile virus, which was first detected locally last year. But human factors like an increasingly older population with weaker immune systems and the growth of international travel to exotic locales make the ebb and flow of the biosphere so complex that there is no way to prepare for a specific climate-induced health threat.
"You have to anticipate the potential that there could be an introduction of some new diseases related to this," said Dr. Dale L. Morse, the director of the division of infectious disease at the New York State Department of Health. "But climate is only one of several factors we are looking at, and it's hard to say what weight one factor may have over others."
Some planners are also afraid to share ideas, apparently out of concern about alarming the public. Scientists and environmental groups say that the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey has begun a comprehensive internal examination of how climate change could affect the region's transportation network, especially how runways at low-lying airports like La Guardia and Kennedy International could be protected from rising waters.
Port Authority officials declined repeated requests to discuss their analysis or research. A spokesman, Steve Coleman, said researchers were concerned that preliminary ideas would be misconstrued as definitive plans.
In other cases, climate goals are bumping against old-fashioned reality. In Brooklyn, a pilot science curriculum using sustainable energy as the thread to teach concepts about fossil fuels, gas emissions and climate has been tested in a few high schools over the last several years. But experts in environmental education say the program's future is in question because the State Regents exam, which all students must pass to graduate, still relies on traditional science.
And some researchers are looking backward for possible lessons about climatic future. Energy conservation is considered one of the prime ways in which institutions and individuals can reduce greenhouse gas emissions. But Dr. Morse said that energy-saving efforts in the 1970's could have been partly to blame for the spread of Legionella pneumophila, or Legionnaires' disease. To conserve energy, Dr. Morse said, many hospitals reduced the temperature of their hot water by a few degrees, and that slight difference was apparently enough to allow the disease to propagate.

SECTION: Section 1; Page 30; Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1081 words

HEADLINE: Italian Sociologist's Goal: Make Opium Farming Fade Into History

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE

DATELINE: TASHKENT, Uzbekistan

 BODY:
Like the other former Soviet republics on the drug route dubbed the New Silk Road, Tajikistan lacks the resources to combat the flow of narcotics from neighboring Afghanistan en route to Russia and Western Europe.
Afghanistan is now the world's largest producer of opium, the base of a multibillion-dollar international heroin trade that feeds European addiction. 
 If Pino Arlacchi has anything to do with it, however, opium should become as much part of history in Afghanistan as it now is in Thailand, which is getting ready to open a museum of opium.
Mr. Arlacchi, a 49-year-old Italian sociologist and expert on organized crime, became the United Nations' top antinarcotics official three years ago. Years of studying and writing about the Italian Mafia, he said, convinced him that the war on narcotics does not have to be fought with armies and tens of millions of dollars.
As he spoke, Mr. Arlacchi (pronounced are-LOCK-key), was flying over the snow-covered peaks that separate Uzbekistan from Tajikistan, on his way to open a new, experimental drug-control agency established with United Nations help in the Tajik capital, Dushanbe.
Over the last year, the fledging Tajik agency and a force of 11,000 Russian border guards have reported seizing about 1.3 tons of heroin from Afghanistan and Pakistan. This is equivalent to amounts intercepted in Europe or the United States, Mr. Arlacchi said.
Opium poppy cultivation on a significant scale is now found in only three countries: Afghanistan, Myanmar and Laos. With the help of a $60 million international fund, Laos promises to be free of opium in five years, Mr. Arlacchi said. Myanmar, formerly Burma, is down to 60 percent of recent production because of pressure from neighboring Southeast Asian nations. Vietnam and China have also slashed opium growing.
Law enforcement is not the only, or even the most important, part of trying to convince poor farmers to stop producing narcotics, Mr. Arlacchi said. "First of all, we have to convince people that organized crime is not invincible," he said, recalling similar experiences in Sicily. "We are not fighting enemies that are bigger than us."
Now he is saying to skeptical governments that most narcotics production can be eliminated more cheaply than most people think. "The farmers do not get rich with opium production. In Afghanistan, at $30 a kilo of opium, you are poor even if you produce 10 kilos. The farmers get a minimal amount, so it's easy to provide them an alternative. Even with the traffickers, who are supposed to make most of the profit at origin, we're speaking about quite modest profits at the source."
"So when I told people that for $25 million a year for 10 years we can eliminate opium poppy production in Afghanistan, nobody believed that," he said. "Even now, when I tell people that $3.5 million invested in technical assistance to the agency in Tajikistan and the Russian border troops there, we can block the northern heroin route, people don't believe because they are used to inflated figures."
By Tajik standards, for instance, the 300 members of Tajikistan's new antidrug squad -- chosen, trained and equipped by European experts -- are very well paid at $100 a month in hard currency.
The money, contributed by several European nations, goes directly to the squad members, not to the government, to minimize opportunities for corruption.
Mr. Arlacchi argues that in an age of mass communication "every peasant in the most remote areas of Myanmar or Afghanistan knows perfectly that what he is doing is harmful for other people," and is receptive to alternatives. But, he said, alternative crops sometimes take too long to show a return, meaning that aid is needed -- to people and governments.
In Afghanistan, however, few foreign governments want to deal with the Taliban, preferring a "ring of security" around Afghanistan to contain the problem. Mr. Arlacchi said he is consistently refused money to work inside Afghanistan.
It is also not clear how sincere the Taliban is in its pledges to halt opium production. Their militias, who now control an estimated 95 percent of Afghanistan, face hunger on a national scale and political disaster if they end opium production without offering people alternative incomes.
When the Taliban order poppy production cuts, Mr. Arlacchi said he sees the edicts as "more a way to test the cost of a measure like this than a real, serious attempt to implement it."
In Tajikistan, the United Nations drug-control program cultivated ties with the pro-Russian president, Emomali Rahmonov -- a task that Mr. Arlacchi said was easier than getting the backing of the United States for a program that has so far spent $2.6 million.
Mr. Arlacchi, a tenured professor of sociology at the University of Florence who left a safe seat in the Italian Senate to join the United Nations in 1997, is one of several outsiders hired by Secretary General Kofi Annan for their real-world expertise.
The Italian newcomer ruffled feathers at the United Nations' drug program headquarters in Vienna, removing several top bureaucrats and dispatching others into the field, away from their desks.
A few weeks ago, Mr. Arlacchi visited Bolivia, which is within months of declaring itself free of coca cultivation, and found the backlash against a coca ban there reminiscent of his Sicilian experience. "There was a moment," he said, "when the economy in Sicily got bad and there were demonstrations of thousands of workers against us -- construction workers with billboards saying: 'We want the Mafia back because the Mafia gave us jobs.' "
"In Bolivia, there are very harsh times, and you get demonstrations of coca producers, cocaleros, who have exactly the same platform: 'We want to go back to cultivating coca because it gives us an income,' " he said. "I told the Bolivian government that they have to be firm not giving in, but at the same time they have to listen to them and go ahead and give more resources."
In Thailand, Mr. Arlacchi recalled, the king told him about a village where there was resistance to changing a water course to irrigate fields. The farmers finally admitted that redirecting the water channel was impossible because there was a ghost in the way. They asked the king, who is considered superhuman by many Thais, to deal with the ghost. He said he would, and the water soon flowed to the needy new crops -- at no cost at all to the United Nations program.

HEADLINE: PRO FOOTBALL: NOTEBOOK;
More and More, Coaches Earn Their Keep

BYLINE: By MIKE FREEMAN

 BODY:
When it comes to head coaching salaries, the Jets' Al Groh is earning the National Football League equivalent of minimum wage. His $800,000 salary ranks near the bottom in his profession.
But the Jets (6-4) are getting a big bang for their buck. If you were to take this on a prorated basis for each victory (which, of course, you can't), Groh is earning about $133,000 a victory. Compared with some more stratospheric coaching salaries, his is bargain basement. 
 Especially when Groh's deal is compared with Mike Holmgren's. The Seattle coach-general manager is the highest-paid coach in N.F.L. history at $4 million this season. The Seahawks are 4-7, so Holmgren is earning a nice $1 million a victory.
Like everything else in sports, like player salaries, ticket sales and television contracts, the salaries of N.F.L. head coaches have skyrocketed. With an increase in coaching stress, pressure and responsibilities come fatter paychecks.
"They're higher principally because so many coaches have total control," said Art Modell, the Baltimore owner. "That started the inflationary spiral of the salaries."
In other words, blame Jimmy Johnson.
When Johnson left the Dallas Cowboys in 1993, after guiding them to Super Bowl victories, he stayed out of coaching for two years, eventually joining the Miami Dolphins. But before taking the Dolphins job he wanted total control, meaning Johnson wanted final say on things like the draft and free agency. He also asked for, and received, a multimillion-dollar yearly salary.
Johnson was not the first football guru, but he was the first to have all of the power while also commanding a large payday. Soon after Johnson, a legion of coaches, like Bill Parcells and Tom Coughlin, began insisting on total control as part of their coaching packages. In the process, they were paid more money.
Another reason for the large salaries? As the paychecks of players increase, some owners and general managers made a wise calculation -- they needed the salaries of their coaches to at least be in the same universe as that of their players. You cannot have a coach earning the equivalent of pennies while a player raked in the gross national product of some nations.
When Washington Coach Joe Gibbs retired from football after the 1992 season, he was the highest-paid coach at the time, earning $2 million a year. Now, his salary would barely crack the top 10. In the mid-1990's, Rich Kotite, then the coach of the Jets, was making $400,000 a year; Bill Parcells, then the coach of New England, made $1.2 million a year; and Dan Reeves, then the Giants' coach, made $1 million a year.
Coaching salaries are among the most closely guarded secrets in the sport, but a collection of owners, general managers, coaches and agents gave some insight into just how high the salaries have risen.
Several owners estimated that, in the past decade, coaching salaries have increased about 100 percent. Almost all of the top 10 highest-paid coaches make more than $2 million. Several, like Denver Coach Mike Shanahan and Tennessee's Jeff Fisher, make around $3 million, and Holmgren earns $4 million.
Many in football think coaches deserve the big paychecks. To be certain, they consistently work 15- to 20-hour days, they spend little time with their families during the season and some have health problems because of stress.
But no one should feel sorry for them, either. This is what they chose to do. They love it and, more than ever, they are highly paid for it.
"The salaries are just going to keep rising," Modell said. "There's no end in sight."
 
Dolphins' Taylor Soaring
When the Jets play at Miami today, they will once again see one of the top, but underrated, defensive players in the league: Jason Taylor.
Taylor is having the best season of his career and one of the best of any defensive end in the league. Last week, with his 12-yard sack of San Diego quarterback Moses Moreno, Taylor raised his sack total to a career-high 10 for the season. He also tied the franchise record for consecutive games with a sack, with six.
Taylor is one of the quickest ends in the N.F.L. and is also one of the best athletes of any end in football. He has good sack numbers, and he is equally adept at stopping the run -- his 49 tackles are among the leaders at defensive end.
A Jets coach said Taylor was a major concern for the Jets' offense.
Taylor often deceives offensive linemen because he looks smallish. Taylor stands 6 feet 6 inches tall and has a lanky build, but he weighs a solid 260 pounds. He is quick enough to get around the average tackle but has enough bulk to jam a team's running game.
Taylor is a big reason the Dolphins have one of the best defenses in the N.F.L. and why Miami seems a lock to make the playoffs.
 
George Muddles Through
It has been a rough few weeks for Tennessee's Pro Bowl running back, Eddie George, one of the toughest players in football. He has sprained his knee and sustained a stinging sprained big toe on his right foot. The latter injury irritated him so much that he received a cortisone shot in the toe last week just so he could get through practice.
George is wearing down. Part of the reason is that he has recently faced some of the best defenses. The Titans' last four games have been at Baltimore, at Washington, then home against Pittsburgh and Baltimore.
George is always the focal point of any defense, so defensive coordinators emphasize to their players to punish him physically. And since George is fearless, he rarely runs out of bounds to avoid a tackle; in fact, he likes collisions.
Tennessee can perhaps afford to rest George in spots and allow his body to heal because the team's remaining six games are not that difficult. There are two against Cleveland and contests against the struggling Dallas Cowboys, Cincinnati Bengals and Jacksonville Jaguars. The only difficult contest is at Philadelphia on Dec. 3.
The Titans could risk not playing George against Cleveland and Cincinnati and still easily beat those teams.
 
Chargers' Losses Mounting
San Diego is without a victory in 10 games and has a realistic chance of not earning a victory this season. The Chargers have lost games in every way possible: blowing leads, fumbling the football in the final minutes and missing field goals that could have gained them a victory.
Last week against Miami, the Chargers discovered yet another creative way to lose a football game. In that contest, three San Diego quarterbacks threw interceptions: Moses Moreno had two and Ryan Leaf and Jim Harbaugh each tossed one.
The last time that happened in an N.F.L. game was in November 1995, when three Green Bay quarterbacks -- Brett Favre, Ty Detmer and T. J. Rubley -- all threw picks against Minnesota.

HEADLINE: Long Wait for DNA Result Can Be Justice Delayed

BYLINE: By C. J. CHIVERS

 BODY:
Sometimes, when he awakes in his bedroom, Miguel Camacho is overcome by tightness in his chest. It is painful, he says, to feel his heart beating so fast. Other times, he imagines he is back in his bunk on Rikers Island, awaiting trial for a rape he did not commit.
"I wake up, thinking, 'I'm still in here?' " Mr. Camacho said. "I'm thinking, 'Who's going to help me? Who's going to get me out?' " 
 Mr. Camacho, who was wrongly labeled a violent sex offender this fall, became caught in a frightening trap in modern law enforcement. Jailed on the strength of a witness's word, he faced a long wait before DNA tests proved his innocence.
In the last decade, as the use of DNA has become commonplace, police departments and prosecutors have called this new forensic technology the most important identification tool since the advent of fingerprinting. But for all of DNA's promise, there exists a persistent gap between its potential and its use.
Because of staff shortages and backlogs of evidence at forensic laboratories, the turnaround time for results is often slow. Although forensic labs in New York are in the midst of expansion, it can still take months for DNA tests to be completed, meaning that cases that could be solved quickly are delayed, and, in some cases, the wrongly accused wait in pretrial confinement before DNA proves their innocence.
Such was the case for Mr. Camacho, a resident of the South Bronx who has never been convicted of a crime.
On Sept. 27, he was placed in a police lineup in front of a Parks Department employee who earlier that day had been raped and robbed at gunpoint in Bronx Park, near the New York Botanical Garden. The woman told detectives that he was the rapist.
Although Mr. Camacho, 24, had never met the victim and had three alibi witnesses who said he was home asleep at the time of the crime, it did not matter. He was arraigned the next morning on first-degree rape, first-degree robbery, weapons possession and 12 other charges. He was sent to Rikers Island without bail, and, as an accused sex offender, placed alone in a cell under protective custody.
For nearly a month he prayed, he cried and he told anyone who would listen that he was innocent -- actions that are hardly unusual in any prison, anywhere. Mr. Camacho said one fellow inmate, a Black Muslim who roamed the corridor like a self-appointed cleric, heard his alibi, and said, simply and inaccurately: "Nine out of 10 people who come here never leave." Even the nun who counseled Mr. Camacho saw him as yet another defendant who said he did not do it.
Although the city, prodded by his defense lawyer, rushed his case through its forensic lab, it still took a month before the comparison of DNA taken from the victim to DNA taken from Mr. Camacho's blood proved what he had said all along: the authorities had charged the wrong man. Mr. Camacho was released in late October. The police now say they have identified another suspect, a sex-crime recidivist whose DNA profile is in a law enforcement database and whom they hope to arrest soon.
DNA experts say this case, and others like it, including those of 82 wrongly convicted inmates throughout North America who have been released from their cells in recent years after DNA proved their innocence, highlight the need to expand forensic labs, and to accelerate the turnaround time for test results.
"Those of us who have advocated for law enforcement's use of DNA should have made a better connection to DNA's exonerative power long ago," said Christopher H. Asplen, executive director of the federal government's National Commission on the Future of DNA Evidence.
"Almost every time you identify someone from a database," he said, "you exonerate someone who has been caught up in a web of suspicion through traditional investigative techniques."
Mr. Camacho, a soft-spoken man who said he was so afraid of his fellow inmates that he did not venture into the prison yard during his entire stay, is not the only innocent man to suffer a false accusation.
In June, Capt. Garrick Benson, an active-duty Army officer, was pulled over by the police in St. Louis and charged with rape, sodomy and burglary in an attack on a 25-year-old woman. Two weeks later, DNA proved that he did not commit the crime. The police have since arrested another man, who was linked to the crime by DNA.
In New York, cases move much more slowly than that, although the forensic laboratories run by both the state and city are expanding, and officials hope to cut test time over the next five years.
At the city medical examiner's office, which conducts DNA analysis on all biological evidence collected in rape examinations, cases typically take two or three months. But the department, which had 37 employees solely dedicated to DNA analysis in January, now has 65 assigned to the task, and plans to have 582 employees and new laboratory space and equipment by 2004. "Once we are fully staffed, there will be no reason we can't turn around cases in one week," said Ellen S. Borakove, the laboratory's spokeswoman.
The State Police Forensic Investigation Center in Albany is undergoing a similar expansion.
It had 30 employees in January, and his since hired 65 more. The new equipment and staff are underwritten by $13.2 million in the state budget earmarked to improve the use of DNA in criminal investigations, a roughly 17-fold increase from the $750,000 the state spent on the technology in 1995. The laboratory's officials hope to cut its turnaround time, which can now take months, to 30 days by next fall.
In many respects, Mr. Camacho, for all his ill fortune, was lucky to be freed in only one month. The authorities say this case received accelerated handling only after the Legal Aid Society lawyer assigned to it, James A. Rogers, sent all three alibi witnesses to testify before the grand jury. The witnesses were convincing enough that the assistant district attorney agreed to push for the DNA tests to receive immediate attention.
Once the results came back, Mr. Rogers said, they showed that unless DNA results are readily and quickly available, cases that rely solely on eyewitness testimony will continue to harm the innocent. He noted that the victim of the rape in Bronx Park had sincerely believed that Mr. Camacho was her attacker, and she was wrong.
"Identification evidence always has to be taken with a grain of salt, regardless of the fact that the witness is positive, regardless of the good intentions of the police and everybody else involved," Mr. Rogers said.
"If we relied on the witness in this case, and if there wasn't the DNA, Miguel Camacho would still be on Rikers Island."
Jane Siegel Greene, the executive director of the Innocence Project at the Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law at Yeshiva University, which has helped 42 inmates in North America overturn convictions through DNA testing, said Mr. Camacho's case, like others, fit a type.
"We find in 90 percent of DNA exonerations, faulty eyewitness identification was a major factor in conviction," Ms. Greene said.
"The beauty of DNA is that it shows the systemic failure of our systems," she added. "There needs to be corroborative evidence in eyewitness cases. People are being convicted on eyewitness accounts alone, and it is a scary thing, when you see these consequences."
Mr. Camacho is home now, living with his mother and grandmother in the Bronx. He seems more relieved to be out of his cell than angry that he had been put in it. But he said he continued to suffer consequences from the charges.
There are indignities small and large. They range from the frustration of not having his winter jacket -- the police have yet to return his personal effects -- to his surreal dreams.
He said he also worried about what his neighbors think after seeing his name, photograph and address in news media coverage in which he was described as a terrifying sexual predator -- a man who stripped his victim at gunpoint, and then, after raping her, threw her clothes in a tree, forcing her to run naked through the streets in search of help. He knows of only one television news program that later told viewers he had been wrongly accused.
"I still get people giving me faces, like, 'Yo, we got to watch over him,' " he said.
Moreover, Mr. Camacho, who was unemployed when he was arrested, said he had been unable to find work. Each time he fills out a job application, he said, he is asked if he has ever been arrested. He has to answer yes, he said. Then he has to list the charges: rape, robbery, criminal possession of a weapon, on down the line.
"I try to tell them what happened, but, you know, it's of no use," he said.
"I leave and they're like" -- he made a motion like a basketball free throw -- "there goes my application, into the can."

HEADLINE: COUNTING THE VOTE: THE REPUBLICANS;
Election's Lessons Become Focus for G.O.P. Governors

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr.

DATELINE: WESLEY CHAPEL, Fla., Nov. 18

 BODY:
The Republican Governors Association ended its annual meeting here today with its new chairman, Gov. James S. Gilmore 3rd of Virginia, declaring that "against this background" the meeting had been the best ever for the group.
He might just as easily have declared that "against this background" the meeting had been the most frustrating ever for the group. 
 The "background," of course, was the still up-in-the-air outcome of the presidential race in Florida.
The governors were gathered here, at a golf resort just north of Tampa, not because Florida was the scene of the most disputed election in modern memory but because it was Florida's long-scheduled turn to play host to the yearly affair. Their program originally called for them to discuss such things as governing in the New Economy, but the Florida balloting brouhaha so dominated the two-day meeting that they all but junked their scheduled discussions and focused instead on the fairness, and unfairness, of the American electoral system and whether, indeed, it could endure.
They concluded that it probably could -- but only if Democrats were persuaded that their seemingly endless challenges to the system were slowly but surely eroding confidence in it. And even if the erosion were stopped, they said, it would be best before the 2004 election to take a fresh, hard look at how to prevent another Florida-style recount.
"We have to somehow reassure Americans of the integrity of the system," said Gov. Tom Ridge of Pennsylvania, going on to suggest, as did many of his colleagues, that states needed to develop better voting procedures and machines.
Publicly, just about all of the 26 governors in attendance here said they were confident that in the end the most prominent member of their group, George W. Bush (who did not show), would prevail. But in asides in the hallways of the conference center they used the words "hope" and "frustrated" far more often than the word "confident."
And early this afternoon, during the final news conference of the meeting, the frustration finally boiled to the surface and spilled over, very loudly and very publicly.
Governor Gilmore had just finished saying "I don't believe anybody is discouraged" about where Election 2000 was headed when Gov. William J. Janklow of South Dakota, never less than outspoken, stepped forward, leaned into the microphone and offered a different opinion.
"There's nothing we can do," he began, his voice quaking and rising. "They're going to steal the election. We all know it. But what we can do is start now changing the rules for the next election. You know how we send observers to other country's elections? Well, we're at the point where others are going to have to start sending observers to watch us."
Governor Gilmore tried again, taking back the microphone and offering that perhaps it was not "wise" to anticipate too much about the future.
Earlier, during one of the conference's formal sessions, Gov. Bill Graves of Kansas said the current American election system was "a Crock-Pot process in a microwave age."
Gov. Bob Taft of Ohio also called for revisions in the way the nation votes. "It needs to be made more reliable," he said. "What's happened here in Florida is a wake-up call for modernizing the system."
But while there was much talk at the conference here of modernizing the current election system, there was no concerted call for federal intervention or for taking any steps that might raise constitutional questions, such as doing away with the Electoral College. In almost every case, governors said it should be left to individual states to modernize their systems, and in most cases they spoke only of streamlining and simplifying rules and procedures, along with installing better balloting machines and processes.
"This is more a matter of working with what we've got," Governor Gilmore said. "We certainly don't need any federal involvement and we most certainly should avoid any fundamental changes in the system. Retuning, yes. But no more. In fact, if people had just followed the laws and procedures already on the books, this mess in Florida would have been cleared up days ago."

HEADLINE: Defiant Chinese Muslims Keep Their Own Time

BYLINE: By ELISABETH ROSENTHAL

DATELINE: KASHGAR, China

 BODY:
In this far western outpost, where a Muslim majority lives restively under Chinese rule, you can tell a lot about a man's politics by how he sets his clock.
For the last half-century, China's Communist leaders have required the entire country to mark the hours by Beijing time, even though this far-flung city of veiled women, spice markets and donkey carts should be two, probably three, time zones behind. In Kashgar, in Xinjiang Province, really living by Beijing time would mean getting up in total darkness nearly 365 days a year. 
 So many local Muslims, defiant and increasingly disaffected, set their watches two hours behind Beijing, a nod both to nature and their separate identity. "The Chinese want us to follow Beijing time, but most of us are unwilling," said a young soda vender named Abduljim, whose timepiece on a recent morning read 7:45, when the official time was 9:45. "We are Uighurs -- Muslims -- we should follow Xinjiang time, our time, here."
Time, like almost everything else here in Kashgar, has become suffused with questions of power, control and ethnic divisions -- between the dominant Chinese and the native Muslims, Uighurs who speak a Turkic language and are culturally related to the peoples of nearby Central Asia. And in recent years, those divisions have intensified greatly, as more Chinese move into the region and local Uighurs have fallen on economic hard times.
A small Uighur separatist movement has carried out an occasional bombing in Xinjiang and Chinese leaders rail against "splittest" activities here. But far more common are the million little acts of personal defiance -- small efforts to proclaim the difference -- like wearing Islamic dress, refusing to speak Chinese or setting your watch to local time.
The divisions are "definitely worse now that 5 or 10 years ago," said a Uighur businessman who lives in a coastal city but frequently returns home to Xinjiang. "People are angry, they are having trouble finding work, and they feel they have been left out as the country has prospered."
It is unclear whether the sum of all the grumbling and discontent is large enough to threaten Beijing's control over the region or presages larger conflict. After all, Xinjiang has been part of China for 250 years. And if the estimated seven million Uighurs who live here chafe under Chinese rule, they are also wary of the kind of Islamic militancy that has been growing in the former Soviet republics just across the border.
"People always ask, will the Uighurs go get training from the Taliban?" said Dru Gladney, a professor at the University of Hawaii who is an expert on Chinese Muslims, noting that a few have probably already gone. "Sure, if there's money there -- these people don't have much of an alternative, and they're pretty disillusioned. But if someone offers them a scholarship to Harvard, they'd take that, too."
This rising disillusionment comes in part because government programs that once assisted minority groups have dwindled, but even more because of a vast influx of ethnic Chinese into the region -- diluting the culture and taking natives' jobs.
In a province with a heavy police presence, where news is controlled and public meetings forbidden, the Uighurs protest in whatever little ways they can. "When I am there I only buy from stores run by Uighurs, even though I know the price will be higher and the quality not as good," said the businessman. "It's the principle."
He added that the crowded mosques and veiled women in Xinjiang did not reflect piety so much as protest -- people trying to display and preserve their cultural heritage. "Most Uighurs are not very religious, its just that this is the only way they are allowed to express themselves."
Although Uighurs often accuse the Chinese of actively trying to erase their culture, and for many years the Beijing government transferred state employees into the region, today many Chinese from poor surrounding areas come on their own, lured by what for them is a relatively good local job market.
"I think relations have deteriorated and become more polarized than they used to be and that has to do with the market economy," Professor Gladney said. "There has been a large in-migration of Han Chinese," he said, adding, "That has meant that the Uighurs are more marginalized."
He and other experts say that government spending cuts throughout China have only increased the Uighurs' sense of isolation; there is now less money for state television to make Uighur language programming, for example, and for documents to be translated into Uighur.
The net effect is that Uighur culture has receded in much of Xinjiang Province. Many local news programs now uses Mandarin rather than Uighur. More signs are in Chinese characters -- with Uighur script in tiny letters underneath. Urumqi, the provincial capital, has almost lost it ethnic Uighur feel, becoming just another medium-sized Chinese city of white tile office buildings.
Education cutbacks have meant that young Uighurs are not learning functional Chinese, as highly paid native Chinese speakers have been replaced by cheaper local teachers. "My sense is that language ability has dropped a lot in the last 10 years," Professor Gladney said. Without the language, the Uighurs are less able to find jobs in an economy increasingly dominated by Chinese companies.
The changes have been unsettling, pushing many Uighurs into poverty and to the fringes of cities where they once formed the heart and soul. The Uighur businessman, a successful middle-aged man who has lived outside of Xinjiang for more than a decade, said he was shocked at the level of alienation and disaffection he found on a recent trip to Urumqi, which he said stemmed mostly from economic hardship and massive unemployment.
Even college graduates have serious trouble finding jobs, experts say, since the larger companies are mostly Chinese-owned and tend to hire Chinese. Idle time has contributed to a very serious drug problem in the provincial capital.
As Uighur influence has faded in much of the province, many have come to see Kashgar -- a bustling market town, whose Sunday bazaar is filled with camels, sheep and elaborately carved daggers -- as the last holdout against the encroachments of Chinese culture, a symbol as much as a place.
People here know the latest on Rebiya Kadeer, a prominent businesswoman now jailed on charges of revealing state secrets -- her crimes included sending newspaper articles to her husband in the United States -- even though her story has not been covered in the Chinese state media. And they are also well versed in the NATO bombing of Yugoslavia last year, which some celebrate for "liberating" the Muslims in Kosovo; they fantasize about a similar "rescue" here.
In Kashgar, the tension between Chinese and Muslims bubbles beneath the surface, two people living side by side who rarely ever mix. There are Chinese businesses, and Uighur businesses; Chinese restaurants and Uighur restaurants. There is the huge People's Square, presided over by one of the country's largest Mao statues; and the equally sprawling Idkah Square, home to hundreds of vendors and one of China's largest mosques.
When, on Oct. 1, the sky in Kashgar reverberated with the boom of fireworks, a group of young Uighurs on a donkey cart could not figure out what the commotion was about. It was National Day, China's most important holiday.
"We have nothing to do with each other," one Uighur said. "The Chinese here act like they see right through us, like we're not people to them."
Then there is the issue of the time. Big stores, or those owned by Chinese, mostly quote opening hours in Beijing time, as if it were their umbilical cord to civilization. Those owned by Muslims, which tend to be small businesses, are two hours behind.
"We Chinese go by Beijing time," said a bartender named Wang, whose father was sent here to work 20 years ago. "But the Uighurs do not."
Of course, nature -- the sunrises and sunsets -- favors the Uighur point of view on this one, and in practice the Chinese here have had to make a thousand little adjustments in order to live formally by Beijing's clock.
Government offices wait until 10 a.m. Beijing time to open and stay open until 7:30 p.m. The state schools don't start until 9:30 a.m. for example, and even with that, some people grumble that in winter it is too dark for kids to go to school.
"Of course, they should start at 7:30 or 8 like everywhere else in China," said a Uighur man who gave only his first name, Imamu. "But they can't do that because of the sun problem. You can't have children riding to school in the dark."
