HEADLINE: CLINTON IN VIETNAM: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK;
The Question of Liberty, And the Lure of America

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER

DATELINE: HANOI, Vietnam, Nov. 18

 BODY:
After President Clinton's motorcade swept out of the gates of Vietnam National University here on Friday, an impromptu teach-in began on the steps of the lecture hall, as American reporters quizzed Vietnamese students about their reaction to Mr. Clinton's speech.
More than once, the students deftly turned the tables, questioning the visitors about their country. 
 "Tell me about your system of higher education," said Anh Le, 20, an English student whose unflinching gaze suggested she would not accept a token response. "I have to give a presentation to my class."
The two reporters speaking to her shifted from foot to foot -- offering some thoughts about the number of foreign students on scholarships, and trying to evoke the atmosphere of an American campus.
"How can we go to these places?" she asked. "Mobility is not the same in Vietnam as it is in the United States."
Her comments said much about the lure of the United States for young Vietnamese. But, in the soft evening air, there were hard reminders that Vietnam remains a closed society.
 
Unnecessary Chaperones
Whenever the exchanges grew animated, well-dressed men with wide smiles sauntered over and offered to translate. Since the students spoke English, the offers were gratuitous. But they were enough to shut down one young woman who had seemed eager to discuss Mr. Clinton's remarks about civil liberties.
Not everyone needed an official from the Interior Ministry to act as a chaperone. Nguyen Hoang Lien, 26, an environmental science student, dismissed the president's comments on political freedom as irrelevant.
"Since the 1930's, we have had only one political party in this country," she said matter-of-factly. "All Vietnamese agree with this."
 
Bill Clinton, Rock Star
Pick up any local newspaper here, and one would conclude that Mr. Clinton's visit is groundbreaking, a landmark, and any other word that means really important. But one would have no clue that Mr. Clinton is being treated like a rock star by people in the streets.
Most papers have covered only the formal meetings between the president and senior Vietnamese officials. While a few reported on Mr. Clinton's speech at Vietnam National University, they quoted sparingly from it, and carried no reaction from students or anyone else who heard it.
Two tabloids did offer a glimpse of Mr. Clinton's charm offensive. They ran a picture of him standing on a balcony, stretching to clasp the hands of delighted children in the house next door.
Reporters at The Vietnam News, the English-language daily, said there was no suspense about how their editors would play the trip. Visiting heads of state are memorialized on the top left-hand side of the front page; the article is always accompanied by a picture of the V.I.P. with Vietnam's president.
On Friday, true to form, the newspaper featured an article in that space under the headline, "U.S. President's Visit Hailed as New Landmark in Bilateral Ties." The photograph showed Mr. Clinton and the Vietnamese president, Tran Duc Luong, reviewing an honor guard at the presidential palace.
The last head of state to get such play was from Luxembourg.
 
. . . And the First Lady
Hillary Rodham Clinton's foreign trips have something of a routine, and today, as she has in more than 20 countries, the First Lady was host to a forum of women who are leaders here. Aides to Mrs. Clinton say these events are hit or miss: for every stimulating discussion, there is a stilted encounter.
Today probably rated as a miss. Despite a formidable lineup of business people, educators and government officials, the discussion never got off the ground. Instead, the panelists read long statements, many of which simply affirmed that equality of the sexes is enshrined in Vietnam's Constitution.
After listening for more than an hour, Mrs. Clinton looked like a Senator sitting through a filibuster. "Let me thank the panelists for a thorough discussion of the issues," she said with noticeable exasperation.
Mrs. Clinton took mild issue with the assertion that women have equal rights in Vietnam merely because equality is guaranteed in the Constitution. But she seemed eager to explore the role that women play in the Vietnamese economy and society, which is greater than in many countries.
"What is different is there is a history of women working alongside men, fighting alongside men," Mrs. Clinton said.
 
Diplomatic Chuckle
At one point during his travels, President Clinton chatted with a reporter about Warren M. Christopher, his former secretary of state, who opened diplomatic relations with Vietnam on a trip to the country in 1995.
"I bet Chris wishes he was back here right now," Mr. Clinton said with a chuckle.
Mr. Christopher, of course, is in a quagmire halfway around the world, leading Vice President Al Gore's battle to determine who won the state of Florida, and the right to succeed Mr. Clinton.

HEADLINE: COUNTING THE VOTE: THE OVERVIEW;
BUSH'S LEAD STANDS AT 930 AFTER OVERSEAS COUNT

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE

DATELINE: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Nov. 18

 BODY:
Gov. George W. Bush's lead in Florida more than tripled today as all absentee ballots from overseas were opened and tallied. But his campaign was unable to claim the victory it had expected, as both sides awaited a hearing on Monday in the Florida Supreme Court.
Just as Republicans had predicted, Mr. Bush received an overwhelming share of the overseas ballots, which came in from military personnel and Floridians living abroad, leaving Vice President Al Gore with a far more difficult obstacle to hurdle. 
 Official but uncertified figures from all 67 counties released by the Florida elections division today showed that Mr. Bush had gained 1,380 votes, or 64 percent of the overseas ballots, while Mr. Gore gained 750 votes.
That left Mr. Bush with an overall Florida lead of 930 votes, more than triple the size of his lead before the overseas ballots were counted. All counties were required to report their absentee totals by noon today, and the two campaigns spent the morning trading accusations of misconduct and manipulation over several hundred overseas ballots that were discarded because of postmark disputes.
In Austin, Tex., the Bush campaign held a news conference this afternoon at which Gov. Marc Racicot of Montana issued some of the harshest charges yet against the conduct of the hand vote count, spelling out complaints that included ballots being used as fans and punch holes covered with tape.
Mr. Racicot relayed stories from Republican observers in Florida who said they had seen Bush ballots being put in piles with Gore ballots and chads being knocked out of ballots, allowing the ballots to be counted for Mr. Gore. "This is a process that is completely untrustworthy," he said.
Democrats in Florida said a few minor incidents in Palm Beach had been blown up into a nonexistent trend by Republicans. They contend that the Bush campaign, having lost the legal battle to prevent the hand counts, is now trying to smear the process with accusations of chaos and fraud, and urged an end to the political rhetoric.
The charges and countercharges came a day after an order from the state's highest court prohibited Katherine Harris, the Florida secretary of state, from certifying all votes in Florida, including the absentee ballots, after the noon deadline today. At that point, Mr. Bush would probably have claimed Florida's 25 electors and the presidency for himself, putting the Democrats in the uncomfortable position of having to file a legal challenge to the election after it had been certified.
But the court ruled that Ms. Harris could not certify the election until after it had heard arguments on whether manual recounts in three Florida counties were legal. That hearing is scheduled for 2 p.m. Monday, and the Gore campaign submitted its first briefs to the court this afternoon urging that the certification be halted until all hand counts are completed.
"The question before this court is as fundamental as it is straightforward: whether lawfully cast and counted ballots are to be included in a vote total that will resolve an issue of paramount national importance -- the selection of the president of the United States," the campaign's brief said.
It goes on to say, "This court should direct the secretary of state to include the results of the three manual recounts now under way in the certified election returns, or at the very least, it should instruct her not to certify the result until those manual recounts can be completed and properly reviewed."
The Bush campaign's response is due on Sunday afternoon.
At the same time, the hand counts in Broward and Palm Beach Counties continued today, and the Miami-Dade County canvassing board decided this morning to begin counting its half-million ballots on Monday -- a task that board members estimated could take two weeks, including weekends, with a Thanksgiving Day break.
The board in Miami-Dade hopes to assemble 25 two-person teams of county employees to do the counts, but was having trouble finding enough people.
With Mr. Bush's lead having grown so large, the manual inspection of ballots will have to turn up a substantial number of previously uncounted votes for Mr. Gore if he has any hope of claiming victory here, even if he does win in the Florida Supreme Court.
For example, in Broward County, a Democratic stronghold that is vital to Mr. Gore's chances, the vice president had picked up only 79 votes in hand counts of 43 percent of the county's precincts. If his gains should continue at that rate in the rest of county, he would add only 186 votes through the manual recount.
A group of academic statisticians working with Florida Democrats has projected that Mr. Gore will pick up only about half the votes he needs in the three hand counts, The Miami Herald reported today, not enough to counter the lead Mr. Bush has now built up in the absentee ballots.
One of those cited in the report, Bruce Hansen, an economist at the University of Wisconsin, estimated that a hand recount might be able to produce new results from perhaps 10 percent of the 9,000 uncounted ballots in Palm Beach County.
Mr. Hansen said he was not working for the Democrats but had shared his results with professors who were.
If the added votes were to break along the lines of the original tallies, that would produce a net gain of somewhere between 200 and 400 votes for Mr. Gore in Palm Beach County, he estimated -- more if bulging or "pregnant" punch holes were counted too.
"If you add all of the forecasts of the three big counties, it's going to be lucky if Gore gets the numbers he needs," Professor Hansen said in a telephone interview with The New York Times today.
"It will be really, really a squeaker," he said. "It's just incredible how close this is to a tie."
Earlier in the week, Mr. Gore's forces said they might have a chance at an even split of the absentee votes, predicting that many Floridians living in Israel would cast ballots for a ticket that included Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, who is Jewish. But Republicans predicted all along that the overseas votes would break in their direction, just as they did for Senator Bob Dole in the presidential race of 1996.
Karen P. Hughes, the communications director for Mr. Bush, said the governor was "pleased" that his lead had increased with the absentee ballots.
"We are hopeful that once the Florida Supreme Court has heard arguments in this case, the laws of Florida will prevail and the election will be certified," Ms. Hughes said.
By this morning, when it became evident that Mr. Bush was winning nearly twice as many overseas votes as Mr. Gore, the Democrats could argue only that the number was lower than the Republicans had expected.
Each side accused the other of throwing out legitimate overseas ballots in county-by-county disputes over postmarks and proper markings of the ballots.
An Associated Press survey showed that while 2,203 overseas ballots were counted, 1,420 were discarded.
Counties applied differing standards to the acceptance of the ballots, with some rejecting ballots -- particularly those from the military -- that had no postmarks, and others following the secretary of state's advice that they be accepted.
Florida law requires postmarks on absentee ballots, but federal law says the military must mail the ballots of its personnel without postage.
Republicans charged that Democrats were trying to throw out as many overseas ballots as possible in the belief that doing so would reduce Mr. Bush's lead.
Indeed, according to an analysis of The Associated Press survey, 60 percent of the ballots were thrown out in counties that were carried by Mr. Gore, and of those that remained, Mr. Gore held a slight edge. In counties carried by Mr. Bush, only 29 percent of the ballots were thrown out, and those that remained went for Bush by a better than 2-to-1 margin.
"We're distressed that it appears there's a statewide effort on behalf of Al Gore to discredit military votes," said Mindy Tucker, a spokeswoman for Mr. Bush's campaign. "The Florida Democratic Party has been sending out instructions to their people in the counties on how to protest these votes."
The Republicans released a statement from retired Gen. Norman Schwarzkopf, who said it was a "sad day" when military personnel were denied their right to vote because of a technicality.
But Jenny Backus, a spokeswoman for the Democratic National Committee, said the decisions on whether to accept or reject ballots were made by independently appointed elected officials, not by the campaigns.
"Both sides were out in the counties, but the final decision was up to the elected boards," she said. "It's surprising to me, after a week in which they got rejected in the Florida courts for challenging the authority of locally elected Florida election officials, that they are once again doing so this weekend."
The sprawling teams of local and national lawyers assembled by both sides stayed up all night in law offices around town, conducting legal research and using hastily rented computers to prepare their briefs for the state's high court.
Although the court will be hearing three consolidated cases, the principal issue at stake before the court is whether the secretary of state has the authority to reject manual recounts submitted after the usual seven-day period for certifying election results.
Last week the court permitted the hand counts to continue, but it has not yet taken a position on the central issue of the secretary of state's authority.
A trial judge ruled that Ms. Harris could not reject the hand counts arbitrarily simply because they were late, but said she was allowed to reject them based on her own considered legal criteria.
Democrats, putting their last hope in the manual recounts, have been playing for time in the hope that Mr. Gore would overtake Mr. Bush in the hand counts. At that point, they said, Ms. Harris would be unable to reject a result that could overturn the election.
But Mr. Bush's sharp surge in the overseas ballots may eliminate that possibility.
Thus far the Florida Supreme Court, which is made up of seven justices appointed by Democratic governors, has issued two decisions considered favorable to Mr. Gore. But Monday will be the first time in the case when they hear oral arguments, and they are well aware that the world will be watching every moment, and every question they raise in the hearing, to detect any hints of the ruling to come.
The court session will be televised live, and the court will also make the session available live on the Internet.

HEADLINE: CLINTON IN VIETNAM: THE AMERICAN MISSING;
Clinton Journeys to Where Pilot Died in 1967

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER

DATELINE: TIEN CHAU, Vietnam, Nov. 18

 BODY:
The last transmission anyone heard from Lt. Col. Lawrence G. Evert's F-105D Thunderbird was only three words long: "I'm hit hard." Moments later, an American flier on a bombing run here saw what he thought was the explosion of an aircraft hitting the rice paddies.
That was 33 years and 10 days ago. It took until this year for American investigators to narrow the search for Colonel Evert's plane to just outside this impoverished village, 17 miles northwest of Hanoi, the capital, and to get approval to dig it up. 
 Then, in the weeks before President Clinton's arrival in Vietnam on Thursday, the soft, acidic earth of Tien Chau began giving up bits of wiring, bolts and plastic, clearly from an aircraft, and finally what forensic experts believe are small amounts of human remains.
They have not yet been identified.
Nonetheless, in one of the most emotional moments of his presidency, President Clinton today drove into the Vietnamese countryside, past water buffalo, a Japanese motorcycle factory and farmers tending their flooded fields, to find the site. He hiked along a bamboo boardwalk to the place where some older villagers still remember seeing a plume of smoke after an American fighter was shot down by antiaircraft fire.
He brought with him the downed pilot's two sons, who spent Friday sifting mud through fine mesh, searching for the father they last saw when he flew out of Phoenix on a hot summer day in 1967. "When we were 6 and 8 years old," David Evert said today, choking back tears as he gestured toward his older brother, Dan, "we'd talk about how we would come to Vietnam and rescue him. We kind of feel that we're doing that now."
Mr. Clinton's trip across the pocked dirt roads of this poverty-stricken section of Vietnam was intended as a vivid demonstration of how a new era has arrived, one in which Americans and Vietnamese work together, six days a week, finishing the muddy and emotionally draining business of accounting for 1,498 Americans still listed as missing in action here.
Standing in mud-covered work shoes, Mr. Clinton today called the joint search for remains a coming together of former enemies that was "unprecedented in human history." But like most of Mr. Clinton's trip here, the somber trek into the paddies was a reminder that piecing together America's relations with Vietnam is as slow and agonizing a process as looking for the remnants of Colonel Evert's fighter.
"Look, neither side is ever going to fully get past it," said Pete Peterson, the former prisoner of war who now serves as American ambassador here. "Reminders of the war are everywhere. You drive by them every day. But we can't change the past and we can change the future, and bringing the president here to talk about what we can do together -- I think that opens a lot of minds here."
It is far too early to tell what will come of Mr. Clinton's three-day visit to Vietnam. For all the enthusiasm his visit has generated among young people -- 60 percent of Vietnamese were born after 1970 -- the Communist government in Hanoi remains deeply suspicious of American intentions. Engagement sounds fine, officials say, as long as it does not loosen the party's control of the country or cause economic upheaval.
In particular, the kind of engagement that seems fine to the Hanoi authorities is the one happening out here in the rice paddies of Tien Chau. It is, without question, a remarkable sight, here and five other places around the country where Vietnamese are digging for remains of missing Americans.
Scores of villagers have signed up for jobs slicing away at the mud beneath the recently drained paddy, using a jerry-rigged device called a cheese cutter. They have a lot of cutting ahead of them: Colonel Evert's plane is believed to have tunneled a hole at least 16 feet deep.
With hardly a word, the workers put mud in buckets and pass it along by hand to a wooden platform where dozens of young women sift it, looking for anything that resembles bones or manufactured parts. Hundreds have been found, few are larger than the size of a thumb.
From the site, the workers can see a long metal railroad bridge that American forces were trying to destroy that night. Colonel Evert's plane was the fourth and last in a formation, and no one knows if he dropped his ordnance. They know he never pulled up to head south, and no one saw him eject or spotted a parachute open. A crew member on a nearby plane reported that the aircraft had been hit on the left rear fuselage by intense antiaircraft fire, an image that seemed hard to imagine today on the peaceful paddies, where children were laughing and playing on the narrow dirt road and watching the man from America who arrived with roughly 40 cars, vans and buses.
Five days after the crash, Colonel Evert's fourth child, Elizabeth, was born. His widow, Wanda, raised the children alone.
While nothing conclusive has been found, investigators seem quite certain that what they have tripped upon are the fractured remains of the F-105D. "This is a chance for them to take their family home," Mr. Clinton said today, after touring the site with his daughter, Chelsea, and his wife, Senator-elect Hillary Rodham Clinton, who said nothing in public.
David Evert said today that he had been surprised at the greeting he got from the local townspeople who came out to the site. They asked him about his other relatives, and details about his father. "They wanted to know how old we were when our father crashed," said Mr. Evert, now 39. "It's amazing how hard they work, and how dedicated they are."
It will be months, maybe years, before the Evert family knows for sure what has been dug up. DNA testing will have to be conducted on the tiny amount of remains, which will be sent to Hawaii. Plane parts will be studied for evidence that the aircraft is the one everyone thinks it is. "We can wait," said Mr. Evert, a television cameraman. "We've waited 33 years not knowing much. What's a few more months?"

HEADLINE: COVER STORY;
Bio-Tweaked and on the Run, But Her Heart Will Go On

BYLINE: By BERNARD WEINRAUB

 BODY:
JAMES CAMERON was not initially interested in making a science fiction series like "Dark Angel" for television.
 
 "I felt that science fiction on television doesn't usually work - the sets always look so cheesy," said Mr. Cameron, who struck gold with "Titanic," the 1997 blockbuster that not only won 11 Academy Awards but grossed a record $1.8 billion around the world. "I was leery. You want to create a vast future world, and it comes out looking less than that. I kept wanting to do a straight dramatic series."
 Obviously Mr. Cameron, whose earlier hits include "Aliens" and "The Terminator," was king of the hill in Hollywood and could have made virtually any film he wanted after "Titantic." But instead of plunging into another movie, he took some time off.
 "I felt I had been through two years of hell and it was, like, 'O. K., fine, I'm taking diving lessons and learning to paint. I'm taking some time for myself.' But I was thinking about television too."
 Mr. Cameron, who is 46, said he had yeared for years to involve himself in a television project but would pursue one only with an experienced writer-producer who, as he said, "had the chops, a top guy." That guy was a longtime friend, Charles Eglee, 47, who met Mr. Cameron in the early 1980's when they were both working for the cult filmmaker Roger Corman. Mr. Eglee went on to join Steven Bochoo Productions and work on series like "L.A. Law," "Murder One" and "N.Y.P.D. Blue."
 The two friends spent months sitting in the garden of Mr. Cameron's Malibu home discussing potential drama series: a hospital show, a series about a sheriff in a California border town, a family drama. But Mr. Eglee kept pressing Mr. Cameron about a science fiction show.
 "This was Jim's first foray into television, and my feeling was if his name was going to be on a TV show, you're making a certain promise to the audience," said Mr. Eglee. "This was going to be a show for Fox, and we were thinking of that particular young demographic. Ultimately we were drawn to the idea of an urban youth ensemble. And Jim said: 'What if she's genetically engineered? And she's a fugitive on the run?' And soon we were spinning and creating that world." (The initial title was "Experimental Girl.")
 "Dark Angel" - on Tuesday nights at 9 on Fox - stars an unknown, Jessica Alba, who was selected from more than 1,000 actresses, as Max, a genetically altered teenager with plenty of attitude. Max works as a bicycle messenger in the year 2019 in an anarchic Seattle half-devastated by an electromagnetic pulse set off by terrorists that has crippled the global economy. (The idea came from the apocalyptic Y2K articles in magazines and newspapers last year.) Max is on the run from the evil military program that crated her and several other genetically altered beings. Working with a wheelchair-bound underground journalist, played by Michael Weatherly, she tries to search for her bioengineered brethren, avoid capture and fight the dark forces of corruption around her.
 What led Mr. Cameron to change his mind about working on a science fiction series for television, besides a strong interest in larger-than-life themes, was his 7-year-old daughter. In creating Max, the 19-year-old messenger, Mr. Cameron and Mr. Eglee, who has two daughters, are linking some aspects of the fictional character to their children.
 "Now that I have a daughter, I guess I'm thinking ahead of time of what the life experiences are going to be that she's going to be going through in a few years, and that's going to get fed into Max's character," said Mr. Cameron.
 The show is a risk for Mr. Cameron and an even bigger risk for Fox, which has failed in recent years to build a science fiction franchise following "The X-Files," even with expensive shows like "Millennium" and "The Visitor." The two-hour pilot of "Dark Angel," shown on Oct. 3, was budgeted at $10 million, twice as much as a typical two-hour pilot. For Mr. Cameron the stakes are high because several other high-profile filmmakers, notably Steven Spielberg, have tried and failed to make the leap into television. (Mr. Spielberg's 1993-95 underwater drama, "Sea Quest D.S.V.," and his 1996-97 police drama, "High Incident," were both disappointments.)
 So far, the Cameron-Eglee series is viewed within Fox as a success. It has averaged a steady 14.3 million viewers each week and is No. 1 in the time slot among teenagers. It also seems to be holding at the No. 2 slot among adults 18 to 49, following NBC's "Frasier," which is on from 9 to 9:30 p.m. (Last year, Fox's "Party of Five" drew only 8.1 million viewers in the same time period.)
 Giles S. Lundberg, senior vice president for research and marketing at Fox, said the ratings for the show were impressive. "The show has very quickly appeared to establish itself as the program of choice on Tuesday night for teens and young adults," he said.
 Mr. Cameron said his voyage into television had been, at least for now, a productive one, and he wants to do more television with Mr. Eglee. (He will eventually detach himself from "Dark Angel," he said, to move onto some still unspecified feature films, leaving the project entirely in the hands of Mr. Eglee.)
 "What I like about television is the sheer energy of it," said Mr. Cameron. "It's also the fact that it's not one big throw of the dice like movies. You may work on a film for a year or two, and it gets slammed into a theater on a Friday. And by late Friday evening, or certainly by Saturday night, you know with dead certainty whether or not the last couple of years of yourlife have been worthwhile or not."
 Television is different, he says. "You're not wiped out in a single weekend. It's a fluid process. You can react to what the audience likes or dislikes. You can adjust. You can roll with the punches. In a way it's freeing. You can grow. I want to do more."

HEADLINE: First Woman to Lead Ivy League College Is the Highest-Paid University President

BYLINE: By JODI WILGOREN

 BODY:
The president of the University of Pennsylvania, Judith Rodin, the first woman to run an Ivy League institution, had the highest annual salary and benefits of any college president in the country in 1998-99, receiving $655,557, a survey by The Chronicle of Higher Education shows.
Dr. Rodin tops a list of presidents with steadily climbing compensation packages. Six collected more than $500,000 in 1998-99, compared with only one in 1995-96, and 74 -- nearly double the number three years ago -- earned at least $300,000. In addition, Harry C. Payne, the retiring president of Williams College, received $878,222, most of it in long-term retirement benefits. 
 Of the 10 best-compensated college presidents, four were in the New York area: L. Jay Oliva of New York University, $639,633; Richard C. Levin of Yale University, $525,687; George C. Rupp of Columbia University, $500,204; and Harold T. Shapiro of Princeton University, $456,170.
The survey of 479 private colleges was compiled from tax forms the schools are required to make public, and 1998-99 is the latest year available. The figures include salary and routine benefits like health insurance, but typically do not include perquisites like housing, cars or speaking fees. The leaders of public universities are typically paid less.
The median package was $185,721.
"It's a splendid thing when there is a prestigious salary list and a woman is on top of it," said Sheila Wellington, president of Catalyst, a New York-based group that studies women in business. A recent Catalyst study showed that 4.1 percent of the 2,500 top earners in Fortune 500 companies were women. More broadly, Catalyst estimates that women earn about 77 cents for every dollar men earn.
"Judith Rodin is an exceptional person," said Ms. Wellington, who was secretary of Yale when Dr. Rodin was the provost. "And it's wonderful to see exceptional people achieving up to their potential and being recognized and rewarded for it."
Experts in compensation and higher education attributed the swell in presidential salaries to the general health of the economy, which has sent many university endowments skyrocketing and helped innumerable presidents post record fund-raising successes. They said some universities feel they are competing with the corporate sector -- where the average compensation for chief executives was $11.9 million in 1999 -- and the bulging compensation packages reflect a transformation of the presidency in recent years.
"The technical title is still president, but you hear people talking about the C.E.O.," noted David Breneman, dean of the school of education at the University of Virginia. "We've adopted this corporate terminology."
Indeed, James S. Riepe, chairman of the board of trustees at Penn, referred to the university as "a very large company," with a $3 billion budget and 20,000 employees. And he explained why Dr. Rodin deserved the one-year rise of $107,000 in salary and benefits.
"We think we're getting value for what we're paying her," said Mr. Riepe, whose job as vice chairman of T. Rowe Price paid him $2.8 million in salary and bonus last year, according to Business Week magazine.
Martin Lipton, chairman of the board at New York University, credited Dr. Oliva with building the school's international reputation since he became president in 1991, and says the trustees pay no attention to where their institution falls on the annual list.
"It's all about the person," Mr. Lipton said. "The university is his entire life. He's there day and night, playing basketball with the kids. He is the essence of the university."
At the other end of the spectrum is Daniel L. Ritchie, who refused to accept a salary when he took over as chancellor of the University of Denver in 1989. Mr. Ritchie, the former chief executive of the Westinghouse Broadcasting Company, has instead donated more than $50 million of land to the university, a private school with about 9,500 students that was founded in 1964.
Unlike Dr. Rodin and Dr. Oliva, Mr. Ritchie happily agreed to a telephone interview.
"I really don't need the money," he said. "I've given away most of what I have, but I still have enough that I don't need the money to live."
Mike Jarvis feels differently. Mr. Jarvis, the men's basketball coach at St. John's University, was the highest-paid coach in the survey, at $860,093, more than any college president except the retiring Mr. Payne.
"I think I earn every dime that I make," said Mr. Jarvis, who, as of Friday, had a 54-18 record since arriving at St. John's three years ago. Mr. Jarvis disputed The Chronicle's figures, saying he knows several coaches with higher salaries than his.
"My definition of salary is what I get in my hands," he said. "There are some people who work for a dollar a year, because that's all they need. I'm sure that there are presidents that on paper make less than I make but at the end of the month they have more money than I have."

HEADLINE: Children's Books;
The Master Builder

BYLINE: By Paul Goldberger; Paul Goldberger is the architecture critic of The New Yorker.

 BODY:

 FRANK O. GEHRY: OUTSIDE IN
 By Jan Greenberg and Sandra Jordan.
 Illustrated. 48 pp. New York:
 DK Ink. $19.95. (Ages 10 and up)
 
 ARCHES TO ZIGZAGS
 An Architecture A B C.
 By Michael J. Crosbie.
 Photographs by Steve Rosenthal
 and Kit Rosenthal.
 Unpaged. New York:
 Harry N. Abrams. $18.95.
 (Ages 3 and up)
 
 ROBERTO THE INSECT ARCHITECT
 Written and illustrated by Nina Laden.
 Unpaged. San Francisco:
 Chronicle Books. $15.95. (Ages 5 to 9) 
 Architecture is not like sausage, something you are inclined to like only if you don't know how it's made. The process by which architecture is made is actually quite enticing. And most people don't know the first thing about it. Even people who love buildings tend to see them as pure and perfect finished objects, not as the product of months, even years, of anguish, debate, and trial and error. Accident can determine architectural form as much as intention, and who is to say how and why an architect prefers one shape over another?
"Frank O. Gehry: Outside In," by Jan Greenberg and Sandra Jordan, does more to address these questions than any book I know that has been written for adults. This is not a biography for children, though it contains a great deal of information about Gehry's life, and it is not a guide to his buildings, though there are spectacular color photographs of many of his best works, including the extraordinary Guggenheim Museum in Bilbao, Spain, the project that has probably done more than any other single building to make architecture a subject of wide popular passion today.
This book is a journey through the creative process. It is the best introduction to Gehry's architecture that we have. Maybe I should go farther and say it is one of the best introductions to architecture that we have. Like many of the best children's books, "Frank O. Gehry: Outside In" gets to the heart of its subject without any of the obfuscations of books written for adults. It brings you into Gehry's life and into his work, and it addresses the way each of these things has affected the other.
The authors, who also wrote a remarkable book about the artist Chuck Close, do use Gehry's life for a kind of basic narrative structure. We are told, often in his own words, about his childhood in Canada, about his family's financial woes, about his life as a truck driver as his family attempted an economic recovery in Los Angeles, and then about his growing awakening to architecture in general and to the artistic culture of Southern California in particular. "As he searched for his own style, he realized he had more in common with the methods of cutting-edge West Coast artists than with the standard fare of other architects," the authors say. And then they quote Gehry: "The artists were working with inexpensive materials -- broken wood and paper -- and they were making beauty."
Gehry is an easy conversationalist, not the prima donna his recent celebrity might suggest, and his words are often endearing. In one of my favorite sections, Greenberg and Jordan ask Gehry about his own house in Santa Monica, a conventional Dutch colonial that he covered with chain-link fencing, plywood and corrugated metal. "Buildings look more interesting before they are finished," Gehry says, explaining why he left the ceiling beams and joists and some of the pipes exposed. "If things look good when they are installed, why cover them up?"
I am not sure how easy it is for children to understand what Gehry means when he says: "Life is chaotic, dangerous and surprising. Buildings should reflect it." But I know that this remark can provoke a fascinating conversation among all but the youngest children about why certain buildings appeal to them and others do not, and how accurately it takes us into Gehry's way of thinking. Greenberg and Jordan understand that Gehry is not some kind of crazy sculptor, but very much an architect who is concerned with fulfilling the needs of his clients, and they devote a fair amount of space to explaining exactly how he does this and comes up with buildings that look so different from everybody else's.
Their book includes several of Gehry's best projects from the days before he became an international superstar, like the law school of Loyola University in downtown Los Angeles, a village of simple shapes arranged around a small public square, which they juxtapose with a photograph of the Roman Forum, making the connection absolutely clear. Gehry loved the way the Forum was a collection of pieces, many in ruins, and the way it tied his project, symbolically at least, to the origins of the law.
For one of his residential clients, who warmly remembered growing up near the Griffith Park Observatory in Los Angeles, Gehry designed a house that is also a kind of village, but with a copper dome over the largest section to echo the observatory. "I try to realize my clients' fantasies and create something special for them," Gehry is quoted as saying in a chapter that I love most of all for its title: "Every Building Has a Story."
Most important of all, Greenberg and Jordan make clear how slow and difficult the design process is. "After a number of quick sketches Gehry makes the first of many models," they write. "Again and again he revises. 'I'll move a wall on a model, look at it for two weeks, then move it again. And I worry about things. I'm like a mother hen.' "
"Outside In" is illustrated with a mix of first-rate color photographs (including a superb set of the Guggenheim in Bilbao), Gehry's own drawings, and computer-generated drawings that explain the role of software in creating many of Gehry's unusual shapes. It ends with a discussion of Gehry's struggle, after the acclaim of Bilbao, to avoid being pushed into making the same building over and over again. This may be one of the few books for young readers to address honestly not just the payoffs of artistic success but also the risks.
Readers who are not ready for "Frank O. Gehry: Outside In" (probably anyone under the age of 10) may well enjoy Michael J. Crosbie and Steve and Kit Rosenthal's "Arches to Zigzags," a kind of architectural dictionary in rhyme. The world does not need another A B C book, but this one is so beautifully photographed, and so clever in its choices, that you cannot not make room for it on your shelf. "W," for example, doesn't stand for window, but for widow's walk, which is illustrated by an elegant 1819 house in Salem, Mass., while "R" is for ruin, shown by the Wupatki National Monument, a 12th-century site in Arizona. The architectural terms are illustrated with color images of buildings as different as H. H. Richardson's Ames Free Library in North Easton, Mass. ("arch"), an Art Deco hotel in Miami Beach ("neon") and the John Hancock Center in Chicago ("X-bracing"), and the rhymes are clear, fun and not too cute.
ALAS, there are no limits to cuteness in "Roberto the Insect Architect," by Nina Laden. This is the tale of a termite who wants to be an architect so he can follow in the footsteps of "Hank Floyd Mite and Fleas van der Rohe." Those names tell you all you need to know about this rather insipid story, which is mainly a string of puns that exist solely to amuse adults, or children whose reading level is light-years beyond this. Roberto defies his fellow termites, who doubt that he can become an architect, and after he makes it big he gets the rewards of a television interview with Barbara Waterbugs and an offer for the film rights to his life from Steven Shieldbug.
Humbug.
 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: College Endowments Learn to Live With Risk

BYLINE: By EDWARD WYATT

 BODY:
SOME years it is the football coach. Others, the Nobel Prize-winning physicist. This year, however, the biggest celebrities among college faculty members and administrators sit not in the field houses or the science labs but in the investment offices, where they have guided endowments to record gains.
The group that oversees Duke University's endowment steered its $1.7 billion pool of capital to a 59 percent gain in the year ended June 30. The University of Notre Dame's investments gained 58 percent in the same period, those of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology jumped more than 50 percent, and at least six other large universities recorded investment returns exceeding 40 percent. Harvard's 32 percent profit generated $4.6 billion for the university, more than the total endowment of all but seven other American colleges. 
 While other investors have enjoyed similarly stellar returns in the last few years, the profits reaped recently by university endowments contrast with the staid reputation that such funds have long had, particularly among alumni eager to see their contributions invested wisely.
Those profits were generated by taking no small amount of risk -- including a heavy reliance on speculative venture capital, or private equity, where investors bet on companies at such an early stage that an entire investment can be wiped out before a product or service even gets to market.
Propelled by the roaring stock market, however, venture capital has produced triple-digit returns for many endowments by letting them make early bets on companies like eBay, Phone.com and Sycamore Networks. The biggest risk often seemed to be in having too few such investments.
Until now. Even some of the biggest fans of venture investments are warning that the rich recent returns are not likely to last.
"A lot of the money going into private equity now, I think, is going to generate very disappointing returns," said David F. Swensen, the chief investment officer at Yale and the man whom many of his peers credit with forging the new theory of aggressive endowment investment.
Indeed, recent stock market weakness, including a 40 percent fall in the Nasdaq composite index since its peak in March, has caused private-equity portfolios to give back some of the gains and raised questions about when and how well those investments actually diversify a portfolio.
Yet many colleges and universities that previously failed to move much money into the riskier assets are now trying to do so. Those schools, including the University of Pennsylvania and the University of California, face the danger of buying overpriced investments just as their value is beginning to fall.
"Institutions that were primarily focused on large-cap U.S. stocks and bonds are now saying, 'Maybe I'll make some investments in these other places,' " said Todd E. Petzel, chief investment officer for the Commonfund, which invests more than $26 billion for 1,400 colleges and universities in the United States and Canada. "But this may be an awkward time to do that. An awful lot of people are coming to this party awfully late, and they have experience only in good equity markets."
BOTH the success and the peril wrought by the performance of venture capital investments is evident at Notre Dame, where the university's venture capital investments rose 400 percent in value last year. At one point, they accounted for about 40 percent of its $3 billion endowment.
By late last month, that had fallen to about 35 percent, in part because of the sale of some stock holdings, said Scott Malpass, who manages the fund. Also taking a toll, however, was the Nasdaq's tumble, which cut the value of many companies that had only recently graduated from venture capital investments to publicly traded stocks and were still in the endowment's portfolios.
While the recent stock market decline has dented the financial strength of some universities, most are still better off than they were a decade ago, when colleges around the country were cutting academic programs and letting faculty and administrative jobs go unfilled because of financial woes.
Today, some of the wealthiest universities are experiencing a period of great prosperity. With hundreds of millions of dollars unexpectedly in hand, institutions are enjoying an unrivaled period of building and expansion. That growth has untold economic benefits for the communities around colleges and universities.
"The performance of the endowment in the last several years has certainly given us the ability to do new things," said Jeremy Knowles, the dean of the faculty of arts and sciences at Harvard. Among them are new academic initiatives like creating centers for the study of genomics and American political science. More mundane tasks "that should have been done 85 years ago" have also been attended to, he said, including air-conditioning the rooms holding valuable library collections.
So far, in most cases, increased spending has not come at the expense of the endowments' capital. Yale's endowment has grown to $10 billion from $1 billion when Mr. Swensen arrived in 1985, even as its contribution to the annual budget has risen to nearly 30 percent from 10 percent, he noted. Yet that contribution still accounts for less than 5 percent of the endowment's assets.
Clearly, if the value of the endowment were to plunge, Yale's budget would feel the pinch, as would the economy of New Haven. But Mr. Swensen said the portfolio's diversity -- with investments in hedge funds, the value of which should rise if the market falls, and real assets like timber, which do not track the stock market as closely as, say, corporate bonds -- will smooth out any short-term jolts.
Institutions that are less wealthy would suffer more in a long slump, of course, particularly if endowment income makes up a significant share of their operating budgets.
For this reason, even enthusiastic advocates of alternative investments are advising their universities not to expect that their wealth will continue to expand forever.
"It is important that we not delude ourselves into thinking that double-digit returns will persist indefinitely," Jack R. Meyer said in his annual report on the Harvard endowment. Mr. Meyer is chief executive of the Harvard Management Company, which oversees the 8,600 funds that make up the endowment.
Investing in venture capital and other exotic assets has only recently begun to catch on broadly at American universities, according to the National Association of College and University Business Officers, which each year surveys endowments at more than 500 American colleges.
As of June 1999, the end of the most recent fiscal year for which complete figures are available, only 8 percent of the average college endowment was invested in alternative assets like real estate, hedge funds, oil and gas partnerships, distressed securities, arbitrage opportunities and private equity, which includes venture capital and leveraged buyouts. Such investments make up more than 20 percent of larger endowment portfolios, including those of Harvard and Yale.
AND where the average endowment has 54 percent invested in American stocks and 24 percent in bonds, larger endowments put far less money there -- an average of 43 percent and 18 percent, respectively.
By taking bigger risks in a bull market, big endowments have outperformed their smaller peers. Endowments with more than $1 billion in assets gained an average of 18 percent annually from 1995 through 1999, according to the survey by the business officers association. Those with $300 million to $1 billion in assets gained 16.9 percent, and those under $300 million gained less than 16.5 percent, on average.
Mr. Swensen of Yale, who laid out his arguments for long-term investments in venture capital and other nontraditional assets in a recent book, "Pioneering Portfolio Management" (Free Press, 2000), has been advocating their use for years.
A professorial man who eagerly shares the credit for Yale's endowment success with his investment team, Mr. Swensen said his belief in the value of nontraditional endowment assets came out of his review of the long-term needs, goals and methods used by portfolio managers.
Endowments are, he observed, the ultimate long-term investors, with no plans to cash out, ever. Unlike pension funds, they have no guaranteed benefits for which they are responsible. Most universities pay out a certain percentage of the endowment to support the budget each year, but that payout can be changed, usually by a vote of the trustees.
Mr. Swensen concluded that rather than favoring predictability in choosing investments, endowments should embrace risk, and they can do so in a way that is not available to many other institutions and individuals.
Endowments can afford to own risky investments in volume, he said. They can buy commercial property in one area and residential space in another, for example, where the local economies are fueled by different industries. The values of those investments are more likely to be independent of each other than are corporate bonds and domestic stocks.
Recognizing the need to invest in other types of assets was one thing; doing so was another. When it came time to try to actively manage a portfolio of unusual, alternative investments, "we did not have all the tools we needed" to invest effectively, Mr. Swensen said.
SO, he built them. "Part of our success at Yale is the ability to create tools that didn't exist before or to use them more aggressively," Mr. Swensen said. Unable to find enough qualified firms that managed real estate, oil and gas properties and other classes of alternative assets, the Yale investment office under Mr. Swensen has put "18 to 20 firms into business" managing portions of its specialized portfolios.
When Mr. Swensen arrived from Wall Street, two-thirds of Yale's endowment was invested in publicly traded shares of American companies. Today, that proportion is down to 15 percent. In the same span, private equity has grown from almost nothing to 25 percent of the portfolio, 10 percentage points of it in venture capital partnerships focused on technology start-ups and 15 percentage points in leveraged buyouts.
As Mr. Swensen delved into venture capital and other alternatives at Yale, Jack Meyer was doing much the same thing at Harvard.
Mr. Meyer began his effort to improve Harvard's investment process by focusing on how much it cost to invest in the most desirable assets, and whether that cost was excessive for endowments, given their nature.
"I think institutions often overpay for liquidity," he said. Because endowments never need access to most of their investments in the form of cash, he said, there is relatively less risk for them in a leveraged buyout or some other high-return asset that cannot be sold quickly.
While they have both embraced alternative investments, Mr. Meyer and Mr. Swensen take fundamentally different approaches on how to oversee their portfolios. Mr. Swensen's office, on Yale's campus, consists of a small staff that oversees the portfolio strategy, but leaves the picking and trading of actual investments to outside money managers. Harvard, in contrast, directly invests much of its billions, and Mr. Meyer commands a staff of about 140 professionals housed on the edge of Boston's financial district, across the river from Cambridge.
Because of their common investment philosophies, the results at Harvard and Yale have been similarly compelling.
Harvard's endowment, for example, has gained an average of 23 percent annually over the last five years. That is about 4 percentage points above the annual benchmark return that Harvard would expect if it simply matched its target rate of return in each of the various asset classes in its portfolio.
Put another way, if Harvard had earned just those targeted returns over the last five years, the university would have $6 billion less than it now has.
The venture capital profits of Harvard and Yale have now attracted others, including the University of California, which recently raised the portion of its $5.1 billion endowment eligible for venture investments to 7 percent from 2 percent.
Another faithful advocate is Eugene J. McDonald, who retired as president of the Duke Management Company in September.
PRIVATE capital investments, which at more than 25 percent of the portfolio account for one of the largest portions of Duke's total endowment of $2.7 billion, gained 214 percent in the year ended June 30. Those investments have been so successful that their weighting in the portfolio has grown beyond Duke Management's long-term target of 15 percent; Mr. McDonald said the weighting had been "at or above the 30 percent level" at times during the last fiscal year.
One of the biggest issues aggressive endowment managers face, said Mr. McDonald, is that venture capital "is an asset class that does not easily permit rebalancing." In all but the most recent times, there is a long stretch between investment and payoff.
Venture capital partnerships are typically managed by firms that gather cash from investors, find companies with promising prospects and buy substantial stakes. The venture capital firm's principals often sit on the board and have a direct hand in its management, helping to guide the company toward an eventual initial public offering of stock.
Even then, however, the venture capitalists cannot immediately cash out. Usually, their shares are restricted from trading for a set period after an initial offering; even when the restriction is lifted, the owners can sell only a certain amount of securities each month.
Venture capital funds typically distribute shares, rather than cash, to their investors after an offering, so the universities themselves are left with thousands of shares that they are unable to sell immediately. That can spell trouble in a volatile stock market, as venture investors are left trying to unload shares that move rapidly up and down in price.
To try to reduce the risk at each stage in this process, endowment managers compete to invest with venture capital firms like Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers that have demonstrated they can attract promising new firms and pick winners.
Endowment managers say that failures among the top venture capital partnerships have numbered only a few out of several hundred investments in recent years. But those partnerships often are oversubscribed and unwilling to take on new investors. So while hundreds of venture capital partnerships raised billions of dollars in the last year, endowment managers have been calling on their alumni with Silicon Valley connections for help getting into the best funds, said Craig Carnaroli, treasurer at the University of Pennsylvania.
What makes venture capital investments worth such efforts is the payoff. Equity acquired for pennies a share can be sold for thousands of times as much in just a few years -- if the company survives.
CONSIDER Juniper Networks, which makes telecommunications equipment. In June 1996, the company sold shares to three venture-capital partnerships managed by Kleiner Perkins for the equivalent (adjusted for subsequent stock splits) of less than a penny a share. On June 25, 1999, the company completed its initial public offering, selling its shares at $5.67 apiece. Last month, Juniper's shares peaked at $243 a share.
Investors in the Kleiner Perkins partnerships received a distribution of shares sometime between mid-February and mid-April of this year, when the stock was trading at about $100 on Nasdaq. For those investors, which included Duke, Yale and many of the other large endowments, that price -- less than half the peak -- represented a profit of more than 10,000 percent.
Such returns, having been the rule in the last two years, are by far the exception over longer spans of history. Venture investors are finding that out even now.
Mr. Meyer said it was possible "that returns for the second half of the calendar year will be negative" on venture capital investments.
Indeed, for fiscal 2001, which lasts through next June, he said the entire endowment "could have a negative return year -- something that has not happened since fiscal 1984."
Still, Mr. Meyer said his diversified portfolio "has less risk than one with 65 percent in U.S. stocks and 35 percent in U.S. bonds." That is demonstrated by the recent experience of another Ivy League institution, the University of Pennsylvania.
Penn's $3.3 billion endowment is one of no more than a handful of university funds that lost money last year. Mr. Carnaroli declined to characterize the fall other than saying saying it was "a slight loss at the margin." But when compared with the gains of more than 30 percent experienced by many of the top universities, any loss looks terrible.
Part of the reason for the underperformance is that Penn's endowment has followed a strategy of value investing, buying beaten-down stocks whose financial position, long-term prospects and strategic position in their industry made them appear undervalued.
In recent years, value investing has performed badly when compared with a growth-investing strategy, one that relied more on the rate of growth in earnings or, for profitless Internet companies, in sales.
Penn also suffered because its equity portfolios had almost no correlation with broad American stock indexes like the Standard & Poor's 500, which has gained about 24 percent a year on average over the five years that ended June 30.
Mr. Carnaroli, who joined Penn from Merrill Lynch early this year, said the university had redeployed about one-third of its assets, many of them going from domestic equities to alternative investments.
"We've replaced some managers, and we now have broader exposure to the indexes," he said. "We've turned over one-third of the portfolio in the last 18 months."
But getting into the most desirable venture capital funds at this late date has not been easy. While Penn has been able to invest in some recent funds put together by Kleiner Perkins, "we got only a very small allocation" in those funds, he said.
WITH $3 billion in the bank, Penn is in no danger of going broke. But with each year of little or no growth, inflation eats away at the endowment's value.
In 1993, budget struggles caused in part by poor endowment performance led the university to close three departments. Though the endowment has grown markedly since then, Mr. Carnaroli said, "We still face significant operating pressures."
"We've had extraordinary cost increases, huge growth in our research enterprise and in the costs of things like campus security," he said. "All of those outstrip the growth in inflation."
With universities around the country facing similarly rising expenses and the financial markets jittery, endowment managers are certain to be looking more closely at alternative routes to investment.

HEADLINE: Environmentalists Applaud Votes in Nassau

BYLINE: By JOHN RATHER 

 BODY:
JOINING a regional and national trend toward increased local spending for open space and environmental programs, Nassau voters in the Towns of North Hempstead and Oyster Bay have approved $45 million in new borrowing for environmental purposes.
This was first time that residents in Nassau municipalities have voted on local proposals for such programs, a point all but eclipsed on Long Island by the tumult following the presidential election and the victory of Hillary Rodham Clinton in her Senate race with Rick A. Lazio. 
 Last week local officials and civic and environmental groups were still expressing surprise and even amazement at the results. The proposals, for $15 million in North Hempstead and $30 million in Oyster Bay, were approved by more than two-to-one margins in both towns.
In Suffolk County, where voters have repeatedly backed town, county and state initiatives to preserve farms and open space, there was disagreement over the impact of the voters' rejection of a proposal to set limits on borrowing to acquire farms and open space.
Officials and environmental groups that lobbied against the Suffolk proposal said it would have sharply curtailed borrowing against future sales-tax revenues for land and farm purchases at a time when development pressure warranted maximum spending. Taking a contrary view, officials supporting the proposal said its defeat meant there could be no borrowing. Now the issue will have to be sorted out by the county Legislature and county lawyers.
Results were more clear-cut in Nassau, where supporters of the town programs said they had feared that the county government's financial crisis and property-tax increases resulting from it would weigh heavily on voters.
"If there had not been all of the major problems with the county fiscal situation, I would have had no question but that North Hempstead would support this kind of effort," said May W. Newburger, the North Hempstead town supervisor, a Democrat who had been only "cautiously optimistic" about the outcome.
The supporters had also worried that a countywide reassessment would raise uncertainties about future tax rates, thus hurting the proposals' chances.
Instead, they said, voters in the two towns were unexpectedly decisive in their support. "I figured there was an appetite, but I had no idea it would be this well received," said Joshua F. Klainberg, the political director of the New York League of Conservation Voters, whose group was one of several that worked for the North Hempstead initiative.
Environmental organizations on Long Island said the town votes proved their long-held opinion that Nassau voters would support environmental spending if given the opportunity, just as voters in Suffolk County have done.
"I cannot tell you how I pushed for this and stumped for this and worked for this," said Bonnie Eisler, an Oyster Bay town councilwoman, a Democrat. "I was so excited we got such overwhelming support. It means we are on the right track."
The Oyster Bay plan, approved for the ballot by the Republican-controlled town board in September, will provide $20 million to acquire environmentally sensitive land and $10 million for park and recreational improvements, said John Venditto, the town supervisor. He said an advisory group would prepare recommendations on how the money should be spent, with an emphasis on equal spending in all areas of the town. The town board would then vote on the recommendations.
Approval of the $30 million plan has raised expectations of community groups that back buying up particular parcels.
"It certainly enhances the possibility there will be money for the Underhill property," said Joseph H. Lorintz, a lawyer from Jericho and the president of the Society to Preserve Underhill. He referred to an 81-acre parcel in a special groundwater protection area in Jericho. The owner, the Tilles Investment Company, has been trying to build houses there for years.
In North Hempstead, Jennifer Rimmer, the director of planning for Residents for a More Beautiful Port Washington, said the town's $15 million program, called the Environmental Legacy Fund, could be used to add to publicly owned waterfront. An example, she said, would be town participation in public purchase and razing of an unused building next to the Barbara John Memorial Park on Manhasset Bay in Port Washington.
Mrs. Newburger, the North Hempstead supervisor, said proposed projects would go to an advisory committee whose members were yet to be appointed.
Donald V. Pupke, a lawyer in Westbury who worked for the Oyster Bay proposal, said the overwhelming support for the town programs should set the stage for a county program. "The town votes provided the baseline of public support for preserving open space and showed the public willingness to pay for preservation," Mr. Pupke said. "Even if the county is in a somewhat dire financial situation, people are willing to pay for a quality of life."
But in Suffolk, in a bewildering turn, county officials and environmental groups were at odds over the voters' rejection of a proposal that would have limited borrowing for land and farm purchases under the 0.25 percent sales-tax program, which voters extended last year.
The environmental groups said they believed that the rejection meant that the county could borrow for environmental programs against total revenues expected under the sales-tax program, which begins Dec. 1 and continues through most of 2013. The county estimates those revenues will total about $176 million over the 13-year period.
The proposal was narrowly defeated, 128,580 to 142,318, according to unofficial returns. But only about a third of the Suffolk residents who voted for president also voted on the environmental proposal. Stewart Lowrie, the director of government relations for the Nature Conservancy, said the low vote count showed the proposal was "very difficult for people to interpret."
The counsel to the Suffolk County Legislature, Paul Sabatino, said the vote meant the sales-tax program remained "a 100 percent pay-as-you-go program," with no borrowing permitted against future revenues. Those who thought that defeat of the proposal would allow widened borrowing were "misinformed and dead wrong," he said.
Michael J. Caracciolo, a Republican county legislator from Riverhead, said the proposal would have allowed the county "to borrow up to 25 percent of that program over the next 13 years in a fiscally responsible manner." With its defeat, he said, "we don't have any authority to borrow."
Opponents of the proposal disagreed. Paul Rabinovitch, the executive director of the Nature Conservancy on Long Island, said there was no evidence that borrowing against future revenues was proscribed. The group led a campaign to defeat the proposition, arguing that it would cripple the county program.
"Somehow over the course of our campaigning it became the flip side of that, and the supporters were saying it would give bonding capacity where there wasn't any before."
The resulting confusion and the low vote, he said, made intent unclear. "Suffolk voters always vote for open space preservation," he said. "But I would not hang my hat on this vote as being a clear mandate."
