HEADLINE: Changing the White Male World at the Top of the Foundations

BYLINE: By KAREN W. ARENSON

 BODY:
EMMETT D. CARSON had a confession to make: Minnesota has one of the largest concentrations of Somalian immigrants in the United States, but as of mid-October, there were none on the board of the Minneapolis Foundation, which he directs. Nor did he have any Hmong board members, even though there is a sizable local Hmong community. For several years, he had two Hmong trustees, but with the recent departure of one, he had none.
For Mr. Carson to castigate himself like that might seem unnecessary. The Minneapolis Foundation, an 85-year-old community foundation with $576 million in assets, is one of the most diverse in the United States. Of 26 board members recently (not counting four empty slots), half were women, seven (including Mr. Carson) were African-American, two were American Indians and one was Hispanic. His staff is similarly diverse. 
 That is in sharp contrast to the foundation world generally, where about 90 percent of all trustees are white and two-thirds are male, according to a survey by the Council on Foundations. The foundations' top leadership was even less diverse racially and ethnically. Although about half of the full-time paid chief executives were women, fewer than 6 percent were minorities.
If this makeup seems familiar, look at the ranks of the nation's wealthiest individuals, or the top executives of the largest companies. They are mostly white males. But to Mr. Carson and others, the lack of racial and ethnic diversity in the top rungs of foundations is both an embarrassment in a country that is increasingly diverse and an obstacle to effective philanthropy.
"It creates a disconnect between a value we think is important and our ability to live up to the thing we say we value," Mr. Carson said. Equally important, he noted, "It affects where the money goes."
That is not to say that an all-white male board will not support the United Negro College Fund or the Girl Scouts. At the $21 billion Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation, for example, where decisions are made by four white people -- William H. Gates, the Microsoft chairman; his wife, Melinda; his father, William H. Gates Jr.; and a former Microsoft senior executive, Patty Stonesifer -- $1 billion in scholarships has already been allocated for minority students (to be given over 20 years), and tens of millions of dollars are being donated to improve health in Africa.
But in Mr. Carson's view, a homogeneous board is less likely to engage in "more risky" projects that are outside the board's range of experience. "It doesn't mean you don't have good grant-making," he said. "But it means it is harder to create trust relationships with those communities, to understand the fault lines, to listen to their radio programs and keep your fingers on the pulse. Opportunities are lost."
In a society that is becoming more diverse and increasingly prizes diversity, a growing number of foundations are trying to close that gap in their own ranks and among their grant recipients. Some are trying to bring in more minority and women trustees and grant makers, and asking their grantees do likewise. They are asking grant applicants to assess the effect of their projects on minorities and women.
They are also developing programs to increase giving by blacks, Hispanics and other minority groups. And they are sponsoring research to learn how diversity affects philanthropy.
It is a slow process, but change is beginning to occur. Consider the Council on Foundations, a Washington association of about 1,700 foundations. In 1996, the council set a goal that within four years at least a quarter of its officers and directors would be from minorities. By last December, that figure had reached 21 percent; with new hires and promotions, the goal was achieved this year.
The council also established a committee on inclusiveness to promote practices that encourage diversity at the council and among its members. And Dorothy S. Ridings, the council's president, has made progress on diversity a focus of her annual reports.
Rosie Zamora, a Houston businesswoman who is a council trustee and the chairwoman of the inclusiveness committee, knows firsthand what it is to be the only woman and the only Hispanic on a board. She has been on many such boards. As a trustee of the Houston Endowment Inc., a 63-year-old family foundation with about $1.7 billion in assets, Ms. Zamora, who heads her own survey research firm, was the first Hispanic trustee on the nine-member board and is still the only one.
"It is harder for a family foundation to become inclusive, because the family doesn't want to give up its power," she said.
One of her aims was to encourage the hiring of a Hispanic grant officer at the endowment. It happened, but it took a couple of years. She said she had also been pressing the Council on Foundations to increase its hiring of Hispanics. "They say they can't find them," she said, "and we tell them they have to do better."
She does not mind serving as a link to the Hispanic community, she said, but tries to offer other expertise, like education reform. "Being a Hispanic board member, you can't just isolate yourself to Hispanic issues," she said. "You have to find other issues that are helpful to the Hispanic community but also help business and help Houston in the global economy. You play a double role."
She added with a laugh, "You have to work harder."
The Ford Foundation is noted for its emphasis on diversity within its ranks and in its grant-making. It tracks the makeup of the board and its staff, and the diversity of both has grown considerably. And it leans on its grant recipients to do the same. In the United States, Ford's pursuit of diversity rarely comes as a surprise. But overseas, it is sometimes seen as an American construct, said Alex Wilde, a vice president and spokesman for the foundation. Mr. Wilde recalled that as a grant maker in South America, he worked with human rights groups whose boards were full of distinguished male lawyers.
"In the course of my work in Peru and Chile and Argentina," Mr. Wilde said, "I would have discussions with all the human rights organizations about how, if they were to take on women's rights issues, it would be helpful to have women who understood those issues on their boards and staffs."
The discussion, he said, would take place in various stages over several years. "We would talk about how a diverse board could be helpful to them," he said. "We would talk about the openings coming up on their boards. They would say, 'We are beginning to think along these lines.' "
In the majority of cases, he said, Ford's grant recipients concluded that diversity should be a genuine concern and made changes. "Of course, they are free to look elsewhere for grants," he said. "But rarely does it come down to that. My own experience is that many people feel it is very helpful to have these discussions."
HE added, "Basically, we're looking for organizations that share our core values, and this is part of our core values. This is an issue our trustees feel very deeply about."
Even groups that are in accord, however, like the Inter-American Dialogue, a Washington policy analysis group that receives about a quarter of its budget from Ford, sometime find that cultivating diversity can be a challenge. When Inter-American Dialogue was founded 18 years ago, only a couple of its members were women, and none were on the executive committee, said Peter Hakim, the president since 1993. Today, he said, he tries to make sure that the membership is mixed geographically, racially, politically and by gender.
But when he began to seek such a membership, he discovered that he had to look beyond the corporate world, which provided most of the group's male members, and instead sought prospects in government, academia, the legal profession and elsewhere.
With help from the Ford Foundation, he helped to develop a network of women -- the Women's Leadership Conference of the Americas -- that has become a source of members not only for the Inter-American Dialogue but also for other projects.
"Not only do you put more people in the pipeline, but they bring others," Mr. Hakim said. "The moral is that once you begin to focus on this issue, it becomes something that is important to you."
Finding and keeping women staff members has proved to be a harder task, he said, noting, "The numbers aren't as good yet."

HEADLINE: GRASS ROOTS;
A Meal at Boxcar Bertha's Supports One for the Road

BYLINE: By DULCIE LEIMBACH

 BODY:

NAME -- Boxcar Bertha's Cafe.
 
FOUNDED -- 1999, Portland, Ore. 

MISSION -- To operate as a profitable restaurant in the up-and-coming Pearl District while providing revenue for Sisters of the Road Cafe, a 21-year-old nonprofit organization that offers job training and food to poor and homeless Portlanders through discounted or bartered meals in the Old Town neighborhood.
 
CONSTITUENCY -- Directly, people who support Sisters of the Road by dining out on the Boxcar's fresh doughnuts, grilled burgers, homemade sauerkraut and espresso and pastries, all for affordable prices. Indirectly, Sisters of the Road clientele.
 
FINANCING -- Boxcar's $274,000 seed money came through private and public grants, not including $10,000 from a city housing fund that financed the cafe's feasibility study. The grants have paid for the cafe's five-year lease, physical improvements and equipment, laundry and food supplies this first year. Boxcar, which is operating at a loss, projects that it will be profitable in three to seven years.
The business pivots around an 80-20 model: 80 percent of its employees have restaurant experience and might or might not have been homeless or poor at one time; 20 percent have indeed suffered from poverty or been without a home. The restaurant wants to eventually flip that equation. Wages are competitive; some employees are "graduates" of the Sisters of the Road Cafe training program, taking on supervisory duties at Boxcar Bertha's.
Sandy Gooch and Genny Nelson, Portlanders who wanted to create a safe, nourishing place for primarily homeless women and children, hatched the idea for Sisters of the Road Cafe in 1979. It is named after the female hobos who lived the freight-train life during the Depression. Boxcar Bertha derives its name from Bertha Thompson, who wrote an autobiography about her hobo travails.
The Boxcar is Oregon informal: checkered tablecloths, living-room-style lounge, live music. Next year's projects include installing a lunch counter, reminiscent of Edward Hopper's "Nighthawks," and a takeout window. "We'll expand on the 1930's theme," said Keith Bernhardt, a Sisters of the Road development associate.
The difference between Sisters and Bertha's is that the former is designed to serve customers their main meal of the day, which costs $3 to produce but is priced at $1.25. At Bertha's, customers are neighborhood people who can order an omelet for $5.50 while sipping a cup of the house blend for a dollar -- not Depression prices but not new economy, either. DULCIE LEIMBACH

HEADLINE: Moving Beyond the Four Horsemen of the Philanthropy Beat

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER

 BODY:
THE good-news headlines are familiar. "Gates Will Donate $1 Billion Toward Scholarship Fund," declared The Houston Chronicle a year ago. "Even Elvis's TV Antenna Gets Sold at Charity Auction," reported The Plain Dealer in Cleveland, around the same time. "High-Tech in High Spirits/Silicon Valley Charity Ball raises $1.2 million at speakeasy in San Jose," The San Francisco Chronicle declared last spring.
So, sadly, are the bad-news headlines. The Tampa Tribune reported last fall on a "Former Charity Boss Charged With Fraud." A Los Angeles Times article last June under the headline "Man Accused of Charity Fraud May Surrender" reported on the pursuit of a former executive of the American Cancer Society's Ohio chapter, who was suspected of stealing $6.9 million from the charity. 
 The four horsemen of nonprofit coverage -- charity balls, big gifts, soft features about worthy programs and, of course, scandal -- have defined the general press's perspective of the nonprofit sector. But over the years, as that sector has grown to encompass 7 percent of the national income and employ about 8 percent of the national work force, these reflexive modes of covering the nonprofit world have gradually changed.
For one thing, there is more coverage than there was a generation ago. For the past 13 years, two major publications, The NonProfit Times and The Chronicle of Philanthropy, have focused on coverage of the nonprofit sector. And while higher education and nonprofit hospitals have been part of established newspaper beats, philanthropy is now a regular beat on The Minneapolis Star Tribune, The San Jose Mercury News, The St. Petersburg Times, Cox Newspapers and The New York Times, among others.
The Washington Post and The Wall Street Journal have historically covered it and plan to continue, though at both newspapers the beat has lapsed. The Seattle Times's assistant managing editor for features, Carole Carmichael, has focused new attention on nonprofit issues this year; a reporter currently on maternity leave will be taking on a nonprofit beat next year.
Douglas C. Clifton, editor of The Plain Dealer, said he had talked about establishing a philanthropy beat, but added ruefully, "It's evidence of my resolve that I haven't done it yet." Other priorities, like doubling the number of health-care reporters to six, intervened. He added that as long as journalists reverted to the four forms of coverage, the beat would not be a draw for the best journalists. The coverage, he thinks, needs basic rethinking.
Earlier this year, Ms. Carmichael and 15 other journalists attended a workshop on nonprofit coverage at the Poynter Institute. James M. Naughton, Poynter's president, said, "It did seem to me that in an era particularly in which foundations were getting interested in the nature and working of journalism, that journalists ought to get interested in the nature and working of foundations."
The groundswell of philanthropy coverage is gratifying, even if the increase in competitors is a bit unnerving, said Stacy Palmer, editor of The Chronicle of Philanthropy. But she and her publication have been around long enough to see how coverage of philanthropy ebbs and flows with the cycles of the newspaper economy. "I wonder how much of this is related to the new economy and Bill Gates giving away money," she said. "When that goes away, how interested will the newspapers be?"
Just as noticeable are the new lenses the media are trying out. While writers covering the social scene will always feed newspapers and magazines a diet of celebrities and socialites having fun while doing good, the coverage of nonprofit organizations and their missions is undergoing a subtle shift.
Roll the tape back to the 1960's, the time of President Lyndon B. Johnson's Great Society and the War on Poverty. Government social service programs were expanding, and coverage of nonprofit institutions tended to be an offshoot of social service coverage. That emphasis has never entirely disappeared, but during the 90's, with organizations like Doctors Without Borders playing crucial roles in humanitarian crises from Rwanda to Bosnia, there was new reporting on the nonprofit scene from a foreign affairs perspective.
Most recently, as wealth from the new economy has poured into the nonprofit sector, business reporters are taking more interest in questions like the tax implications of giving.
Peter Hero, the president of Community Foundation Silicon Valley, said that most of the recent inquiries he had fielded "are from general news reporters and from business reporters, from publications like Worth and Fortune and Forbes."
"Their stories have more to do with the deployment of the wealth of these new people," he said, adding that "there is also a sort of People magazine interest."
WHAT sets the new giving apart, he thinks, is its origin in the workplace rather than in the church or a more traditional incubator. "The biggest difference from the Carnegies and Rockefellers is that this giving is influenced not by church and by one's friends, but by the workplace," he said. "Informal networks in the workplace are driving philanthropy around here."
Lester M. Salamon, the director of the Center for Civil Society Studies at the Johns Hopkins University, said, "Businesses are seeing the value of an engagement with social issues." In addition to benefiting the community, he said, companies use charity to burnish their brands. "Corporate image is much more important than ever."
Whatever lens is used, every philanthropy can produce a list of what it thinks are ignored subjects. For Michael J. Horowitz at the Hudson Institute, a conservative research group, what matters is how the wealth of largely conservative individuals is often put to liberal purposes. For David Callahan, the research director at Demos, a year-old public policy organization in New York City, it is "the way money is going into politics under the guise of nonprofit spending."
Paul Clolery, the editor of The NonProfit Times, said journalists could "try to look at the number of people cut" from a charity's roster of clients, or what type of client the organization was helping. He added, "If you look at the type of individual served by a food bank six years ago and now, you'll see some similarity, but I guarantee you the client's income will be higher right now."
And he said: "What we're looking at is unprecedented need at food banks, unprecedented need in service programs."
Scandal coverage fulfills an important watchdog function, he acknowledged. It also tends to have more resonance than a more nuanced look at how the nonprofit sector works on a daily basis. For instance, The St. Petersburg Times recently covered the debate among foundation executives about the level of annual giving that the federal government should require before allowing a private foundation the maximum tax break.
Leslie Lenkowsky, a professor of philanthropic studies and public policy at the Center on Philanthropy at Indiana University, said that in general, "foundation mistakes and errors don't get much coverage." But he is not ready to agree that the nonprofit sector is undercovered, citing health, education and social service coverage as part of the beat.
He also sees a downside to scrutiny and the demands that charities disclose more information about themselves and donors. He fears that such close inspection may discourage anonymous giving. But he added, "One of the sadder things about charitable giving is that it is seldom anonymous."
Anonymity is indeed out of vogue; a recent report from the Council on Foundations urged nonprofit groups to be more aggressive in courting the media. But increased press scrutiny often means a warts-and-all picture of the nonprofit world, like The Philadelphia Inquirer's 1993 examination of tax-code abuses and other economic issues raised by the growth of nonprofit groups.
More consistent coverage could provide an antidote to the hypercredulous and hypercritical treatment of the subject. Nonprofit groups themselves, however, may find themselves uncomfortable with regular, dispassionate scrutiny. "People who lead organizations have to realize that with more coverage comes more points of view and more criticism," said John Thomas, a vice president at the Independent Sector, a Washington group that supports the work of nonprofit institutions. "We have to be prepared for criticism and for telling our stories in the best way we can."

HEADLINE: More Students Are Saying That a Big Paycheck Can Wait

BYLINE: By GEANNE ROSENBERG; Geanne Rosenberg teaches journalism at Baruch College.

 BODY:
LEE DAVENPORT, a recent graduate of the University of Texas, was headed for a business career. But Mr. Davenport thought he would first do a stint in the National Civilian Community Corps, a unit of AmeriCorps, a government-sponsored program based in Washington that focuses on community service.
In the late 1990's, when his classmates were entering the nation's strongest job market in decades, Mr. Davenport signed on for a stipend of about $4,000 a year, plus room and board, and a chance to help Americans in crisis. 
 Now a team leader, he talks about fighting wildfires in Southern California and assisting Florida flood victims and homeless Vietnam War veterans. "I've become really excited leading volunteers and seeing the energy and enthusiasm of people who want to give of themselves," he said, adding that he has ditched plans for an M.B.A. in favor of public interest work.
He is one of many.
"We're hearing from everywhere that there is a significant increase in young people deciding they want to work in the nonprofit sector," said Sara E. Melendez, the president and chief executive of Independent Sector, a coalition of nonprofit organizations in Washington.
Those reports coincide with increased rates of volunteering. A 1999 Independent Sector survey showed high levels among 18- to 24-year-olds. When considering all age groups, the study reflected record participation.
"The rate of volunteering is the highest we've ever picked up," said Keith Hume, a research associate at Independent Sector, who noted that the surveys have been conducted since 1988.
Despite the strong job market, record salaries for new graduates and high student loan and credit card debt, the shift toward volunteerism appears to be filtering down to college and university campuses. Career placement officers are reporting robust demand among college students and recent college graduates for public interest work.
Nonprofit experts, placement officers and a recent Harvard survey say that while students express apathy and disillusionment with the government and the political process, their enthusiasm for community public interest work is extremely high. And some companies are tapping that interest to strengthen their own employee recruiting and retention efforts.
"This stuff is sweeping America," said Reynold Levy, the president and chief executive of the International Rescue Committee, an organization based in New York devoted to helping people who have been uprooted by persecution, war or violence. "So a company would have to be very dumb to ignore this impulse, which is playing itself out across the nation."
According to a recent survey by the Institute of Politics at Harvard University, 60 percent of college students reported being involved in community service during the past year; 85 percent of college undergraduates said they preferred community volunteerism to political engagement to solve important community issues; and 60 percent preferred community volunteerism to political engagement to solve important national issues.
"We're the MTV generation," said Leslie Salba, a junior at the University of Michigan and the coordinator of the public service internship program there. "We need a quick result. We don't want to work in the background and know something will come months from now."
SOME companies are offering students an opportunity to both pursue their careers and engage in community volunteerism. That combination helped attract Monica M. Martinez, a recent engineering graduate of the University of Miami, to I.B.M. She is a network test engineer for I.B.M. in the Raleigh-Durham area of North Carolina and an "e-mentor" to middle-school students under a new I.B.M. community-service program.
The company has found that public interest opportunities and supporting its employees' philanthropic interests are valuable hiring tools.
"There's no question that there seems to be an increase in the interest among business-school students and new hires in what companies do in the community," said Stanley Litow, the vice president of corporate community relations at I.B.M. and president of the I.B.M. International Foundation. He said that good corporate citizenship and support of public interest programs, including education, "provokes a sense of loyalty in employees." He added, "It also helps enhance the value of your brand."
Nonprofit experts, career counselors, students and private-sector sources have many explanations for the increased interest in volunteering. "I think we're moving into a more idealistic time," said Virginia Hodgkinson, a research professor at the Georgetown University Public Policy Institute in Washington. There is "a wish on the part of many young people to improve their community, nation, world."
Some experts said that the strong economy had given students confidence that they could make a bundle in the stock market or get a higher-paying job later on, if money should become an issue.
As a result, students are not worried about taking lower-paying public interest jobs right after graduation. Others said that students were performing community service through high school and college community-volunteer programs and that the fervor for public interest jobs had grown out of that early exposure.
Former Senator Harris Wofford of Pennsylvania, a founder of the Peace Corps and the chief executive of the Corporation for National Service, a Washington-based government agency devoted to public service, has his own theory. He cited how John F. Kennedy inspired a generation by asking what people could do for their country.
"The No. 1 reason people volunteer is that they're asked," Mr. Wofford said. "The spirit of service and the appeal of adventure of working on the hardest problems, I think, appeals to any generation and is dormant there, and the question is, 'How do you bring it to life?' "
Public interest programs are learning how to do the asking, he said, and materialism appears to be giving way to a commitment to helping others. "I think we may find a wave of people who have done very well for a while getting back into community action," he said.
Those who have found satisfaction doing good works are sometimes less interested in financial rewards. Andrew Zuckerman, a Cornell University graduate, thought that he could embark on a business career while taking a detour into the public interest sector. Mr. Zuckerman participates in a pilot program co-sponsored by Teach for America, a nonprofit group that trains recent graduates to teach in underprivileged areas, and Andersen Consulting, a management and technology consulting firm. The deal involves two years of teaching followed by a job at the Andersen office in New York.
MR. ZUCKERMAN'S teaching experience at the Lucy Ellen Moten Elementary School in southeast Washington is challenging and sometimes invigorating, he said.
Recently, he taught his fifth graders about Congress and took them outside to view the Capitol, which can be seen from the school grounds. For many of the students, he said, it was the first time they could "look at the Capitol right in their backyards and have a complete sense of what is accomplished in that building and by whom."
Now Mr. Zuckerman is debating whether to take the job at Andersen. "I'm in too deep to get out," he said. "People get hooked on teaching. They see the difference they can make in people's lives, and I don't think they want to give that up."
Teach for America says that 57 percent of its graduates remain in education after their two-year stints.
As for Mr. Davenport, the Texan working for a unit of AmeriCorps, he intends to head to Kenya next year in a program sponsored by a Presbyterian church in Dallas, building classrooms and teaching computer classes in a small community. After the six-month assignment, he plans to pursue a graduate degree.
"I'm really looking forward to entering a school to study nonprofit management," he said.

HEADLINE: Behind the Prosperity, Working People in Trouble

BYLINE: By ANNE ADAMS LANG

 BODY:
IT has become an unspoken cultural axiom: anything less than financial well-being is a person's own fault. After all, this nation has been on a prosperity bender for the better part of a decade, intoxicated by the economy's seemingly boundless potential to generate fortunes or, at least, jobs.
Certainly, there are sober moments when the plight of those bypassed or trapped by the boom pierces the collective conscience. Mostly, though, people in need seem to be a parenthetical phrase in the rosy rhetoric of sustained expansion. 
 "Against this backdrop, you'd think the only people we have to serve in this country are the middle class, with all this talk about tax credits or whatever," said Fred Grandy, the president of Goodwill Industries International, which is based in Bethesda, Md. "There's an attitude that given full employment and a strong economy in most sectors, we've solved the problem of the have-nots. We haven't."
There are no aggregate statistics on the number of working families who are turning to charity to make ends meet. But agencies like Goodwill report a steady climb in the number of clients with annual incomes far in excess of the federal poverty level of $16,700 for a family of four. As the government continues to withdraw from core entitlement programs like subsidized housing, the private nonprofit sector has been left to pick up the slack.
Which it is doing, to some extent. Philanthropic largess is measured in head-turning numbers, according to Giving USA, an annual analysis of American donor activity produced by the AAFRC Trust for Philanthropy. Giving to human-service charities, which includes everything from crime prevention to housing, nutrition and vocational training (but not education), increased 31 percent from 1989 to 1999, adjusted for inflation, to $17.4 billion from $13.3 billion. The gross domestic product went up 35 percent, also adjusted for inflation, in that period. Donations to health services (including research organizations) rose 35 percent, to $18 billion from $13.3 billion, adjusted for inflation.
But experts warn that these sectors are getting a smaller piece of the charitable-contribution pie, their share declining to 18.6 percent last year from 21.7 percent in 1998. They also wonder what will happen when the economy slows.
"It's not that we're not a compassionate nation," said Betty S. Beene, the president and chief executive of the United Way of America, based in Alexandria, Va. "It's that we like to believe everyone is like us and lives in the same milieu. So when we hear that someone making $45,000 in Silicon Valley is living in a car, we say, 'Why don't they move?' But that is where the job for that skill is. Move? Where?"
Nowhere, said Nancy Tivol, the director of Sunnyvale Community Services in Sunnyvale, Calif. "It's almost impossible to find a one-bedroom apartment for less than $1,250 a month and it requires a deposit of thousands up front," she said. "In this area, $46,000 for a family of four is considered low income."
In this fast-beating but arrhythmic heart of Silicon Valley, Ms. Tivol blamed skyrocketing real estate prices and the cost of prescription medicine for a surge in emergency services. "The same house that costs $300,000 in other parts of the state costs $1 million here," she said. "If everyone had health coverage, we'd lose half our clients. Many of our clients never considered themselves working poor until recently."
Ms. Tivol has watched as the number of families who apply to the Sunnyvale organization has increased to 600 a month from 80 a month 10 years ago, some of them knocked from the fragile perch of economic security by an illness, a layoff or a small crisis.
Magali Estrada, a new caseworker at Sunnyvale, knows what it's like to suddenly be on the cusp of disaster. She and her husband, Carlo, a supervisor in a high-tech firm, were working when Ms. Estrada fell and broke her back. Mr. Estrada took a second job and one of their four children took on an after-school library job while Ms. Estrada was awarded disability payments. Still, the vise was tight.
"The children were demanding clothes, shoes and toys," Ms. Estrada said. "My kids had to learn to do without." The food and mortgage assistance the Estradas got from Sunnyvale were a blessing.
Zeke and Tracy Leavenworth were stunned to find themselves in the same boat. "I never imagined myself in a situation like this," Mrs. Leavenworth said.
Nor would anyone else, most likely. While Mrs. Leavenworth, 28, stays home with their three children, Mr. Leavenworth, 27, works 40 hours a week as an electrician, earning $36 an hour. But he gets no vacation or time-off pay. When Social Security, taxes, union dues, insurance contributions and the expenses of supporting a family of five are deducted from his paycheck, there is a crisis.
"It's good money," Mrs. Leavenworth said. But the rent on their three-bedroom mobile home increased $240 a month, to $1,795, eating up about half of her husband's take-home pay. Last month, a $2,000 repair bill for Mrs. Leavenworth's car put them at the brink.
"I told the landlord I would have been able to pay the rent, but then we wouldn't have been able to pay utilities or buy food," she said. "We don't have any savings. But we needed the vehicle or daily life would have just stopped. Zeke had to take his car to work or he couldn't get there."
While grateful for the one-shot help from the Sunnyvale organization, Mr. Leavenworth found the situation embarrassing.
"On paper, we should be a lot better off than we are," he said. "Two thousand dollars shouldn't be that big a deal. And we would have made it, but it would have been tough. I felt kind of bad, though. I still have pride. I thought there's a lot more people who need more help than I do."
Needing help and getting it are two different things. Ms. Tivol said a number of people hid their need. "There are a few cars that pull up to this office building between 7 and 8 in the morning, when the bathrooms open," she said. "People clean up their kids and send them to school. They clean themselves and go to work. At one point, these families were lower middle class."
THE pattern is repeated nationwide. "You have to look for the hidden signs of poverty," like families doubling up to avoid becoming homeless, said Sister Paulette LoMonaco, the executive director of Good Shepherd Services, a $25-million-a-year nonprofit social service and youth development agency in New York City. "We've seen no decrease in the number of people coming to us who need emergency clothes or food. You'd expect that to decrease in these prosperous times."
Deborah Leff, president and chief executive of America's Second Harvest, the nation's largest domestic hunger relief group, said: "People are working full time and have to make choices they shouldn't have to make -- a doctor or a meal, a prescription or a meal, housing or a meal. What's happened to hungry people in America is hidden. It's not where American stereotypes place them. They're not looking like the hungry people we expect. They're working."
Second Harvest, which is based in Chicago and operates food banks and food networks in every state, reported that demand for services was up 18 percent last year. Despite increasing the amount of food distributed this year to 1.5 billion pounds from 1 billion pounds last year, the organization turned away a million people. Ms. Leff says hunger is growing fastest in the suburbs, where housing is expensive and transportation usually requires a car. And a car valued at more than $4,650 makes its owner ineligible for food stamps.
"Sometimes I don't have enough money to buy groceries," said Cheryl Thompson, a 30-year-old mother of five in Fair Grove, Mo. "We buy them, but it takes away from other things. My husband, Chris, and I haven't had new clothing in two years. We don't buy our kids games or rent movies."
Mr. Thompson, 37, is paid $10.85 an hour to manage the flow of parts to an assembly line, a job that entails a 76-mile commute in the family's only car. From his pay, he has to deduct taxes, Social Security, union dues and a $413 monthly mortgage payment for their mobile home. Mr. Thompson calculated that it would not make sense for his wife to take a job, given the cost of child care and a second car.
"Sometimes, you get aggravated it doesn't pay as much as another job would," he said. "Then I look at other people out there who work at McDonald's, who make less money and get no insurance. They're even worse off than I am. I'm thankful to have what I do. But it bothers me when the kids need something and I can't buy it. Training for other jobs is possible, but you need time. The kids have baseball games and such, and we only have one vehicle. And you have to pay for all that training. You can't pay for it if you don't have it."
The Thompsons have health insurance through his job; Medicaid covers the children. There are no preventive checkups for them because the Medicaid clinic is open only during the day, while their father has the car at work. Their 3-year-old son has been waiting six months for a dental appointment at a clinic 15 miles away.
The family receives $55 a month in food stamps. That feeds them for about a week. To supplement, they go to the Ozarks Food Harvest Agency once a month. "The food bank helps a lot," Mr. Thompson said.
Dorothy Kurtz, 70, and her husband, Richard, 71, who founded the Church Food Pantry in Austin, Tex., can empathize.
"We have been where a lot of these people are now after one of our businesses took us down the drain," Mrs. Kurtz said. "That experience really opened our eyes for how it is to not be able to go to the store and buy what you want and pay your bills. With the cost of medicines, it was just awful."
Getting by on Social Security and subsidized housing -- they get no salaries -- Mrs. Kurtz said: "We know it's kind of hard to ask for help if you can do without, until you discover how many others in the same situation are getting assistance. It's hard to do that when you've been self-sufficient."
OPERATING for less than a year, the Kurtzes' pantry helped 549 families, or 2,131 people, in September, up from 108 families, or 527 people, in January. The food bank is open only two mornings a week, and Mrs. Kurtz is certain that more hours would increase the numbers.
"Right now, we need more funding if we're going to do that," she said. "We just did 87 families today. And they say there's no hungry people in Texas or Austin."
Local support has been strong, she said, with help from a bank, a barbershop, a grocery store and an apartment management company. There is a growing list of individuals who give at least $100 a month, and contributions are rising. Volunteers from the St. Vincent de Paul Roman Catholic Church in Austin staff the pantry.
"People know that these folks are really in need," Mr. Kurtz said. "They're down below where they should be as far as money. These people are trying. The world has changed so much lately here that they don't have the education they need and can't afford to get one."
Underlying private initiatives is a fundamental assumption that charitable giving will continue unabated. With need outstripping resources in good times, organizations wonder what will happen when the economy cools and the impulse to donate diminishes. "Until we talk about the contract between employer and employee that includes health benefits and a living wage, we fool ourselves that this prosperity is deep and lasting," said Harvey Robins, who was the deputy commissioner of the Human Resources Administration in New York City under Mayor Edward I. Koch. "The boosterism of the great economy deflects everyone from recognizing what is actually happening in people's daily lives."
Mr. Robins, who is now the assistant executive director for policy and planning at the Children's Aid Society in New York, added: "When a calamity hits not the poor or working poor but the middle class, they are only one or two paychecks away from being impoverished and in trouble. All levels of government tell them to ring another doorbell, a church or a nonprofit. But the cruel hoax is that churches and nonprofits are already stretched beyond even their expanded means. We need to redefine, again, the future role of government."
 
Hungry, Tired and Poorer
 IN the last decade, hunger-relief agencies have found that the hungriest people in the United States are the working poor. Here is a statistical snapshot of people who seek emergency help from soup kitchens, food pantries and shelters served by America's Second Harvest Food Bank, the nation's largest domestic hunger relief organization.
* There is at least one working adult in 39 percent of households receiving emergency food. Of those adults, 49 percent work at least 40 hours a week.
* Of the 21 million needy people seeking emergency food assistance, more than 8 million are children.
* About 70 percent of poor families with children in the United States include a person who works.
* Over the last two decades, the poverty rate among working families has risen nearly 50 percent.
* According to census estimates, two-thirds of parents with low earnings work in retail or service trades.
* Between 1978 and 1988, families headed by high school dropouts increased their annual working hours by nearly 12 percent, ending up with 8 percent less income.
* Of the emergency food recipients, 40 percent have less than a high school diploma or equivalent, including 16 percent who completed grade school or less.
* Forty-three million Americans have no health insurance, even for emergencies. Nearly half of all parents in working-poor families lack health insurance.

HEADLINE: Concern in Minneapolis as Target Remakes an Icon

BYLINE: By FRANK CLANCY

DATELINE: MINNEAPOLIS

 BODY:
ON Jan. 30, 2000, the Dayton Hudson Foundation one of the nation's oldest and most respected corporate foundations -- officially became known as the Target Foundation, mirroring the name change of its corporate parent to the Target Corporation.
The change was long overdue: Target, a discount retailer, had been Dayton Hudson's most profitable division for 20 years. Thanks mostly to Target's growth, the corporation's charitable giving has increased 252 percent in six years, to $81 million from $23 million when the current chief executive, Bob Ulrich, took over in 1994. 
 The sizable increase in Target's corporate giving, however, has paralleled a seismic shift in how the money is managed. The Dayton Hudson Foundation long functioned as an independent institution that distributed much of the corporation's charitable funds. Recipients of grants -- generally modest amounts of less than $50,000 -- included a wide range of social service agencies, artists and institutions.
But as the corporation morphed from staid retailer to hip marketer, strutting attitude on a national stage, the foundation has come to play a greatly reduced role in its giving strategy. In the last few years, it has distributed only 10 percent of Target's charitable dollars and, starting this year, to a smaller universe: organizations that provide food, shelter and clothing to the poor, and "programs that promote the visibility and accessibility of the arts at a community level." Target's operating divisions, each with its own charitable focus, handle most of the largess.
Because the Dayton Hudson Foundation was seen as the flagship of corporate philanthropy in a state that has been a leader in the field, the change in strategy, coupled with recent staff changes, has caused much concern.
"This community has a long history of being very pure in its giving," said Joseph Galaskiewicz, a sociology professor at the University of Minnesota who has studied corporate giving here. "By that I mean companies have traditionally given for the purpose of ensuring that needs are met."
While the Dayton family certainly thought that corporate giving would benefit the bottom line, corporate interests did not drive its philanthropic decisions. "It's still an open question whether Target's approach is to put corporate needs first," Professor Galaskiewicz said.
Unease about Target's charitable giving, and the foundation, is unfounded, said Gail Dorn, Target's vice president for community relations and a foundation trustee, who added, "We do have a new name, but we're giving at the same level, if not more, and that commitment remains."
The company, Ms. Dorn said, is continuing its 54-year-old practice of donating 5 percent of profits to charitable causes, a figure that is unmatched by most large corporations. This year, the foundation said it would be distributing $8.5 million -- about $1 million more than last year -- to nonprofit organizations in the Twin Cities. But for many beneficiaries of Target's philanthropy, the reality is that the rules have changed: after years of dealing with the foundation, they must now work with new staff, new grant-giving criteria and, in some cases, with divisions of the corporation.
Target executives say the changes amount to streamlining and consolidation, a "course correction" in the company's giving program. Mr. Ulrich declined to be interviewed for this article. But Laysha Ward, who was named foundation director in January, elaborated. "There aren't dramatic changes in the arts category," she said. The decision to support organizations that provide food, shelter and clothing was an attempt to fill a "big gap" in Target's corporate giving in its headquarters city.
"We're still going to provide support through the operating divisions for various self-sufficiency programs," she said. Ms. Ward was referring to corporate donations to programs that help young people and women learn job skills, a focus of the Dayton Hudson Foundation, which supported programs enabling people to find work.
Each of the three operating divisions has its own charitable guidelines. Target Stores, which accounted for 67 percent ($40.5 million) of Target's philanthropy last year, emphasizes family violence prevention, while the department stores division focuses on preventing child abuse and encouraging "youth self-sufficiency." Mervyn's California donates to programs that assist women and children. All three divisions also support the arts, while the department stores and Mervyn's give to education as well.
Target also encourages employees to volunteer in projects like Habitat for Humanity and a program called Operation Playground.
In framing the foundation's role, "we looked at the full range of what we're currently funding in social action," Ms. Dorn said, adding, "If you looked at what Dayton's and Mervyn's and Target Stores were funding, we had every area covered except that one" -- emergency needs like food, clothing, shelter.
Answering that need entailed a sea change in the foundation, which helped forge Minnesota's reputation as a leader in corporate philanthropy. "Giving by Dayton Hudson became kind of the Good Housekeeping Seal of Approval," said James Shannon, who served as the executive director of the General Mills Foundation from 1980 until his retirement in 1988. "Other foundations, which didn't have the resources to investigate as thoroughly, saw that and concluded that the program was worthy of support."
In Minnesota, reaction to the foundation's transformation has been publicly muted -- Target gives away too much money to too many organizations for people to feel comfortable commenting for the record -- but privately troubled.
Karen Miley, a veteran consultant who raises money for a variety of social service organizations, was among the few who were upbeat. "They've honored their legacy of what was here, for years, with the Dayton Hudson Foundation. My experience has been that for the projects they were working with at the time, they made the transition, they have in no way decreased their level of enthusiasm or support."
But many leaders in the Twin Cities' close-knit nonprofit community expressed confusion and concern. "There's a lot of anger and resentment currently in this community about how the Dayton Hudson Foundation evaporated overnight and turned into the Target Foundation," said one veteran fund-raiser, who insisted on anonymity.
Others take a wait-and-see approach. "You need to look at a grant list," said Jon Pratt, the executive director of the Minnesota Council of Nonprofits, an umbrella organization. "We don't know yet how it will turn out." That list for the 2000 fiscal year will not become available until the foundation files its tax return next year.
A hallmark of the Dayton Hudson Foundation was its willingness to support an organization's general operating costs over the long term. It is a category of financing difficult to secure. Ms. Ward said she did not know yet how many groups would have their foundation pipeline shut down. A few organizations that did not fit the new guidelines have received money from other sources within the company, nonprofit administrators said.
Part of the anxiety about the foundation stems from a series of recent mergers and acquisitions that have changed the state's corporate landscape. At least 10 large companies with major giving programs have been affected, including Honeywell, which gave nearly $8 million in 1998 but moved its headquarters to New Jersey after being acquired by AlliedSignal last year. (The larger company, which took the Honeywell name, was acquired by General Electric.) 
"Dayton Hudson is just the tip of the iceberg and is symptomatic of a larger change in the community," said the executive director of one nonprofit group. "There are going to be significant consequences for this shift in corporate philanthropy."
Referring to the Target Foundation, an executive at another foundation said: "In the nonprofit sector, there is a sense of something having been lost. Even if the dollars remain the same, there are questions of motivation and access."
Access is an issue at Target partly because the foundation laid off its staff in January. Ms. Ward has assumed the responsibility of three foundation professionals while she retains her post as director of community relations for Target's stores. In that post, she supervises the divisions' grant-making in the Twin Cities.
Target officials said layoffs were needed to streamline the foundation and coordinate the company's donations in Minnesota. Ms. Dorn said the company trimmed $500,000 in administrative costs, which will be given to charitable organizations.
But the character of Target's corporate giving has changed, as it has for corporate America generally. "We have had a fundamental paradigm shift, from one where companies gave as a responsibility to their communities," said Dwight Burlingame, the associate executive director of the Center on Philanthropy at Indiana University. "Most corporations today are giving as Target is doing, tying it to the benefit of the company."
That wasn't the arrangement when George Draper Dayton founded the Dayton Foundation in 1918 and, years later, the family committed the company to donating 5 percent of profits. Mr. Draper's grandsons, Bruce and Kenneth Dayton, ran the company in the 60's and 70's, ensuring that its commitment to philanthropy continued even after the company went public in 1967. But the younger Daytons did more than give money; they acted as missionaries for giving, urging companies to give generously and act responsibly.
Under Mr. Ulrich, who began working for Dayton Hudson as a merchandising trainee in 1967 and became president of Target Stores in 1984, the company married marketing and corporate giving. According to company figures, for example, nearly four million customers, or "guests," have enrolled in its Take Charge of Education program, which donates 1 percent of store credit card purchases to a school designated by the cardholder. As of October, the company said, it donated more than $23 million to schools nationwide.
Target has also benefited: internal research showed that customers enrolled in this program spent significantly more at Target than other charge card customers.
Target successfully capitalized on another charitable interest in the late 90's, during which it donated $2.5 million to the campaign to restore the Washington Monument. It raised another $4 million donation from its vendors. Last year, Target introduced a home products line designed by the architect Michael Graves, whose scaffolding enveloped the monument.
At the foundation, Ms. Ward said that for both arts and social service grant recipients, Target would "do what we do best, which is help them tell their story -- we're wonderful marketers."
For much of its life, the foundation operated independently of the corporation, said Peter Hutchinson, who was foundation chairman and a corporate vice president throughout most of the 1980's. Mr. Hutchinson, now the president of Public Strategies Group, a consulting firm for governments, said his predecessor told him, "Mr. Dayton told me, and I'm telling you, we're responsible for nothing that goes on inside the store and everything that goes on outside." Mr. Hutchinson understood that "if we could, through our giving, enhance our community -- enhance its quality of life, its economic viability and livability; if we could make the community stronger and more vibrant, it would in turn enhance our business."
That theory was tested in 1987, when Dayton Hudson became the object of a hostile takeover attempt. The takeover was averted, partly because nonprofit groups rallied to the company's support, pressuring the state legislature to meet in a special session.
It is the independence and far-ranging interests of the old Dayton Hudson Foundation that many in Minnesota's nonprofit community fear has been lost.
Leslie Lenkowsky, a professor of philanthropic studies and public policy at the Center on Philanthropy in Indiana, put it bluntly: "Corporations now feel that their philanthropic activities have to be more allied with their business activities."

HEADLINE: South Carolinians Nurture a Little Cause That Could

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr.

 BODY:
THE coastal landscape around Charleston, S.C., has long been known as the Low Country -- wetlands filled with waterfowl, beaches on barrier islands where waders can walk far out to sea and still be knee-deep, forests growing at an altitude of approximately zero and waterways shallow and deep interlaced throughout.
This ecosystem has been hit over the years by a force as powerful, if not as catastrophic, as a hurricane: the creep of urban growth, suburban sprawl and industrial expansion in and around Charleston and ports nearby. 
 So in 1989, just months before Hurricane Hugo came ashore on Charleston's barrier islands, Dana Beach and a few of his associates set out to found the South Carolina Coastal Conservation League.
How they built the organization, which in the years since has become a significant, if still relatively frail, barricade against the erosion of the landscape at the hand of man, is largely a story of philanthropy: raising money in small donations from members and in larger amounts from a few wealthier individuals and foundations.
Each type of donor makes a vital difference for a small organization starting with little more than a wish and a promise. And the group's experience is not unique: all over the country, many other local environmental groups follow a similar pattern, according to people experienced in environmental advocacy.
"Groups that are based in and working in specific places, that are relatively new, that are moving from a small to a medium-size budget, are doing some of the most interesting work," said Peter Bahouth, the director of the Turner Foundation in Atlanta, which has contributed to the league and other antisprawl groups. "They operate in that zone where the strictly local and broader global concerns meet and mix. Like the area where the water and land meet: there are a lot of nutrients and a lot of growth."
In some ways, the coastal Carolinas are an odd place to see such a group succeed. South Carolina's economic development policies have encouraged industrial development, and it is a conservative state in which environmental advocacy might not be expected to flourish. But it also has a combination of old and new landed gentry, some rich, some inclined to preservation for its own sake, and others because they love to hunt and fish. A small group can find that grass roots grow deep in that kind of society.
From its tiny start, the Conservation League has grown to about 4,000 members; in 1999, its budget was $1 million, a number that is growing rapidly.
Mr. Beach recalled that he came to the venture circuitously. It started with a business degree from the Wharton School, a stint in banking and work as a management consultant in New York. He later moved to Charleston, worked in politics and volunteered with the Sierra Club on local issues.
Gradually, he came to think that a full time, professionally staffed advocacy group was needed to protect the coast. "It's a great place," he said, "but it's definitely under pressure. It is one of the biological hot spots in the nation, and like so many others, it is under growth pressure."
In the Charleston region, the league said, population increased 40 percent in two decades, while developed land -- subdivisions, shopping malls, office parks and industrial land -- expanded 240 percent, six times as fast as the population. And there are projections that population will grow an additional 50 percent in the next 30 years.
In recent years the group has won a series of fights: overturning permits that would have allowed construction of the largest marina in the state, on Bohicket Creek, potentially degrading water quality and undermining local historic preservation efforts; helping a coalition of environmental groups defeat a "takings" bill that would have hampered government zoning controls by requiring compensation for property owners; and advocating significant changes in Forest Service plans for the Francis Marion National Forest after Hurricane Hugo devastated the ecosystem of endangered longleaf pine, blackwater creeks and bottomland hardwoods.
The group faces an especially big challenge in opposing plans for a huge port expansion in Charleston.
It was a presumptuous claim in the first place that the unknown and untested Conservation League could protect the threatened natural resources of the coastal plain by fighting what its founders considered misguided growth. "We made some undefended and unfounded assertions about what we were going to do -- some of which we did end up doing," Mr. Beach said.
Crucial early support came from founding board members, which included a core of landowners who had already committed themselves to conservation on their own property. One member who helped pull along many others was Gertrude Legendre, the owner of the Medway Plantation, which is now under a conservation easement and held by a private foundation. The most generous donor of the group's first five years was Ethel Jane Bunting, a wealthy philanthropist. When she died a few years ago, she bequeathed $25,000. Before she died, she set up a charitable remainder trust that will eventually benefit the league.
With a little of their money and their names as important collateral, Mr. Beach and his staff of "two and a half," as he put it, worked to obtain seed money from foundations. A handful of them got the league off the ground in the first year: the Hillsdale Fund of North Carolina, the M. R. Babcock Foundation of Winston-Salem, N.C., the W. Alton Jones Foundation in Charlottesville, Va., the Mary Flagler Cary Charitable Trust of Manhattan, the Merck Family Foundation in Boston and the Town Creek Foundation in Easton, Md. Altogether, the group raised about $95,000 its first year of operation.
Then it was time to build a base of smaller donors and members. "I marked 1,000 names in the phone book -- everyone I knew or had ever heard of in Charleston," Mr. Beach said. And the group began mailing solicitations.
They signed on 300 donors -- a striking 30 percent return rate. The average donation was about $40, and there were 20 donors who gave either $500 or $1,000.
From there, growth has been steady. Membership income has leaped from zero to $160,000 a year, excluding major donors. (The group's summer newsletter lists about 60 individual donors who gave at least $2,000 recently, about 70 more who gave at least $1,000 and about 100 who gave at least $500.)
Charlotte Caldwell, who is in charge of the group's current fund-raising campaign, says she makes her pitch in three steps. First, she explains that there is no other full-time coastal conservation advocacy group in the state. Then she spells out the differences between advocacy and other methods that donors might have tried, like preserving their own property in land trusts. Finally, she emphasizes the group's goals with simple examples, like opposing moves to lower water-quality standards for the benefit of the operators of animal feedlots, or opposing the removal of protective designations from scenic roads where the moss still hangs from overhanging oak branches.
Like some of the major donors she seeks, Ms. Caldwell moved back to the South, in her case from Massachusetts, and said she wanted to protect the landscape that she lived in. "A sense of place is very important to me," she said. "It is an insult to see a place bulldozed that I chose for its beauty, for enjoyment and even for spiritual benefit."
Part of the increase in major donations, Mr. Beach said, was spurred by a challenge grant in 1993 from the Lyndhurst Foundation of Chattanooga, Tenn., which matched major donations. That led to a fivefold increase in major donations over just a few years.
In 1998, the league wrote a 10-year growth plan. It has doubled its staff to 20, opened two new offices in cities nearby and is building toward a $3 million endowment to provide about 10 percent of its annual operating income. That will be about $1.5 million next year.
The overall goal is to shift the breakdown of revenues from its 1998 sources (55 percent foundation grants, 25 percent major donors and the rest smaller amounts from members) to a target of 38 percent from foundations, 38 percent from major donors and 24 percent in smaller amounts.
Board members -- the biggest of the big donors -- are crucial to meeting these targets, which will require raising $6 million in pledges over several years, enough to create the endowment and expand operations. The group expects that current and past board members will contribute about $2 million; there are 20 people on the board and the average member's pledge, Mr. Beach said, is about $76,000.
HOW will the money be spent?
The group will open an office in Georgetown, about 60 miles north of Charleston, and enlarge offices in Beaufort and Charleston ($1 million); open a full-time policy office in Columbia, the state capital ($500,000); and modernize its communications and technology programs, both for advocacy and advanced analysis of land issues ($750,000). It will also set up a $750,000 reserve and a $3 million endowment.
Groups like this rarely get national attention. But according to Nancy Stoner of the Natural Resources Defense Council, a national advocacy group, they do much of the important work on the ground. The Coastal Conservation League, for example, is one of more than 1,000 local organizations that work together through the Clean Water Network, a coalition of advocacy groups.
"Information flows two ways in the network," said Ms. Stoner, who is on the network's steering committee. "We let people in the field know what is going on in Washington; they contact the federal regulatory agencies, weigh in with members of Congress and provide local examples to prove the harmful or beneficial effects of proposed changes. And when we are developing comments on major regulations, we seek input from them. And then, people obviously get in touch with each other."
So, just as all politics is local, there are times when local philanthropy has effects far from the fields where its seeds are sown.

HEADLINE: Britons Love a Cause With Legs, Preferably Four of Them

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
IT begins with a solitary yap, then builds to a crescendo of barks, howls, whimpers and growls. In the distance, a plaintive mewing joins the chorus. Moving between the cages, humans murmur to one another and appraise the animals clamoring for attention. Charitable Britain is doing one of the things it most likes to do -- finding new homes for lost dogs and cats.
From the Battersea Dogs Home, in the shadow of a vast, unused power station on the south bank of the River Thames, some 6,000 dogs and 3,100 cats were sent to new homes last year, a process called "re-homing," which is woven into Britain's social tapestry. Recent adoptive owners include Sir Elton John and the ex-Spice Girl Geri Halliwell. Every day, around 30 strays and sad-eyed rejects find their way to the home. 
 "We lost ours four weeks ago," said Doreen Carruthers, a London homemaker who was casting a speculative eye over the home's crop of Staffordshire bull terriers, her favorite breed. "Maxine, she was called. Died of a heart attack. Now we want a new one. But it has to be a Staffordshire."
These modest courtship rituals between animal and human are generally viewed as quaint. But they reflect one of the more bizarre aspects of British giving. According to the most recent figures from the Charities Aid Foundation, a private charitable body that promotes philanthropy, animal-protection institutions ranked third, after cancer and international aid charities, in voluntary income in 1997-98, ahead by a whisker of children's charities with donations of 200 million, or $290 million, at the current exchange rate.
Among Britons, needy children are seen as the responsibility of the government's social services, said Cathy Pharaoh, the head of research at the Charities Aid Foundation.
"In the United States, they have always had a bigger sense that it is the role of the philanthropist to provide for social welfare," she added, while Britons are used to the idea that the welfare state will look after needy children -- unless the children are in far-flung lands beset by disaster. During Mozambique's floods last year, millions of British pounds were raised overnight after television films showed women and children in distress there.
Animals are on their own, which may help explain why, when it comes to bequests, they are miles ahead here. "Animal charities receive the greatest proportion from legacies at just over 40 percent," said a statement issued earlier this year by the Charities Aid Foundation, widely known by the acronym CAF.
Why this should be seems a blend of sentimentality and deeper social trends in a nation that has seen the erosion of traditional family support systems.
Britain's reverence for small, furry creatures is well known. Queen Elizabeth the Queen Mother is routinely photographed with her retinue of corgi dogs. Early evening television regularly features shows -- like "Animal Hospital" -- that focus on veterinary surgeons saving sick animals in excruciating close-ups.
A sense of protectiveness toward animals is so ingrained that a vocal antiblood sport lobby has propelled its campaign to ban fox hunting onto Parliament's legislative agenda, despite the pleas from horse-riding fox hunters that such a ban would mean the demise of many hunting dogs.
So keen are Britons to shield their animals from infection that it was only last year that the authorities relaxed stringent antirabies quarantine laws by permitting people to import domestic pets, provided that the animals had the necessary health checks and shots, and an implanted microchip to prove it.
But Ms. Pharaoh ascribed Britons' attachment to animals, and their readiness to bequeath money to animal charities, to a more somber cause: "Lots of isolated people for whom pets are the only source of contact," she said.
In terms of causes and individual charities, Britons, possibly mindful of a colonial past, generally give the most to international aid agencies, among which Oxfam (an organization that focuses on the poor) emerged as No. 1 in the CAF list of Britain's 500 leading charities. The Battersea Dogs Home, which took in about 8.53 million, or about $12 million, in 1999, ranked 106, but other animal charities made the top 20. The highest ranking was the Royal Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, which is 14th on the list.
"The British are very loyal to their big, major charities," Ms. Pharaoh said. In absolute terms, Britons donated 337 million, or $488 million, to international agencies in 1998, slightly ahead of cancer charities, with approximately $478 million. Oxfam's total income was $205 million, according to CAF.
OVERALL, Ms. Pharaoh said, the income of Britain's charities, including selling merchandise, grants and investment returns, totals around 14 billion, or $20.3 billion a year, more than a third coming from public donations. But the picture remains uneven, with the smallest amounts going to charities related to AIDS and mental health -- traditionally neglected areas -- while some high-ticket charities boom.
In global terms, including its relatively huge income from investments, merchandising and entrance fees rather than voluntary donations, the richest charity in Britain is the National Trust, which owns hundreds of historic sites, castles, stately homes and gardens. Its 1998 income was $307 million, reinforcing the notion that an Englishman's home really is his castle, if vicariously.
And for the first time in 1998, according to CAF's most recent figures, the renovated Royal Opera House -- viewed by some critics as elitist -- entered Britain's top 10 charity list in 10th place, with total income of about $130 million, almost two-thirds from voluntary contributions. (This is an attractive charity for corporate donations.) By contrast, the Royal National Lifeboat Institution, at No. 5, had roughly the same total income for a cause that reflects older traditions. "England is an island with a strong seafaring tradition," Ms. Pharaoh said.
But in real terms, she said, there has been little change in individual giving for several years, except that the overall number of donors has decreased, so that fewer philanthropists are making larger donations. And, Ms. Pharaoh said, "The lack of growth in corporate giving is quite a challenge for British charities."
What many charities look for is a sponsor like Tesco P.L.C., Britain's biggest supermarket chain, which adopts a charity for a year, buffing up its brand name through a display of concern while enlisting its employees to raise money for the cause. This year, said Fiona Archer, a manager of community affairs at Tesco, the chain is backing MacMillan Cancer Relief, which supports the care of terminal cancer patients. The charity's name is printed on all of Tesco's plastic shopping bags in a joint logo.
Arguably, the biggest hope for British charities lies in measures announced by Gordon Brown, the chancellor of the exchequer, in his budget last April, enabling both donors and charities to secure tax breaks on charitable gifts and, for the first time, on donations in the form of equities.
The measures, which could be worth about $550 million a year for charities, allow them to reclaim 22 percent in taxes while the government has scrapped a $145 a month limit on tax-free payroll donations.
Underlying the tax breaks is a perception among charities that the abrupt rise in wealth, created by the so-called new economy, has generated a new pool of potential givers in electronic businesses.
"I think we have come full circle and are looking at the giving age," Ms. Pharaoh said. "We are looking at an attempt to stimulate more charitable giving from those who have made a lot of money over the past decade from the City" -- London's Wall Street -- "and the dot.coms."
The pressure to exploit new sources of giving has even filtered down to establishments like the Battersea Dogs Home, which, for more than 100 years, has relied on the generosity of pet-loving benefactors. (More than two-thirds of its 1999 donations were from legacies.) Just recently, said Sophie Allen, a spokeswoman, the home organized a charity walk in which 80 of its dogs were sponsored by benefactors to raise money for itself and the MacMillan Cancer Fund. "Fund-raising is something we are only just getting into," Ms. Allen said.

HEADLINE: GRASS ROOTS;
In Milwaukee, a Chance for Free Job Training to Escape the Low-Wage Life

BYLINE: By DAN CUFF

 BODY:

NAME -- Esperanza Unida ("United Hope")
 
FOUNDED -- 1971, Milwaukee.
 
MISSION -- To empower the community through economic development by training people for higher-wage jobs. 

CONSTITUENCY -- Primarily the Latino community in Milwaukee. But the organization trains inner-city residents of all backgrounds.
 
FINANCING -- Half of the $3 million annual budget comes from the sale of products that are built or renovated by people in the program. They make trash bins, recycle donated cars and run a print shop, among other projects. The rest comes from donations from individuals, grants from corporations and foundations, and from the city of Milwaukee.
The group offers training in auto repair, welding, construction, printing, day care and customer service. Some 55 employees train 450 people a year in the free program. The job placement rate is 70 to 80 percent, said Richard Oulahan, 53, the executive director.
Esperanza Unida has branched out over the years. The organization made a big jump in the 1980's, when it bought an abandoned auto dealership and began to train mechanics. Since then, it has added two other sites and offers training for other skills in English and Spanish. It runs a day-care program and houses an alternative high school "for kids who haven't made it in the regular system," Mr. Oulahan said. It operates a coffee shop and bookstore, and has a lawyer who helps with workers compensation and unemployment claims.
Keeping the organization running "has always been tough," Mr. Oulahan said. But it has been harder since Wisconsin implemented welfare reform three years ago. Esperanza Unida had a $500,000 annual contract with the state to put welfare recipients into skilled jobs. But Mr. Oulahan said the state changed its emphasis from skill training to placing welfare recipients into minimum wage jobs. So the group lost its state contract. Money from the city has been reduced for the same reason, to $180,000 from $500,000 a year, he said.
In the last decade, the regional economy lost 80,000 industrial jobs, Mr. Oulahan said, while replacing them with 120,000 low-paying service jobs. In this low-wage economy, he said, he hopes to find family-supporting jobs for inner-city people to give them a better chance of participating in the community.
"People with low wages tend not to vote," he said. "They don't get involved in the schools or anything."
 DAN CUFF
