HEADLINE: For Most Local Phone Users, Choice Is Not Yet an Option

BYLINE: By SETH SCHIESEL

 BODY:
AT&T's plan to break itself into four pieces has many experts worried that nationwide competition in local telephone service is at risk.
Four years after a grand political compromise among telecommunications interests was supposed to usher in a new era of consumer choice, only about 3 percent of household and small-business telephone lines are served by a competitor to the longstanding local phone company, according to recent preliminary Federal Communications Commission data. At most, some experts believe, no more than 1 in 10 households has any real choice at all. 
 AT&T officials insist that the company's offspring -- even as they retreat from a strategy of bundling local, long-distance and cable television service into a single product -- will continue to offer aggressive competition for local phone companies.
But many analysts say that is unlikely, and any pullback from AT&T's push into local phone markets would be only the latest disappointment for consumers whom Washington policy makers promised a choice of local telephone providers.
The Telecommunications Act of 1996 was supposed to sweep away barriers to competition that lingered from the era of the first AT&T breakup, in the early 1980's.
But the Baby Bell companies showed a greater penchant for consolidation than for competition, and most upstart local phone carriers decided to focus on serving business customers rather than consumers. Meanwhile, the arcane details of opening local phone networks to long-distance companies and other would-be competitors were mired in legal and regulatory debate.
Most recently, revenue has begun evaporating in the long-distance telephone business, potentially reducing the Bell companies' enthusiasm for that market and undermining the formula -- letting local carriers into the long-distance business once they open their local networks -- on which the Telecommunications Act relied.
And so the supposed tidal wave of competition that the law was expected to unleash is barely a ripple for most local phone consumers. Instead, some consumer advocates say that the local phone giants are set to maintain their dominance in the $100 billion local communications business -- even as federal regulators allow them to expand into the $80 billion long-distance market.
"Certainly less than 10 percent of consumers have any meaningful choice of local service," said Gene Kimmelman at the Washington office of Consumers Union. "There were lots of overblown promises from telecommunications executives that they would provide competition, and it's not happening."
Representative Thomas J. Bliley Jr., the Virginia Republican who was the act's primary author in the House, insisted that the law was fulfilling its promise, if at a measured pace. "Competition has already resulted in lower prices, and it has spurred new, innovative services in many markets, although not all," the representative said yesterday. "It is not surprising that new entry to a market, once 100 percent controlled by the incumbent provider, is taking significant effort."
Most of the customers with a choice, however, are corporations. There were about 191 million phone lines in the nation at the end of June, according to the F.C.C. Competitive local phone companies served about 12.3 million, or 6.4 percent, of those lines. That number is growing quickly, but almost two-thirds of those competing phone lines were connected to big businesses. The slow pace of competition for consumers may be one reason local phone rates have continued to keep pace with inflation since 1996 while long-distance rates have tumbled sharply.
"There are higher margins and higher rates for business customers and consumer prices tend to be much lower," explained J. Cliff Eason, chief executive of the Southwestern Bell unit of SBC Communications. "The competitors are going after the denser-packed business customers more than the consumers."
For consumers, much of the competition is in just two states, New York and Texas, where the Bell companies have been allowed to sell long-distance services. New York is also a primary market for the RCN Corporation, perhaps the only major new local telecommunications company that has focused on serving residential customers.
Representative Edward J. Markey, Democrat of Massachusetts, points to RCN's existence as evidence that the 1996 law is working.
"Only by passing the telecom act, by removing the bar that almost half of all states had in barring almost all local phone competition, would we have this start," said Mr. Markey, who started pushing for an overhaul of communications laws in the 1980's. "It's not perfect, but the passage of the act has led to $40 billion in investment in new infrastructure that will eventually pay off for consumers."
But some communications experts wonder what "eventually" means.
"For consumers, the prospects for local competition look abysmal in the near future," said Brian Adamik, president of the Yankee Group, a technology research and consulting firm in Boston. "In most of the country, it is just not happening."
Assuming that no company was rich enough to build a new phone network to compete with the local Bell companies' wires, the 1996 act required the Bells to sell the use of their systems to competitors.
But that arrangement had a built-in tension. Fundamentally, it was like telling a car company that wanted to compete against General Motors that it had to purchase the use of G.M.'s factories to make its cars.
Though Bell Atlantic (now Verizon) and SBC Communications finally persuaded the F.C.C. that they had opened their systems -- thereby securing the right to enter the long-distance business in New York and Texas, respectively -- some would-be competitors have come to believe that it is just not worth playing by the Baby Bells' rules. Specifically, many potential competitors complain about the prices they are asked to pay for access to the Bell companies' systems.
"What we're finding nationwide, with only a few minor exceptions, is that these rates have been set at a rate so high that it is virtually impossible to make a profit," said John J. Langhauser, vice president for law at the AT&T consumer unit.
AT&T has signed up almost a million local phone customers in New York and Texas, where the company is paying to use Verizon and SBC lines rather than cede business to its competitors.
Rather than depend on the Bells, however, the big plan of C. Michael Armstrong, AT&T's chairman, was to own his own wire into homes and businesses. AT&T spent more than $90 billion acquiring cable television systems, planning to upgrade them to provide local phone service and bypass the Bells altogether.
Now, with Wall Street's impatience with that strategy forcing AT&T to carve itself in four, many communications analysts and executives say that the company's successors will not be able to, or perhaps want to, expand into local phone service so aggressively.
The cable business, for instance, will no longer be able to count on subsidies from the rest of AT&T to underwrite its telephone operation. And the consumer unit will probably have big dividend and interest payments to meet that could be impaired if it signs up millions more local customers.
"We're not going to see AT&T delivering local competition like we thought they would," predicted Robert C. Taylor Jr., chief executive of Focal Communications, a new local carrier based in Chicago that focuses on business customers.
AT&T insists that its separate consumer and cable units will continue to push into local markets. "Our goal is to make the AT&T brand on local phone service as ubiquitous as possible," said Richard J. Martin, an executive at AT&T. "Each of the businesses that we have created has been given the capabilities to offer voice telephone service, and they will each be able to use the AT&T brand in marketing those services."
Ivan G. Seidenberg, co-chief executive of Verizon, says that the slow pace of local phone competition is a nonissue. Consumers and regulators, he said, should look to new technologies, like wireless phones, to provide competition.
"One of the mistakes that people make on this issue is that they are expecting an analogue of Verizon," he said. Instead, consumers and regulators should focus on the changing realities of phone service.
"Joe Schmoe has cut his bill to us in half," Mr. Seidenberg said. "He's buying wireless from somebody. He's buying long-distance from somebody. In three years, having a 'choice' of local phone company will be irrelevant."
Not surprisingly, consumer advocates like Mr. Kimmelman of Consumers Union say that despite the new technologies, consumers suffer without a choice for local service.
"The average consumer spends almost 10 times more time on the phone for local calling than for long-distance calling or wireless calling," he said. "The fact that more people have a wireless phone does not mean that it can compete on price or quality with local calling."
Mr. Adamik of the Yankee Group said: "It seems that we've lost sight of what our long-term interest in telecommunications policy ought to be. We created this vibrant long-distance industry, and now we're killing it; as the Bells enter long-distance it's like shooting fish in a barrel for them. I'm not a big fan of regulation but we have to do a better job of coordinating our long-term telecom policy because right now we're going backward."
With local competition slow to develop and revenue dwindling in the long-distance business, some analysts question whether the grand compromises of the Telecommunications Act need to be revisited. But lawmakers and regulators who participated and watched as the law took four years to enact do not show much stomach for that.
"I would advise caution on reopening the telecom act," William E. Kennard, chairman of the F.C.C., said in a statement. "Local phone competition is advancing. We need to keep a steady course to allow this nascent competition to grow."

HEADLINE: Auto Sales Have Slowed This Month

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

DATELINE: DETROIT, Nov. 20

 BODY:
Auto sales, often a leading indicator of the economy's health, have slowed since the beginning of the month, prompting carmakers to increase their already deep discounts and to consider additional temporary closings of factories, industry officials said today.
General Motors and the Chrysler unit of DaimlerChrysler have already closed some factories for a week at a time and appear likely to announce further temporary closings soon, they said. Ford Motor has avoided closing factories so far, except because of parts shortages, but its officials have been warning that the entire industry is slowing. And even foreign automakers are seeing some weakness in sales and have been offering many discounts. 
 Shares of G. M. plunged $4.25 each today, to $51.75, after the company predicted that its sales would drop 4 percent to 7 percent this month, compared with weak results in the month a year earlier. The giant automaker predicted that the entire auto industry's sales would fall by a similar amount. G. M. also announced that it had begun offering $500 discounts on 17 high-volume models on top of already available low-rate loans and large rebates.
Struggling with bloated inventories, Chrysler faces weak orders from its dealers for new vehicles, company officials say. Last week, DaimlerChrysler removed Chrysler's president, James Holden, and three of Mr. Holden's senior allies at the company were forced out this morning. But slowing sales do not appear to be a problem confined to Chrysler.
The scale of the industry's slowdown will not be clear until Dec. 1, when many automakers will announce their sales for November. But Wall Street is clearly worried. Rod Lache, an analyst at Deutsche Banc Alex. Brown, lowered his estimates today for fourth-quarter earnings at G. M., Ford and DaimlerChrysler, citing worries about fourth-quarter sales.
Some in the auto industry say that sales have only weakened slightly but that bloated inventories are forcing manufacturers to consider deeper cuts in production.
The auto industry's sales averaged an annual pace of 18 million vehicles last winter, and the industry did not slow down its factories when sales weakened last summer to an annual pace of 17 million, said George Pipas, a market analyst at Ford. Auto executives are now concluding that sales are not going to return to last winter's levels and are trying to decide how to reduce production and sell the extra vehicles that have accumulated on dealers' lots, he said.
"The manufacturers kept producing as if it were an 18 million rate, and for every month you kept doing that, you have to make an inventory adjustment that is greater than the 5 or 6 percent reduction in sales," Mr. Pipas said.
Until the last two years, a sales rate of 15 million vehicles a year was considered strong.
Car dealers say that shoppers are nervous about interest rates and the weak stock market. "There has just been a lack of traffic in the dealerships, they're just not coming in, and why they're not coming in, I don't know," said Frank Ursomarso, a dealer in Wilmington, Del., who sells Pontiacs, Fords, BMW's, Jaguars, Hondas and GMC trucks.
Mr. Ursomarso said that he had sold 123 automobiles so far this month, compared with 138 by this date in November of last year. The proportion of people who enter his showrooms and buy a vehicle has fallen to 26 percent so far this month from 31 percent during the first 20 days of November 1999, he added.
Theodor Cunningham, Chrysler's executive vice president for global sales and marketing, and Kathleen Oswald, the company's chief administrative officer, retired today while Tony Cervone, Chrysler's vice president for communications, quit.
Mr. Cunningham's replacement is to be named soon, Chrysler said. Ms. Oswald's job, overseeing human resources and other administrative activities, is being eliminated. Kenneth A. Levy, a former G. M. spokesman in Europe, will succeed Mr. Cervone.

HEADLINE: Youngstown Reformers Seek Mob-Fighting Tips in Sicily

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES 

DATELINE: YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Nov. 16

 BODY:
After years of struggle with organized crime, and dozens of indictments of officials in this proud city, sadly dubbed Crimetown U.S.A., weary leaders of the reform movement are journeying to the ultimate Old World role model for help.
More than a dozen Youngstown residents will pay their own way to Sicily next month to accept an invitation from Mayor Leoluca Orlando of Palermo to study "the Palermo Renaissance," the progress of that city in rooting out corruption and violence of the quasi-feudal sort that critics say bedevils Youngstown. 
 "We want to look at the cultural side of this," said James B. Callen, a lawyer and a leader here of reformers who have been trying for 20 years to arouse citizens against the political inroads of organized criminals.
Mr. Callen will head a delegation to a United Nations conference in Palermo on new methods for altering the cultural roots of organized crime.
The four-day symposium will focus on programs to influence the young and, through them, their families and society about the traditional ways criminals can exploit cultural solidarity. Re-education through schools and churches is a key part of programs against organized crime under way in Palermo, Hong Kong and Baja California.
Dealing with different ethnic groups but similar cultural tolerances, leaders in the three areas have taken a new tack toward entrenched crime, said Roy Godson, a professor of government at Georgetown University. Mr. Godson runs the National Strategy Research Center, which studies remedies for the problem, and introduced Palermo officials to the efforts of Mr. Callen's organization, the Citizens' League of Greater Youngstown.
Mayor Orlando invited Mr. Callen to the Dec. 12 symposium "to learn lessons from the Sicilian experience in fostering cultural change." For 20 years, Palermo's battle with Mafia criminals has attracted worldwide attention, first with the brazen mob assassinations of leading prosecutors, then with the community revulsion and resolve that followed.
The new Sicilian Renaissance Institute, born of the local reform effort, has been inviting scholars and officials from around the world to study the mix of school, church and political programs that Italian reformers have put to work. The Youngstown visitors will find themselves alongside officials from the Republic of Georgia and other regions deeply troubled with criminal subcultures.
The new re-education approach uses role-playing and pop culture to show youngsters how peer pressure toward casual criminality can be resisted, Professor Godson said. The Baja California school program, for example, uses Spanish versions of the novel "Lord of the Flies" and the film "Goodfellas" to underline lessons on youthful hero worship and the need for fair rules in society. Mr. Godson said that curriculum was being used in schools near both sides of the Mexico-United States border and had been so promising that it would be increased to 60 classroom hours a year from 36.
"This has immense potential," said Mr. Callen, who expects to visit such places as Corleone, a picturesque village steeped in Mafia history, where Sicilian officials say there has been a sharp turnaround in the age-old mistrust of the honesty of law enforcement.
"We hope we'll be able to translate what we find out over there into concrete action here," said Mr. Callen, who for two decades has prodded a spirited and hardly one-sided debate in Youngstown about the pervasiveness of organized crime.
Youngstown's mayor, George M. McKelvey, a popular Democrat who styles himself a leading crime buster, has politely declined the trip to Palermo, arguing that this city is well on the way to recovery from a time when public figures "sold their souls to the mob."
"We are cutting that cancer out of our community," Mayor McKelvey maintains, in the face of skeptical reformers who point to a continuing investigation in which more than 70 officials and local mob figures have been prosecuted.
Youngstown is one of the most scrutinized areas of the country. Waves of special federal investigators comb this eastern Ohio region of faded steel-mill towns and post-immigration insularity long rooted in the mistrust of despotic Old World politics.
Local and federal officials regularly attack a complex nest of political kickbacks and mob corruption punctuated by murder and extending through the surrounding Mahoning County. Even a prosecutor hailed as a mob buster was eventually indicted as tainted, while another prosecutor was shot and wounded after the mob deemed him unbribable.
A tough, blue-collar city, Youngstown has been bypassed by the economic boom in the surrounding suburbs. Residents endure both limited opportunity and the sting of stereotypical Mafia jokes. Through it all, many rally to the colorful, combative local congressman, James A. Traficant Jr., a Democrat who says that both he and the city are being unfairly singled out by federal investigators who are themselves run by the mob.
While steering well clear of that accusation, Mayor McKelvey contends that "ivory tower" reformers have made a grave mistake in claiming that the public is so passive and cynical about local politicians that it accepts ties between politics and the underworld as inevitable.
"This is a key difference," Mayor McKelvey said, touching the heart of Youngstown's reform debate. "I repeatedly hear our electorate insulted, and I don't join in that chorus. The failures here have been on the part of elected officials, not the electorate."
The mayor campaigned first against mob vending machines at City Hall and now insists that a new generation of political leaders is unsullied.
But Mr. Callen warns that unless determined efforts are made to change an underlying culture of tolerance, Youngstown will live out its corrupt habits in a repetition, as in the film "Groundhog Day."
Hearing that, Mayor Orlando wrote Mr. Callen an encouraging note that "Palermo, too, was like 'Groundhog Day' " but now had lessons to offer in "reversing those deep-rooted attitudes of indifference, skepticism and cynicism which are fertile fields for illegality."
Mr. Callen said, "Palermo seems like a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity," and he said he was eager to see what Ohio and Sicily might have in common.
"If this trip forces a confrontation, that's good," he said of his critics in local news organizations and politics. "It's exactly what we need in this community."

HEADLINE: City Revises Plan to Create Jobs for Poor

BYLINE: By ERIC LIPTON

 BODY:
The Giuliani administration, after winning a nine-month legal battle with the city comptroller over $104 million in city contracts to place welfare recipients into private-sector jobs, is now backing away from that plan, according to the top executive of the company at the center of that conflict.
The move reflects the broad troubles the city has had in starting its new welfare program, according to several contractors involved in the process. Fewer than 4,000 people have been placed in jobs under one set of contracts, compared with a goal of more than 17,000 placements this year, city records show. 
 The complications mean that the city no longer intends to ask Maximus Inc. of Reston, Va., the company at the center of the legal fight between the Giuliani administration and the city comptroller, to deliver all of the services for which it had been hired, said David V. Mastran, Maximus's chief executive. And other companies the city is already working with on the welfare-to-work effort are angry over what they say is a poorly organized program to shift welfare recipients into jobs.
The welfare recipients are being referred to contractors without the required screening to determine if they need to learn English, for example, or if they have drug or mental health problems, several companies under contract with the city said. Even when these recipients are ready for work, they often cannot start or keep jobs because the city has at times failed to provide the needed day care, health care or routine transportation allowances, the contractors said.
"It has been an operational nightmare," said one contractor, who, like the other three interviewed over the last two weeks, asked not to be identified for fear of retaliation by the city. "They could not have done a worse job if they did it intentionally." All four of the contractors provided similar descriptions of the program's problems.
The Giuliani administration did not respond to repeated requests over the last two weeks for documentation detailing progress with the program. Instead, it issued a statement late yesterday that said, "The city's innovative welfare-to-work contracts have helped move thousands of New Yorkers from dependency to self-sufficiency."
The statement did not dispute that the welfare-to-work contracts have not met administration goals. But city officials have noted that the welfare rolls continue to decline, to 557,349 as of last month from a peak of 1.16 million in 1995, in part because many welfare recipients, benefiting from the city's booming economy, are apparently finding jobs on their own. The administration says adding the people who have found jobs themselves to those placed by contractors brings the number of job placements this year to 94,000, although the city would not provide the documentation to support that assertion.
The overall goal has been to transform a welfare employment program run by the city's Human Resources Administration that emphasized placing the poor in manual-labor city jobs, like cleaning parks or city office buildings, into one that focuses on getting them private-sector jobs, like clerical, retail or custodial work.
Starting last year, state and federal grants previously given to the city's Department of Employment were transferred by the Giuliani administration to Human Resources, which then signed contracts with companies that would be paid, with some small exceptions, only if they succeeded in placing welfare recipients in jobs.
Late last year, the city awarded 17 contracts, totaling $469 million over three years. Maximus won $104 million, the largest single chunk. But in February, before payments for any work were approved, Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi objected to the contracting process, claiming that the Giuliani administration had improperly used an accelerated system of picking winning bidders that was less rigorous than it should have been.
Ultimately, Mr. Hevesi blocked only the two Maximus contracts, which he said were particularly troublesome. He said its executives had been given improper access to top officials before the bidding began. Mr. Giuliani sued the comptroller and lost. But last month, the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court sided with the mayor, concluding that the city was justified in using the abbreviated contracting process and that there was no evidence of favoritism toward Maximus.
Criminal investigations of the matter by the Manhattan district attorney's office and the federal government are under way, but the appellate ruling cleared the way for the city to reinstate the Maximus contracts. Mr. Hevesi has until the end of the month to decide if he will appeal, although he has acknowledged that that will be difficult because the the five-justice Appellate Division's decision was unanimous.
To date, Maximus officials and the city have not met to discuss reinstating the contract, company officials said yesterday. The Human Resources statement yesterday said the city was "determining the best way to implement Maximus contracts into the city's ongoing welfare-to-work initiatives."
But Mr. Mastran said his company was in no rush to restart its New York City effort.
"Everybody has been shellshocked" about the process, Mr. Mastran said Thursday in a telephone conference call with investment analysts. "The mayor only has another year in office and the next mayor could possibly be this comptroller. So we are not anxious, really, to step out big time on this."
The plan now, Mr. Mastran told investors, is to pursue a project that would generate only about $3 million to $4 million a year in revenues for Maximus, compared with the approximately $35 million a year previously expected. Under its original contract, Maximus would have evaluated welfare recipients, provided them with job training if needed, and placed them in jobs that the company would find.
Under this new contract, Mr. Mastran said, the company would focus on one of the primary problems in starting the new welfare effort: ensuring that clients referred to the contractors are prepared to actually take on jobs in the private sector.
Several of the contractors said they were getting far fewer referrals from the city than they had expected. And of those whom they did get, only a tiny percentage had been screened. Part of the trouble has been that Maximus was supposed to have helped with the screening, but the problem is so extensive that even if Maximus's contracts had been approved, it would not have been resolved, several contractors said.
The result is that far more of the welfare recipients than the contractors had expected require extensive counseling or other services before they can be placed. The contractors, several of which took advance payments from the city to start their efforts, have in many cases placed so few welfare recipients that the city is asking for some money back. That has angered many of the contractors, who rented space and hired staff members expecting much greater demand for their services than the city has delivered.
For example, the Wildcat Service Corporation of Manhattan, which began work last November, has placed 740 welfare recipients to date, compared with an agreed-upon annual goal of 3,315 placements, according to city documents. America Works of New York, which also started providing services last year, has 231 confirmed placements, compared with its goal of 2,000, city documents show.
Citywide, 30,087 people have been referred to the employment services and placement contractors, and of the 21,843 who were seen by the contractors, 3,711 had been placed as of Nov. 12, according to a city spreadsheet provided by one contractor. That overall placement rate, 17 percent, is less than half of what some of the contractors said they had hoped to achieve. By comparison, an adult job-training program for welfare recipients run by the Department of Employment in 1998 had a 32 percent placement rate, according to a 1999 city audit.
"They have tried to do the right thing, a good thing," one of the contractors said. "But Human Resources is probably the largest and most complex welfare system in the whole country, and to mount something as quickly and all-encompassing as they tried to do was bound to run into a lot of operational problems. And it has."

HEADLINE: Fujimori Resignation Sets Off Succession Scramble in Peru

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS 

DATELINE: LIMA, Peru, Nov. 20

 BODY:
The Peruvian Congress received President Alberto K. Fujimori's formal resignation today, setting off a flurry of maneuvering by congressional leaders to decide who will succeed him and oversee the transition to new elections.
A day of back-door negotiations led to the resignation of Second Vice President Ricardo Marquez, Mr. Fujimori's hand-picked successor, making it likely that the opposition will take over the government by the end of the week. But it still remained possible that another former aide to Mr. Fujimori could rise to power to administer the transition toward new presidential elections in April. 
 In a letter from Tokyo addressed to Valentin Paniagua, the new president of the Congress, Mr. Fujimori said he was stepping down "to open a definite political path that will permit an orderly transition, and no less important, preserve the solidity of our economy."
With Mr. Fujimori signaling to aides on Sunday his intention to resign and remain indefinitely in Japan, there were spontaneous celebrations in the streets ranging from workers and students dunking each other in the colonial fountains of Arequipa to protestors burning tires in other provincial cities while carrying banners demanding that the entire "Fujimori mafia" be imprisoned. The sense of relief that Peru's long roller-coaster of a political crisis may be coming to an end was summed up by the simple banner headline in today's Liberacion newspaper: "Finally!"
But Mr. Fujimori's resignation, following months of corruption scandals and turmoil in his own ranks, left many questions unanswered, and his country's stability in doubt. The Congress will begin Tuesday what promises to be raucous proceedings to decide who will take over the government until a new elected president can be inaugurated in July. Mr. Paniagua, a veteran centrist legislator, is considered the favorite. But First Vice President Francisco Tudela, who resigned last month, was said to be considering to offer himself for the job.
Mr. Fujimori's shadowy former intelligence chief, Vladimiro Montesinos, apparently remains at large somewhere hidden in Peru while prosecutors investigate charges against him involving money-laundering, gun-running and death squads.
Alejandro Toledo, the main opposition leader who always appears to be abroad at the worst moments, rushed home from Madrid, but not before suggesting that Mr. Montesinos might have already been killed to keep all his secrets and embarrassing videotapes from coming to light.
The government appeared in a shambles tonight, with no one acting as president. Only three members of Mr. Fujimori's cabinet showed up for work today, and at least five Fujimori allies in Congress announced that they were deserting his coalition.
Opposition leaders huddled through the day with congressional allies of Mr. Fujimori and two senior Clinton administration officials who arrived in Lima today. The opposition's efforts to pressure Mr. Marquez to resign appeared to gain Washington's support, and Mr. Marquez was quick to remove himself from the government after taking charge for less than 48 hours.
"What the country deserves is political stability," Mr. Marquez told reporters at the presidential palace tonight. Looking tired and disheveled, he added, "Many political leaders have called on me to resign and I have decided to do that for the good of the stability of the country."
The power vacuum emerged when Mr. Fujimori, 62, telephoned top aides on Sunday to tell them that he would resign and not return to Peru anytime soon.
In a statement released early today, Mr. Fujimori said he made his decision after the opposition took control of the Congress last week -- timing suggesting that he was concerned that the opposition would use its power under the Constitution to remove him by voting that he was "morally incapable" of serving.
The crisis was set off by the presidential elections last April and May, which were widely criticized here and abroad for vote fraud and government manipulation of the campaign. But pressures for Mr. Fujimori to leave office reached critical mass in September, when a videotape was broadcast on a local television channel showing Mr. Montesinos the former intelligence chief, apparently bribing an opposition legislator to join the government's congressional delegation.
While pressuring Mr. Montesinos to resign, Mr. Fujimori announced that he would serve only one year of his third five-year term and then hand power over to a new president to be elected next April and inaugurated in July. Mr. Montesinos fled to Panama, but returned to Peru last month. He remains at large even as government prosecutors investigate several foreign bank accounts linked to him that contain nearly $60 million.
After Mr. Montesinos returned on Oct. 23, First Vice President Tudela resigned. But since his resignation was never accepted by the Congress, he could still be a presidential contender.
After Mr. Marquez resigned, Congresswoman Cecilia Martinez, an influential independent, said she backed Mr. Tudela for the presidency. "No one has questioned his moral authority and he would make a fine president," she said.
Opposition leaders said today that they would move to have the Congress vote not to accept Mr. Fujimori's resignation, and then vote to remove him from office and set up an investigation into his financial dealings for eventual prosecution. They said they welcomed Mr. Marquez's resignation and would work to block Mr. Tudela if necessary.
Throughout the day, opposition leaders had said they were not sure they had to votes to elect one of their own, an effort they said was important to ensure a fair administration of the electoral process for the April 8 balloting. Although the opposition took control of the Congress last week by a 64-51 vote, opposition leaders said that five or six independent lawmakers would probably go along with Mr. Fujimori's forces.
"Paniagua will be the next president of Peru," said Fernando Olivera, an opposition lawmaker and a leading presidential candidate. "There are rumors of Tudela coming back, but I doubt it."
Opposition leaders said they had appealed to the Clinton administration and the Organization of American States to help convince Mr. Marquez that assuming the presidency would only lead to more political unrest. They said they appealed to Peter Romero, assistant secretary of state for Western Hemisphere affairs, and Arturo Valenzuela, the top Latin America adviser at the White House, who arrived in Lima today, to back Mr. Paniagua.
The United States ambassador, John Hamilton, met today with Mr. Marquez, an adminstration official said, adding that the second vice president was told he "does not have U.S. support."
The official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said, "We think Paniagua should be the guy."
But it was not clear whether the United States had played a crucial role in convincing Mr. Marquez to step aside. Mr. Marquez always appeared to be an unwilling leader, suggesting a few days ago that he might resign.

HEADLINE: Blue-Collar Urgency: Bathroom Rights

BYLINE: By MARY WILLIAMS WALSH

 BODY:
For three years, Audrey Jo DeClue endured an endless stream of workplace abuses, according to a complaint filed in federal court. Ms. DeClue, the first female line worker for the Central Illinois Light Company, said she had been shoved, hit and propositioned by male co-workers; had plied country roads in trucks fluttering with pornographic magazines; and had been subjected to the sight of men urinating on the ground in front of her.
So she sued the company for sexual harassment. Alas for her, the statute of limitations had expired for all but one of her grievances: Central Illinois Light's failure to respond to her repeated requests for a private place to relieve herself at work. Her whole case rested on the single issue of bathroom access. And a judicial panel ruled against her on that. 
 Ridiculous? Not for wage-earning women. Though the issue of bathroom access is virtually unknown in the white-collar world, it can be a flash point in factories, telephone calling centers, food-processing plants, construction sites, even schoolrooms. Lawyers, executives and journalists may hop off their chairs and seek relief at will, but employees at lower rungs of the economic ladder can be timed with stopwatches in the bathroom; stonewalled when they ask to go; given disciplinary points for frequent urination; even hunted down by supervisors with walkie-talkies if they tarry in the stalls.
"It's something out of the last century, but it's something out of this century as well," said Charley Richardson, director of labor extension at the University of Massachusetts in Lowell. He thinks bathroom access is being increasingly curtailed in certain workplaces as American businesses adopt Japanese production methods that link workers in interdependent teams. If one ducks out to the bathroom, the whole team flounders, he said.
While no agency keeps comprehensive statistics, occupational health specialists say they hear frequent complaints, especially from poultry workers, who cannot step away from fast-moving assembly lines without causing pileups of dead chickens. Then, said Jackie Nowell, health and safety officer for the United Food and Commercial Workers, which has organized some poultry plants, when a 10-minute rest break arrives, they use up the entire time just walking across cavernous plant floors and taking off their cumbersome rubber smocks and protective gear -- forget about getting to a toilet.
"I hear it a lot," said Ms. Nowell, who added that some workers resort to wearing adult diapers under their gear.
Factory workers are not the only ones afflicted. The Norfolk Southern railway runs hundreds of locomotives without flush toilets, only a "dry hopper system" consisting of a stool lined with a plastic bag. Train operators recently showed their derision by hurling the used bags off moving trains, but Norfolk Southern moved to restore order by printing employee numbers on the bags, and keeping track of which employees brought them back full.
When Marc Linder, a labor historian at the University of Iowa in Iowa City, surveyed a group of grade-school teachers in that state, more than half said they were pinned down in their classrooms for hours at a stretch, unable to relieve themselves. Most coped by avoiding coffee and water, but a few routinely wore sanitary pads to work and "11 percent of elementary schoolteachers brought all the children with them to the bathroom when they were unable to hold it any longer," Mr. Linder said.
Disturbed by such findings, he went on to be a co-author of a 244-page history of workplace bathroom practices in the United States and Europe, "Void Where Prohibited" (Cornell University Press, 1997). The title may be a pun but the rest of Linder's tour d'urinal is grim, revealing among other things that the federal government regulated the number of toilets at workplaces but did not require companies to let workers use them. (The Occupational Safety and Health Administration has since issued a memorandum closing that loophole. Mr. Linder says he plans to research whether the memorandum has had any effect.)
In Illinois, Ms. DeClue's high-voltage electrical crew worked in open farmland, with no gas stations or even trees to hide behind. Once, she ducked behind a bulldozer for cover, only to discover she was squatting directly in view of a homeowner who came out and excoriated her, then went back inside and reported her to the utility.
Her question for the court: Did the electric utility's failure to provide sanitation and privacy constitute harassment? A federal district judge in Peoria threw out the case last December. Ms. DeClue appealed. At the appellate level, the three-judge panel split revealingly along gender lines.
The two male judges conceded that women may be "more reticent about urinating in public than men," but said Ms. DeClue had erred by making her case on "hostile work environment" grounds rather than "disparate impact" grounds, and they could do nothing for her.
To that, the female panelist, the Reagan appointee Ilana Rovner, issued a remarkably personal dissent. She chided her colleagues for their "formulaic constructs" of gender discrimination. She wondered how eagerly a lone male would "drop his trousers" after bouncing around in a truck full of female co-workers and pornographic magazines. She recalled that as recently as the early 1990's, the seemingly trivial issue of bathroom access had the power to change the course of government: because there were no women's rooms convenient to the House and Senate chambers then, female legislators risked missing votes.
Legal scholars say that nearly a quarter- century after President Jimmy Carter began naming large numbers of women and minorities to the federal bench, women jurists are lending a measurably more receptive ear than males to cries of gender discrimination. Judge Rovner's opinion makes an illuminating example of that trend. She remembered her own appointment, and the welcoming note she received from a male judge who said, "At long last, the ladies' room off the judges' conference room will have some use!"
"Thank goodness there was a woman's room," Judge Rovner wrote, in a dissent some have interpreted as a call for more women to come forward with bathroom-access complaints. Already, a case is moving through the lower levels of the same federal circuit, involving a female construction worker who says she was required to stay in position for a whole day with no chance to relieve herself. In her complaint, she says she heard a "pop" and wet herself. When a colleague took her to the hospital, she was fired for leaving her post.

HEADLINE: WINE TALK;
Where the Sommeliers Shop

BYLINE: By Frank J. Prial

 BODY:
IN New York's overheated wine market, restaurant owners and their sommeliers are often forced to go to auctions to find the fine wines they want. Last Saturday, one of the city's best-known restaurateurs did just the opposite: he went to Sotheby's to sell wine, about $343,000 worth, as it turned out.
The wine, some 241 lots of it, was from the cellar of Union Square Cafe, Danny Meyer's popular restaurant on East 16th Street. All but three of the lots were sold, according to Oliver Bareau of the wine department at Sotheby's, many of them to other restaurants. 
 It was the first time since wine auctions became legal in New York in 1994 that anyone could recall a high-profile restaurant's selling wine in a place other than its dining room.
"We were running out of room," said Mr. Meyer, who owns the restaurant with his partners, Michael Romano and Paul Bolles-Beaven. "I've been paying between $30,000 and $40,000 a year for refrigerated storage space in New Jersey. Things were getting out of hand."
Almost as important was the rapidly increasing value of so many of the restaurant's older bottles. The prices of many fine and rare wines have increased exponentially in the last decade. "My customers don't come in looking for $2,000 bottles of wine," Mr. Meyer said, "but that's what some of this stuff was worth." In fact, a case of a rare Bordeaux, Chateau Le Pin 1982, brought $24,150 at Saturday's auction. "I paid less than a tenth of that when I bought it," Mr. Meyer said. "I couldn't afford to keep it any longer." Similarly, six bottles of Sine Qua Non, a syrah from a small, so-called cult winery in California, sold for $1,400, while a case of 1990 Chateauneuf-du-Pape from the renowned Chateau de Beaucastel went for $1,300.
The most expensive lot sold was five cases of 1990 Bordeaux; one each of the chateaus Lafite-Rothschild, Mouton-Rothschild, Latour, Margaux and Cheval Blanc. It went for $21,650. A single case of Bryant Family Vineyard Napa Valley cabernet sauvignon went for $6,325.
Of particular interest was the fact that none of the Union Square wines were old and possibly past their prime. The oldest wines offered were the 1975 Chateau d'Yquem from Sauternes and a 1978 Burgundy, a Pommard Rugiens from the Domaine Michel Gaunoux. Most of the wines offered were from the 1980's and 1990's, some from very recent vintages, like a case of 1998 Batard-Montrachet, a rare white Burgundy, from the Domaine Paul Pernot.
Mr. Meyer opened Union Square Cafe in 1985, shortly before the current, frenzied market in fine wines began. He established his wine cellar by buying at prices newer restaurant owners can only dream about. "I bought way, way too much," Mr. Meyer said. "I used to buy 20 cases when I needed, at most, 10." It would seem to have made sense to share the inventory with his other New York restaurants, Gramercy Tavern, Eleven Madison Park and Tabla. But each has its own liquor license, and under state law it is illegal to use one restaurant's license to sell wine from another.
No doubt, many sommeliers, restaurant owners and wine stewards would love to have Mr. Meyer's problems. In fact, wine-trade professionals accounted for as many as half of the purchases at Saturday's auction. Well-heeled collectors bought the rest. Some of the Union Square Cafe wines should begin to appear on other restaurant wine lists fairly soon.
Restaurants that opened in the 1990's have often been desperate to find enough wine to create any cellar at all. Ralph Hersom, the wine steward at Le Cirque 2000, said he has never had excess inventory (the cellar was severely depleted before the move from 65th Street). Indeed, he often haunts the auction rooms, the only places to find the high-priced rarities that some of Le Cirque 2000's guests demand.
Other restaurant owners have found other ways to control their wine inventories. The Ryland Inn in Whitehouse, N.J., has one of the most extensive collections in the New York metropolitan area. The owner and chef, Craig Shelton, sells wine to an informal club of regulars and then stores it for them to use when they come to the restaurant. At Windows on the World, in the World Trade Center, the wine director, Kevin Zraly, controls his large stocks by what he calls "spring cleaning."
"This is the high season," he said, "right through Jan. 1. Then everything slows down. In February and March we simply stop buying and work off our inventory. All our suppliers know this, and they leave us alone until we call them."
In the peaceful days before wine shortages, restaurateurs used different techniques to thin out their wine collections. In the 1980's, at Le Chambertin, a small West Side restaurant with an excellent wine list, the owner, Louis Daniel, would go through his cellar periodically, singling out wines, usually top Bordeaux he felt had reached their peak. Then he would offer, at an irresistible price, dinners for two or four that included several bottles of the wines he wanted to move.
At the "21" Club, when H. Peter Kriendler was one of the owners, he would cull famous but aging wines from the restaurant's collection and offer them at $100 a bottle regardless of vintage or provenance. "No guarantees, no returns, no complaints," he would say. "You may get a dud, you may get a great buy." Harsh terms, but "21" regulars lined up.
Sotheby's had no trouble selling Union Square Cafe's bottles either. "It was a great success," Mr. Meyer said. "We sold 99 percent of everything we offered." In fact, his timing was excellent. This is the wine buying season, and while the economy may be slowing at some levels, it obviously has not yet affected the high rollers and eager restaurateurs who buy expensive wine.

HEADLINE: British Retailer Thrives the U.S. Way

BYLINE: By SUZANNE KAPNER

DATELINE: LONDON, Nov. 21

 BODY:
When making out their holiday shopping lists, few investors would place shares of British retailers at the top. They have been among the worst-performing stocks this year as the industry undergoes a profound shift that promises to alter permanently the way many of these companies do business.
In sharp contrast to the clumsy results from Marks & Spencer and Arcadia, where profits are shrinking, Matalan, one of Britain's pioneering discount chains, is cut from a different cloth. 
 Its net income has doubled in each of the last three fiscal years, to 37.6 million ($53.5 million), on sales of 398 million ($566.7 million). And there appears to be no end in sight. Through Aug. 26, the end of the first half of Matalan's fiscal year, profit doubled yet again as sales jumped 58 percent.
Since Matalan went public in 1998, its shares, adjusted for splits, are up more than tenfold. They closed today at 738 pence ($10.51).
"Matalan keeps beating earnings estimates, and the estimates keep going up," said Biagio Manieri, a senior analyst with Federated Investors, which counts Matalan as a top-10 holding in its $1.3 billion International Small Cap fund. "It's the Target of England," he added, referring to the discount store chain in the United States.
Matalan's resemblance to American discount stores is no accident. The company was founded by John Hargreaves, 57, the son of a Liverpool dock worker, who left school at 14 and cut his teeth as a street vendor selling second-hand goods from Marks & Spencer. Some years later, while vacationing in Los Angeles, Mr. Hargreaves was impressed with the supercenters springing up along the freeways and returned to England, where in 1985 he opened a warehouse-type store in Preston, 200 miles north of London.
Today, Mr. Hargreaves's 52 percent stake in Matalan is worth some $2.2 billion. As chairman, he still oversees many day-to-day details, like signing off on new collections. More than 80 percent of Matalan's merchandise is designed in-house, and one recent Monday morning Mr. Hargreaves inspected fall 2001 babywear, deciding which of Matalan's 112 stores would stock which pint-size jumpers.
The formula has been winning over British shoppers.
Pat Selsby, 56, and her daughter Linda, 31, used to shop at the local Marks & Spencer near their home in North London. Now they drive an extra 30 minutes to shop at the Matalan store in Greenwich.
"The value is brilliant," Mrs. Selsby said.
British consumers have not always been treated to great value, analysts say. "The U.K. has been a rigged market in terms of pricing," said one, who insisted on anonymity. "Things have been presented as good value which really haven't been. They've been priced to make a return on an expensive cost base."
While in the United States rents are often based on a percentage of a retailer's revenue, rents in Britain are fixed. If they move at all, it tends to be in one direction -- up.
At the same time, Marks & Spencer, Britain's largest retailer, stuck steadfastly to a policy of obtaining products domestically. As the pound soared, so did merchandising costs.
Faced with these rising costs, retailers simply raised prices, which worked fine until the Asian crisis in 1998 flooded England with cheap imports. Then came Rip Off Britain, the government crusade aimed at wiping out inflated pricing.
To stay competitive, retailers have had to cut prices deeply, which set off spiraling deflation. Recent figures from the Office of National Statistics show the sharpest decline in clothing and footwear prices since 1947.
Scrambling to lower costs, Marks & Spencer has recently restructured to obtain more products overseas -- but not before profits took a hit.
British consumers, like shoppers elsewhere in the world, meanwhile, started spending less on clothing and footwear, and more on travel, health and electronics. When they did buy, it was less from middle-market chains and more from discount stores or the luxury sector.
"Most retailers were unprepared for these changes and are still reeling from the shock," said Richard Hyman, chairman of Verdict Research.
Matalan, which already operated on a skeleton cost base, was one of the few prepared for these changes. Angus Monro, Matalan's chief executive, estimates that the company's costs are about 13 percent below those of in-town competitors because it pays less rent on out-of-town stores and cuts out middlemen by buying directly from factories.
To be sure, Matalan's lead is narrowing as other retailers are forced to become more efficient. And even though the discount market in Britain is still relatively small, commanding just 11 percent of retail sales last year, it is unlikely to dominate as it does in the United States. Population density means that a majority of Britons still shop in town. And strict regulations curtail building in rural parts of the country.
Even the world's best retailers, from Wal-Mart to the Gap, stumble eventually. With Matalan shares trading at 50 times this year's earnings, compared with an average price-to-earnings ratio of 17 for the retail sector, some analysts are concerned there could be quite a fall.
For now, though, Matalan executives are bent on bringing American-style value to Britain. Mr. Hargreaves and Mr. Monro recently returned from a trip to Long Island, where they scouted local Target and Kohl's stores for ideas.

HEADLINE: Theater Club Has Plans for Broadway House

BYLINE: By ROBIN POGREBIN

 BODY:
The Manhattan Theater Club, one of New York City's most prominent nonprofit theaters, has agreed to renovate and take over operation of the Biltmore Theater, a deteriorating Broadway landmark that has been dormant for more than a decade.
The deal is dependent on city approval of a development proposal that includes a high-rise apartment building next to the theater. 
 The 75-year-old Biltmore, damaged by fire in 1987, will be rehabilitated as part of a plan by a consortium headed by the Jack Parker Corporation that includes construction of the new apartment building with four floors of commercial space at 47th Street and Eighth Avenue. The theater club will put up one quarter of the $18 million renovation costs, and the rest will be paid by a development consortium, said Barry Grove, executive producer of the theater club.
"The Biltmore is a theater that needs to be rescued," said Mr. Grove. "The Manhattan Theater Club has been looking for additional space for quite some time."
Plans for the project require approval from the City Planning Commission and the City Council because the proposed apartment building would be larger than ordinarily permitted by the city's zoning code. The developer plans to seek approval for a "theater bonus" that would allow construction of additional space because of the rehabilitation of a landmark Broadway theater.
The bonus would allow construction of the planned adjacent building to grow from as few as 33 stories, or 270,000 square feet, to as many as 62, or 480,000 square feet, said Martin McLaughlin, a spokesman for the development consortium, Biltmore 47 Associates.
If the developer is not granted the bonus, Mr. McLaughlin said, the high-rise would proceed, but the theater restoration would fall away. "If they don't give us the bonus, we're not going to get the extra revenue and the deal will fall through," he said.
The project is to be designed by Polshek Partnership Architects, whose work includes the Rose Center for Earth and Science at the American Museum of Natural History and the current renovation of Carnegie Hall. Under the plan, the theater club would continue to operate its two theaters, with capacities of 299 and 250 seats, at the City Center on West 55th Street. The rehabilitated Biltmore is expected to open in time for the 2002-3 Broadway season.
The Biltmore Theater, originally a 948-seat space, will be redesigned with a 623-seat capacity and improved public amenities, Mr. Grove said. The promise of a new stage comes at a time when the theater club has moved two shows to Broadway -- "Proof" and "The Tale of the Allergist's Wife" -- and when its nonprofit peers are increasingly looking to Broadway.
The Roundabout Theater Company, which recently moved into the historic Selwyn Theater (now called the American Airlines Theater) on 42nd Street, renovated at a cost of $25 million, and Lincoln Center Theater's Vivian Beaumont stage are already considered eligible for Tony Awards. The Biltmore would make Manhattan Theater Club productions Tony-eligible, which brings national exposure and a potential boost to ticket sales.
Mr. Grove said that the theater club would also consider selling the name of the theater to a sponsor. The Biltmore will allow the theater club to have an orchestra pit for the first time, and fly space for scenery. "We've been bursting at the seams at City Center in terms of audience capacity," Mr. Grove said. "A larger canvas is natural."
Although acknowledging that the theater club's budget of $11 million would have to increase to accommodate its new overhead, Mr. Grove said he was not prepared to estimate by how much. The theater club, which would have a long-term lease on the theater, will mount a capital campaign to help pay for the Biltmore's renovation, Mr. Grove said.
The developer will also be seeking approval from several city agencies or panels to include in the new building unused air rights from the adjoining fire house at the corner of West 48th Street.
Last year the Biltmore became the subject of a court battle between a real estate developer, Joseph Moinian, who said he wanted to restore and book the theater, and the Nederlander Organization, which said it might try to more than double the house's size so that it could accommodate big musicals.
The Moinian Group is now a partner in the consortium headed by the Parker Corporation, which owns numerous properties around town including the Parker Meridien Hotel.
Small theaters like the Biltmore, Belasco, Cort and Lyceum have been difficult to book because they have second balconies where many theatergoers don't want to sit and limited seating which makes it difficult to earn a return on a theatrical investment. But given the recent strength of the real estate market, the popularity of the Times Square area and the demand for Broadway theaters, these properties are suddenly more attractive.
John Fisher, the president of the Clinton Special District Coalition, said he was concerned that apartments in the proposed high-rise would command top rents and put further pressure on prices in the rapidly changing neighborhood to the west. "The city should have its working class neighborhoods, and it should have its version of the Hamptons," he said.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Troubled Session Scatters Investors in Many Directions

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Stock investors, although tired of selling and eager for a rally, struggled in vain to find a direction yesterday and sent stocks wavering throughout a choppy session.
Uneasiness about falling profits, the country's economic slowdown and more analyst downgrades of high-profile stocks made it impossible for any substantial gains to stick. By the end of the day, investors had taken to their recent approach of bidding blue chips moderately higher and selling technology issues. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average at times soared above 100 points, but it retreated to close up only 31.85 points, or 0.3 percent, to 10,494.50.
Broader indicators were mixed. The Nasdaq composite index ended off 4.19 points, to 2,871.45, after bobbing in and out of positive territory. It was the Nasdaq's lowest close since Oct. 27, 1999, when it finished at 2,802.52.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 4.73 points, or 0.4 percent, to 1,347.35.
Investors were still waiting for Wall Street's typical post-election rally and they seemed to want to bid stocks higher. However, they had trouble overcoming disappointments about earnings and worries that the economy is slowing at an uncomfortably fast pace, analysts said.
"They're trying to bounce a little bit," said Jim Myers, director of technical research for Janney Montgomery Scott in Philadelphia. "But the economy is softening faster than most people suspected."
Investors were somewhat inspired by good earnings results reported by two technology companies, Agilent and Medtronic. Agilent, the company spun off by Hewlett-Packard, gained $4, to $48.63. Medtronic, a medical technology concern, rose $1.56, to $51.13.
But, analysts said, the market still has some unrealistic earnings expectations, and that means the sharp sell-offs in recent sessions will continue when companies come out with disappointing results.
"We are still going to have to come to grips with earnings expectations that are too high," Mr. Myers said.
But investors are right to focus on earnings, some analysts said.
"Prior to this year, you could buy just about any stock and it would go higher," said Chris Dickerson, market analyst for Global Market Strategists. "Now you have to be a lot more careful and pay attention to the fundamentals of the stock."
Investors punished Lucent Technologies, pushing it down $3.38, to close at $17.56, after it announced that its fourth-quarter revenue was $125 million less than it first reported.
Yahoo slid $7.19, or nearly 15 percent, finishing at $41.69, after Mary Meeker of Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, the well-known Internet stock analyst, said Yahoo had a 30 percent chance of missing revenue estimates for the current quarter.

Little Change on Yields
By Reuters
Treasury bond yields were little changed yesterday as uncertainty over the presidential contest compounded already depressed pre-Thanksgiving volumes.
The 10-year Treasury note rose 3/32, to a price of 100 23/32. The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 5.65 percent from 5.66 percent on Monday.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond climbed 12/32, to 107 13/32. The bond's yield declined to 5.73 percent from 5.75 percent on Monday.

HEADLINE: September Trade Gap Raises Some Fear on Pace of Slowdown

BYLINE: By JOSEPH KAHN

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21

 BODY:
Imports surged, exports slipped and the United States trade deficit widened sharply to a record in September, raising fears that the economy is slowing faster than expected and that the robust dollar may come under pressure.
The trade gap reached $34.3 billion in September as imports rose to $126.62 billion, up 3.1 percent from August, and exports fell 0.7 percent, to $92.36 billion, the Commerce Department announced today. The deficit is on course to reach $365 billion this year -- it grows on average by $1 billion a day -- with the total likely to surpass the record 1999 level by about $100 billion. 
 Most economists have treated the seemingly relentless march of the deficit with relative equanimity this year, arguing that it reflects the disproportionate strength of the United States economy compared with major trading partners and, more recently, the possibly temporary rise in the price of imported oil.
But September's data, which was considerably worse than expected, seems to have shaken that confidence. Some economists have begun to wonder whether the combination of the large deficit and a dollar that has strengthened sharply against most major currencies all year raises the risk of a hard landing.
"This is the Damocles' sword hanging over us -- the largest long-term threat to our economy," said Greg Mastel, a trade expert at the New America Foundation. "The next administration is likely to have to adjust trade policy, dollar policy and fiscal policy to find a solution."
The deficit numbers prompted several Wall Street analysts to lower their estimates for economic growth for the third quarter. Several said that they feared that the weak exports reflected tough competition from abroad while high imports suggested that retailers were piling up goods for Christmas sales that some think may be less vigorous than expected, leaving bloated inventories.
Salomon Smith Barney downgraded estimates of economic growth in the third quarter to slightly less than 2 percent, from 2.7 percent, arguing that the poor trade performance knocked anywhere from half to three-quarters of a percentage point off domestic growth for the quarter. Merrill Lynch and several other firms also cut growth estimates.
The Federal Reserve, of course, has been trying to slow the economy without touching off a recession, and to an extent the American ardor for imports and the buying power of a strong dollar advance that goal.
Even economists who say they are worried about the large deficit are not really sounding the alarm; as long as the United States continues to be the strongest magnet for world investment, trading partners may well go on financing the trade gap indefinitely.
But that view assumes that the deficit will top out on its own and not expand quickly. The combination of expensive oil, the recent surge in the value of the dollar against the euro and tough competition for American manufacturers has actually prompted the deficit to widen faster than it did earlier this year.
The dollar is a particular concern. Backed in part by the longstanding Clinton administration preference for a strong dollar, the currency has risen a little more than 20 percent the last 12 months against other major currencies. That is well beyond what some economists think should be its natural trading range.
After the Clinton administration's support for intervention to shore up the euro this fall, the next administration will probably consider at least a subtle tweaking of dollar policy. The goal would be to stabilize exchange rates or signal a desire for a modest retreat, potentially helping United States exports and discouraging imports, economists said.
In September, the trade deficit with China widened. The gap with China, a major supplier of consumer goods and electronics, hit a record $8.72 billion for the month, compared with $8.6 billion in August.
The China trade gap has become the biggest. But the deficits with Mexico and Canada also grew to records. The deficit with European nations and Japan, however, eased. The trade gap with Japan, the second largest after China, fell to $6.09 billion from $6.76 billion in August.

HEADLINE: Power Agency Details Plans For Electric Turbines in City

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
Stepping in to reduce the threat of blackouts next summer, the New York Power Authority is detailing its plans to install a fleet of small electricity generators around Brooklyn, Queens and the Bronx and on Long Island and possibly in Staten Island.
Not only do officials hope to avert blackouts with the generators, but they also hope to hold down the price of electricity on hot summer afternoons, when high demand pushes up power rates in the newly deregulated market. 
 "We're trying to increase reliability here in this city," said Clarence D. Rappleyea, the chairman and chief executive of the power authority, which plans to make the announcement of the new plants today. "We're trying to keep the lights on in the city of New York, and I think everybody knows what happens when we have a problem with that."
In fact, the decision by the state-owned agency to install the generators was a sign that deregulation of the utility industry is not working as was anticipated, at least not yet. The idea behind deregulation was that entrepreneurs would rush to build new power generators to meet high demand, as occurs in other parts of the economy.
"It's kind of going back into the old regime," said John W. Dax, a lawyer for NYC Energy, a company that is trying to win permission from various state and federal agencies to build a 79-megawatt power plant at the Brooklyn Navy Yard. The plant would be built on a barge and could be put in place quickly, Mr. Dax said, but the Power Authority's action was making it difficult to win financing.
"Everybody is saying, do I want to invest in a project that has had the economic legs kicked out from under it by the state," Mr. Dax said.
But Mr. Rappleyea, in a telephone interview, said that the generators would probably not be a good business proposition and that his agency was spending an extra $50 million for additional pollution controls, something that he said a private entity would probably not do.
The Power Authority generators, built by General Electric, will burn natural gas and are to be equipped with acoustic muffling and with devices called selective catalytic converters. Akin to the catalytic converters on cars, they sharply reduce nitrogen oxides, which are a cause of smog, acid rain and particulate pollution. All locations chosen by the Power Authority are in industrial areas, except for one, on Staten Island, which is adjacent to a Con Edison substation but which has housing in the area. That one is still under study.
In a regulatory shortcut, the generators are slightly smaller than the size that would require approval by the state bureaucracy that regulates power plants, although they will need approvals from the Department of Environmental Conservation. There will be 10 of them, or 11, if the site on Staten Island is used. The Power Authority announced in September that it planned to add plants for peak days; it will say today that it has found places to put them.
New York City entered the summer of 2000 with too little capacity for comfort, according to the commission's staff, but made it through because the weather was relatively cool. Demand is growing by 1.5 percent a year, the commission said.
In addition, the area is short of transmission capacity. That has led the organization that arranges power sales in the state to order that companies selling power in New York City have enough generating capacity within its borders to meet 80 percent of their load, a criterion that the Power Authority does not now meet. The generators, shipped in 14 segments and looking like a series of grey metal boxes, are about 140 feet long and 40 to 55 feet high, with a 100-foot stack on the end. Each occupies about an acre. Gas comes in from under ground, and electricity leaves that way.

HEADLINE: Hundreds of Workers Strike At 2 Newspapers in Seattle

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER 

 BODY:
Newspaper Guild workers at Seattle's two daily newspapers, The Seattle Times and The Seattle Post-Intelligencer, went on strike yesterday over issues including wages, pensions and health benefits.
Their walkout began the first newspaper strike in this heavily unionized town in 47 years. Not since guild members walked out of The Detroit News and The Detroit Free Press in 1995 has there been a guild strike against a major-market daily. 
 Art Thiel, a sports columnist for The Post-Intelligencer and a spokesman for the guild, said yesterday that about 90 percent of more than 900 workers -- circulation personnel, copy editors, reporters, photographers and advertising sales representatives -- had walked out.
But H. Mason Sizemore, the president of The Seattle Times, said that when he walked through that newspaper's newsroom yesterday morning, he was "surprised at the number of Newspaper Guild employees who have chosen to work today." Both newspapers are continuing to publish during the strike.
The Times, which is controlled by the family of the publisher, Frank A. Blethen, and The Post-Intelligencer, which is owned by the Hearst Corporation, have separate newsrooms but their business functions are handled jointly by The Times, the senior partner of the two.
Of the 940 or more workers represented by the guild, about 130 work for The Post-Intelligencer and about 810 work for The Times. About 500 of those Times workers are in the advertising, circulation and marketing departments.
In telephone interviews yesterday, spokesmen for both sides in the dispute kept their language studiedly muted. When Mr. Thiel was asked about the worried comments of some reporters, who on Monday night urged their colleagues to wait 48 hours before going out on strike, he said: "Clearly apprehension by a number of people -- as there should be. If people aren't apprehensive about this, they've got a screw loose." He would not venture to guess how long the dispute might last.
The walkout began in the predawn hours of Tuesday morning after guild negotiators, on Monday, rejected what the newspapers' management called the final wage offer: a $3.30-per-hour increase over a six-year contract.
Union negotiators had sought about $4 over three years, though Mr. Thiel indicated that this was negotiable. According to Kerry Coughlin, a company spokeswoman, a federal mediator reported late Monday that the union had reduced its demand to a $3.25-per-hour increase, though still over a three-year period.
The two sides also failed to come to terms on pension and health benefits.
Currently, the top-minimum wage for a reporter at The Times with six years' experience is $857.73, or $21.44 per hour. At The San Jose Mercury-News, which this summer signed a new contract with a strike deadline looming, the comparable top-minimum salary for a reporter is $1,053.
But a company spokeswoman pointed out that merit-pay increases had raised the average newsroom wage 28 percent above contractual minimums. Senior reporters, according to a survey provided by the company, make $29.29 per hour, 4 percent above the median for similar employees reported in a survey by an industry group of 24 comparable newspapers.
Mr. Sizemore said, "Over five years, our increases are above the cost of living. Our wages are competitive with the local economy. The jobs we hire for nationally are competitive with what other people are paying."
Circulation workers, on average, have a lower pay scale, making as little as half what their newsroom counterparts do.
Two rank-and-file guild members from the editorial department at The Times said in telephone interviews yesterday that they were more concerned with the fate of the lower-paid employees.
"I felt I couldn't in all conscience be a credible journalist if I didn't think about others who are in a less-fortunate situation than I'm in," said Stanley Holmes, the aerospace writer at The Times. "Frank Blethen has been good to me and I appreciate that. But it's also about reasonable contract, reasonable representation and reasonable dialogue between the union and management."
The negotiations and their eventual impasse put pressure on Mr. Blethen's bottom line at a time when his minority shareholder, Knight Ridder, has publicly expressed dissatisfaction with The Times's performance. Knight Ridder holds a 49.5 percent share in the business. A buyout offer by P. Anthony Ridder, Knight Ridder's chief executive -- who has long chafed at The Times's industry-lagging profit margins -- was recently rejected by Mr. Blethen.
The Times, which recently reported a daily circulation of about 226,000, ceased afternoon publication eight months ago, beginning a head-to-head competition with the morning Post-Intelligencer. The latter's current daily circulation of 176,000 is about 15,000 below last year's level, an indicator that the new competition has hurt.
Mr. Sizemore said he expected that 92 Teamster-represented truck drivers, who handle the bulk delivery of the newspapers to major distribution sites, might honor the guild picket lines. But, he said, he had replacement drivers on hand.
Would other replacement workers fill in for the newsroom and business-side jobs? Mr. Sizemore responded, "Depending on how long the strike lasts, we have to figure out about making decisions about how to replace the people who choose not to work."
