HEADLINE: Real Estate;
Slim Building Casts a Modern Image

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL

 BODY:
The slender 24-story glass tower rising at 11 East 52nd Street in Manhattan has been described as a thermometer, totem pole, exclamation mark and space needle, while the architect himself has compared the planes of its sloping glass and steel facade to a guillotine blade slicing down.
To the Austrian Cultural Institute -- which expects to move next fall into the building, between Fifth Avenue and Madison Avenue -- the narrow tower's design will help create a modern image for Austria, as well as a conversation piece and tourist attraction for New York. 
 And despite his conjuring up images of Madame Defarge, Raimund Abraham, the Austrian-born architect, who says his comparison was intended in jest, has no doubt that the sloping building will live up to the institute's expectations.
"I was excited that this was a slim building," said Professor Abraham, who teaches architectural design at Cooper Union. "Its smallness provided me with a predetermined proportion of the tower."
Christoph Thun-Hohenstein, the director of the Cultural Institute, who holds doctoral degrees in law and philosophy from the University of Vienna, said, "Our old building became too small for our exhibitions, movies, concerts and lectures."
A diplomat who served in Bonn, Geneva and the Ivory Coast, he is 14 months into his four-year appointment to the institute, and eager to move into its new home.
For now, the institute is on the 20th floor of 950 Third Avenue, at the corner of 57th Street. There, among other duties, Dr. Thun-Hohenstein is busy planning 10 weeks of cultural events to celebrate the formal opening of the $20 million building next October.
Together with pride in his design, for which an international jury awarded him first place in 1992 over designs submitted by 225 other Austrian-born architects, Professor Abraham praised the project's development team. That includes the New York construction manager, Barney Skanska USA, and the New York structural, mechanical, electrical and plumbing engineer, Ove Arup and Partners.
At a mere 25 feet wide -- "barely wide enough to change your mind in," according to one passer-by -- the building was a challenge for the architect, and continues to challenge the engineers and workers who have to wrestle with minuscule tolerances and tight squeezes at almost every turn.
"A small building is a lot tougher to work on than a big building, because there's no room for anything," said Vincenzo Labarbera, the labor foreman at the job site for Barney Skanska. "There's no room to store material, so we're moving things all the time."
With horizontal space at such a premium, the piano for the building's planned 75-seat theater on the second and third floors will be stored in a space in the ceiling, from which it will be lowered onto the stage by a piano lift as needed, then returned to its resting place.
To save space while complying with New York law that buildings have at least two independent exits, Professor Abraham designed what are basically two stairways in one, known as "scissors stairs." At times they run side by side or above and below the other, separated by a firewall.
"I knew if one could not arrive at maximum usable space it would not be economical to build on the site," he said, recounting the political jockeying in Austria that thwarted construction on the building for almost five years. In 1995, the project was suspended after construction had started. Part of the wrangling involved a dispute over money; another issue involved a change of government.
By the time the foundation at 11 East 52nd Street was excavated almost two years ago, after the limestone townhouse on the site was razed, Austria's Ministry of Foreign Affairs had turned the development of the building over to an Austrian corporation.
The corporation, Bundes Immobilien Gesellschaft, the Federal Real Estate Corporation, is widely known by its initials, BIG. Since its founding in 1992, the corporation has managed and built some of the Austrian government's real estate holdings.
But BIG had never developed a building abroad. So its authority to do so came only after several years of debate and after a parliamentary resolution in 1996 amended Austrian law to allow BIG to work outside the country. While the Austrian government still owns the land at 11 East 52nd Street, BIG is the developer. It hired Hanscomb Inc., the New York construction consultants, as its representative to oversee the project.
For several years Professor Abraham despaired that his design -- his second in the United States (the first was for the Anthology Film Archives in Manhattan) -- would fall victim to politics in the country from which he emigrated in 1964. And whenever he visited Austria, he would hear about the project.
"Because of the political controversy," he said, "people on the street would ask me how the building in New York was coming along."
For all the partisan wrangling, Professor Abraham said, "there was never an attempt to influence or interfere with the architecture." He added, "I always considered it my project of destiny."

HEADLINE: Canada's Premier Tugged to Right by Challenger

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: TORONTO, Nov. 16

 BODY:
Riding out of the West on a platform of tax cuts and born-again social conservatism, a smooth-talking college-dropout-turned-politician named Stockwell Day has given Canadian politics its biggest shake-up in years.
Even though Prime Minister Jean Chretien and his Liberal Party are likely to extend their seven-year rule in the national election on Nov. 27, it was Mr. Day and his new Canadian Alliance that prompted the vote and forced Mr. Chretien to tack uncharacteristically hard to the right. 
 In the process, Mr. Day has challenged some of the cornerstones of Canada's identity, including the generous social spending that has saddled Canadians with one of the world's highest tax rates.
One month after Mr. Day arrived in Parliament this fall, Mr. Chretien's government suddenly announced the biggest tax cut in Canadian history, put at about $65 billion over five years. With Mr. Day having lost his main issue, Mr. Chretien then called a snap election, cutting short his second five-year term at three and a half years, the shortest term for a Canadian majority government since 1911.
Although Canadians tell pollsters they do not want an election, the 66-year-old prime minister does not want to wait a year to allow his 50-year-old rival to spread his message. On the social side, Mr. Day, an evangelical Christian, wants to show the world that Canada is not Scandinavia West. On the fiscal side, Mr. Day, a former Alberta treasury minister who instituted a flat income tax for his province, preaches that by cutting taxes, Canada can reverse its southward-flowing brain drain.
"The whining sound you hear is the sound of U-Haul trailers loading up and leaving the country because of high taxation," he told an Alliance rally in a Toronto suburb. The equivalent of a small Canadian city leaves each year for the United States, and referring to that loss of ambitious, well-educated Canadians, Mr. Day said, "Patriotism is wonderful, but if you can no longer afford it, you'll say, 'I'll put my flag in my pocket and put it on the wall of my new house in Denver and sing "O Canada" there.' "
In Ontario, the nation's economic powerhouse, people increasingly say they oppose Canadian income tax rates, which often total 50 percent. "It's a shame that Canada leads the G-7 in taxes," Monica Lozneanu, 19, a television production assistant, said here, referring to the group of industrial nations. "Stockwell Day looks like a leader. I think a lot of my friends will vote for him."
For party organizers, the conversion of people like Ms. Lozneanu to Mr. Day's Canadian Alliance is crucial for the new party to break out of its western birthplace and establish an electoral beachhead in Ontario, home to a third of Canadian voters.
"It is as if you rolled New York and California into one state," Rod Love, Mr. Day's strategist from Alberta, said here of Ontario's importance. Arguing that conservative voters dominate in suburban Toronto and interior Ontario, Mr. Love said approvingly of Ms. Lozneanu's politics: "It's like Nixon's silent majority. The people who obey the law, who pay taxes will vote Stockwell Day."
Arguing that a Canadian pays 25 percent more taxes on average than does an American, Mr. Day plans to spend his last week campaigning in Ontario, a province that has given him large, enthusiastic crowds.
Polls indicate that Mr. Day's drive to unite the right may fall short of its goal of depriving Mr. Chretien of a third consecutive majority government. In the last election, in 1997, Mr. Chretien won a slim 51 percent majority of parliamentary seats with only 38.5 percent of the popular vote, one of the lowest winning totals in Canadian history. He won the majority largely because, in a five-way race, the conservative vote split in Ontario between two right-wing parties, the Progressive Conservatives and the Reformers, the Western-based predecessors of the Alliance.
While polls indicate that Mr. Day is favored among Canadian men outside of Quebec, he lags among women voters who are uneasy about positions he has expressed, but not repeated recently, on abortion, gun control, gay rights and the death penalty. During the campaign, which is restricted to 36 days, Mr. Day has avoided controversial stands on social issues, which have been cut from his party's platform. He has been so smooth that Joe Clark, leader of the rival Progressive Conservatives, derided him in a debate as a "television game-show host."
Button-down Eastern Canadians also feel uncomfortable with Mr. Day's "American style" fondness for the campaign photo opportunity. A trim man who tries to exercise one hour a day, the conservative candidate has been photographed chopping wood, in-line skating, kick boxing and, dressed in a wet suit, zooming across a lake in a personal watercraft.
Those midlife athletics are an extension of a knockabout youth, part Captain Canada, part Jack London.
Mr. Day has lived in half of Canada's 10 provinces as well as in the Arctic territories. The son of a chain store manger, he spent his childhood in Ottawa, where he learned early political lessons, and in Montreal, where he learned serviceable French, a virtual requirement for federal office in a country where nearly one-quarter of the population speaks French.
During the 1970's, Mr. Day spent his 20's bouncing around a variety of jobs in the Canadian West -- working as construction day laborer, picking up bodies for a hearse company, shipping out as a deckhand on commercial fishing boats, driving a logging skidder in the Rockies, working for an oil and gas supply company in the Northwest Territories, killing cows in an Alberta slaughterhouse, running his own auction house and installing curtains for an interior designer.
"It was like something straight out of a Peter Lorre movie -- you'd go down some dark alley and a door would creak open and there would be the guy who worked in the funeral home, deep in the cover of night," Mr. Day said of his job picking up bodies in "Stockwell Day: His Life and Politics," a new biography by Claire Hoy. Of his work in native communities in the north, he said, "You'd be driving out on the frozen Arctic or on the frozen delta carrying a payload of 100,000 pounds of explosives, and the guy you traveled with was an Inuit worker, so you got to know a lot about Inuit life from the ice level up."
In contrast to his current white-collar image, Mr. Day dropped out of two colleges, never getting a diploma. As a youth, he says, he smoked marijuana -- and inhaled. In that hirsute phase of his life, he attracted the attention of Valorie Martin, a pet groomer who lived next door. They married, and she has taken care of his haircuts ever since.
Partly because of his wife's influence, Mr. Day became a strong believer in evangelical Christianity. He and his wife turned their house in Edmonton into a counseling shelter for runaway teenagers addicted to drugs. After studying briefly at a Bible college in Alberta's capital, he worked as a lay pastor and school administrator in Bentley, sometimes described as "the buckle of the Alberta Bible Belt." Living there for eight years with Valorie and their three sons, he gained prominence as a champion of evangelical schools.
From that base, Mr. Day was elected to the Alberta legislature in 1986. Rising through the ranks, he served eight years as a minister in conservative governments, stepping down last spring as treasury minister.
The outspoken Mr. Day says that his careful statements are often taken out of context, and that his call for a "values based" approach to teaching sex education in schools was reduced by reporters to total opposition to sex education. Mr. Day wrote in a letter to his local newspaper, the Red Deer Advocate: "I am not against sex. (Ask my wife.) I am not against sex education. (Ask my kids.) I am for parental choice of what type of sex education kids should be getting."
Opposed to Canada's new gun-registry law, Mr. Day bought a .38-caliber handgun when the first such bill was introduced in Parliament in 1994. Actions like this prompted Maclean's, a national news weekly edited here, to publish a Day cover article last summer with the title: "How Scary?" The writer mused ominously: "There is something, well, vaguely American about him."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

U.S. Trade Deficit Rose To a Record in September
Imports surged, exports slipped and the United States trade deficit widened sharply, to a record $34.3 billion in September, raising fears that the economy is slowing faster than expected and that the robust dollar may come under pressure.
The trade deficit is on course to reach $365 billion this year -- it grows on average by $1 billion a day -- with the total likely to surpass the record 1999 level by about $100 billion. Page C12. 

Privacy Worries on E-Mail Tracking
New software allows senders of e-mail to learn, undetected, when recipients read the messages and whether they send them to anyone else. Marketing companies regularly keep tabs on which prospective customers open their e-mail solicitations, and at what time of day, arguing that the data is used to devise more personalized promotions. But privacy advocates contend that such practices open a new window of surveillance on a traditionally private sphere of communications. A1.
 
Inquiry Begun on Goodyear Tires
Federal regulators opened a safety investigation into Goodyear tires installed on very large pickup trucks, vans and sport utility vehicles, the latest sign of spreading concerns about tire safety after Firestone's recall. C5.
 
Nasdaq Slips in a Mixed Session
Stocks were mixed on uneasiness about falling profits, the economic slowdown and downgrades of high-profile companies. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 31.85 points, or 0.3 percent, to 10,494.50, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 4.73 points, or 0.4 percent, to 1,347.35. But the Nasdaq composite index fell 4.19 points, to 2,871.45. C12.
 
More Allegations in McKesson Deal
The New York State Common Retirement Fund, one of the nation's largest institutional investors, contends in a lawsuit that the board of McKesson knew about accounting irregularities at HBO & Company before the companies merged. Floyd Norris: Market Place. C10.
 
Jewelry Theft and a New Friend
Dean O'Hare, chief executive of Chubb, the insurer, recalls an unusual client, a co-founder of a major weight-loss company. On a trip to Florida, $12 million worth of jewelry was stolen. "She was determined to recover her jewelry," he said, "and over two or three years she was successful, finding pieces at auctions, for instance. We had paid her entire claim, and every time she recovered a piece, she'd send us a check to reimburse us. We've since become good friends." The Boss. C6.
 
$653 Million Deal for Ticketmaster
Ticketmaster Online-City Search, which sells tickets online and manages 77 city Web sites, agreed to buy Ticketmaster, a subsidiary of USA Networks, for $653 million. C2.
 
Ford Expands Services for Workers
Ford and the United Automobile Workers announced one of the most ambitious social efforts ever undertaken by an American corporation, a program that will provide child care, recreation programs for teenagers and book clubs for retirees at centers nationwide. C8.
 
Review Released on Web Wiretap
A technical review of Carnivore, the Internet wiretap system developed by the F.B.I., has found that the system does what law enforcement officials say it does: gathers information from Internet service providers about the online messages sent and received by criminal suspects. But that conclusion did not satisfy critics of the system, who said that a study of specifications does get to the heart of privacy issues raised by Carnivore. A19.
 
Altered Corn Protein Reappears
Aventis said that a genetically altered protein unapproved for human consumption had been discovered in a variety of corn that could be headed toward the nation's food supply. The protein is the same one in StarLink, a variety of corn that turned up in taco shells. C17.

LENGTH: 619 words

HEADLINE: Joyful Holiday Travel

 BODY:
Thanksgiving, like any self-respecting holiday, is all about tradition. You have your family, your turkey, the annual argument about how long it should be cooked, the Lions game on TV, the pumpkin pie and the day-after sales. Oh, and don't forget being trapped for hours at an airport so mobbed it brings to mind the hellish "Gone With the Wind" scene of the Confederate wounded at the rail yard.
This year, with America's arteries clogged even on the best of days, the holiday travel season may be more trying than ever. At La Guardia Airport in New York City, to take one notorious case, the system is so strained that less than half the flights arrived on time in the month of September. Yet over the Thanksgiving holiday, a quarter more passengers than usual will be flying through La Guardia. That does not mean more flights, only longer lines and more frayed nerves. Nationwide, a record 2.2 million people are expected to fly on Sunday. At Newark Airport, passengers are being advised to show up three hours before their departure time over the holidays. 
 The onslaught of winter in parts of the country and the airlines' acrimonious labor relations threaten to create further mischief. There is at least one disgruntled union at all five of the largest airlines. Though no job actions have been publicly acknowledged, the airlines are wary. United and Northwest have obtained court orders directing their mechanics not to engage in any slowdown or other disruptive action over the holidays.
In recent days, United had to cancel an unusually large number of flights due to maintenance-related problems and has accused the union of an illegal slowdown. As harried travelers well know, United was forced to cancel some 20,000 flights this summer because of pilots' rejection of overtime out of frustration over the state of contract negotiations. Now Delta may face a similar predicament. The angst surrounding holiday travel should focus attention on the inadequacies of our transportation infrastructure. More than just a hassle, congestion threatens our economic well-being. Airline deregulation in the late 1970's caused a dramatic increase in air traffic, but the public entities of the aviation system have not adapted to the brave new world. Washington has been operating on autopilot when it comes to transportation matters.
Money is an issue, but not the only issue. Other countries have proved more nimble and creative at effecting reforms to cope with a surge in traffic. There is no scarcity of proposals worth considering in this country, from resolving the institutional conflict of interest at the Federal Aviation Administration (it is both the operator of the system and its safety cop) to a wholesale privatization of the air traffic control system. Some academics have floated the idea of giving airlines antitrust immunity to coordinate scheduling. An emerging consensus would have airports at long last adopt a more market-based approach to pricing landing rights, something now being considered by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.
The next president, whoever that may be, ought to think creatively about these issues and exert some leadership to alleviate the congestion in the skies. Distressingly little was said on the campaign trail about transportation issues, even though "air rage" and "road rage" have entered the nation's lexicon to describe the growing frustration people feel when stuck in traffic, either driving to work or flying across the country.
That anxiety should be in full evidence this holiday season. But whatever delays you may experience, don't get enraged at the beleaguered airline employees. Remember, it's not their fault.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Congress Puts Baseball Economics in Play

BYLINE: By IRVIN MOLOTSKY

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21

 BODY:
Senator Mike DeWine, an Ohioan whose state embraces a baseball team of "haves," the Cleveland Indians, and "have-nots," the Cincinnati Reds, convened a Congressional hearing today to ask what baseball was doing to make teams in small markets competitive.
Every team "ought to have hope" at the beginning of the season, he said, paraphrasing the song from "Damn Yankees," the musical about the lowly Washington Senators when they were more than just one of the chambers of Congress. 
 "The status quo is simply unacceptable," said DeWine, a Republican and longtime Reds fan. "Unless something is done to correct the payroll and revenue disparities among the teams -- unless we untie the stranglehold around the small- and medium-market teams by increasing competition -- baseball cannot survive."
Bud Selig, the commissioner of baseball, testified and supported DeWine's complaint.
"An increasing number of our clubs have become unable to successfully compete for their respective division championships," he said, "thereby making postseason appearances -- let alone postseason success -- an impossibility.
"The enduring success of our game rests on the hope and faith of each fan that his or her team will be competitive. At the start of spring training, there no longer exists hope and faith for the fans of more than half our clubs."
And unless something is done, he said, the disparities will grow because the teams with greater broadcast income will be able to sign the best players by outbidding teams with less lucrative contracts.
"In an age when the Yankees are rumored to be in line for a $100 million-a-year local media contract," Selig said, "it is difficult to have hope in Montreal, which, for the 2000 season, had no television contract and local revenue of just $14 million."
Selig said that sweeping changes were needed to correct the imbalance so that "all clubs -- those from markets that are diverse geographically, demographically and economically -- are provided a reasonably level playing field on which to compete."
DeWine said that he had called the hearing, by the antitrust arm of the Judiciary Committee, not to draw up legislation but instead to air a problem, which is done frequently in Congress.
Witnesses included the journalist George F. Will, the sports broadcaster Bob Costas and the former Senator George J. Mitchell, who repeated some of the findings of a panel that previously looked into baseball's economic imbalance.
"Changes are necessary if competitive balance is to be restored," Mitchell said. "When you have such clear symptoms of a problem, you act lest you wait until the patient is dead."
In answer to a question from DeWine, Selig said that baseball had in place a system in which 30 percent of the revenue was distributed from the larger to the smaller clubs.
"Is it enough?" DeWine asked. "No," said Selig, who added, "We need to take that 30 percent and boost it up."
Selig said that the Yankees were paying $17 million in revenue sharing, the Mets $15 million, with the clubs at the bottom (which he did not name) receiving $23 million, $20 million and $16 million.
Selig said that baseball as a whole was "in a loss position," with 18 to 20 of the 30 clubs having lost money in 2000.
DeWine suggested that some owners were willing to suffer losses in anticipation of selling their clubs at a big profit later.
Selig responded: "I heard that for many years and it was true to an extent. That is the 'greater fool theory.' The problem is that we've run out of greater fools."

HEADLINE: China to Stop Selling A-Arms Delivery Systems

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21

 BODY:
The Clinton administration and China said today that China had pledged to stop selling missile parts or the equipment needed for missile production to countries developing nuclear weapons.
In exchange, Washington agreed to waive economic sanctions for past sales of such materiel to Iran and Pakistan, the State Department said. This will allow American companies to apply again for licenses to launch satellites on Chinese rockets. 
 The agreement would help bring China into line with international standards restricting missile-related exports, officials said. They said that step, like membership in the World Trade Organization, would push China to be more responsible.
But in announcing the accord, which President Clinton and President Jiang Zemin reviewed at their meeting last week in Brunei, officials cautioned that China's pledges have yet to be enacted. "This looks good on paper," said one senior official involved in the talks. "What we'll have to watch is implementation," a job for the next administration.
The most promising aspect of the accord, officials said, was China's commitment to adopt an export-control list under which Beijing would require Chinese companies to get licenses to export "equipment, materials and technology that can be directly used in missiles, as well as missile-related dual-use items."
But the Chinese failed to specify what penalty companies would suffer if they exported without licenses.
It was also unclear how thoroughly the export-control list would be in compliance with the Missile Technology Control Regime. That agreement, which restricts sales of specific missiles and missile parts, was signed by 32 countries, but not China.
China's continued export of missile production facilities to Pakistan has been of particular concern in Washington since the nuclear tests by Pakistan and India in 1998.
The issue complicated White House efforts to win Senate passage of a bill this year granting China permanent normal trade relations, especially after American intelligence agencies reported that China exported a few dozen long-range missiles to Pakistan in 1992 and sent missile production facilities in the 1990's. Among the items China sent to Pakistan after the 1998 nuclear tests were specialty steels and guidance systems.
The announcement today, in effect, confirms those Chinese exports, which under American law required sanctions. The administration said today that while technically it was imposing the sanctions, it was waiving them in view of the new pledges.
For American companies, the immediate effect will be the unfreezing of licence applications to launch American satellites on Chinese rockets. Applications were frozen in February because of concerns that Chinese aerospace companies were exporting missile-related materials to Pakistan and Iran.
Many American companies, from cellular telephone networks to international television conglomerates, are waiting in line for satellites to be sent into orbit, and China has expressed eagerness to offer low-cost services.
Two American companies at the forefront of satellite launches in China, Hughes Space and Communications International and Loral Space and Communications, will not be affected by the waiving of sanctions, officials said, because they are under investigation to determine whether they improperly advised the Chinese on rocket design in the mid-1990's without obtaining licenses. The companies have denied any wrongdoing, but officials said they would not be allowed to apply for licenses until the cases are resolved.
In the past, Washington has twice imposed sanctions on China for its proliferation of missiles.
Each time the sanctions were lifted on the strength of promises made by Beijing. In 1991 sanctions were imposed on China for assisting Pakistan's missile program in the late 1980's; they were lifted a year later. In 1993 sanctions were imposed for China's help to Pakistan for the building of M-11 missiles; they were removed in 1994 when China agreed to comply with the main provisions of the technology control regime.
In light of China's past record, the agreement today was greeted with some skepticism. Senator Fred Thompson, Republican of Tennessee, said, "Once again, the Clinton administration appears to be rewarding China for promises made instead of promises kept."
A Democratic staff aide said the "jury was still out." But the agreement appeared, for the first time, to rule out any kind of Chinese assistance for missile programs in other countries, the aide said.
Yet the accord merely says in its first paragraph that China has no "intention" of assisting, in any way, any country to develop ballistic missiles that can be be used to deliver nuclear weapons, the aide said.
At a State Department briefing, a senior official was asked if the administration was letting China off the hook. In reply, the official argued that having made the "legal determination" that China had indeed exported missiles, exports that required sanctions, the administration then chose to waive the penalties.
"The purpose of the law after all is not to impose penalties," the official said. "The purpose is to encourage better nonproliferation behavior." 
http://www.nytimes.com

Florida Court Allows Hand Counts Until Monday
The Florida Supreme Court unanimously ruled that recounts could continue in three heavily Democratic counties but that the results must be submitted no later than Monday morning. It set no standards for determining how to count partially punched ballots. A1
 
The matter of whether ballots with small indentations on the unpunched boxes next to the names of Gov. George W. Bush or Vice President Al Gore count as votes could swing the election. Without the so-called dimpled ballots, Mr. Gore has little chance to overtake Mr. Bush. A1
 
Officials on both sides described the two candidates as intransigent, but Mr. Bush enjoys a political advantage because his backers are as determined as he is: they are more unified and more willing than Democrats to wage total war, at all levels legal and political, to win. A21
 
Major donors and fund-raisers for Mr. Gore and Mr. Bush expressed continuing support for their candidate and their cause, at least for now. Many say they are willing to invest whatever it takes to finance the postelection efforts. A21
 
Maria Cantwell, the Democratic candidate for United States Senate in Washington, pulled ahead of the Republican incumbent, Senator Slade Gorton, by nearly 2,000 votes, with fewer than 12,000 still to count. If Ms. Cantwell wins, the Senate will be split 50-50, assuming that Senator Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut does not become vice president. A19

The decision about whether the giant balloons take part in Macy's Thanksgiving Day parade depends on the answers to two questions: Will wind speed be above 23 miles per hour when the parade starts? Will gusts be stronger than 34 miles per hour? A yes to either question will ground the balloons. B1

HEADLINE: Peru After Fujimori

 BODY:
Alberto Fujimori, the unpredictable and often erratic president of Peru, resigned from office this week while on a visit to Japan. Peru's Congress, in turn, refused to accept his resignation and instead ousted him, declaring him "morally unfit" for office. It was an appropriately bizarre exit. The circumstances surrounding Mr. Fujimori's decision remain somewhat mysterious, but should not obscure the fact that his departure is a positive development. Peru's citizenry and opposition parties, as well as the international community, should capitalize on this opportunity to encourage the start of a new democratic era in Peru.
Valentin Paniagua, a Fujimori opponent and president of Peru's Congress, is poised to assume the nation's presidency until the elections scheduled for April. His caretaker government ought to focus on creating the conditions for a truly free election, conditions that were woefully absent in last summer's contest presided over by Mr. Fujimori. Peru must establish an autonomous electoral authority to oversee the process, grant its judiciary independence and provide competing political factions with equal access to the nation's media. 
 More broadly, the new government ought to restore a sense of stability and certainty to Peruvian life. The nation's 27 million people and fragile economy have been held hostage to the whims of Mr. Fujimori and his shadowy intelligence chief and indispensable aide, Vladimiro Montesinos. The new government must also pursue investigations into the alleged criminal activities of Mr. Montesinos, who reportedly squirreled away at least $58 million in overseas bank accounts and is now believed to be in hiding in Peru.
Peruvians living in poverty -- more than half the population -- were the real victims of President Fujimori's determination to retain power at all costs. The economy shrank in September as a result of the furor following the broadcast of a video that showed Mr. Montesinos paying a bribe to a politician. President Fujimori was once the darling of foreign investors, but as his administration became increasingly arbitrary, tax collection rates plummeted, capital fled the country and prospective investment dried up.
Not long ago, Washington would have greeted Mr. Fujimori's departure with mixed feelings because of his support for drug interdiction programs. Mr. Montesinos had longstanding ties to the Central Intelligence Agency. But in recent months Washington wisely distanced itself from both men. The United States should now welcome the formation of a more legitimate caretaker government and offer its assistance to assure that new elections are free and fair.

HEADLINE: Lucent Lowers Revenue Stated In Last Quarter

BYLINE: By SIMON ROMERO

 BODY:
Lucent Technologies warned shareholders yesterday that it would revise financial results already reported for the last quarter by cutting revenue by about $125 million. The unexpected move by the company, a maker of communications equipment, sent shudders across Wall Street.
Shares in Lucent plunged 16 percent, to $17.56, deepening the decline in the stock price to 75 percent this year. Lucent said the reduction in revenue could cut 2 cents a share from earnings for the quarter and the year. The company had originally reported earnings of 18 cents a share, or $600 million in profits from operations, on $9.4 billion of revenue. 
 In addition, the company warned investors to ignore earlier estimates for financial results for the quarter ending in December while an investigation of its accounting practices by its outside auditor, PricewaterhouseCoopers, begins.
Lucent had previously said revenue for the fiscal first quarter would decline 7 percent from $7.9 billion in the period a year earlier, while earnings from operations would break even at about $1.08 billion. The company has warned that earnings will be lower than expected each quarter this year.
"Just when you thought you were bottom-fishing with Lucent, wham" said Daniel P. McKelvey, managing partner of Forte Capital, a private equity and money management company in San Mateo, Calif.
Lucent's most recent woes reflect the problems the company faces in seeking to compete with companies that have eroded its market share as the transmission of data over the Internet has grown in importance over the delivery of voice calls. A host of nimble new companies, like CoSine Communications and Juniper Networks Inc., and larger companies like Cisco Systems and Nortel Networks, have benefited from a prescient emphasis on data transmission that Lucent, with its roots in the old Bell telephone system, has been slower to take advantage of.
The move renews pressure on Henry B. Schacht, who replaced Richard A. McGinn last month as Lucent's chief executive, and on Deborah C. Hopkins, who was appointed the chief financial officer earlier this year after occupying a similar post at Boeing. Lucent did not make either executive available for interviews.
"From what I understand, this came on her watch," said Michael E. Eggly, co-manager of the Northern Communications Fund in Chicago.
In a statement, Mr. Schacht said: "We wanted to make this public as soon as we discovered the issue. I have asked our outside auditor and our outside counsel to assist us in doing a complete review of this and any related issues."
While Lucent declined to specify the source of the revenue shortfall, some analysts who felt left in the dark shifted their opinion of the company. Michael Ching of Merrill Lynch downgraded the stock from a buy to accumulate and lowered his earnings estimate for the fiscal year 2001 and the quarter ending in December.
"I'm not suggesting that there's anything sinister going on at Lucent," Mr. Ching said, "but the release of information in this way raises more questions than it provides answers."
Analysts were also left to question whether Lucent will adopt different accounting practices as a result of yesterday's announcement. Among large makers of telecommunications equipment, Lucent was known for relatively aggressive ways of recognizing revenue. The appointment of Mr. Schacht as chief executive could lead to a change in these practices, analysts said.
"Lucent needs to tread carefully not to appear in a similar league with Oxford Health Plans and Tyco International," said John Gonsalves, vice president of Adventis, a communications consulting company based in Boston, in reference to two companies accused in the past of misleading investors about their financial situation. "Quick, solid disclosure of information on their part would be a positive move."
Lucent has hired the law firm of Cravath, Swaine & Moore to assist in the review of its financial results, a process that some analysts said could result in shareholder lawsuits. Such defensive moves by Lucent, which is the world's largest maker of telecommunications equipment, with yearly sales of more than $34 billion, should put competitors on alert, said Adrian Slywotzky, a senior partner at Mercer Management Consulting.
If these kinds of bombs can explode at Lucent, Mr. Slywotzky asked, are there other potential land mines lurking elsewhere in the industry? "At a time when trends in communications infrastructure are developing far faster than they were a couple of years ago," he said, "now is when companies need to focus more than ever on their customers' needs."
Many investors, of course, have already shifted their focus from Lucent to other companies in telecommunications and different sectors of the economy.
"All I can say is that I'm happy we got Lucent out of our portfolio," said John P. Waterman, managing director of Rittenhouse Financial Services, a Philadelphia investment manager that sold all of its 7.2 million Lucent shares in the last several weeks.
Lucent gave no indication of how soon it would explain what caused the shortfall.

HEADLINE: Trenton Backs Off Proposal To Take Control of Camden

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON

DATELINE: CAMDEN, N.J., Nov. 21

 BODY:
New Jersey backed away today from its ambitious plan to take over the collapsing fiscal and civic management of Camden. Instead, it offered a blueprint for recovery based on cooperation with a city government that state officials were once determined to supplant.
Yet even today's plan, a mix of economic incentives and administrative money savers for the all-but-bankrupt city, relies on a central feature of the takeover legislation introduced last summer: a powerful executive at the center of all City Hall decisions, with the mayor and the City Council in subsidiary roles. 
 The original takeover proposal, which is still before the State Legislature, envisioned a supermanager taking over the core roles now performed by elected officials. But the idea quickly ran into strong opposition from several important elements in the Legislature, including black members -- Camden's population is mostly black and Hispanic -- and the dozens of mayors and municipal council members who are also state legislators.
Today, instead of pursuing that root-and-branch approach, Jane M. Kenny, the state commissioner of community affairs, presented a consultant's plan that puts the state back in the position it once said was intolerable: needing the consent of the Camden City Council and its mayor, who is now on trial on corruption charges.
Announcing the plan at a news conference on Camden's waterfront, state officials seemed to be keeping all their options open, proposing a new approach while keeping the old one alive. Ms. Kenny would not even say that the state endorsed the new plan. "It's not up to the state to endorse it," she said, "because this plan could not be implemented without the cooperation of the city and other leaders."
But today, the president of the Camden City Council reacted coolly to the plan.
There are two versions of the takeover plan awaiting committee action in the Legislature. Today's plan is likely to become part of the debate.
Most of Camden's operating budget is paid for by the state, yet New Jersey officials have been frustrated in their efforts to instill a sense of frugality in the city's operations. Camden fails to collect nearly a third of its real estate taxes, but its payroll and benefits eat up two-thirds of the annual budget. City employees receive higher salaries and better benefits than most other public employees in the state.
Ms. Kenny, whose agency enforces the state's municipal management laws, said today's proposal was an alternative to a takeover.
"What we put on the table originally was a very bold, radical approach that we hoped would very quickly begin to solve the city's problems," she said. "But we said at the time that if we can get the same goals at the end of the day -- change the status quo, get some professional government in place, provide necessary services to the people -- then we would not be wedded to one particular way of doing things."
The new proposal, the City of Camden Multiyear Recovery Plan, was drawn up by Public Financial Management, a Philadelphia consulting firm. It calls for a city manager equivalent to a chief operating officer: someone "with sole responsibility for hiring, directing and managing personnel, coordinating day-to-day operations and implementing the management initiatives of the multiyear plan, and proposing ordinances."
But it did not say who would appoint the manager. In the old takeover plan, the manager would be appointed by the state.
The elected City Council, the new plan suggested, would have an oversight role like that of a board of directors in private industry.
But the plan immediately ran into opposition on the Council. Gwendolyn A. Faison, the Council's president, attended today's event and said afterward that she strongly favored the elements that involved spending state money in Camden, including money to help pay the city's debt and revitalize its economy.
But in language reminiscent of her attacks on the takeover plan, she dismissed the idea of a city manager with powers greater than those of elected officials. That, she said, was the idea that sank the takeover plan, and she was not about to accept it in this new form. "Let me tell you," Ms. Faison said, "I will reach out to anyone who is willing to help the city of Camden, but I will not let anyone take my rights as an elected official away from me."
Last summer, state officials said that waiting for the cooperation of city officials, after a decade of fruitless state fiscal supervision, was pointless. They spoke of a city administration whose budget numbers were like quicksand, and of the need for a clean break with the past as the only way to create the conditions in which upright citizens could come forward to serve.
So assiduous was the state's groundwork in preparing the way for a takeover that Trenton even got an endorsement from the city's black ministers, as deeply aware as any of the civil rights implications of a white Republican administration in Trenton superseding minority-group elected officials at home. But they despaired of any other way to move the city forward.
Today, Commissioner Kenny characterized the takeover bill as a kind of stick used on local leaders to get their attention. Now, she said, her department is working with state legislators, including Senator Wayne R. Bryant, a Camden Democrat and leader of the antitakeover forces, to work out a new approach, one presumably based on today's blueprint, with the separation of powers at City Hall still to be worked out.
Besides proposing measures like a wage freeze and some givebacks in benefits, the new plan calls for some new taxes to help close Camden's budget gap, and to help the state shift millions of its dollars from balancing Camden's budget to paying off the city's long-term debt.

HEADLINE: British Airways Chief Ready to Make Broad Changes

BYLINE: By SUZANNE KAPNER

DATELINE: LONDON, Nov. 22

 BODY:
When the subject of the Singapore Airlines crash in Taiwan came up during a recent gathering of British Airways executives, the chief executive, Rod Eddington, stunned colleagues by going into a detailed technical analysis of what happened to the plane, right down to its takeoff speed, people who were present said.
Mr. Eddington, who became chief executive at British Airways on May 1, has been praised for being able to find his way around a cockpit as easily as through a balance sheet. Since he took over, the price of British Airways shares has increased about 10 percent as the company returned to profitability from a loss last year. 
 Some of the new strategies were put in place by Mr. Eddington's predecessor, Robert Ayling. Soon, however, Mr. Eddington will have a chance to show his real mettle. Within the next two weeks, he is expected to announce broad changes at British Airways aimed at eliminating the 300 million ($425 million) in losses the airline incurred last year on short-haul routes, people close to the company said.
At the same time, British Airways is reassessing its alliance strategy after its unsuccessful attempt to merge with KLM Royal Dutch Airways. One outcome could have British Airways going back to the regulators in hopes of receiving antitrust immunity for its alliance with American Airlines, company executives said.
But first, Mr. Eddington plans to reverse one of his predecessor's longstanding policies of relying on Gatwick Airport as part of a hub-and-spoke system with London's other international airport, Heathrow. As such, Gatwick handled short-haul transfer travel and long-haul routes, but it failed to build enough traffic to cover costs. Last year, operations at the airport lost 40 million ($57 million) before overhead. As a result, British Airways will leave the transfer market and will shift long-haul routes back to Heathrow, leaving Gatwick to focus on short-haul city-to-city service, people close to the company's planning said.
To further bolster profitability, British Airways plans to consolidate operations at Gatwick by combining its European operations there with CityFlyer Express, a wholly owned franchisee, these people continued.
British Airways is also expected to streamline its short-haul franchise network of a dozen or so carriers, these people said. As part of that process, the airline has already said it will sell Go, its low-cost carrier.
Steve Double, a spokesman for British Airways, declined to comment on the proposed changes.
"Gatwick is strategically important for them," said Chris Tarry, an analyst with Commerzbank Securities. "This is all about getting the right cost base."
Next on Mr. Eddington's list will be the alliance strategy. After the collapse of the proposed merger with KLM, British Airways reopened discussions first begun in April with Delta Air Lines and Air France to join their SkyTeam alliance, but those talks have since been abandoned, people close to the negotiations said.
Instead, British Airways will try to strengthen its OneWorld alliance with American Airlines, part of the AMR Corporation. "We could go back to regulators with a revamped proposal in the next 6 to 12 months," said Andrew Sentance, British Airway's chief economist.
British Airways would probably assert that the competitive landscape has changed vastly since the two airlines first approached regulators, in 1996, Mr. Sentance added. Then, there were fewer direct flights to the United States from Continental Europe, so most European passengers had to transfer at Heathrow, giving British Airways a disproportionate share of that market.
Today, increased competition on those routes is causing British Airways to leave the transfer market, where losses have piled up.
Moreover, British Airways said it was facing tougher competition on its home turf, where the Star Alliance, a group of 15 international airlines that includes Air Canada, Lufthansa, United Airlines and British Midland, commands 25 percent of traffic at Heathrow, making it a close second to British Airways' 36 percent share.
It is unclear whether these arguments would sway the regulators in Washington, who have withheld antitrust immunity until the United States and Britain sign a new aviation treaty that would open Heathrow to more United States airlines.
In the meantime, two rival alliances, one made up of United, which is a unit of the UAL Corporation, and Lufthansa, and the other one between Northwest Airlines and KLM, have been granted antitrust immunity. That permits them to share crucial pricing and traffic information, and it has helped them win customers away from British Airways.

HEADLINE: DANCE REVIEW;
It Makes the World Go Round, Among Some Other Things

BYLINE: By ANNA KISSELGOFF

 BODY:
"Looking at Love . . . ," which may sound like a magazine title, was what the New York City Ballet called the benefit opening of its fall-winter season at the New York State Theater on Tuesday night.
Under the company's current formula, a five-week run of "The Nutcracker" (starting tomorrow) is sandwiched between this gala and the two-month repertory run that begins in January. 
 What then, to devise for a single evening that requires a theme for a dinner and a performance intended to raise money and be brief enough for hungry donors?
The idea that the company would explore facets of love embedded in a wide range of its usual ballets sounded like something of stretch. But Peter Martins, City Ballet's artistic director, managed to, yes, stretch a gimmick into an ingeniously arranged program of excerpts.
"Looking at Love . . ." did what it promised. The structure was shrewd, beginning with the virginal symbol of the 16-year-old Princess Aurora meeting princely suitors in "The Sleeping Beauty" and ending with the triple wedding of George Balanchine's "Midsummer Night's Dream."
Love was not necessarily romance. The program varied more classical excerpts with contemporary jagged images of the battle of the sexes. If love meant women were saying they were sorry in the first half of the evening, by the end they gave as good as they got.
Balanchine kept his women on a pedestal, Jerome Robbins sometimes put them on the floor. Mr. Martins and William Forsythe, the American director of the Frankfurt Ballet, belong to a younger generation and kept their combatants equal. Fourteen ballets were represented by 15 excerpts ("Dream" had 2); the evening's conductor was Hugo Fiorato.
Bits and pieces do not show the depth of a first-rank company like City Ballet, but the striking aspect of this array was the innovative range of movement in the choreography. The genius of Balanchine, the company's founder with Lincoln Kirstein, was represented in this respect by the economy of gesture and feeling in an experimental ballet like the Stravinsky "Duo Concertant" and the neo-Romantic extremes (a woman carried laterally) of his luscious Brahms ballet, "Liebeslieder Walzer."
Mr. Martins's 1991 staging of "The Sleeping Beauty" was represented by an abbreviated first act led by Margaret Tracey's subdued Aurora.
A change of pace came with Balanchine's ode to big-city romance in "The Man I Love" duet from his Gershwin ballet, "Who Cares?" Janie Taylor offered a less sophisticated image than others have in the role but her purity was not at odds with Nilas Martins's jazz-age gallantry. The final duet of Robbins's "In the Night," turns its Chopin music, played by Cameron Grant, into a turbulent quarrel that Jenifer Ringer and James Fayette filled with the stunning passion of their dancing.
Jennie Somogyi, a teen-age hipster bouncing around a falsely indifferent Jared Angle, danced an excerpt from Peter Martins's "Waltz Project." Other comic relief came from the torrid duet in Balanchine's "Slaughter on Tenth Avenue" with Helene Alexopoulos in fine bump-and-grind form to seduce a good-natured Damian Woetzel.
At the other emotional extreme, there was touching performance by Alexandra Ansanelli as a doll who accepts a paper heart from a toy soldier, strongly characterized by Tom Gold in Balanchine's miniature Bizet ballet, "The Steadfast Tin Soldier."
The eccentric duet that ends Mr. Forsythe's "Herman Schmerman," danced to Thom Willems's electronic score, received full value from Wendy Whelan and Albert Evans. No need to ask why they both wear short yellow skirts. One has only to appreciate the off-balance images of love on a precipice.
Not every excerpt was a pas de deux. Monique Meunier was a charmer in the chatterbox solo from Robbins's "Dances at a Gathering," as three men passed her by. Kyra Nichols was delicious as a Titania in love with Kipling Houston as the donkey in "Dream."
The updated apache dance that Mr. Martins devised for Maria Kowroski and Charles Askegard in "Them Twos" was sensationally danced. A brief comic scene from Robbins's "Concert" featured Robert La Fosse as the henpecked husband and his spouse, Melissa Walter. The nicely ridiculous was followed by the sublime images of love and loss that Yvonne Borree and Nikolaj Hubbe rendered perfectly in "Duo Concertant."
Darci Kistler and Philip Neal, as well as Miranda Weese and Jock Soto, offered a glimpse of the drawing-room love stories in the first act of "Liebeslieder Walzer." The dream ballet from Robbins's "West Side Story Suite" seemed like too much schmaltz right after, but Mendelssohn and Balanchine reconciled all lovers on a higher plane at the close.

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY;
Unions Pushing to Organize Thousands of Amazon.com Workers

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE

 BODY:
Seeking to exploit a major retailer's vulnerability during the holiday season, the labor movement has begun a broad campaign to unionize thousands of workers at Amazon.com in what is labor's most ambitious foray into the new economy.
The Washington Alliance of Technology Workers, an arm of the Communications Workers of America, is seeking to organize 400 of the company's customer-service workers in Seattle. At the same time, the United Food and Commercial Workers Union and an independent organizing group are seeking to unionize more than 5,000 workers at the eight distribution centers across the country used by Amazon. 
 With unions representing only a handful of workers in high-technology companies, the Amazon campaign is by far labor's biggest enlistment effort in the fastest- growing sector of the economy.
"This is an important way for labor to enter the new millennium," said Duane Stillwell, president of the Prewitt Organizing Fund, a new independent group that is seeking to work with several unions to organize Amazon's distribution workers. "This is a labor force that unions need to get next to. Amazon is obviously the leader in the Internet e-retailing economy, and as they go, so goes the industry."
Labor leaders say the time is ripe to unionize Amazon because many of its workers are complaining about mandatory preholiday overtime and the way their stock options have plummeted in value.
Union organizers say they hope that if enough Amazon workers put their support behind unionizing during the Christmas rush, management's fears of disruption might cause it to grant union recognition or grant concessions making it easier for workers to unionize.
Amazon is fiercely resisting the organizing drive, saying that its employees, who are given stock options, are owners of the company and in no way need a union.
"Obviously we don't feel that having a union at Amazon will benefit our employees, our customers or Amazon as a whole," said Patty Smith, an Amazon spokeswoman. The company. which is based in Seattle, expects revenue of more than $2 billion this year, but has yet to make a profit.
At a distribution center in Fernley, Nev., last week, Jeff Bezos, Amazon's chief executive, spoke out against the unionization drive in a pep talk to employees putting in large amounts of preholiday overtime.
"I'm not concerned it will disrupt the holidays," he said. "Everyone in this company is an owner. We don't need unions in Amazon.com."
Low-key unionization efforts began at Amazon two years ago, but they did not get far, largely because workers were delighted with their stock options and saw huge opportunities for promotion. At that time, Amazon's growth seemed boundless and its stock price was four times its current level of $25.19.
But the unionization campaign has gained some traction this fall because the stock has sputtered and many employees think less about promotions than about possible layoffs, having seen the company lay off 150 workers last January. Amazon recently began using more than 100 customer-service representatives in New Delhi, causing the Seattle representatives to fret that they will be laid off in favor of the Indian workers, who are paid far less.
Last week in Seattle, 50 customer-service representatives who support unionization went public with their effort. Their aim is to get a majority of the 400 customer-service workers in Seattle to sign cards before Christmas saying they favor unionizing.
Several union supporters said they hoped that Amazon might be so eager to keep operations running smoothly during the Christmas rush that it might quickly grant them union recognition.
"The work these people are doing shatters the myth that high-tech workers don't want a union," said Marcus Courtney, co-founder of the Washington Alliance of Technology Workers.
Many of the customer-service representatives complain that their wages, which usually run from $11 to $15 an hour, are too low for them to live well in high-cost Seattle. They also complain that they often receive little notice about schedule changes and having to work overtime. Several workers said that after working so much overtime they had tired of Mr. Bezos's mantra that it is Day 1 and Amazon is a start-up in which workers need to work hard.
"Our ownership feels hollow," said Kirk Sheldon, a 25-year-old customer service worker in Seattle. "They always say they are willing to hear our input, but there isn't follow-through. The inaction is the root of why we're organizing."
Officials from the food and commercial workers' union and the Prewitt fund said that over the next few weeks several dozen organizers would distribute fliers and collect signatures at Amazon warehouses in Delaware, Georgia, Kansas, Kentucky and Nevada. Until two weeks ago, the union and the Prewitt fund were working together on organizing the warehouse workers, but their cooperative efforts have fallen apart.
Greg Denier, a spokesman for the food and commercial workers, said many Amazon warehouse workers were eager to join unions because they were upset with overtime, with their wages of $7 to $9.50 an hour and with the way they were treated.
"Amazon may be the symbol of the new economy, but it has the worst of the working conditions of the old economy," he said.

HEADLINE: Fox Follows Up on Pledge Of Diverse Mexican Cabinet

BYLINE: By GINGER THOMPSON

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Nov. 22

 BODY:
Following on his promise to build a government that is representative of his country's 100 million men and women, President-elect Vicente Fox Quesada began announcing today the names of an eclectic mix of people who will be in his cabinet.
Among those whose appointments were announced at a packed news conference in an elegant 18th-century European arts museum were economists, a well-known Latin America author, a banker, an environmentalist, the president of a company that manages Mexican tourist resorts and a former governor. 
 The resumes of the cabinet members indicate that they have all distinguished themselves in their respective professions. But several have little or no political experience, a fact that many people find refreshing but makes some a little nervous.
Leticia Navarro, a cosmetics company executive who was named tourism secretary, acknowledged in her acceptance speech that she was such an unknown that a newspaper article had called her "the incognito secretary."
Mr. Fox, who will take office on Dec. 1 and is the first politician in 71 years to wrest the presidency from the long-governing Institutional Revolutionary Party, seemed to revel in the moment.
"Above all," he said, "we want this to be a citizen government. So that you working woman, housewife, you professional, you peasant farmer, land owner, worker, adolescent, child or elderly will make your voices heard and will help us move our country forward."
Among those whose appointments were announced yesterday were Francisco Gil Diaz, general director of a long-distance telephone business, Avantel, as treasury secretary. Luis Ernesto Derbez, a former economist at the World Bank who had posts around the world, was named economy secretary, at a new ministry that will take over the responsibilities of the former Commerce Ministry.
Jorge G. Castaneda, a Latin America scholar and author, will follow in his father's footsteps and be foreign minister. A former supporter of left-wing causes, Mr. Castaneda later became one of the world's foremost scholars on the Latin American left. He had been tied to Cuauhtemoc Cardenas, a left-wing leader in Mexico, until the early 1990's and opposed Nafta during the years of negotiations.
"Fox has built from early on a broad coalition of voters, sympathizers and advisers, and he wanted that initial broad coalition that took him to the presidency represented in his government," Mr. Castaneda said in an interview. "I am a reflection of that commitment."
In his acceptance speech today, Mr. Castaneda said he intended to make foreign policy more inclusive and supportive of all Mexicans and reiterated his commitment to provide greater support to the hundreds of thousands of Mexicans who migrate each year to the United States.
"Businessmen seeking to generate export opportunities and flows of foreign investment will find they have friends in the Foreign Ministry," he said. "So will artists and writers that work to promote culture and art around the world. And above all, so will those Mexican workers that have felt forced to abandon their homes and their country."
Among others whose appointments were announced were the former governor, Ernesto Ruffo, as czar of the northern border. When Mr. Ruffo, of the conservative National Action Party, was elected governor of Baja California in 1989, he became the first opposition politician to win such a post in recent history.
An airline executive, Ernesto Martens Rebolledo, 67, was appointed energy secretary. The agriculture secretary will be Javier Usabiaga Arroyo, known in his home state of Guanajuato as the King of Garlic because his family business has grown into the region's chief garlic exporter. The environment secretary will be Victor Lichtinger, former executive director of a trilateral environmental commission created by the United States, Canada and Mexico under the North American Free Trade Agreement.
And Eduardo Sojo Garza-Aldape, an economist, was named coordinator of public policy advisers. Educated at the University of Pennsylvania, Mr. Sojo was the president-elect's chief economic adviser when Mr. Fox was governor of Guanajuato.
"All of us in the new government carry the same banner for change," Mr. Sojo said. "But change is very abstract if it does not take hold in the daily chores of each public servant."

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
No matter who's the next president, there will be some hard choices to make.

BYLINE: By Jeff Madrick; This column appears here every Thursday. Jeff Madrick is the editor of Challenge Magazine and a new collection of essays, "Unconventional Wisdom: Alternative Perspectives on the New Economy." Mr. Madrick, Virginia Postrel, Alan B. Krueger and Hal R. Varian rotate as contributors.

 BODY:
ONE piece of conventional wisdom making the rounds these days is that investors in the financial markets may prefer the Washington gridlock that a close presidential election brings. No new policy is good policy, the argument goes. But circumstances are shifting rapidly, and such a view seems especially naive right now.
The presidential campaign was fought over how to distribute the spoils of prosperity, but the new president will face different economic conditions from those expected only a few months ago. The pace of economic growth is slowing significantly, and some economists are beginning to discuss the possibility of recession in 2001. The unemployment rate could rise, and the projected budget surplus could dissipate. Moreover, the record trade deficit and unusually high value of the dollar, which so many economists have brushed aside as unimportant, could well tie the hands of the nation's policy makers. 
 The case for slower growth begins with falling stock prices and rising oil prices. Both are inhibiting consumer and corporate spending and raising the costs of doing business. But it does not end there. With individual and corporate debt so high, any slowdown in the growth of income can result in cutbacks in spending to meet debt service payments. After having invested so much in information technology, business may also be nearing the saturation point, and consumers appear to be slowing their buying of personal computers.
The evidence is, of course, not conclusive, but retail sales in general, and auto sales in particular, weakened this fall; housing leveled off; capital spending slowed; and profits were disappointing at many companies, including high-technology leaders like Dell Computer.
Prosperity breeds complacency, however, and the view of many forecasters is that if the economy unwinds rapidly, the Federal Reserve can always save the day by reducing interest rates. But such rate reductions had more impact when rates were higher. It will take a considerable cut in rates from today's relatively low levels to stimulate the quantity of mortgage and state debt refinancings that provided so much buying power in the 1990's, when such rates hit 8 and 9 percent.
The only resort may well be fiscal stimulus, from either tax cuts or more federal spending. Odds are still against a recession, but the long-time Wall Street economist Albert Wojnilower, now with Monitor-Clipper Partners, says that without such stimulus, he thinks a recession is in the cards.
At this point, presidential leadership of a high order will be required. A nation long educated to fear federal budget deficits may resist fiscal stimulus when it is needed. The bond markets may also punish any fiscally oriented president with higher rates. The new president will have to convince the public, the financial markets and the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, that fiscal stimulus is in order.
My guess is that a slowing economy will open minds to a tax cut. And some traditional liberals, like Max Sawicky, an economist at the Economic Policy Institute, find themselves, paradoxically, acknowledging that George W. Bush may be in a better position than Al Gore to advocate more stimulative policies, even if it threatens a new federal deficit. Vice President Gore has been especially adamant about the need to balance the federal budget and pay off part of the national debt every year.
But the kind of tax cuts undertaken also matters. One that mostly benefits the wealthy, like the one proposed by Mr. Bush, will largely be channeled into savings, not the needed spending.
What will probably be forgotten in all this is that fiscal stimulus can also result from more government spending. The nation, in my view, will be better served by a more generous earned-income tax credit, to take one example, than by a large tax cut. The new economy also presents new demands that only government investment can meet either directly or through subsidies -- like more accessible child care, improved and continuing education and flexible work hours. Such spending has the dual benefit of stimulating growth and raising the long-term potential of the economy.
But the new president will face a further deterrent to sensible policies. Because of its record trade deficit, America is not entirely the master of its own fate. The current expansion is being financed by a huge inflow of foreign capital as America buys much more from overseas producers than it sells abroad.
If domestic growth falters, however, investors may have second thoughts. As the dollar falls, because of the sliding stock market and the pullout of investors, it could precipitate still more capital flight. And the falling dollar would be inflationary, pushing up import prices and probably persuading the Fed that to attract foreign investors it has to keep interest rates higher than it would otherwise. This would make a slowing economy still weaker -- and could push a merely weak economy into recession.
Once again, many analysts are complacent. Some argue that the dollar will hold its value because, if the American economy weakens, international investors will have nowhere else to go with their money as their economies will also sputter. But Rosemary Sagar, a managing director at U.S. Trust, has her doubts.
She notes that Europe as a whole is less dependent on exports to the United States than is generally thought. Also, stimulative tax cuts have been enacted across Europe that will not be entirely offset by government spending reductions. And European interest in acquisitions in the United States, a main source of capital inflow, is diminishing. In sum, Ms. Sagar says, the dollar is likely to fall as the gap between growth rates and interest rates in the United States and Europe narrows.
Events are conspiring to make the new administration a more difficult one than the campaigning implied. Far from simply allocating the benefits of rapid economic growth, the next president may have to persuade a hesitant nation to adopt fiscal stimulus while persuading the Fed not to offset it with higher interest rates. He will have to persuade foreigners that America is still the place to invest even as the economy grows more slowly. A sharply falling dollar could spur a financial crisis. Ideally, he will apportion fiscal stimulus intelligently among tax cuts, social programs and public investment.
For all the sly rhetoric to the contrary, the president does indeed matter.
