PUB-DATE: November 24, 2000

SECTION: Section E; Part 1; Page 1; Column 1; Movies, Performing Arts/Weekend Desk

LENGTH: 3754 words

HEADLINE: A Newly Cool Newark Says, 'C'mon Over!'

BYLINE: By ANDREW JACOBS

 BODY:
LET'S go to Newark!
Go ahead, shake your head. Roll your eyes. You've heard all the jokes about Newark. You've probably made a few of your own. Thanks to Hollywood and the media, who can blame you for thinking of New Jersey's largest city as America's pre-eminent symbol of inner-city decay, runaway crime and unrelenting despair? 
 But 33 years after civil unrest and staggering depopulation sapped this city of its vitality, Newark is finally, and unmistakably, back. There's a shimmering new performing arts center, a minor league baseball stadium and a charming world-class art museum. But you knew that.
What you may not have known is that Newark has a top-notch collection of Art Deco architecture, a vibrant enclave of Brazilian and Portuguese immigrants and an unheralded hip-hop, soul and gospel music scene, all just minutes from the overpriced mayhem of Midtown Manhattan. There's a jaw-dropping cathedral to rival St. Patrick's, more flowering cherry trees than in Washington and an astonishingly efficient subway line with 53-year-old rolling stock that will make you smile.
Unlike most American cities, Newark's downtown is a place to be strolled. With a 50 percent drop in crime since 1995, its streets feel safe; its parks are welcoming and well-tended. There is plenty to eat, from a trove of Spanish and South American cuisine to a newly opened high-end restaurant that offers some of the Garden State's most refined dining.
Of course, it would be misleading to portray Newark as chic, bustling and self-confident. There are still acres of parking lots, sorrowful rows of vacant buildings and plenty of disheartening sights. Its residents, most of whom live outside the city center, remain mired in poverty.
But for the first time in a generation, there are good reasons to explore this former industrial powerhouse by the Passaic River. Straddling most of the region's highways, it's a quick car trip from anywhere in the metropolitan area, although this tour guide encourages a visit by mass transit. Most of New Jersey's commuter trains stop here, and Manhattan residents can dive under the Hudson on PATH, a subway that costs a mere dollar. (But hurry: a fare increase is in the wind.) For an extra 75 cents, New Jersey Transit trains make the trip from Pennsylvania Station nonstop in 15 minutes.
In contrast to the cramped, windowless catacomb that replaced McKim, Mead & White's soaring locomotive palace in Manhattan, Newark's Pennsylvania Station survives with all its Art Deco glories intact. Designed by the same architects, it was raised during the depths of the Depression, although you wouldn't know it from the embarrassment of Napoleon gray marble, rose yellow travertine and Indiana limestone.
Peek into the waiting room and look up at its cobalt blue ceiling tiles, the zigzagging aluminum door trim and the row of medallions ennobling such modes of travel as the canoe, the stagecoach and the stallion. A $38 million modernization and faithful restoration of the station, where 70,000 commuters a day pass through, is continuing.
 
Next: The Ironbound
Turn around and exit through the station's rear doors, which leaves you facing Ferry Street. This is the Ironbound, a neighborhood of Iberian and Latin American immigrants that maintained its dignity (and its real estate values) while the rest of Newark fell into the abyss.
Named for the railroad tracks that nearly surround it, the Ironbound was dominated by Polish, Italian and Spanish immigrants until the 1960's, when the poverty of Portugal under the dictator Antonio Salazar persuaded many of its people to go elsewhere. Newark, with a population of 263,000, probably has 19,000 Portuguese residents and even a consulate, although a thriving economy back home and European Union membership have slowed the influx of new arrivals. Brazilians, drawn in part by a shared language, have been filling the void, as have smaller numbers of Ecuadoreans, Colombians and Mexicans.
Head up Ferry Street, the main artery, into what feels more like a village than a city. On weekends, the sidewalks buzz with energy, as do the restaurants, bakeries and food markets.
There are two schools of eating in the Ironbound: the old-guard Portuguese and Spanish restaurants, with their dark paneling, red tablecloths and melding of American and Iberian fare, and the newer, fuss-free Brazilian establishments with their simple meals and local clientele.
Fornos of Spain, Iberia Peninsula and Seabra's, among the best known, serve garlic-laden seafood, the standard paella and fragrant Spanish wines. The crowds are often out-of-towners, although the bars fill up at night with work-worn Portuguese men chatting loudly as they down broiled shrimp and wine.
 
Flickering Street Lamps
Sol-Mar, a good 10-minute walk up Ferry Street, is typically Portuguese, with its Disneyfied mishmash of old Lisbon and country tavern decor. There are flickering street lamps and a waterfall, and old plows and saddles hang from the ceramic-tiled eaves. The portions of oxtail and spaghetti, grilled tilefish, and pork cubes with clams can be staggering.
Brazilians tend to gather at the three Casa Nova restaurants, one of which sits across the street from Sol-Mar. Rodizio de churrasco, the endless parade of grilled meats, is the specialty here. The decor is simple and the mood appropriately boisterous.
Before you head back downtown, a dozen bakeries demand careful consideration. The Portuguese ones dominate Ferry Street, among them Coutinho's, Delicias and Aveirense, where pastel de coco (coconut cups) and bolo de arroz (rice pudding cakes) cry out for a cup of espresso. Padaria Brasileira has its own take on dessert, with crisp caramel-stuffed pastries called folhadas and coconut-and-cheese-filled queijadinha. It also serves an array of Brazilian lunch staples like crab cake, collard green soup and roasted ribs.
If you have a hankering for sardines or mackerel, Ferry Street's fish markets will make you swoon. (Fresh shipments arrive from Portugal on Thursdays.) Local travel agencies offer cheap air fares to Portugal and Brazil, and the furniture stores sell outrageously flamboyant ensembles that really belong in a museum.
With doggie bag in hand, head back toward Penn Station. You could walk the four blocks from here to downtown, but then you'd miss one of the city's most thrilling attractions, the 4.3-mile Newark subway. The last surviving leg of a long-vanished streetcar system, Newark's City Subway is essentially a trolley that plunges underground for its last mile. Stepping into the vintage cars, with their Cyclops headlights and pull cords for stops, will bring on a wave of nostalgia, even if you were born after the American streetcar was slain by the bus. The cars, built in 1947, are clean and graffiti-free, and serious crime, the conductors swear, is nonexistent. Even its underground stations are quaint. Wall mosaics at each stop depict life on the old Morris Canal, a link between the Delaware River and the Atlantic that was drained in 1930 to make way for the subway.
There is another compelling reason to hop a trolley: the cars are not long for this world. Sometime next year, they are to be replaced by a modern fleet of light rail cars, a necessary evil dictated by the old fleet's inaccessibility to disabled passengers. There are other problems with the creaky cars: replacement parts are impossible to find, and the lack of air-conditioning makes them stifling in summer. One can only hope that the 45-cent off-peak fare will hold for a while longer.
 
An Olmsted Park
Take the train to Park Avenue, which will leave you at the edge of Branch Brook Park, 10.8 acres of rolling meadows, 3,000 blossoming cherry trees and two meandering streams. Designed by Frederick Law Olmsted and opened in 1895, the park is in fairly good shape, considering the absence of deep-pocket benefactors. There are a few sorry sights, like the vandalized granite plinth, built in 1903 to honor a long-forgotten singing troupe.
Head for the towers of Cathedral Basilica of the Sacred Heart and make your way around the lake and head up the hill. Started in 1899, this French Gothic behemoth wasn't finished until 1954, when it became the official seat of Newark's Roman Catholic archdiocese. These days, the entrance is on Ridge Street, which rules out a ceremonial entrance through the massive Italian-made bronze doors. (They were, of course, flung open for Pope John Paul II's 1995 visit.) Set on Newark's highest point, Sacred Heart has a nave wider than Chartres, vaulting higher than Canterbury and towers that would overshadow Notre Dame.
It is an awesome space, with three dreamy rose windows and richly carved chapels dedicated to the ethnic groups that poured their hard-earned savings into the cathedral's construction. Even though its congregation has dwindled over the years, Sacred Heart, the archdiocese's showpiece, is meticulously maintained. There is a sporadic series of concerts.
 
The Signs of Renewal
Take an alternate route through the park on your way back to the Park Avenue subway station. Get off at Washington Street, which skirts the edge of Rutgers University's Newark campus. New Jersey Institute of Technology and the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey are just a few minutes away as well.
If a group of philanthropists and business leaders prevail, these forlorn town houses and empty lots will one day become a round-the-clock village of apartments, restaurants, nightclubs and shops. The New Newark Foundation has bought three square blocks, and its hope is to capitalize on the success of the New Jersey Performing Arts Center and the thousands of students who commute to nearby campuses but leave after nightfall. Its most promising venture so far would turn the immense Hahne's department store building into luxury housing.
There are already signs of renewal: the year-old Euphoria Cafe, a sofa-stuffed coffee house on Academy Street, and Je's, a soul-food restaurant on Halsey Street, where Shaquille O'Neal and Queen Latifah dine when visiting their former hometown. Another pocket of optimism can be found on and around nearby James Street, a 20-block historic district where dozens of stately Queen Anne houses have been restored. At the other end of Halsey Street is Hobby's, a delicatessen that is the only remnant of Newark's Jewish community, which started migrating to the western suburbs in the 1940's. For a contrasting slice of Newark, head over to the Priory on West Market Street, a jazz club and restaurant that fills up with the churchgoing crowd on Sunday afternoons.
For now, however, walk along Washington Street until you reach the Newark Museum, one of this city's biggest drawing cards and reason enough for Jerseyphobes to leave Manhattan. Entry is free. The museum was founded at the turn of the last century, and Louis Bamberger, the department store magnate, financed the museum's first building of its own in 1926, setting it beside a 25-room Victorian mansion, the Ballantine House, that puts Martha Stewart's decorating impulses to shame. In 1989, the Princeton architect Michael Graves helped bring all the elements together with a $21 million expansion that doubled the museum's exhibition space.
Philistines overwhelmed by mega-museums will find Newark's collection an easily digestible joy. From Winslow Homer to Andy Warhol, the collection takes in an eclectic range of 19th- and 20th-century painting and sculpture.
It also features the nation's finest array of Tibetan art, an impressive display of African crafts, a planetarium and even a miniature zoo. The recently restored Ballantine House, built by the beer-brewing family in 1885, is a wonderfully cluttered primer on Victorian life. The museum's atrium cafe, selling basic soups, salads and sandwiches (including peanut butter and jelly), is a soothing place to pause.
 
A Spiffed-Up Skyscraper
Leaving the museum takes you to Washington Park, the city's first marketplace, former home of its merchant princes and setting of some of its most glorious 20th-century public edifices: the public library, with its three-story atrium and mosaic-covered vaults; the sober neo-classic Veterans Administration Building; and the oddball American Insurance Company headquarters, a Greek temple grafted to the base of a modern skyscraper. Across the park is the former headquarters of Mutual Benefit Life, a crisply rendered, green-glass homage to the International Style. A few paces down is the Art Deco beauty built for the company most of us still refer to as Bell Atlantic.
Walk along Broad Street, where the ghosts of the past bump up against a more hopeful future. Between the year-old Riverfront Stadium, home to the Newark Bears baseball team, and the sparkling performing arts center are a score of old department stores and office buildings that await a new life. There are S. Klein's, the Griffith Piano Building and Hahne's, their windows pitifully dark, and then there's the sparkling Newark National Building, the city's tallest skyscraper and all spiffed up after a $50 million renovation. Starbucks, the coffee chain, has given Newark its stamp of confidence by setting up shop in a ground-floor storefront. Facing Military Park is the old Essex Club, which has been restored as the new home of the New Jersey Historical Society.
Directly across the street is Trinity Cathedral, a country church that hasn't changed much since a group of Episcopalians laid its cornerstone in 1742, infuriating the Puritan power brokers still trying to maintain a monopoly on the city's religious life.
Robert Treat, the Puritan patriarch who founded the city in 1666, might have been completely forgotten if not for the hotel across Military Park that bears his name. When it opened in 1916, on the 250th anniversary of Newark's founding, the city was a puffed-up industrial giant. President and Mrs. Woodrow Wilson attended the opening and were the hotel's first guests.
Somehow the Robert Treat survived the grim years, and its owner, emboldened by the opening of the nearby performing arts center, recently spent several million dollars refurbishing its 169 rooms. The hotel's regrettably bland addition has become home to Maize, a high-end restaurant that may be the canary for those who believe Newark can overcome its poisoned past.
With $25 entrees and a chef whose credentials include Le Bernardin and Bouley in Manhattan, Maize, at least during a few recent visits, seems to be drawing back the reluctant suburbanite.
 
A Lavish Arts Center
Of course, the single greatest hope for Newark's revival is the $180 million performing arts center, now entering its fourth season. Even if you don't have evening concert plans, duck into the lobby of what many critics say is the finest new arts complex in the country. It is a lavish and generous affirmation of Newark, and unlike many performing arts centers, set on vast, offputting plazas, Barton Myers's design meets the city at the sidewalk. Theater Square Grill, the stylish in-house restaurant, has become so popular that pre-theater reservations must be booked weeks in advance.
It may not be apparent to the newcomer, but this extravaganza of brick and glass has had its desired effect as an engine for urban renewal. New restaurants like Maize and the growing collection of downtown development projects are tapping into the arts center's energy. A new riverfront park, under construction across McCarter Highway, will become the theater's front lawn, and a new light rail line linking Penn Station to the area is to open in 2005.
But perhaps the most powerful statement of the arts center's -- and Newark's -- success can be glimpsed on warm summer nights, when thousands of people throng its outdoor plaza for a weekly music series that has become Newark's town social. Sound in the City, as it is called, draws a racially mixed crowd of young professionals, many of them commuters who would surely have blanched at the thought of venturing into this city after dark a few years ago.
As day gives way to night, they mingle and stroll around nearby streets without looking over their shoulders. Like a growing number of people, they have stumbled upon a secret that one hopes will reach more ears. New Jersey, they have discovered, is not just an endless series of highways, strip malls and mind-numbing sprawl. Newark is proving otherwise. And what a relief it is.
 
Hidden Assets
 
Newark is about 10 miles from New York City. Attractions and restaurants in downtown Newark, along with travel information:
 
Attractions
 
NEWARK CITY SUBWAY. The 4.3-mile system serves 11 stations between Pennsylvania Station and the Newark-Belleville border. Bus and rail lines connect with the subway, making it accessible from other parts of Essex County.
 
 BRANCH BROOK PARK, bordered by U.S. Route 280 to the north and the Newark-Belleville rail line to the south, crossing Bloomfield Avenue, Park Avenue and Heller Parkway. Designed by Frederick Law Olmsted's firm, this park was created in 1895 as the first park in the Essex County park system.
 
 CATHEDRAL BASILICA OF THE SACRED HEART, 89 Ridge Street. (973) 484-4600. This 100-year-old church has daily services in English and Spanish, as well as monthly classical music concerts. The next concert, on Dec. 19 at 8 p.m., is the 30th annual Christmas carol sing, with the Cathedral Choir and Orchestra, under the direction of John J. Miller and Pablo Fernandez, organist.
 
NEWARK MUSEUM, 49 Washington Street. (973) 596-6550. "Treasures of 19th-Century American Art," through Dec. 3. "Needless Necessity: Jewelry, Silver and Personal Meaning," through Dec. 31. "Katherine Choy: A Promise Unfulfilled," ceramic showcase, through Jan. 21. "Narratives of African-American Art and Identity: The David C. Driskell Collection," through Feb. 25. "Night Skies: The Art of Deep Space," astral photographs by David Malin, through Feb. 25. Admission is free. Hours: Wednesdays through Sundays, noon to 5 p.m.; Thursdays until 8:30 p.m.
 
 NEW JERSEY HISTORICAL SOCIETY, 52 Park Place. (973) -596-8500. Exhibitions, lunchtime walking tours and lectures. "Pride of Newark: Baseball's Bears and Eagles," about the history of baseball in Newark, through March. "Dining In, Dining Out," featuring photographs, video clips, rare silverware, period furniture and 18th-century cookbooks, through next summer. "Resource-Full New Jersey," an exhibition on natural resources, past and present, and land-use consequences, through 2002. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.
 
 NEW JERSEY PERFORMING ARTS CENTER, 1 Center Street. (888) 466-5722. Tonight at 8 in Prudential Hall, the Canadian Brass in a holiday program featuring Christmas selections and Gershwin's "Porgy and Bess" suite. Tickets: $12 to $48. Tomorrow at 8 p.m. in Prudential Hall, the Keith Jarrett Trio in a jazz concert of repertory ranging from the 1930's to the 50's. Tickets: $14 to $48. Sunday at 2:30 p.m., in the Victoria Theater, Endesha Ida Mae Holland's autobiographical drama, "From the Mississippi Delta," about an African-American woman who rises from poverty in the rural South to a successful life in academia. Tickets: $48. Sunday at 3 p.m. in Prudential Hall, Andre Watts, pianist, in a recital of Beethoven, Chopin, Haydn and Mozart. Tickets: $14 to $58. Events next month include the Boston Symphony Orchestra (Dec. 8), the Vienna Choir Boys (Dec. 16), Savion Glover in "Foot Notes" (Dec. 21 and 22) and the St. Petersburg State Ballet on Ice performing "The Nutcracker" (Dec. 27 to 31).

Getting There
 
BY TRAIN: PATH trains direct to Newark leave from the World Trade Center. A connecting train, which can be boarded at 33rd Street, 23rd Street, 14th Street and Christopher Street stations, travels to Newark via Hoboken with a change of trains at the Exchange Place, Grove Street or the Journal Square stations in Jersey City. The fare is $1 one way; free for children under 5. New Jersey Transit Trains leave from New York's Penn Station for Newark's Penn Station hourly on weekends; the one-way fare is $2.50; $1.10 for children and the elderly. Amtrak trains leave from Penn Station for Newark Penn Station, approximately hourly, for $18; $15.50 for the elderly.
 
 BY BUS: The No. 108 bus leaves for Newark every hour on the hour from 6 a.m. to 1 a.m. from the Port Authority Bus Terminal in Manhattan. The bus leaves from gate 213 from 6 a.m. to 10 p.m. and from gate 316 from 10 p.m. to 1 a.m. In Newark there are stops at Penn Station and at Clifton Avenue. The one-way fare is $3.25.
 
 BY CAR: from Manhattan take the Holland Tunnel to Jersey City. Take U.S. 1 and 9 South to the Raymond Street exit, which leads to downtown Newark. ANDREW JACOBS

PUB-DATE: November 24, 2000

SECTION: Section E; Part 2; Page 33; Column 3; Leisure/Weekend Desk

LENGTH: 3584 words

HEADLINE: ON THE ROAD;
Flashin' Those Dreamy Eyes Way Down Yonder

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr.

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS

 BODY:
They have their own way of doing things in the Big Easy. They always have.
They have their own languid pace, which led Tennessee Williams, a sometime resident, to rhapsodize about "those long rainy afternoons in New Orleans, when an hour isn't just an hour but a little piece of eternity dropped into your hands, and who knows what to do with it?" 
 They have their own music -- not only jazz, which was more or less invented in Storyville, the red-light district long since replaced by a scruffy, drug-plagued housing project, but also zydeco, the stomping sound from the small Cajun towns west of here, and the blues, in whose evolution New Orleans played a major role, together with other spots along the Mississippi River.
They have their own drinks, seldom found elsewhere -- sazeracs and Ramos gin fizzes and sugary hurricanes at Pat O'Brien's on Bourbon Street, as well as Barq's root beer, which has lately become a national brand. They have their own sandwiches, like muffulettas and po'-boys, and their own sauces, like remoulade and ravigote, derived from but not really very similar to the French originals, and idiosyncratic dishes like etouffes, which are seafood stews. They drink their coffee heavily laced with chicory and eat beignets with it rather than doughnuts.
They have their own accent, which at its ripest sounds a little like Brooklyn and a little like Savannah; as rendered hereabouts, the name of their city is "New AWL-yuns."
They have their own legal system; like all of Louisiana and unlike the other 49 states, they operate under the Napoleonic Code, a legacy from the days when this was Nouvelle Orleans, the pride of French North America. They live in parishes, not in counties.
They have their own way of burying the dead. Because the city was built on low-lying land, coffins placed underground had a nasty habit of bobbing to the surface during floods and downpours. So New Orleans cemeteries are filled with mausoleums, row upon row of above-ground tombs. "Cities of the Dead," these are called, spooky in the moonlight and in Anne Rice's novels. They have their own odd approach to nomenclature, particularly place names. The streets that cross St. Charles Avenue at the downtown end are named for muses -- Terpischore, Erato, Clio, Euterpe.
In the French Quarter every first-time visitor encounters and inevitably mispronounces Chartres Street ("Charters") and Burgundy ("Burr-GUN-dee"). You can drive down Elysian Fields Avenue, another echo of New France, but sadly, the streetcars no longer run to Desire.
 
American by Purchase Only
Right from the start, New Orleans has been a French and Spanish, black and Catholic city, standing well apart from the largely Protestant, Anglo-Saxon American norm. Founded by Jean-Baptiste Le Moyne in 1718 on a big bend in the Mississippi (hence the nickname "Crescent City"), ruled for decades by Spain, it came under American control with the Louisiana Purchase of 1803. By then its ways were already set.
This is a Caribbean city, an exuberant, semi-tropical city, perhaps the most hedonistic city in the United States. You see more orgies (and more nuns) in New Orleans than you see anywhere else in the nation. Even more than Miami, it looks to the south, toward the volatility that is Latin America.
A long time ago, that paragon among journalists, A. J. Liebling, described New Orleans as a cross between Port-au-Prince, Haiti, and Paterson, N.J. It reminds me of Marseille, with a civic culture marked by crime, corruption, humidity, poverty and poor education on one hand, and a love of good food, good drink and good times on the other. Its joie de vivre is well-nigh inexhaustible, and for all its raffishness and fine distinctions of class and caste, its people have an inborn sweetness that extends from Garden District matrons to garage mechanics.
After an evening spent discussing the city's problems with us, Pixie Reiss, a schoolmate of my wife, Betsey, called me to say: "Don't forget the grace. It's a graceful city."
So it is. It is also "some decadent," as a waiter named Ronald remarked to us another evening as we reveled in yet another rich dinner.
From time to time New Orleans mayors have struggled against corruption. One who did so was an aristocrat named deLesseps S. Morrison Jr., known as "Chep," who served in the 1950's. More recently, Ernest Morial and his son Marc, the current mayor, have had a go. Still, graft remains endemic here; in truth, the city seems to prefer its politics with a dash of Tabasco.
There was always plenty of support in New Orleans for Edwin W. Edwards, the smooth-talking Cajun governor who once boasted that he would never be beaten unless he was "found in bed with a live boy or a dead girl." But after one trial that ended in a hung jury and another that produced an acquittal, Mr. Edwards was finally convicted of racketeering, conspiracy and extortion last May in a case centering on riverboat gambling licenses.
 
A Violent Streak
Meanwhile, poverty persists, cheek by jowl with wealth, much of it inherited. A block or two from mansions with palm-shaded gardens stand crude unpainted bungalows fronting on crumbling streets, more reminiscent of the third world than dot-com America. In 1989, according to Census Bureau figures, 31.6 percent of New Orleanians lived below the poverty line; in 1993, the figure was 37.9 percent, and in 1995, it was 33.6 percent -- one in three.
Most of the poor, in a city almost three-quarters black, are African-American. Few of them are Asian. The 10,000 Vietnamese who settled here, in a hot, damp, tangled, swampy landscape like the one they fled, have prospered.
The city's police superintendent, Richard J. Pennington, who is black, told me that most of the violent crime here takes place in or around public housing and other poor neighborhoods, and that most of it is black upon black. In New Orleans, he said, "we don't have very many black people preying upon white tourists -- or upon white residents."
This is a very violent place. The F.B.I. Uniform Crime Report for 1998 said that in that year, New Orleans ranked second to Pine Bluff, Ark., in murders per 100,000 population. Pine Bluff had 33.8, New Orleans 22.1 and the United States as a whole 6.3.
But Mr. Pennington, a tall, imposing man who came here from Washington, D.C., six years ago, has had real success in driving the numbers down. He raised pay to help recruiting (rookies went from $16,000 a year to $30,000), converted apartments in housing projects into mini-stations, attacked departmental corruption and moved officers out of offices and onto the streets. When he arrived, the force numbered 1,280; it is currently approaching 1,700.
"We weren't putting anyone in jail," he said. "Now we are, and we have registered 15 straight quarterly declines in violent and property crime since I reorganized the department. But I don't fool myself; we have a lot more poverty and a lot fewer cops than Washington, which has the same population."
Annual quality of life surveys taken by the University of New Orleans show that more residents think things are getting better than think they are getting worse. Mr. Pennington gets much of the credit; he has an 83 percent approval rating, and many politicians expect him to be the city's next mayor.
But even Mr. Pennington would be hard pressed to revitalize the city's economy. Once the South's largest city, the nation's fifth largest in 1860, New Orleans fell behind Houston in 1950 and has slipped further in the half-century since then. Although it has its share of new skyscrapers, it has been overtaken by Atlanta and Nashville and Charlotte, the economic capitals of the New South. The days when cotton was king here have long since passed, and now the oil boom has ended, too. Most of the local banks are now branches of bigger banks in bigger cities.
"Tourism has become not only the leading industry but the only industry," said Paul Fabry, the retired head of the World Trade Center here. "We are a colonial economy. All the owners of hotels and airlines live somewhere else, and we are left, for the most part, with low-paying jobs -- taxi drivers, waiters, bellmen. And the port? The port is mostly about transferring bulk commodities from ships to barges and barges to ships. We make about as much money from the port these days as the mailman does from the $500 check in his sack."
Mr. Fabry also detects an increasing reluctance on the part of able young people, black as well as white, to remain in New Orleans, and worries where the civic leadership of tomorrow will come from. Not long ago, he said, he asked a group of other older men "who once belonged to the city's elite" how many had children who had left. Three-quarters of them raised their hands.
Still, for every Walter Isaacson, who moved north and became the editor of Time magazine, others move south, attracted by the climate, the cheap, easy living and the good food. In the old days, writers like Tennessee Williams and William Faulkner and Sherwood Anderson spent time in New Orleans. Anne Kearney, the chef at Peristyle, came on vacation in the winter of 1991, two days before Mardi Gras, saw that "the trees were green," got a job and stayed. Virginia Claiborne Miller, whose family has roots in the city, came from Washington and helped start a public relations firm.
"The magic," Ms. Miller told us, "outweighs the provincialism."
 
A Sinking Feeling
People in New Orleans fret about the Formosa termites that attack the old wood houses every May, and they worry about signs that the old city is slowly sinking, like Venice, despite the levees that protect it from floods.
"We're surrounded by water and the land is like pudding," Terrence Fitzmorris, a professor of history at Tulane University, told The Associated Press early this year. "What it's created is a survivors' mentality."
To survive, they eat. And eat.
Eating is a New Orleans obsession; the city has more overweight people for its size than any in America. This is the place brunch was invented, by a certain Mme. Begue, who called it second breakfast. (One wasn't enough for her clients.) Oysters Rockefeller were first served at Antoine's and bananas Foster were created at Brennan's, where you can still order them as the crowning glory to a modest breakfast of baked apple followed by a crawfish omelet.
Friends, meeting in the street, exchange thoughts about where to find the best red beans and rice on Monday, when that homely favorite is traditionally eaten. They flock to favorite holes-in-the wall as well as the white-tablecloth temples of haute cuisine.
They go to Casamento's for oyster loaves, which are baguettes hollowed out and filled with fried oysters. To the Central Grocery for muffulettas, which are sandwiches of Italian cold cuts, cheese and crushed olives on round rolls. To Felix's, where oysters are opened before your eyes and placed on a marble bar, innocent of plate, for your pleasure. To the Camellia Grill, a glorified diner with a mere 29 stools housed in a miniature Tara, for crisp pecan waffles in the morning and cheeseburgers after midnight. To Eddie's or Dooky Chase for gumbo. To the Cafe du Monde, day or night, for another coffee fix.
And they know why they eat what they do. I asked Paul C. P. McIlhenny, whose family firm has made Tabasco for generations, why he and his fellow townsmen liked chicory in their coffee. We were having lunch at Galatoire's, the most traditional of New Orleans restaurants, where the waiters sometimes call their customers, male or female, "cher" or "chere," for "dear."
It started during the Napoleonic war, he explained after he finished a mouthful of oysters en brochette. The British blockaded French ports, so Parisians made do with the roasted and ground roots of endive, which is called "chicoree" in French. When the war ended, almost two centuries ago now, the French went back to the real thing.
"But here in New Orleans," he said, "we never got the message."
Change, as you may gather, comes slowly here. Quint Davis, the producer and director of the city's annual Jazzfest, put it this way: "Here heritage is not something you see in the rearview mirror. It's also shining brightly through the windshield."
 
Party Animals
A big part of that heritage is, of course, Carnival, the explosion of parties, balls and parades that swirls through New Orleans just before Lent every year, ending on Fat Tuesday, the day before the lean days begin. The rhinestones, tulle and masks of Mardi Gras cost an immense amount of money -- hundreds of thousands of dollars to stage one dance among dozens -- and it is all paid for by private citizens, of all classes and races, and the city. No corporate subsidies here.
Originally the domain of the Creole upper classes, descended from the French and Spanish settlers, Mardi Gras has become everyone's property while remaining a tightly orchestrated social ritual. For the grandees, having one's daughter named queen of one of the "krewes," or clubs, ranks among life's great milestones. For simpler folk, black and white, the goal is fun.
One krewe, Babylon, is made up mostly of physicians. Zulu is mostly black. Iris is for women only. Rex is the grandest. The king of Rex is automatically king of Carnival, and for more than a century, he has been a business or civic leader who belonged to the old-guard Boston Club.
If you're not in New Orleans at showtime, you can get a sense of the thing at an excellent Mardi Gras museum housed in the old Presbytere -- one of the historic landmarks on Jackson Square, along with the Cabildo, the Pontalba Apartments and St. Louis Cathedral. Recent parades are shown on videotape. Costumes, floats and favors from years past are on display, along with plastic "go-cups" (so vital for portable booze) and "throws" -- the cheap beads and aluminum "doubloons" that float-riders toss to the crowds in response to the cry, "Throw me something, mister!"
You can also take the city's exuberant pulse every night of the year at jazz and blues haunts like Preservation Hall and the Funky Butt and all-purpose clubs like Tiptina's and the Maple Leaf. The action centers on Bourbon Street, the only street in the Quarter where neon is permitted. It lasts all night. New Orleans has no legal closing hour, and some nightspots are still throbbing when the sanitation men arrive in the dirty white light of morning to clean the debris from the gutters.
Things were particularly wild on our most recent visit. It coincided with Halloween, which attracts people from all over the country, including large contingents of gay men and lesbians, many of whom lavish enormous attention on their costumes. When we ancients gave up the ghost at midnight, the teeming streets of the Quarter looked like a Bruegel fantasy come to life.
 
Jazz, and All That Jazz
The Mardi Gras collection is just part of a trend that threatens to turn New Orleans into a museum town, of all things. The old Mint, a stern gray Greek Revival temple, now houses a small but choice collection of the Arts and Crafts pottery made early in the last century at Sophie Newcomb College for Women, as well as the New Orleans Jazz Collection, a must for any aficionado.
There are photographs of old jazzmen, letters that testify to the hard lives they lived, a map of Storyville "showing the principal sporting houses." Instruments: Johnny St. Cyr's banjo, Irving Fazola's clarinet, Bix Beiderbecke's cornet, the kazoo that Tony Spargo played in the Original Dixieland Jazz Band and, in a place of honor, the trumpet Louis Armstrong learned on.
New Orleans has a small opera company and a symphony orchestra, the Louisiana Philharmonic, patched together a decade ago by the never-say-die musicians of the defunct New Orleans Symphony. Maxim Shostakovich is a frequent guest conductor. But the city's most profound musical passions bubble up from the streets, into jazz and rhythm and blues, brass bands and zydeco, Cajun fiddling and gospel song.
Armstrong, born a century ago, a graduate of a boys' reformatory, is the city's hero, with a park named for him. His global renown eclipsed that of any other American musician. Jelly Roll Morton, Buddy Bolden and Sidney Bechet, also born in New Orleans, were other pioneers of jazz. Mahalia Jackson, the greatest of gospel singers, is the city's favorite musical daughter.
So why did so much music flower first here and not elsewhere?
Lolis Eric Elie, a columnist for The New Orleans Times-Picayune, offered this explanation: "The French here in New Orleans had different conceptions about slavery than the English in the rest of the country. The French let the Africans keep their drums."
A famous battle was fought at New Orleans on Jan. 8, 1815, when Andrew Jackson defeated crack British troops under Maj. Gen. Sir Edward Pakenham at Chalmette plantation. The final battle of the War of 1812, it cemented the American claim to the Mississippi and lifted the young nation's spirits. But if you head downriver to visit the battlefield, remember one of American history's ironies: the battle was fought, and General Pakenham died, after a peace treaty had been signed but before word of it reached the contending armies.
The big military noise in New Orleans more recently has been the debut of the National D-Day Museum, situated here because of a remark Dwight D. Eisenhower made to his biographer Stephen E. Ambrose, a longtime professor at the University of New Orleans. The general asked Professor Ambrose whether he knew much about Andrew Jackson Higgins, a hard-drinking, hard-driving boat builder who invented and built thousands of flat-bottomed, ramp-fronted boats that ferried American troops onto enemy beaches in Italy, Normandy and the Pacific.
"That Higgins," Ike said, "was the man who won the war for us."
"What a comment!" Professor Ambrose said. "What a source!"
 
Evoking the D-Day Landing
Now a new Higgins boat built by some of his 30,000 former employees sits in the atrium of a museum that attracted 175,000 people in its first three months. On the upper floors visitors can view a mockup of a D-Day glider landing, view hundreds of photographs and listen to excerpts from the thousands of interviews Professor Ambrose has conducted with survivors of the invasion and people who worked in the plants that provided them with war materiel.
Across the street, the Taylor Library (1888), the only building in the South by Henry Hobson Richardson, a Louisiana native, is being converted into a museum, and a new building is going up alongside it. They will open in 2001 as the Ogden Museum of Southern Art, showing 1,500 pieces from the collection of Roger H. Ogden, a local businessman. It contains works by well-known artists like Martin Johnson Heade and John James Audubon, by less prominent ones like James F. Pringle, an early marine painter, and by people most of us don't think of as visual artists at all, like Eudora Welty, a gifted photographer as well as a novelist.
Audubon, the great Haitian-born naturalist and painter, lived for a time in New Orleans, and his name is remembered here in that of the Audubon Zoo, one of the city's real ornaments. Upgraded extensively in recent years, it provides vivid glimpses of a wide variety of animals, many of them rare: muscular jaguars with pale, menacing eyes; alligators cruising silently just beneath slimy green waters, with only their eyes showing; tall, spindly red-crowned cranes. Almost all are shown in natural settings, contained by moats and not cages.
 
Sisters and Cousins
The zoo is just beyond the Garden District, which is the architectural showpiece of New Orleans -- block after block of Greek Revival and Victorian houses built in the glamorous antebellum years when this was one of the richest cities in America. Especially interesting are the "Seven Sisters" on Coliseum Street, a series of elegant and fastidiously maintained shotgun houses built on speculation; the three-story house at 1410 Jackson Avenue, with 48 classical columns and 22,000 square feet of living space; and the grand mansion at 2343 Prytania Street. A cast-iron fence whose design copies a cornstalk surrounds the Italianate house at 1448 Fourth Street.
The best of the French Quarter lies downriver from Ursulines Street, well beyond the blare of the Bourbon Street bars, the window-shoppers outside Royal Street's rich antiques shops and the venerable mule-drawn carriages queued at Jackson Square. The Old Ursuline Convent itself, the oldest building in the Mississippi Valley, is just the kind of formal, symmetrical building you find in provincial French capitals; the nearby Gallier House, at 1118-1132 Royal Street, has elegant cast-iron columns and a wonderful wrought-iron balcony.
Finally, the New Orleans Museum of Art merits a few hours of your time, for its superb glass collection, its Paul Storr silver, its three Derains and three Miros, its Gilbert Stuart portrait of Maj. Peter Fort, who fought under Jackson at Chalmette, and much else. But nothing so gripped me as the Degas portrait of his sister-in-law and first cousin, Estelle Musson Degas. The French artist's mother was born here, and he visited the city in 1872 and 1873, producing not only this fine picture but the famous view of his uncle's cotton office, which now hangs in the Musee des Beaux-Arts at Pau in southwestern France.

HEADLINE: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE

 BODY:
A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.
 
BETTY BRILL BUILDING YULE, Fez, 380 Lafayette Street, at Great Jones Street, East Village, (212) 533-2680. Betty, the fierce trio of rocking pop queens, begins a holiday run at this downtown club with carefully twisted versions of holiday pop favorites. Theo of the Lunachicks makes a special appearance. Sundays through Dec. 17 at 7:30 and 9:30 p.m.; admission is $15 (Ann Powers). 

CONJUNTO CLASICO, Copacabana, 617 West 57th Street, Clinton, (212) 582-2672. The classic part of Conjunto Clasico is its lineup of trumpets, percussion and the sharp delicacy of a tres guitar, playing time-tested styles like the son and the Puerto Rican bomba. Through the years the group has nurtured future salsa stars like the singer Tito Nieves. But the momentum it generates on a dance floor is completely contemporary. Tomorrow at 11 p.m., on a bill with Ramon Rodriguez and the 344 Orquestra; admission is $15 before 11, $25 after (Jon Pareles).
 
 MARSHALL CRENSHAW, Bottom Line, 15 West Fourth Street, Greenwich Village, (212) 228-7880. Marshall Crenshaw's songs seem to roll off the guitar in a casual blend of pre-1970's styles -- folk rock, surf rock, country and above all the Beatles -- that put melody first. With his winsome tenor, he delves into the ways love goes right and goes wrong, from distant yearning to the aftermath of infidelity, hiding turmoil within the chiming tunes. Lianne Smith and Neill Furio open shows tomorrow at 7:30 and 10:30 p.m.; admission is $20 (Pareles).
 
 GARY BARTZ QUINTET, Jazz Standard, 116 East 27th Street, Manhattan, (212) 576-2232. After 30 years, Mr. Bartz, the burning saxophonist, still has something of an underground reputation; he's always the stealth candidate. It's largely because he hasn't had the wide exposure on records that he deserves, but records never tell the truth anyway. He seems particularly comfortable at this club, so one could rightly expect all the elements to be in alignment. Sets tonight and tomorrow are at 8 and 10:30 p.m. and midnight, with a $25 cover for the first two sets, $18 for the midnight show; Sunday night sets are at 7 and 9 p.m., with an $18 cover; there is a $10 minimum for all shows (Ben Ratliff).10
 
 BORAH BERGMAN QUARTET, Tonic, 107 Norfolk Street, near Delancey Street, Lower East Side, (212) 358-7501. Mr. Bergman, the painist whose music is a battering, sometimes exultant form of post-Albert Ayler self-exploration, doesn't play in situations larger than a duo very often, so it's good to see him expanding. Here he is playing with the charismatic violinist Mat Maneri, the saxophonist Louie Belogenis and the drummer Michael Wimberly. Tomorrow at 10 p.m.; admission is $10 (Ratliff).
 
 FREDDIE BRYANT AND KALEIDOSCOPE, Jazz Standard, 116 East 27th Street, Manhattan, (212) 576-2232. This all-around guitarist has played with everyone from Tom Harrell to Charles Earland in jazz, and he has done classical music and a tour with the African pop star Salif Keita, too. But this is his jazz group with a Brazilian cast of mind; he'll mix in Antonio Carlos Jobim with standards. It's part of a free afternoon series at the Jazz Standard aimed at bringing a new, young audience to jazz; no food or drinks are served, and children are encouraged to come. Tomorrow from 2:30 to 4 p.m. (Ratliff).
 
 DEEP BANANA BLACKOUT, Irving Plaza, 17 Irving Place, at 15th Street, Manhattan, (212) 777-6800. Working the neopsychedelic jam band circuit, Deep Banana Blackout sets out to fuse Janis Joplin's blues-rock with the funk of the Meters. It pumps out wah-wah vamps while Jen Durkin insists she's ready to "Bump and Sway"; so are the fans. Tonight and tomorrow at 9 p.m.; tickets are $18.50 in advance; $22 day of show (Pareles).
 
 ELECTRIC HOT TUNA, Beacon Theater, 2124 Broadway, at 74th Street, (212) 496-7070. The guitarist Jorma Kaukonen and the bassist Jack Casady started Hot Tuna as a side project from the Jefferson Airplane, but it has now outlasted the original band. Mr. Kaukonen plays spiky, fingerpicked blues that calmly contemplate death and loss, still harking back to the Rev. Gary Davis; with Hot Tuna's electric lineup he also unleashes one of the most distinctive solo styles of the psychedelic era, burning with cold like liquid nitrogen. Tomorrow at 8 p.m.; tickets are $35 and $48 (Pareles).
 
 * ELEVENTH DREAM DAY, Mercury Lounge, 217 Houston Street, at Ludlow Street, Lower East Side, (212) 260-4700. Eleventh Dream Day has managed to become a supergroup despite itself. The Chicago-based institution is beloved by aging underground rock fans for its tension-filled guitar-bass-drums crackups, but younger listeners probably know the members' other projects better: the fiery guitarist Rick Rizzo has recorded with Red Red Meat, Palace and Tara Key; Douglas McCombs fingers the bass in Tortoise; and the drummer Janet Beveridge Bean plays a singing country sweetheart in Freakwater. This rare live show will probably feature assistance from other independent stars, like Ira Kaplan of Yo La Tengo. Tomorrow at 9 p.m.; admission is $12 (Powers).
 
 MAJEK FASHEK, Wetlands, 161 Hudson Street, at Laight Street, TriBeCa, (212) 386-3600. Majek Fashek, from Nigeria, puts the loping beat and determined resistance of Jamaican roots reggae at the core of his songs. But he turns the music into his own trans-Atlantic hybrid, using touches of rock guitar and traditional Nigerian talking drums. Sunday at 4 p.m.; admission is $10 (Pareles).
 
 BELA FLECK AND THE FLECKTONES, Beacon Theater, 2124 Broadway, at 74th Street, (212) 496-7070. Who but this banjo master would have thought to combine bluegrass with Indian tablas and Tuvan throat singing? With his recent album "Outbound" (Sony), Bela Fleck cements his position among the most adventurous fusion artists in the world. This show should draw a crowd that is part neohippie, part country traditionalist and part New Age jazz sophisticate. Warning to haters of progressive rock: although not scheduled, the singer Jon Anderson of Yes could make a guest appearance to repeat his "Outbound" vocals. Tonight at 8; tickets are $25, $32.50 and $37.50. (Powers).
 
 CHARLES GAYLE TRIO, Tonic, 107 Norfolk Street, near Delancey Street, Lower East Side, (212) 358-7501. Mr. Gayle, the saxophonist, has scaled down his terror-tenor style since he established himself on the New York scene in the early 90's and won a scrupulously attentive audience. It's still not straight-ahead jazz by any means, but you're more likely to hear some burnished Coleman Hawkins-style playing than the ghostly, paint-peeling ululations we got used to a decade ago. Mr. Gayle being Mr. Gayle, however, you may get a reading from the Bible or a sermon on homelessness. Tonight at 8; admission is $10 (Ratliff).
 
 * GO-BETWEENS, Maxwell's, 1039 Washington Street, Hoboken, N.J., (201) 798-0406. "I don't want to change a thing when there's magic in here," sings Grant McLennan on "The Friends of Rachel Worth" (Jetset), the first Go-Betweens album in a dozen years. Things have changed, inevitably, since the Australian band was one of the greatest not to hit the big time back in the 1980's. But Mr. McLennan and Robert Forster are a salt-and-pepper songwriting team, balancing each other perfectly on an album that hurts and heals. If you think the Beatles were good, you're right, but why not check out these secret stars and find out who rules in a parallel universe? Portastatic opens the show. Sunday at 9:30 p.m.; tickets are $12 (Powers).
 
 ARLO GUTHRIE, Carnegie Hall, (2212) 247-7800. Thanksgiving weekend brings the annual appearance by Arlo Guthrie, who honors the American tradition of the tall tale, spinning them in songs and between them. Whether recollecting his past as a shaggy-dog story or inventing narratives for characters, his timing and detail are drolly impeccable. Tomorrow at 8 p.m.; tickets are $23 to $38 (Pareles).
 
 * ROY HAYNES QUARTET, Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South, at 11th Street, Greenwich Village, (212) 255-4037. Mr. Haynes has played the drums with practically everybody of major significance in jazz since the 1940's -- from Louis Armstrong to Pat Metheny, as he likes to say, with a lot of bebop along the way. And he is marvelous, still an unprogrammed, original outrageously swinging musician. He seldom repeats rhythmic patterns; he displaces his band's rhythms, making the music sound as if it's spilling out all over the stage, and he hits the snare so hard and pointedly that he can remind you of a timbalero. Sets through Sunday are at 9:30 and 11:30 p.m., with a 1 a.m. set tonight and tomorrow; cover charge is $20 (Ratliff).
 
 ABDULLAH IBRAHIM TRIO, Iridium, 44 West 63rd Street, Manhattan, (212) 582-2121. More than any other pianist in jazz, this South African makes music that is still, calm, deliberate; it may be the ultimate expression of the drawing-room or parlor aesthetic in jazz. His sets tend to be movies for the ears with flowed-together themes and vamps, and he is an "I know this from somewhere" composer: his small, tight melodies put you in mind of a Stephen Foster song, an Ellington or Monk melody, a hymn. Sets are tonight through Sunday at 8:45 and 10:45 p.m.; cover charge is $25 and there is a $10 minimum (Ratliff).
 
 * KEITH JARRETT TRIO, New Jersey Performing Arts Center, 1 Center Street, Newark, (888) 466-5722. Because of health problelms, Mr. Jarrett has reduced his performing schedule in recent years, but his recent activity suggests improvement: this is the second time he has passed through this area in six months (and many are still talking about his Carnegie Hall show in May). This pianist's highly sensitive touch can make large halls seem intimate, and for improvised commitment, this longstanding trio -- with Gary Peacock on bass and Jack DeJohnette on drums -- is about as good as it gets. Tomorrow night at 8 p.m.; tickets are $14 to $48 (Ratliff).
 
 SHEILA JORDAN AND CAMERON BROWN, Cornelia Street Cafe, 29 Cornelia Street, Greenwich Village, (212) 989-9319. One of the most original singers to emerge in the late 50's and early 60's -- a time that also produced Abbey Lincoln and Jeanne Lee -- Ms. Jordan is still in good form, and she has just released a duet record with the bassist Cameron Brown, "I've Grown Accustomed to the Bass" (Highnote), from which the duo will draw their set. Sunday at 9 p.m.; cover charge is $10 and a one-drink minimum (Ratliff).
 
 * KIKI AND HERB: JESUS WEPT, Fez, 380 Lafayette Street, at Great Jones Street, East Village, (212) 533-2680. How can one describe the genius of Kiki and Herb? It's drag cabaret with the gut-wrenching impact of the best punk rock, the smarts of the snobbiest underground music, and the sick attractions of vintage torch lounge. It's the most hilariously disturbing show you'll see this season. And now the wild chanteuse and her stalwart accompanist are putting on a holiday show! That means they do cruel justice to standards like "Frosty the Snowman" alongside tunes by Belle and Sebastian and Styx. Ms. Kiki (known to the postal carrier as Justin Bond) once more matches Gena Rowlands in Method acting intensity. And the hapless crowd, ducking her advances, loves it. Tomorrow at 6:30 p.m.; tickets are $15 (Powers).
 
 GLADYS KNIGHT, FOUR TOPS, Westbury Music Fair, 960 Brush Hollow Road, Westbury, N.Y., (516) 334-0800. While Ms. Knight's husky alto was one of Motown's underused assets, it also made a lasting impression in songs that gave her a career that lasted well past the 1960's glory days of classic Motown, from "I Heard It Through the Grapevine" to "Midnight Train to Georgia." The Four Tops are equally tenacious. Until Lawrence Payton died in 1997, it was a paragon of group longevity, with the same lineup since 1954. It still has Levi Stubbs's dynamic baritone to charge through Motown classics like "Reach Out, I'll Be There" and "I Can't Help Myself." Tonight at 8; tickets are $50 (Pareles).
 
 VICTOR LEWIS QUINTET, Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, above Bleecker Street, Greenwich Village, (212) 242-1785. Mr. Lewis is a marvelous drummer, known in the 80's for associations with Stan Getz and Bobby Watson and in the 90's for freelancing and playing with his own band. He has hired important contributors to the modern scene like the saxophonist Seamus Blake, the pianist Stephen Scott and the trumpeter Terell Stafford. Sets through Sunday are at 9 and 11 p.m., with a 12:30 a.m. set tonight and tomorrow; cover charge is $20 cover, $10 minimum (Ratliff).
 
 MARILYN MANSON, Hammerstein Ballroom, 311 West 34th Street, Manhattan, (212) 564-4882. Marilyn Manson can't stop thinking about God, violence, fame, mass-media propaganda and deviant impulses. While Eminem has taken over his position as the top pop scourge, he's still a songwriter and showman who's determined to leave a creepy aftertaste. Tonight and tomorrow at 8 p.m.; tickets are $30 (Pareles).
 
 MOE, Roseland, 239 West 52nd Street, Manhattan, (212) 777-1224. Moe, from upstate New York, is one of the most invigorating bands on the jam-rock circuit. It keeps adding options to its core of Grateful Dead and Allman Brothers rock: reggae, Little Feat funk, touches of jazz. It's best onstage, where it can turn a minuscule little riff into music that keeps on generating unexpected ideas. Tomorrow at 7:30 p.m.; tickets are $20 (Pareles).
 
 * PINETOP PERKINS, Chicago Blues, 73 Eighth Avenue, below 14th Street, West Village, (212) 924-9755. Pinetop Perkins was the longtime pianist in Muddy Waters's Chicago blues band. He has the entire blues vocabulary in his fingers, from boogie and shuffle bass lines to florid barrelhouse trills and filigrees. But he plays his solos like a card sharp who shows only what he needs to, and his ruthless economy translates into pithy, ornery blues. Tonight and tomorrow at 9:30 and 11 p.m. and 12:30 a.m.; admission is $20 (Pareles).
 
 * SONNY ROLLINS, B. B. King Blues Club and Grill, 243 West 42nd Street, Manhattan, (212) 997-4144. If stamina's your thing, here's your man. With no sign of letup, Mr. Rollins still plays as if on a dare, sustaining raw power as he unrolls long lines within his epic improvisations. He is often the only soloist in a tune, and the tunes often run long. He has some good new material from a new album, "This Is What I Do" (Milestone),including the Hawaiian standard "Sweet Leilani," which, oddly enough, fits him beautifully. Tomorrow at 8 and 10:30 p.m.; tickets are $40. (Ratliff).
 
 SASHA AND JOHN DIGWEED, Twilo, 530 West 27th Street, Chelsea, (212) 268-1600. A longing for rapture and transcendence is never far from the surface of dance music, particularly in the utopian pulsations set out by the English disk-jockey team of John Digweed and Sasha. They are leaders in trance music, using steady repetition to hold time at bay and floating, whooshing sounds and voices to suggest freedom from the rigors of form. Doors open tonight at 11 p.m., with Sean Cusick warming up and John Digweed and Sasha starting at 1 a.m., continuing well past dawn. Admission is $35. To support the charitable group City Harvest, people bringing three items of canned goods will get reduced admission, and the first 20 people bringing full shopping bags are to be admitted free (Pareles).
 
 DR. LONNIE SMITH TRIO, Smoke, 2751 Broadway, at 106th Street, (212) 864-6662. The indefatigable organist sets up with the guitarist Peter Bernstein and the drummer Leon Parker for a weekend stay. Sets are tonight through Sunday at 9 and 10:30 p.m. and midnight; cover charge is $15-20, and there is a two-drink minimum (Ratliff).
 
 GREG TARDY QUARTET, Tonic, 107 Norfolk Street, near Delancey Street, Lower East Side, (212) 358-7501. The tenor saxophonist Greg Tardy -- who always sounded different from the others, not really a bebop-rooted player, and who has grown from recent associations with the trumpeter Tom Harrell -- had a little shot at recognition with an album on Impulse a few years back, before that operation folded. He is still a figure worth watching, often hooking up with some of New York's best younger musicians. Among those musicians is the pianist Ethan Iverson, who'll be with him for this set. Tomorrow at 8 p.m.; admission is $10 (Ratliff).
 
 McCOY TYNER, Blue Note, 131 West Third Street, Greenwich Village, (212) 475-8592. Mr. Tyner is the living mainline of jazz, the definer of modern harmony, the course that all developing players must pass through. Despite some lackluster recent albums, he is worth hearing in performance; he is still the music's deepest colorist and conjures a great, thunderous ring from his piano. Sets are tonight through Sunday are at 9 and 11:30 p.m.; cover charge is $35, plus a $5 minimum (Ratliff).
 
 UNCLE BONSAI, Bottom Line, 15 West Fourth Street, Greenwich Village, (212) 228-7880. Andrew Ratshin's songs -- with sly observations, twisted premises and intricate three-part high harmonies -- garnered Uncle Bonsai a dedicated cult following on the folkie circuit in the 1980's; the group has reunited for its first New York show in 12 years. Sunday at 3:30 and 8 p.m.; tickets are $20 (Pareles).
 
 PAPO VASQUEZ'S PIRATES AND TROUBADOURS, Up Over Jazz Cafe, 351 Flatbush Avenue, at Seventh Avenue, Park Slope, Brooklyn, (718) 398-5413. One of the best trombonists in town -- you've seen him if you've seen the Chico O'Farrill orchestra -- has a smoking new record, "At the Point, Vol. 2" (Cubop). The Puerto Rican bandleader will be playing his new Latin-jazz compositions, which are hotter and less music-school benign than a good deal of the genre. Shows are tonight and tomorrow at 9 and 10:30 p.m. and midnight; cover charge is $18; $5 minimum (Ratliff).
 
 * YO LA TENGO, Bowery Ballroom, 6 Delancey Street, at the Bowery, (212) 533-2111. Yo La Tengo's songwriters, the husband-and-wife team of Ira Kaplan on guitar and Georgia Hubley on drums, prize succinct, tuneful songs about the modest pains and pleasures of daily life and love. From those songs, however, a welter of fuzz-tone and feedback can erupt at any time, like a psychedelic disruption of quotidian reality. The band is sharing double bills with other well-traveled independent-circuit bands that explore longterm couple dynamics. Tonight at 9, with Damon and Naomi opening. Formerly of Galaxie 500, Damon and Naomi have retained their old group's hushed dynamics and searching simplicity. Tickets are $16 (Pareles).

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Europe's Central Banker Sees Signs of Slowing

BYLINE: Bloomberg News

DATELINE: BRUSSELS, Nov. 23

 BODY:
Wim Duisenberg, the president of the European Central Bank, said today that there were signs of slowing economic growth and inflation, indicating that interest rates might have peaked.
Recent reports "suggest some moderation" in the pace of economic expansion in the second half of this year, Mr. Duisenberg told members of the European Parliament. Inflation in the 11 nations that use the euro is likely to taper off, he said. 
 Germany's economy, Europe's largest, expanded 0.5 percent in the third quarter, less than half the rate of the previous three months, the Bundesbank said today.
German business confidence fell for a fifth straight month in October, a report showed on Tuesday. Rising oil prices and interest rates have increased costs for companies and curbed spending by consumers.
In a separate report today on Britain, which is not part of the euro zone, the nation's economy expanded 0.7 percent, down from 0.9 percent in the second quarter, government figures showed.
The euro's decline has pulled inflation into the region by raising the cost of imported goods.
The currency's weakness is a "cause for concern," Mr. Duisenberg said today in quarterly testimony to the parliament. The exchange rate with the dollar is "out of line with fundamentals," given a narrowing in economic growth rates between the United States and Europe, he said.
Mr. Duisenberg would not comment on speculation that the central bank would intervene in currency markets to bolster the euro, and he said he regretted an interview with The Times of London, which led some investors to speculate that the bank was reluctant to intervene.
He said that the bank was "trying to improve communication" and that process would include the twice-yearly publication of economic forecasts, including gross domestic product and inflation figures.
Even so, he played down a decision to publish economic forecasts that would allow investors a glimpse into the central bank's decision-making process, saying they would not offer a long-term guide to interest-rate decisions.
The euro region's economy is likely to expand 3.2 percent in 2001, compared with 3.3 percent in the United States, the European Commission predicted on Wednesday. This year, the euro zone's gross domestic product is likely to grow 3.5 percent, 1.6 percentage points less than the United States, the European Union's executive agency said. The gap in interest rates has also narrowed, after seven increases in rates by the European Central Bank in a year.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Russia Hopes to Revive Sagging Power Industry

BYLINE: By SABRINA TAVERNISE

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Nov. 23

 BODY:
After years of dwindling investment and neglect, Russia's power industry is beginning to crumble.
A decade after the fall of the Soviet Union, investment is down by two-thirds, and nearly half of the existing infrastructure has aged beyond its intended life span. With economic growth surging and generation capacity last expanded in the 1980's, Russia needs to modernize fast. 
 To upgrade its sagging infrastructure, built mostly in Soviet times -- portions predate the 1917 revolution -- Russia's monopoly electricity company said it would need $30 billion over the next 10 years. This investment, roughly equivalent to all of this year's federal government spending, is far greater than what local capital markets can provide. The solution, the company said, is to deregulate the industry and sell stakes in newly formed companies to foreign buyers.
"Russia's power sector, its technology and the condition of its equipment, is a disaster," said Anatoly B. Chubais, the chief executive of the national grid company, Unified Energy System. "Russia hasn't just reached the point of needing a restructuring, it has no other choice. The only way to rescue this sector is through private investment."
Russia's post-communist government tried to reorganize the electricity industry during the country's mass privatization in the 1990's. In that initial sale, Russia broke the industry into two layers. Unified Energy, the grid operator, was given almost all the biggest, most efficient power generators, while a second layer of 73 regional companies took weaker generators and local distribution. Foreign portfolio investors, like banks and mutual funds, snapped up stock in both Unified Energy and many of the regional companies during the stock market boom of 1996 and 1997, and now own about a third of Unified Energy.
But that first reorganization failed to generate new investment for the sector or to solve the chronic problem of nonpayment that, until recently, had strangled the industry. Regional companies fell hostage to powerful local politicians who blocked cutoffs and protected large customers who sometimes failed to pay their bills. And though Unified Energy is still one of Russia's most popular stocks, its share price is down more than 75 percent from its 1997 peak, and public offerings on the stock market no longer look like a viable way of raising cash for investment.
There does not seem to be a single, foolproof formula for deregulation, which is a recent development even in countries with well-established market systems. In California, for example, brownouts and soaring electricity prices have followed deregulation. Power cuts can have tragic consequences in Russia, where temperatures in parts of Siberia regularly plunge to 60 degrees below zero in winter, and power lines cross 11 time zones, so would-be reformers must tread carefully.
The aim of the new change is to liberalize Russia's highly regulated market and expand a wholesale market for electricity, where the country's biggest companies could shop around for the best price. Russia's existing federal wholesale market is extremely limited, with only 13 commercial consumers granted the right to buy electricity.
Mr. Chubais's new plan would separate power generators from the distribution companies that deliver power to and collect the bills from the end consumers. These generators, from hydroelectric plants to coal-powered plants, would be grouped into new companies, which would compete among one another for the best customers. In this way, reformers hope that intrusive local politicians would lose their grip on the power companies. Once a rudimentary market is established, Mr. Chubais would begin to sell stakes in those companies to big foreign power companies.
Central to the plan is foreign investment, which Russia has been notoriously bad at attracting. A weak court system, lax contract enforcement and a predatory tax system have deterred many foreign companies from entering Russia. While countries like Brazil brought in about $20 billion in foreign investment during its recent electricity restructuring, it is not clear that investors will have that kind of confidence in Russia.
Current foreign shareholders are among the biggest opponents of the reorganization plan. Investors profoundly distrust Mr. Chubais on a personal level and said they feared a repeat of Russia's earlier asset sales programs, when Mr. Chubais, then the head of the government's privatization committee, sold the best companies to his political allies on the cheap. A recent regrouping of regional energy companies south of Moscow on the Volga River has raised suspicions. Unified Energy said the shift would improve company management. Earlier this week, a leading foreign shareholder announced the government had agreed to change the company's charter to increase scrutiny of Mr. Chubais's plan.
Much of the power industry is still plagued with deep problems. For years, power companies have subsidized the Russian economy by continuing to supply non-paying customers with electricity and accepting a large share of payments they did receive in barter and mutual debt write-offs. That has improved tremendously the last two years as payments in money have risen to 90 percent from a low of 10 percent, aided by an economic recovery and Mr. Chubais's tougher approach to chronic debtors.
Also, electricity prices are still too low to justify large new investments, foreign power companies said. Though prices paid by large industrial companies are rising slightly, individual Russians pay deeply subsidized rates, less than one-tenth the price American consumers pay. Power failures, mostly because of bad management and fuel shortages, are still widespread.
These problems must be resolved, or at least reduced, before Russia begins restructuring, critics said.
"It's trying to run before you can walk," said Scott Foster, director of European power at Cambridge Energy Research Associates in Paris. "You need a functional system where money is flowing, all players are confident, and prices provide a fair return on capital. That's probably still a missing link."
Mr. Chubais, ferociously pro-market, said these problems would resolve themselves as soon as a market was created. His program would push the necessary laws through parliament and create the necessary market infrastructure such as a network administrator by the end of next year.
"The only possible way of attracting private investors is to make a market," said Mr. Chubais. "Current prices aren't inherently bad because they are low, they are bad because they are set in a very wrong way -- by the government."

HEADLINE: Telephone-Related Companies Lead Rise in European Stocks

BYLINE: Bloomberg News

DATELINE: LONDON, Nov. 23

 BODY:
European stocks rose, led by phone-equipment and phone companies like Alcatel and Vodafone as some investors bought the worst performers of the last month. Drug makers including Merck gained amid optimism they would be dependable profit generators as economic growth weakens.
Phone-related stocks "have fallen a very long way, and you can't rule out a sharp rebound," said Jim Stride, who helps manage about 40 billion ($56 billion) at Axa Sun Life Investment Management. "The survivors in the industry will make a lot of money, and consumer demand for telephony is not falling just because the stocks are." 
 Danone climbed after saying it would not bid for Quaker Oats.
The United States stock market was closed for the Thanksgiving holiday, leading to below-average trading volume in Europe.
Alcatel, Europe's No. 2 phone-equipment maker, rose 4.15 euros ($3.50), or 7.4 percent, to 60.5 euros ($51.05), trimming its one-month decline to 20 percent. Vodafone, the world's biggest mobile-phone company, climbed 8.5 pence (12 cents), to 250 pence ($3.52), cutting its slide over the last month to 11 percent.
Merck, Germany's fifth-biggest drug maker, rose 2 euros ($1.69), or 4.4 percent, to 47 euros ($39.66), and AstraZeneca, Europe's No. 1 pharmaceuticals company, climbed 85 pence ($1.20), or 2.6 percent, to 3,345 pence ($47.07).
Phone and computer-related shares surged late in the day. Traders who sold stocks they did not own in the morning, expecting them to fall after the Nasdaq composite index dropped 4 percent on Wednesday, had to buy them back in the afternoon as declines failed to materialize. "There have been a few shorts out there, and the moves this afternoon suggest there was some aggressive buying to cover those positions," said Peter Cogliatti, a trader at Williams de Broe in London. "With thin volumes, that pushed prices quite a bit higher."
Danone added 9 euros ($7.59), or 6.3 percent, to 153.1 euros ($129.19), reversing an earlier decline of up to 4 percent. Danone said it would not pursue a takeover of Quaker Oats.
British American Tobacco lost 33 pence (46 cents), or 6.3 percent, to 492 pence ($6.92). The company's Brown & Williamson Tobacco unit must pay a $750,000 award to an ill smoker after the Florida Supreme Court reversed an earlier appeals-court decision on Wednesday.
While the verdict is small compared with the record $145 billion Miami jury award levied against Brown & Williamson and four other tobacco companies in July, yesterday's decision marks the first time a tobacco award has been affirmed by a state's highest court.
ABN Amro declined 1.37 euros ($1.16), or 5.5 percent, to 23.6 euros ($19.91). The biggest Dutch bank said it would sell shares or assets to finance the $2.75 billion acquisition of National Australia Bank's Michigan National unit, its second purchase in Michigan.
Telecom Italia climbed 0.21 euro (18 cents), or 1.6 percent, to 13.2 euros ($11.14). Italy's biggest phone company said it would sell a stake in a real-estate unit with assets primarily in the nation's three most-populated regions, enabling Telecom Italia to cut its debt by 17 percent.
In European currency trading, the dollar rose against most other major currencies. The euro settled at at 83.88 cents, down from 84.13 cents on Wednesday, and the dollar traded at 110.24 yen, up from 110.14.

HEADLINE: Company Says Tracing Problem Corn May Take Weeks

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER

 BODY:
It might take weeks to figure out how the insect-killing trait in genetically altered StarLink corn migrated into a variety of corn that was not supposed to be genetically modified, according to the Garst Seed Company, the producer of the corn.
Garst, which announced on Tuesday that it had encountered the biological mystery while testing samples of corn seed marketed as early as 1998, said it might also take weeks to sort out how widespread the problem was and whether any of the corn had made it into the food chain. 
 Garst's announcement was just the latest twist in a biotechnology controversy that began in September with the discovery that small amounts of corn from StarLink crops, which were supposed to be sold only for animal feed or industrial use, had shown up in taco shells and other food products.
StarLink corn, which was invented by Aventis CropScience, the agricultural division of the Aventis Corporation, contains a gene that produces a protein called Cry9c, which is toxic to corn borers and related insects. StarLink has no known health effects on humans, and similar toxins are widely used in agriculture. But the Environmental Protection Agency decided in 1997 that Aventis's technology should be kept out of human food because laboratory tests indicated that the protein might cause food allergies.
Biotechnology critics jumped on the unauthorized spread this year of StarLink into the food chain as proof of how hard genetically engineered traits are to segregate once they are in the agricultural marketplace. Many critics argue that much of the technology should be banned until stricter controls and better assessments of any potential long-range effects are in place.
Garst's announcement this week opened up a new front in the battle by suggesting that breakdowns in segregation can come even before the seed reaches the farmer.
"This blows a lot of assumptions out of the water," said Margaret Mellon, senior scientist with the Union of Concerned Scientists in Washington. "How do you regulate risks that manifest themselves even before the product is out there?"
The new controversy involves a strain of corn called 8481 that Garst bred for growing conditions in the heart of the Midwest.
One version of the corn sold in 1998 had the StarLink trait but the other, known as 8481IT, did not. Or so Garst thought. After a few farmers complained that tests showed their supposedly unmodified 8481 carried the StarLink gene, Garst began investigating and concluded that small amounts of StarLink had apparently made their way into 8481IT seed grown in 1997 for the 1998 market.
Garst said it did not know whether the transfer came during pollination as the seed was being grown or through mixing of seeds after harvest. Garst said there was no sign of a similar problem in 8481IT it raised in 1999 or 2000 but that some of the 1998 supply had been stored and sold in those years.
A bit of the 1998 supply might be on the market this year, as well, said Jeffrey W. Lacina, a spokesman for Garst, which is based in Slater, Iowa. But Garst is carefully screening all seed it is selling for the 2001 planting season to make sure that none of it contains the StarLink gene, Mr. Lacina said on Wednesday. Indeed, Garst said its push to make sure that this year's products are pure and to contact anyone who bought 8481 in the past is keeping it from tracking down what happened in 1997 as rapidly as it would like.
The Agriculture Department responded swiftly to Garst's announcement by calling for a meeting on Monday of industry representatives, researchers, policy experts and economists to discuss Garst's findings and the appropriate response. But Garst's timeline for gathering crucial data on the cause and scope of the problem suggests it may be hard to reach any conclusions.
The new controversy is also certain to be felt on Tuesday in Washington when the Environmental Protection Agency holds a meeting on Aventis's petition for an agency ruling that StarLink corn can be accepted in food for the next four years. One of the arguments is that so much of the StarLink corn has been accounted for and directed to permitted uses since the controversy erupted that whatever is left will not be enough to present a food-allergy threat.
The entire 2000 StarLink crop amounted to less than one-half of 1 percent of the nation's corn harvest. Aventis has withdrawn its registration for StarLink, and no new StarLink crops are to be planted in 2001.
A ruling allowing whatever StarLink is in the food chain to simply pass through might save millions of dollars in testing and food recalls. But critics say the 8481 developments this week raise new questions about how far beyond the StarLink crops themselves the potential risks run.
