HEADLINE: The Way We Live Now: 11-26-00: The Ethicist;
Open Courts for All

BYLINE: By Randy Cohen

 BODY:
My friend and I play tennis in a neighboring town where only residents who pay a yearly fee of $50 may use the courts. The courts are unsupervised, and one or both of them are always vacant. We are not preventing any resident from playing. Are we committing an unethical act by using the courts? -- Shane Mullane, Westchester County, N.Y.
I'm afraid you are acting badly. This is a version of what economists call the "free rider" problem: is stealing cable really theft? You cost the cable company nothing and prevent no one else from using cable. Yet if everyone were to steal cable, the company would go under -- no more cable TV, no more "Sex in the City" (which many economists would consider lamentable, although I don't see why). Hence your obligation to pay your share for any such service. 
 However, while you behave badly, that neighboring town behaves worse by giving you no way to pay your share even if you wish to. The town does have a legitimate interest in financing its facilities and regulating their use, but this can be done without pulling up the drawbridge.
Residents-only policies, redolent of gated communities, are disturbingly undemocratic and too often have the effect, if not the provable intent, of excluding minorities and the poor. Happily, in most American towns, public facilities like museums and ball fields, libraries and playgrounds, are open to all. You don't have to show your papers to enter Central Park in Manhattan, even if you hail from Westchester.
My husband and I will soon put our house on the market. It is a beautiful house in a great neighborhood, but the builder cut some corners on the construction. After the closing, when my disclosure can't affect the sale, should I tell all? My husband says to let the buyer's engineer determine what needs to be done, but I'm afraid he'll miss some things. What do you think? -T.C., Long Island, N.Y.
I'm with your husband. There is a built-in conflict of interest between seller and buyer: the former wants to get the highest price; the latter wants the lowest. The solution is for both parties to adhere to the standards of behavior that customarily govern such transactions. That means you must honestly answer any question put to you, and you may not conceal any flaws, but the buyer should not rely on you to volunteer every defect in the house. It is the buyer's responsibility to have a good engineer check out the place. In short: caveat emptor.
The more important consideration is what you do before the sale, not after. But if you spring a list of shortcomings on the buyers two minutes after the closing, they may not be as grateful as you anticipate. Even though unspoken, the word "sucker" might echo through the inadequately insulated bathroom beneath the leaky roof.
At a fast-food restaurant, I parked next to a well-worn car that sported a bumper sticker with some pretty foul language. Although the words on display are used commonly -- I have used them myself -- I was offended, and if I had had a can of spray paint, I would have been tempted to paint over them. Would that have been wrong? - G. Kaye Holden, Roseville, Calif.
The idea of free speech is to increase, not decrease, conversation. A better response would be to leave a note telling the driver what you think of his bumper sticker. He gets his say, and you get yours. Nobody's bumper gets painted, and nobody's nose gets punched by someone angry that his bumper got painted.
Send your queries to ethicist@nytimes.com or The Ethicist, The New York Times Magazine, 229 West 43rd Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, and include a daytime phone number.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: The Way We Live Now: 11-26-00;
Two Nations, Undivided

BYLINE: By Andrew Sullivan; Andrew Sullivan, a contributing writer for the magazine, writes daily commentary at www.andrewsullivan.com.

 BODY:
If you take a look at that remarkable postelection map, in which all of George W. Bush's states are red, and all of Al Gore's states are blue, you would be forgiven for thinking that we live in essentially two nations. A friend recalled the map of pre-independence India: a vast, red Hindu subcontinent adorned with a Muslim necklace in the regions that would shortly become Pakistan and Bangladesh. Look at postelection America, and you see a similarly clear geographic divide: the liberal, urban coasts with a couple of Midwestern blobs nervously framing a homogeneous, conservative heartland. As the political analyst Michael Barone first noticed, cities with more than half a million people went to Gore by a 3-to-1 margin, but in small towns, Bush won about 60 percent of the vote.
The columnist Mike Barnicle described this divide as "Wal-Mart versus Martha Stewart" or "Family values versus a sense of entitlement." The Democratic pol-turned-pundit Paul Begala had an even starker explanation: "You see the state where James Byrd was lynch-dragged behind a pickup truck until his body came apart -- it's red. You see the state where right-wing extremists blew up a federal office building and murdered scores of federal employees -- it's red." The divide can be described in a million ways: ethnic minorities versus white traditionalists; rootless cosmopolitans versus redneck bigots; Salon.com versus the Drudge Report; iMac users versus tow-truck drivers; Starbucks versus Cracker Barrel; NPR versus Rush. And the close nature of the race, and the deeply different personalities of the two candidates, only accentuate this picture. 
 But if you break the map down into counties, you see something more interesting. What's that blue sliver meandering up the Mississippi? Look at the bluish enclaves in New Mexico, Wisconsin, Louisiana and Tennessee. Check out the red inland counties of California. Democrats won more than half of Texas' Congressional seats. More than four million Californians voted for George W. Bush. In Bush's highest margin of victory in any state, in Wyoming, Al Gore still got well over a quarter of the vote. In Gore's biggest statewide blowout, Rhode Island, Bush still won about a third of the vote.
We live in a prosperously complex time, and the election proved it. The professional political classes' careers were at stake, but many others saw it as a bitter fight over not very much. Two candidates spoke to a real divide; they discussed America's role in the world and the corruption of the political system. And between them, Ralph Nader and Patrick Buchanan could barely scrape up 4 percent of the national vote. The distinctions between the major candidates were, on a cosmic level, trivial. Both proposed to pay down the national debt; both offered tax cuts; both offered some form of prescription-drug entitlement under Medicare; both were internationalists; both were scions of political dynasties. Only the emphases were different.
To add to this, many supported their candidates with severe reservations. Plenty of liberal Democrats would rather listen to a modem than to Al Gore, and plenty of conservatives think W. mangled their arguments. Fundamentalist Christians, blacks and Jews voted as blocks, but they are the exceptions. A third of Latinos voted for Bush; Catholics and Asian-Americans were roughly split. A full quarter of even the gay vote went to Bush -- even more to Republican Congressional candidates.
And then when you look at individual voters, the complexities only mount. I think of my own cultural mishmash: immigrant, gay, urban, observant Catholic, culturally liberal, white Bush-backer in the District of Columbia. I can't be the only one having difficulties fitting into this two-nation business. Look at the first two commentators I mentioned. Mike Barnicle looks as if he belongs in the reddest of states. But he's from Massachusetts, where Al Gore won one of his biggest victories. Or think of Paul Begala, eager spinmeister for the blues. Where is he from? Sugar Land, Tex., home of Tom DeLay, Republican hatchet man. I see Begala sometimes at Mass. He doesn't look like a countercultural subversive to me. In fact, there are many urban elites who have one foot in the heartland. Think of George Stephanopoulos: liberal macher, son of a Greek Orthodox priest. Or take a glance at all the Republican staff members on Capitol Hill: young, urban, "South Park" watchers. Or look at Al Gore: a man born into privilege who married his high-school sweetheart and served in Vietnam. Or W. himself: a man of the heartland who just happened to go to Yale and Harvard. They're each as complex as the other.
It's easier, of course, to put them into neat, little boxes: red and blue, right and left, heartland and coasts. But if this election showed anything, it is that the political need for this simplicity is almost proportional to its disappearance in our lives. We will survive this close vote, and multiculturalism in its deepest sense will be the ultimate victor. To borrow Nathan Glazer's phrase, we are all multiculturalists now -- and this hybrid identity doesn't just separate us from one another, but equally separates us from ourselves. We can either bemoan this complexity or celebrate it. I'd rather celebrate and marvel at the way our old political system has now absorbed the new cultural kaleidoscope of all our lives.

HEADLINE: PRACTICAL TRAVELER;
Stretching For Safety Aloft

BYLINE: By BETSY WADE

 BODY:
MEDICAL studies have produced conflicting conclusions on whether there is a link between travel, particularly in an airplane, and venous thrombosis, or blood clots in veins. But following the death of Emma Christoffersen, a 28-year-old who collapsed at Heathrow upon debarking from a 20-hour Qantas flight from Australia and died of thrombosis on her way to the hospital, the nuances of the dispute were lost.
Deep-vein thrombosis can be fatal when a large blood clot in the leg breaks off and migrates to the heart and lungs, as it did in Ms. Christoffersen's case; this sort of threat required President Nixon to keep his leg elevated on air trips in 1974. Vice President Dan Quayle was hospitalized in 1994 for clots his doctor ascribed to sitting too long on planes. 
 Despite researchers' recent conflict over the relationship between air travel and thrombosis, medical experts in the field of travel are clear about who is at risk -- those with a history of clots, women taking birth-control pills, and people with cancer or who have had recent surgery. And experts are likewise clear about safeguards for health in flight.
 
Debate Over Aspirin
These specialists describe as unwise the advice of a British organization, the Aviation Health Institute of Oxford. After Ms. Christoffersen's death, it said air travelers should take aspirin before a long flight as a blood thinner. There are no clinical data on the value of this step absent personal medical advice, said Rebecca Wolfe-Acosta, executive director of the Traveler's Medical Service in New York; many people have medical reasons not to take aspirin.
Dr. Nigel Dowdall, senior consultant to British Airways Health Service, who is based in London, deplored the Aviation Health Institute's comments. "Despite their name, they are not a medical research institute," he said.
After Ms. Christoffersen died Sept. 28, many news reports spoke of "economy class syndrome," a phrase used in 1988 in the British medical journal The Lancet. Most experts believe that if blood clots are linked to air travel, they are linked to other forms of travel with cramped, passive conditions -- buses, cars or trains -- and can occur in first class, too.
The 1988 Lancet article was written by Dr. John M. Cruickshank and two associates; Dr. Cruickshank had suffered an embolism after a trip to the Far East, and nearly killed himself by playing tennis after he thought the problem had passed. The authors studied data maintained at Heathrow on 61 sudden deaths of long-distance passengers over three years. Eighteen percent were ascribed to blood clots; the victims tended to be women over 40 with a history of thrombosis in deep veins.
A more recent study was made by four physicians at the Pasteur Hospital in Nice, France. From July 1992 to August 1995 they examined 160 patients, 51.8 percent men, who came to their hospital in succession with thromboembolic disease, as well as 160 in an age-matched control group with other complaints. The physicians, led by Dr. Emile Ferrari, presented their results in Chest, a publication of the American College of Chest Physicians, last year.
This study found a history of recent travel -- not necessarily by air -- was four times more frequent among the thrombosis patients than among the others. All trips of more than four hours in the four weeks before hospital admission were considered: 2 train trips, 9 plane trips and 28 car trips. The risk of thrombosis is not restricted to air transport alone, the paper said: "We show that all means of transport can be 'incriminated.' "
A study finding the opposite was published in The Lancet on Oct. 28. Six researchers at the University of Amsterdam said earlier reports were based on uncontrolled or poorly controlled studies. From April 1997 to January 1999, they studied 788 patients, 58 percent women, who also arrived consecutively at the hospital. The patients were asked if they had made air, bus, car, train or boat trips of more than three hours in the previous four weeks. These questions were answered before diagnostic tests, which were then conducted without knowledge of patients' travel history. Blood clots in veins were confirmed in 186; the 602 others formed the control group.
"Our findings suggest that, for all types of transport examined, there was no association between travel and an increased risk of thrombosis," wrote the authors, led by Dr. Roderick A. Kraaijenhagen.
Dr. Karl Neumann of Queens, the Web editor for the International Society of Travel Medicine, who writes about and counsels patients on health in flight, said the Dutch study represented good news for travelers but should be treated with caution. He strongly urged that passengers who fall into the high-risk category consult doctors about measures to take before air travel.
The cause of thrombosis is pooling of blood in the legs, which is caused by prolonged inactivity and sitting, usually with the backs of the knees against the seat, with a contributing factor the lessened proportion of oxygen in cabin air and thus in hemoglobin.
The study in Chest magazine called dry air a possible contributing factor, and one of Dr. Cruickshank's co-authors, Dr. Richard Gorlin, said that the oxygen-poor environment could mildly affect an average person, but for those with marginal circulation problems, it could cause trouble.
Dr. Neumann said there was no value in drinking a lot of water because it did not increase the oxygen supply and dehydration was not a real threat aboard planes; it is air-conditioning that makes the skin and mouth feel dry, not approaching dehydration.
 
Comfortable Clothes
Passengers concerned about blood clots should dress in comfortable, loose clothes for travel in cars or planes, and should not wear knee socks with elastic tops or other garments likely to constrict blood flow from the legs, Ms. Wolfe-Acosta said. People whose veins do not function well, she said, should see a doctor ahead of time and get fitted for elastic stockings that keep the blood from pooling. "Don't just put on an Ace bandage," she said. "Stay well hydrated, and that will at least force you to get up to go to the loo."
Many airlines encourage passengers to exercise their feet and legs to improve circulation and prevent problems, an activity that Dr. Neumann and Ms. Wolfe-Acosta also urge. Lufthansa has long had a 10-minute video, "Flyrobics," showing exercises to be performed while seat belts are fastened. Dr. Dowdall of British Airways said that his airline was seeking better ways to give information on exercise, perhaps a video. "We want people to get those calf muscles going," he said, but not necessarily in the aisles.
The in-flight magazine for Qantas, The Australian Way, recommends on its safety-information page that passengers move their legs three or four minutes an hour to improve circulation. Steve Kernaghan, a Qantas spokesman in Los Angeles, said that the airline planned to dedicate two audio channels to exercise information.

HEADLINE: FRUGAL TRAVELER;
Ghosts of Portugal in Macao, Now Part of China

BYLINE: By DAISANN McLANE

 BODY:
HAVE you ever been to Macao?" I asked everyone I met in Hong Kong. The answer, nearly always, was yes. Hong Kong residents pop off to Macao for the weekend as casually as New Yorkers head for the Hudson Valley or the Hamptons. It's an easy trip that requires little advance planning. Regular ferries between the two cities, both former colonial outposts, both now Special Administrative Regions of China, zip passengers to and fro across the South China Sea in about an hour.
Since Macao is so accessible, I expected it to be a smaller version of Hong Kong, with a few Portuguese style buildings (Macao was a colony of Portugal until 1999) and a lot of casinos (gambling is legal there). But history and economics can isolate a place as effectively as mountain barriers or xenophobic leaders. Compared with Hong Kong, which tears down and rebuilds itself with abandon, Macao exists in a freeze frame. 
 During the three days and nights I spent there in October, I often felt as if I were walking around in a historical preserve, not a city. Or in an Indiana Jones movie (one of which, I learned later, was filmed partly in Macao).
I decided to toss my map and let my feet lead me through the sepia-toned side streets off San Ma Lo, Macao's main thoroughfare. Passing a row of apothecary shops, their shelves stacked with jars of dried medicinal herbs, I paused to peer through a window at three large jars in which pale serpents floated, coiled, in formaldehyde. On the corner a vendor ladled a bitter-smelling brown tonic into glasses for his customers, old men in white sleeveless undershirts who downed the brew in two gulps. Another vendor spread his wares on the sidewalk: yellowed 1940's advertising posters for Hong Kong perfume companies and brightly colored printed labels carefully peeled off boxes of firecrackers and slipped between cellophane for safekeeping.
There were antique shops at every turn. I entered one carefully, through an obstacle course of porcelain urns and Confucius statues, and stopped to admire a display case filled with dozens of tiny thin-soled silk slippers, all encrusted with sequins. I had never seen Chinese children wearing such treasures, and I suddenly realized that these elaborate slippers had been worn not by children but by women with bound feet.
Macao, not Hong Kong, was the first colonial outpost of the Pearl River delta. The Portuguese settled on the peninsula in 1557, worked out a lease with the local Cantonese authorities, and proceeded to carve for themselves a profitable role that served them well for 100 years or so, as trade intermediaries between a closed China and a spice- and silk-craving Europe. Macao thrived as a halfway house between East and West, a city of Taoist temples and baroque Catholic churches. But its golden years faded along with Portugal's declining fortunes as a colonial power. By the 1700's the Dutch had moved into the East, and the English followed. When the British took possession of Hong Kong in 1841, Macao was already a backwater.
But a savvy Portuguese governor in the 1850's legalized gambling in Macao, a move that has shaped the economy, and the image, of Macao to the present day. Gambling gave Macao an air of raffishness, and a reputation, often deserved, as a refuge for shady characters and deals of every stripe.
After the handover of Hong Kong to China in 1997, several of Hong Kong's notorious gangs, or triads, relocated to Macao. The warfare spilled into the streets, and at one point got so outrageous that the most notorious triad leader, Wan Kuok-koi, nicknamed Broken Tooth, financed a movie in which one of Hong Kong's most handsome actors played him, as a hero. Meanwhile, the State Department issued a traveler's warning about Macao, and tourism plummeted.
Compared with the hubbub surrounding the Hong Kong handover in 1997, Macao's handover from Portugal to China in 1999 passed with relatively little fanfare. But in the 11 months since Macao became a Special Administrative Region of China, the triads have disappeared into the woodwork, and the tourists have slowly started coming back.
Arranging a trip to Macao from Hong Kong -- at steep discount rates -- was so easy that I feared there was a catch somewhere. To book my hotel and my ferry tickets, I went to the Shun Tak Center, a shopping mall on Hong Kong island that connects with the Hong Kong-Macao ferry terminal. Just outside the ferry entrance was a cluster of travel agencies, with window advertisements for hotels. The text in almost all the posters was Chinese, but one agency, Macao South China Travel, had some English print in the window, too, so I went in to inquire.
I told the desk clerk that I wanted to arrange a short stay in Macao, and she gave me a listing of 28 Macao hotels, with the daily rates for the next week in Hong Kong dollars. With a few quick calculations, I realized that the midweek prices on this sheet were 40 to 50 percent less than the rack rates in my guidebooks (weekend prices were only about 10 percent less). But how to choose among 28 hotels?
Sensing my indecision, the clerk handed me a scrapbook filled with hotel brochures. Soon I'd decided on the Pousada de Sao Tiago, a small hotel constructed in the remains of a 17th-century Portuguese fort. At its normal rate of around $150, the pousada would have been too expensive for me. But at the agent's price of $83, I could afford to go upscale, while treating myself to one of the few Macao hotels with historic architecture.
In another five minutes, the agent had completed my hotel booking and booked my ferry tickets (round trip is around $35). "I'll call the hotel with your arrival time and they'll pick you up at the ferry terminal," she said.
I wondered why the Macao hotels were so eager to deal -- were they still starved for the tourists who fled after the triad wars? Or was Macao an Asian Las Vegas, luring visitors to its shores with outrageous discounts in hopes they would lose their shirts at the tables? Probably a bit of both, I figured. Still, I was feeling skeptical.
When I walked out of the Macao ferry terminal to the pickup area, and saw a row of vans lined up for just about every hotel in the book except the Pousada de Sao Tiago, my inner cynic said "I told you so!" I headed back into the terminal, to the office of the Macao Government Tourist Authority, and loaded up on brochures, maps and a "passport" book of discounts to museums and shops, then dragged my bags back into the lobby, wondering if I should hire a taxi.
A man in a dark suit and cap approached me and I got ready to bargain. But he reached for my suitcase, made a reasonable stab at pronouncing my name, and led me to a shiny black Mercedes (the hotel's car) that had been waiting for me at the curb all along.
Passing through the wall of modern concrete hotels that separates the terminal area from the old city, I was glad I'd chosen the pousada, which is on the other side of the Macao peninsula from the ferry. The hotels, most of which have casinos, absorb the majority of the Hong Kong visitors, who come, straight off the boats, to gamble.
But beyond the concrete towers is a rich urban landscape of mostly two- and three-story buildings, dating back at least 100 years, and in some cases many more. A typical facade had European rococo plaster flourishes surrounding Chinese characters.
The entryway to the pousada is a stone staircase that leads up through a narrow passageway. Climbing up the damp tunnel I half expected to find a cannon at the top instead of the front desk. Two clerks handed me a registration form in English, Chinese and Portuguese. Assuming that the latter was the European lingua franca in town, I introduced myself in Portuguese -- to blank, uncomprehending stares. I switched to English. "Doesn't anyone speak Portuguese here?" No, they said.
In my room -- large and grand in the Iberian style, with heavy mahogany furniture, tiled floors and a private balcony overlooking the water -- the folder of information and the room service menu were in Portuguese. As were the signs on just about every public building, street and bus. But I never heard the language spoken. The signs for farmacias and avenidas seemed artifacts of a different century.
I could easily have spent three entire days wandering these avenidas like an Indiana Jones, popping into shadowy shops; exploring the multitiered Taoist Temple of A-Ma; then lingering at twilight in the Latin plaza that dominates Macao's center, the Largo do Leal Senado. Getting around was easy -- Macao is walkable, and when I got tired I hopped onto a bus. After realizing that few of the Portuguese names on my map were in regular use by average Macanese, I asked the hotel staff to tell me the Chinese names of a few main landmarks.
Once I could tell the bus drivers where I was headed in the right language (in Macao that's Cantonese), I covered a lot of ground. One morning I rode up the steep hill to see Macao's most fascinating architectural landmark, the ruins of St. Paul's Church. All that remains of this classic Portuguese-style church, dating from 1602 and nearly destroyed by fire in 1835, is the grand staircase and the magnificent original facade, which has been propped up by steel beams in the back and appears, from certain angles, to be a stage set.
Just above St. Paul's is an old Portuguese fort that was converted to a museum by the Portuguese shortly before the handover. The Macao Museum turned out to be a fascinating place. Its three floors contained well-designed and well-conceived exhibits that explained the city's polyglot history and provided insights into Macanese culture. I learned, for instance, about Macao's traditional cockroach-fighting tournaments -- a pastime so serious and all-absorbing that champion insects who fell in battle were laid to rest in specially carved wooden coffins.
The museum exhibits answered my questions about the curious things I'd observed on the streets. Those syrupy brown tonics were restorative herbal teas. The antique fireworks labels being sold came from factories that had been an important economic force in Macao for a century.
Another morning I rode a bus across a short causeway linking Macao's main peninsula to the islet of Taipa (also part of Macao), where I spent an hour poking around a village of one-story pastel houses that seemed transplanted straight from the Portuguese coast.
Nearby, according to my map, was the Taipa House Museum, a restored row of grand mansions built in the early 20th century by rich Portuguese merchants. Although the houses are open now, when I arrived they were closed for renovations; a crew of workmen perched on scaffolds, leisurely painting the mansions under the hot sun.
I'm not by nature a gambler, but I knew I couldn't leave Macao without at least visiting a casino. With the sun getting hotter, this seemed like a good moment to go.
The casino in the Hotel Lisboa is Macao's biggest. I passed through an X-ray scan into a large, dim room thronged with stone-faced men and women. There were no conversations to disturb the clack of playing tiles, the rattle of dice underneath glass domes. Gambling in Macao appears to be very serious business.
I stood for a while, trying to fathom the rules of the most popular game on the floor, a Chinese game of chance called Dai Siu (Big-Small). Gamblers flung Hong Kong dollars and Macao patacas onto the Chinese characters on the green felt-top table. And I was tempted to join them, once I'd mastered the basics. (You bet whether the dice will add up to a large or small number, with the odds about the same as hitting a red or black in roulette.) My fingers itched for the zipper on my bag. With a bit of luck, this trip to Macao could turn out to be really frugal!
But the temptation passed, as I realized that I'd already placed my bet on Macao, and hit the big time. A smart traveler knows when to quit. I walked out of the Lisboa Casino with all my patacas.
 
The bottom line: pinching patacas adds up to less than $120 a day
 I spent three days and nights in Macao; the total for hotel, meals, local transport and museum admissions came to $350.
Shops, hotels, casinos and restaurants in Macao do business in two currencies, the Hong Kong dollar and the Macao pataca. The prices below are calculated at 7.8 Hong Kong dollars to the United States dollar, and 8 patacas to the United States dollar.
 
Getting There
Fast ferries run every 15 minutes daily from the Hong Kong-Macao Ferry Terminal in the Shun Tak Center on Hong Kong Island. The trip takes about an hour. The economy fare from Hong Kong is $18, and the return trip from Macao is about $19.30.
 
Hotels
Several travel agencies in the Shun Tak Center, a shopping complex that connects with the Hong Kong-Macao Ferry Terminal, specialize in discounted hotel packages to Macao; the biggest discounts are for midweek stays.
At Macao South China Travel, Shop 318, Shun Tak Center, (852) 2815-0208, fax (852) 2544-9378, e-mail southchina@ctimail.com, I was able to book a standard room at the Pousada de Sao Tiago for $83 a night, which was about half the hotel's rack rate.
The 24-room Pousada de Sao Tiago, Avenida da Republica, (853) 378-111, fax (853) 552-170, www.saotiago
.com.mo, in a 17th-century Portuguese fort, has rooms on the second, third and fourth floors, up steep flights of stone steps. An alfresco restaurant looks out onto the bay.
I also inspected the 240-room Hotel Sintra, in a high-rise building closer to the center of town, at Avenida de Dom Joao IV, (853) 710-111, fax (853) 567-769. Although the outside was drab, rooms were large, cheerful and recently renovated, with sitting areas and ocean views. The midweek rates were around $60.
 
Restaurants
The Pousada de Sao Tiago's restaurant Cafe da Barra, is expensive but popular -- it has the best view in town. I had tea and sandwiches there one afternoon for about $9.
At Long Kei, 7B, Largo Do Leal Senado, (853) 573-970, I had an excellent Cantonese lunch of fried noodles with slices of garoupa (grouper) and bits of bok choi. With a beer, it came to $8.50.
There's a row of Macanese restaurants around the corner from the Pousada da Sao Tiago, along Rua do Almirante Sergio. The food combines the flavors of Lisbon and South China, with a bit of Mozambique peppers thrown in for spice.
At Barra Nova, 287 Rua do Almirante Sergio, (853) 965-118, I tried Macanese chicken -- stewed in a coconut-milk curry pepper sauce. Along with a soda, lunch cost $8.50. Next door at A Lorcha, (853) 313-193, a dinner of Cantonese roast chicken rubbed with hot peppers, codfish fritters and a glass of wine came to $21 with tax and tip.
Margaret's Cafe e Nata, Rua Comandante Mata e Oliveira, (853) 710-032, is a European-style cafe with outdoor tables, where strong cappuccino and a delicious Portuguese-style pastry was about $2.50.
 
Activities
The public museums in Macao are excellent, new and not expensive. The Macao Museum, in the fort adjacent to the St. Paul ruins, (853) 357-911), www.macaumuseum.gov.mo, contains three floors of historical and cultural exhibits, some of them interactive. Admission is $2, but with a discount "passport" voucher from the Macao Government Tourist Office (at the ferry terminal in Macao), my admission was $1.25. Closed Mondays.
The Macao Maritime Museum, Largo do Pagode da Barra, 1, (853) 595-481, another beautiful new museum, traces the history of European and Chinese sailors in the South China Sea. Admission is $1.25, or 63 cents with the voucher. A junk ride for tourists leaves several times a day from the museum's pier, and takes a 30-minute spin around the Macao peninsula; tickets are $1.25.
 
Transportation
Buses are the main form of public transport. Routes are marked on the tourist board's map, and the bus signs are in Portuguese and Chinese, with Western numbers. The fare around Macao is about 25 cents. DAISANN McLANE
